to address.  The initial problem was that his backspace key wasn't
deleting the character to the left of the cursor until after he logged

"famous" ^H problem).  I was pretty sure I recognized that, & pointed
him to this page 

  http://www.ibb.net/~anne/keyboard.html

which helped, but  then he replied saying that his break key wasn't
working the way that he'd grown to expect when using WinDoze.  His
distro is RH, but I'm not certain of the version - probably 7.x (I'd
know more, but he's about 1500 miles away).

In any case, his description of the problem is below.  I've been
looking in the "Keyboard and Console HOWTO" (as well as the man pages
for toe, tic, terminfo & tset) but I'm now getting a bit sleepy & I've
not yet seen it...  Will tackle it again in the morning...

Many thanks for any enlightenment...

T.

The Apache documentation, available in your source tarball and online, 
includes two docs worth reading:

* Security Tips for Server Configuration
  http://httpd.apache.org/docs/misc/security_tips.html

* Authentication, Authorization, and Access Control
  http://httpd.apache.org/docs/howto/auth.html

From longman at sharplabs.com  Wed May  1 09:10:16 2002
From: longman at sharplabs.com (Longman, Bill)
Date: Wed, 1 May 2002 09:10:16 -0700 
Subject: [PLUG] force dhcpcd to set hostname and domainname
Message-ID: <B14FD9A4BE25D31188A400508B2CBB6FC24ECC@mailsrvnt04.enet.sharplabs.com>

> Subject: [PLUG] force dhcpcd to set hostname and domainname
> 
> 
> I'd like to have dhcpcd automagically set the hostname and 
> domainname for
> my rh7.2 laptop to the value supplied by the dhcp server. I see in the
> fine manual that dhcpcd can be asked to do this w/ the -D and 
> -H switches.
> Any idea where I can use those switches, as dhcpcd is 
> probably be starting
> from somewhere in the /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts?
> -Dan Young

What's your configuration of your network in terms of laptop versus the DHCP
server? In order to get your laptop's hostname assigned, you'll probably
need your laptop's MAC address and you'll need to add that to the
configuration files on the DHCP server. Someone else on the list may be able
to help you with the specifics of setting up the files for.

Getting the default domain name set is pretty trivial. I think there's a
config file in /etc/ for it. Others on the list can help out here -- it's
been many moons since I set this up.

--
WEL



From noone at nowhere.com  Wed May  1 09:08:31 2002
From: noone at nowhere.com (Jeff Burnell)
Date: Wed, 01 May 2002 09:08:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Problem with a eMachine
References: <mailman.1020195925.8795.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <3CD012FF.A4A9735@nowhere.com>

This is only a slightly better solution:

1.  Tell the OS to shut down.
2.  Wait for the hard drive to stop writing and the OS to be finished
with whatever shutdown stuff it does.
3.  Hold the power button down for a few seconds (could be as long as 10
seconds) until the system powers off and the keyboard lights go out.

OR you might try:

1.  Tell the OS to restart.
2.  When you get the video card splash screen or at the start of the
e-machine splash screen when it is doing the memory test, press the
power button.

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed May  1 09:29:39 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 01 May 2002 09:29:39 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Writing spam blocks by IP address
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205010627130.18749-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys
 .com>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020501092135.01f0cac0@localhost>

Exactly the same way you do it in sendmail. :)

Add the IP with REJECT after it in the access database.

For instance, I have the following in my /etc/postfix/access file:

4.19.93.150                     REJECT
emarkethost.net                 REJECT
kjmqrrr.com                     REJECT
networkpride.net                REJECT
lakecity.cc.fl.us               REJECT
150.176.96.2                    550 We don't accept mail infected with SirCam

(Among others)

Once you have the entries you want in there, execute the command postmap 
/etc/postfix/access to make the db file.

The man page for the access file is here: http://www.postfix.org/access.5.html

At 06:29 AM 5/1/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>how can I specify either a specific IP address
>or a block of IP addresses to be rejected by postfix?

Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net

I was just doing some research for my boss on Windows XP, and found this in 
"Tips and Tricks" on the MS website:

Provide Personal Support It never fails: when friends, co-workers, or 
family members discover that you're a Windows expert, you get pressed into 
service as an unpaid support technician. If the party asking for help is 
running any edition of Windows XP and has an active Internet connection, 
your job is much easier. Have the other person send you a Remote Assistance 
request; when you accept the request, you connect directly to their 
computer and can edit Registry settings, fix file associations, set System 
options, and perform just about any other troubleshooting or repair task, 
just as if you were sitting at the other person's desk.


SO, you can ask your friends to let you in, and then you have full control! 
What fun!

have to hand copy....

fstab:

LABEL=/         /               ext2    defaults                        1 1
none                    /dev/pts                devpts  gid=5,mode=620  0 0
LABEL=/home             /home           ext2    defaults 
     1 2
none                    /proc           proc    defaults 
     0 0
none                    /dev/shm        tmpfs   defaults 
     0 0
/dev/hda3               swap            swap    defaults 
     0 0
/dev/cdrom              /mnt/cdrom      iso9660 noauto,owner,kudzu,ro   0 0
/dev/fd0                /mnt/floppy     auto    noauto,owner,kudzu      0 0



lilo.conf:

prompt
timeout=50
default=linux
boot=/dev/hda1
map=/boot/map
install=/boot/boot.b
message=/boot/message
linear

image=/boot/vmlinuz-2.4.7-10enterprise
         label=linux
         read-only
         root=/dev/hda1

image=/boot/vmlinuz-2.4.7-10smp
         label=linux-smp
         read-only
         root=/dev/hda1

image=/boot/vmlinuz-2.4.7-10
         label=linux-up
         read-only
         root=/dev/hda1

From alex at daniloff.com  Wed May  1 10:36:32 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)

In-Reply-To: <3CD010ED.FF4F229F@nowhere.com>
Message-ID: <200205011736.g41HaWq13319@gate.daniloff.com>

Hello linux folkz,
I'm apologize for a such stupid question, but my dept. manager didn't
approve additional spendings for firewall hardware even el-cheapo
pentium PC.
He insists to run firewall on the same box with Web, DB, NFS and Mail
servers to cut our department costs.
So,I need to show him justification why it's dangerouse practice.
His position on this issue is that using iptables you can separate
Internet NIC from Intranet NIC, setup NAT and masquerading and put all
unnessesary ports on Internet interface in stealth mode.
All nessesary services for internal network will be provided on the
Intranet NIC separately from Internet NIC.
If a hacker breaks through the firewall into DMZ (Web, DB, Mail)
server will become volnureable in any way. 
So he doesn't see a point to separate firewall from other servers.

Could somebody please provide an explanation about this issue or point
to the source of information, so I can show it to my staborn manager.
Thank you very much in advance.

Alex






From richard.langis at sun.com  Wed May  1 10:48:04 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Wed, 01 May 2002 10:48:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Running firewall and services on one box?
References: <200205011736.g41HaWq13319@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <3CD02A54.7040309@sun.com>

If a hacker breaks into the firewall, you're vulnerable from the very second 
he gets access.

If you have a second box that runs the services, he at the very *least* has to 
crack that box as well.  This will give you some time - and with the right 
intrusion detection software running on the firewall, that little bit of time 
might save your data AND your ass.

To be fair, I'll admit that I have my home systems setup the way your manager 
suggests.  A lot of my data is stored on my firewall - but this was mainly 
because at tht time I set it up, I didn't HAVE another box to use.  I do now, 
but I'm loathe to tear it all down since it works so wonderfully.  :)

However, a cheap, yet reliable pentium or even 486 box for a firewall 
shouldn't put you back any more than $100, and that's if you eBay it.

But, it's your data...

-R

From john at meissen.org  Wed May  1 11:00:05 2002
From: john at meissen.org (john at meissen.org)
Date: Wed, 01 May 2002 11:00:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Running firewall and services on one 
 =?iso-8859-1?q?box=3F?=
In-Reply-To: (Your message of Wed, 01 May 2002 10:36:32 PDT.)
             <200205011736.g41HaWq13319@gate.daniloff.com> 
Message-ID: <20020501180005.5E1A0745B6@john.meissen.org>

alex at daniloff.com said:
> I'm apologize for a such stupid question, but my dept. manager didn't
> approve additional spendings for firewall hardware even el-cheapo
> pentium PC. He insists to run firewall on the same box with Web, DB,
> NFS and Mail servers to cut our department costs. So,I need to show
> him justification why it's dangerouse practice. His position on this
> issue is that using iptables you can separate Internet NIC from
> Intranet NIC, setup NAT and masquerading and put all unnessesary ports
> on Internet interface in stealth mode. All nessesary services for
> internal network will be provided on the Intranet NIC separately from
> Internet NIC. If a hacker breaks through the firewall into DMZ (Web,
> DB, Mail) server will become volnureable in any way.  So he doesn't
> see a point to separate firewall from other servers. 

Ideally, DMZ != internal network. If they are on separate systems, then
if the web server is cracked it's still isolated from the rest of the
network, and the firewall is still secure. If the firewall is also the
web/mail/etc server, then compromising these also compromises the
firewall, at which point trojan utilities, and hacked services can 
replace the original secure ones and your firewall suddenly becomes
wide open and useless.

If the web server is on the internal network, then if it gets cracked
the firewall (which is still secure) may still be effective in limiting
connections between the compromised system and the outside world.

john-

Rich,

I think you would need to put caddis in the hosts file so that you could 
reference it by name in your firewall scripts and have it resolve. Or, you 
might just have to hardcode caddis' IP in your rules.

Since you are using a different host then you are going to be 
portforwarding the packets on port 80 to port 80 on caddis.

HTH,
Keith

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed May  1 11:43:26 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 01 May 2002 11:43:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Running firewall and services on one box?
In-Reply-To: <200205011736.g41HaWq13319@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <3CD010ED.FF4F229F@nowhere.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020501113000.00baca98@localhost>

What he says is true.

This, however, is my ideal situation.

The firewall box has zero remote access. No ssh, telnet, rsh, or any other 
service running on it. It's simply a smart router that inspects packets (at 
least on the way in) and either passes or rejects them. Fewer services 
means fewer chances for a vulnerability to be found and exploited.

The firewall forwards requests for services to the appropriate box. Port 
80/443 goes to the webserver, etc. If these services are running on the 
firewall, then if  a vulnerability is found, and exploited, other ports may 
then be able to be opened, and the hacker gains access to the box. If you 
have a seperate machine doing the firewall, then this particular method is 
much more difficult, nearing impossibility. Take for instance if there's a 
possibility to hack apache and get it to drop to a shell. Most hackers then 
want to install other programs, and make the box work for them. If it's the 
firewall too, no problem. Just run the services, modify the firewall rules 
and they work. If it's not the firewall, then they still haven't cracked 
the firewall, and getting services out through that firewall are much more 
difficult. This assumes the firewall checks outbound packets too.

What is going to be on this webserver/SQL database? If it's doing 
ecommerce, then maybe the corporate lawyer should be talking to your boss 
about putting the assets of the company at risk. If it's just static pages, 
with no proprietary info on them, then it becomes a question of how much 
exposure to ridicule can the company stand.

At 10:36 AM 5/1/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>So,I need to show him justification why it's dangerouse practice.
>His position on this issue is that using iptables you can separate
>Internet NIC from Intranet NIC, setup NAT and masquerading and put all
>unnessesary ports on Internet interface in stealth mode.

I wasn't too clear. :-). I meant the hosts file on the floppy firewall. I 
use the 1.9 version that has iptables support in it but I just downloaded 
the current ipchains version and there is a hosts file on that image as 
well.

> > Since you are using a different host then you are going to be
> > portforwarding the packets on port 80 to port 80 on caddis.
> 
>   You've confused me here. I have three boxes connected to the switch (plus
> a couple of portables that are not always wired in). The three boxes are
> 'router1', 'salmo' and 'caddis'. AFAIK, the latter two are equivalant when
> seen from the firewall/router. Port forwarding occurs on router1 between the
> two NICs and is mediated by floppyfw. No?
> 


If this is your layout:


Internet------router1(floppyfw box)------hub----salmo,caddis,etc

then:
Your floppyfw machine "router1" has two nics, one external and one 
internal. Web traffic that is coming in from the Internet has a 
destination of router1.appl-ecosys.com (or more precisely, the Internet IP 
assigned to that box). router1 either has to have the service listening on 
port 80 for web traffic OR it has to forward all the traffic destined for 
that port to another machine (port forwarding).


Keith

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed May  1 13:09:51 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 1 May 2002 13:09:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] rsync mirrors
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205011300350.11779-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

I occasionally poke around the sites listed on the Red Hat mirrors 
page looking for rsync servers I can use for the care and feeding of 
my own mirror. The current version of the script I use and today's 
output (edited to remove unresponsive servers) follow.

Why? Just because I thought you'd like to know where you can get stuff 
via rsync :-)

If the length of this message bothers anyone (because of, say, a slow 
modem connection), let me know. I'll stop. Promise.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>


#!/bin/bash
#
# parse the red hat mirrors list and look for rsync servers
#
for h in $( \
  wget -q -O - http://www.redhat.com/mirrors.html | \
  grep '>Updates<' | \
  grep '://' | \
  sed -e 's!^.*://!!' -e 's!/.*$!!' )
do
  echo
  echo '##########'
  echo '##########'
  echo '##########'
  echo
  echo $h
  echo
  rsync --timeout=5 ${h}::
done
echo '##########'
echo '##########'
echo '##########'
exit

  Welcome to distro.ibiblio.org's rsync server!

  You may mirror any of our distributions by using the "distros"
  module.  Simply append the name of the distribution you would
  like to use.  For example:

  http://lists.ibiblio.org/mailman/listinfo/ibiblio-mirrors

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed May  1 13:24:20 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 1 May 2002 13:24:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Running firewall and services on one box?
In-Reply-To: <200205011736.g41HaWq13319@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200205011736.g41HaWq13319@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <20020501202421.JRTZ9799.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@there>

I admit I have my firewall for my home network setup this way. One big 
difference is that I'm not letting any outside systems connect to any 
of the running services on my firewall. I'm not sure I would want to do 
what your manager wants since the box could be comprised through one of 
the running services that you're making publicly available.

I think it better to have the firewall port forward to other systems 
that reside in a DMZ. Systems within the DMZ have no connection with 
your internal network and so nothing really bad can happen if a system 
in the DMZ is compromised. If a system is brought in from the DMZ it 
should be considered suspect such that it is flattened and a complete 
reinstall of all software is performed.

I've seen some places that use two firewalls such that the DMZ resides 
between the firewalls. The back firewall safeguards the internal 
network. 

All I can say is that it won't matter how you have the iptable rules 
setup for each NIC since once the firewall has been compromised the 
intruder can then from from the Internet into your Intranet. The amount 
of time and cost in terms of lost work and productivity by yourself and 
other personnel within the company will exceed the cost of a couple of 
old Pentium systems by a very large factor.

Tony

On Wednesday 01 May 2002 10:36 am, you wrote:
> Hello linux folkz,
> I'm apologize for a such stupid question, but my dept. manager didn't
> approve additional spendings for firewall hardware even el-cheapo
> pentium PC.

> servers to cut our department costs.
> So,I need to show him justification why it's dangerouse practice.
> His position on this issue is that using iptables you can separate
> Internet NIC from Intranet NIC, setup NAT and masquerading and put
> all unnessesary ports on Internet interface in stealth mode.
> All nessesary services for internal network will be provided on the
> Intranet NIC separately from Internet NIC.
> If a hacker breaks through the firewall into DMZ (Web, DB, Mail)
> server will become volnureable in any way.
> So he doesn't see a point to separate firewall from other servers.
>
> Could somebody please provide an explanation about this issue or
> point to the source of information, so I can show it to my staborn

This also protects the DMZ from the users on the internal network. In some 
recent studies, 80% of all hacks occurred from inside the firewall.

$100/month rent explains a lot.  Have you considered satellite?  It's a
little more costly than cable or DSL, but significantly less than a
fractional T1.  I think it's about 256K of bandwidth.  The uplink and
downlink time could make latency an issue for delay sensitive apps (internet
games, voice etc.).  Just a thought.

I checked into it for my house, but I have too many trees blocking the
southern sky.  I couldn't get wireless either.

Good luck,

CurtisE

Message-ID: <200205012055.g41KtOs27406@smtp.easystreet.com>

On Wednesday 01 May 2002 11:43 am, you wrote:
> What he says is true.
>
> This, however, is my ideal situation.
>
> The firewall box has zero remote access. No ssh, telnet, rsh, or any other
> service running on it. It's simply a smart router that inspects packets (at
> least on the way in) and either passes or rejects them. Fewer services
> means fewer chances for a vulnerability to be found and exploited.
>
> The firewall forwards requests for services to the appropriate box. Port
> 80/443 goes to the webserver, etc. If these services are running on the
> firewall, then if  a vulnerability is found, and exploited, other ports may
> then be able to be opened, and the hacker gains access to the box. If you
> have a seperate machine doing the firewall, then this particular method is
> much more difficult, nearing impossibility. Take for instance if there's a
> possibility to hack apache and get it to drop to a shell. 

So how does this work.  Say I'm offering htppd over 80, I can see how they 
can crash apache, but how do they get it to run ssh, telnet or whatever to 
offer a shell across a network.

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed May  1 14:09:57 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 01 May 2002 14:09:57 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Running firewall and services on one box?
In-Reply-To: <200205012055.g41KtOs27406@smtp.easystreet.com>
References: <5.1.0.14.0.20020501113000.00baca98@localhost>
 <3CD010ED.FF4F229F@nowhere.com>
 <5.1.0.14.0.20020501113000.00baca98@localhost>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020501140712.00b8f440@localhost>

In these cases, a typical ploy is to cause the app to buffer overflow, and 
it drops to a shell. Unfortunately, the shell provides the prompt over the 
already established tcp/ip link on port 80. This is also why it's common 
practice to not use a privileged user to run daemons.

At 02:01 PM 5/1/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>So how does this work.  Say I'm offering htppd over 80, I can see how they
>can crash apache, but how do they get it to run ssh, telnet or whatever to
>offer a shell across a network.

Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net

the continuing viability of FORTRAN.

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Wed May  1 17:53:59 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Wed, 1 May 2002 20:53:59 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Recommended configure options for apache?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205011710420.21687-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205011710420.21687-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <E1734Ya-0003r4-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

That depends heavily on what you want to do with the server.....
If you want to mess with PHP I would definitely recommend the additional 
switch to ./configure:

--enable-module=so

that way you can build and install DSO's (loadable modules for Apache) and 
install additional stuff without having to rebuild Apache every time....

I'm guessing you're building 1.3.X please forgive me if I'm mistaken

From revans at e-z.net  Wed May  1 21:38:24 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: 01 May 2002 21:38:24 PDT
Subject: [PLUG] Qmail relay problem
In-Reply-To: <1020279684.30281.25.camel@enlightenment.barkingcorndog.homelinux.org>
References: <20020501113453.A27222@dalsemi.com>
    <1020279684.30281.25.camel@enlightenment.barkingcorndog.homelinux.org>
Message-ID: <20020502043803.GHJF4412.rwcrmhc52.attbi.com@downtown>

You probably have relaying setup correctly. The qmailctl script threw me for a
loop as I have never encountered it before. So the problem is probably in
receiving mail, not sending.


http://www.lifewithqmail.org/lwq.html#multiple-hostnames
==========================================
3.3. Multiple host names
If your system is known by more than one name, e.g., all addresses of the form
user at host1.example.com can also be written as user at example.com or
user at mail.example.com, then you need to tell qmail this so it'll know which
addresses it should deliver locally and which messages it should accept from
remote systems.
To do this, just add all of the names to two control files:
rcpthosts, which tells qmail-smtpd to accept mail addressed to these hosts, and
locals, which tells qmail-send that addresses on these hosts are to be
delivered locally.
===========================================

I don't think I can say it better than this. 


Thank you
Russell

From revans at e-z.net  Wed May  1 22:18:20 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: 01 May 2002 22:18:20 PDT
Subject: [PLUG] help  lilo is booting to "LI"
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20020501081700.00a8aec0@mail.netsailer2.com>
References: <5.1.0.14.0.20020501081700.00a8aec0@mail.netsailer2.com>
Message-ID: <20020502051757.HIZB2627.rwcrmhc54.attbi.com@downtown>

Once booted what does mount give as output? 

Where does linux rescue mount your drives? chroot to the mount point of your /
and then mount	/home on / for your home directories. If the linux rescue
doesn't mount your rive for you mount your / at /mnt and then do a chroot /mnt/
A telinit 3 should start all your services. This will get you back to a working
server, I think, and give you time to figure out what's wrong.

Thank you
Russell

From CurtisE at CurtisE.net  Wed May  1 23:46:05 2002
From: CurtisE at CurtisE.net (CurtisE)
Date: Wed, 1 May 2002 23:46:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] pppd fails
In-Reply-To: <20020501223831.A11294@defiant>
Message-ID: <GJELJBAKILGBFNJHBMKGAECACDAA.CurtisE@CurtisE.net>

I understand your concern.  I could even understand abstaining from using
these services on the principle that they lack Linux (or anything other than
Windoz) support.  However, when you run thin on affordable broadband
options, sometimes principles can become secondary considerations.

I can't say for sure with regard to wireless or satellite, but just because
they don't support Linux doesn't necessarily mean it will not work.  For
example, I have AT&T cable and their web page lists Windoz (several flavors)
as a "system requirement" which in my mind is a bit stronger verbiage than
"not supported".  I have a Linux box, a Solaris box, a PDA, a Cisco router,
a Bay switch and a Novell server (on a wireless network) and yes, a couple
flavors of Windoz boxes all hanging off of this connection and accessing the
internet just fine.  The reason they say Windoz is a requirement is because
they have some lame utilities on a CD that one of their less than network
savvy technicians can use to configure your machine and the utilities are
only written for Windoz.  The utilities are not needed and I wouldn't trust
their techs or software within 10 feet of my systems anyway.  It's also a
cost savings measure, as they don't have to staff their call center with
Linux/UNIX/Mac savvy people.

Seems to me, if their equipment has an Ethernet interface and their network
supports IP, it's a big stretch to say Linux (or anything else with an
Ethernet interface and running IP) won't work.  Even if their equipment has
a serial or USB interface, it could be made to work with a bit more effort.
I'm not aware of any ISPs that don't support IP...

I'll shut my pie hole now.  I'm new here and don't want to be annoying.  I'm
just trying to help you save some $.

CurtisE

Scott Powell's Log: StarDate 0429.0956:
> Bruce,
> 
> I don't know much about pppd -- long time since I used it -- but if you
> are having problems with crypt libraries, there are two possible
> solutions.
>  1) add -lcrypt to your Makefile in the appropriate location (libraries,
> or where it links the entire program)

My programming is weak. Where would be an appropiate location?

>  2) If that doesn't work, go get libcrypt.
> http://sourceforge.net/projects/libcrypt/

I thot maybe this would be simpler. But to get the file, you first
have to be a member of SourceForge. SO, I joined, but that took a
while to get the mail from the end of my huge backlog of spam (Not
fixing that in this message). Then I got the file (crypt-0.03.zip),
and opened it up. It's pretty small. I changed an option in the
CFLAGS: -mpentium got removed. I couldn't find any documentation in
gcc about it, but decided that since it's running on a 486, that flag
was best deleted.

Then I ran make. But there's no Install target in the makefile, so I'm
not sure where to put the file so that the other build(s) will find it.

>  Install it. Use it wisely. Hopefully WvDial will compile. If it
> doesn't, there's a reason you're running linux - go remove all calls to
> crypt()/*politely, please!*/ and see if that works. *G*

*Use it wisely.* That's interesting. Why would you say that? What should
I be aware of?

> --
> A couple of stupid pppd ideas, just because they might help. If not,
> just slap me with a dead chicken.
> 1) Try removing the quotation marks around your u/n and password.
> 2) Make sure your password is correct. I know you already have. Do it
> again. I've stumbled over problems for days because I was *sure* I had
> the right password. I was wrong.
> 3) Send the log to your ISP. The hackers working the support desk should
> be reasonable if you use full sentences, which you seem pretty capable
> of. They may even be impressed with the log -- it's better than coffee
> cup holders, anyway.
> 4) Don't run it as root. Don't run anything as root, if you can avoid
> it. Again, I'm no pppd expert, so it may be a requirement, in which
> case, just ignore my arrogant ramblings.

1. right. But they weren't there.
2. verified it with telnet (the isp supports it, but I generally don't
use it. and I still get email every 30 minutes with it [thru fetchmail].)
3. interesting thot, but I'm not sure it's appropriate yet.
Particularly since Pacifier doesn't support linux.
4. I like that idea, but I've found on my laptop, that network
connections have to be run as root. And this article suggests that as
well. but all my other 'user' stuff is run as brucek. OTOH, maybe pppd
is using user ROOT instead of user BRUCEK, even tho that is what is in
the pap script. I'll try that tomorrow.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu May  2 06:21:57 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 2 May 2002 06:21:57 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Recommended configure options for apache?
In-Reply-To: <20020501201409.K26259@rheingold.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205020609570.29708-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 1 May 2002, Wil Cooley wrote:

> 2.0 is still pretty bleeding edge.  It's released as stable now, but
> a number of 3rd party modules are just being ported to work with it
> (for example, PHP4).  For your purposes, I don't see much reason to
> not use 1.3.  It's been pretty rock-solid for some time.

For doing things like serving up static pages and supporting the 
Mailman scripts, Apache 2.0 will work just fine. Here's a brief 
configure invocation that'd probably do the trick:

  CC=gcc CFLAGS='-O2' \
  ./configure \
    --prefix=/usr/local/apache \
    --enable-mods-shared='most' \
    --enable-auth-digest \
    --enable-ssl \
    --enable-cgi \
    --enable-so

If you won't be using the Mailman web interface from off-site (or if 
you'll only be using it via something like an ssh tunnel), then the 
auth-digest and ssl options aren't really needed.

If you'd like to have your logs stored in /var rather than /usr, then
just put $localstatedir somewhere else, e.g.,

  --localstatedir=/var/local/apache

I've been testing Apache 2.0 in a couple locations for a while now:  
one is setup with mod_perl and AxKit, the other with SSL, DAV, and PHP
4.2 (including MySQL, Postgres, and XSLT supprt). Neither site has 
experienced any hiccups.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From john at meissen.org  Thu May  2 08:49:03 2002
From: john at meissen.org (john at meissen.org)
Date: Thu, 02 May 2002 08:49:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] pppd fails 
In-Reply-To: (Your message of Wed, 01 May 2002 23:46:05 PDT.)
             <GJELJBAKILGBFNJHBMKGAECACDAA.CurtisE@CurtisE.net> 
Message-ID: <20020502154903.64E3F745B6@john.meissen.org>

All the flavors of satellite internet now require Windows. I 
investigated this thoroughly 6 months or so ago. Starband was
the only one that didn't and they changed with the "improved"
modem change towards the end of last year.

The reason is that the connection utilizes a proprietary protocol
and data compression scheme. Starband used to implement it in hardware,
but now all the services provide it as a Windows driver, essentially
turning the modem into something similar to a Winmodem. I've heard
that a Linux version of the software exists, but Earthlink, Starband,
et. al. won't provide it and the developer that they license it from
won't license it to end users.

Without the special Windows software the connection works, but the
throughput is no better than ISDN.

There are several newsgroups available if you want to research it on
your own:
  alt.satellite.internet
  alt.satellite.starband
  alt.satellite.direcpc

And DSLReports has several forums that discuss it as well.

Wireless works fine. I'm running a link over a pair of Cisco 802.11b
bridges with a Linux box at my end.

john-

CurtisE at CurtisE.net said:
> I can't say for sure with regard to wireless or satellite, but just

> box, a PDA, a Cisco router, a Bay switch and a Novell server (on a
> wireless network) and yes, a couple flavors of Windoz boxes all
> hanging off of this connection and accessing the internet just fine.
> The reason they say Windoz is a requirement is because they have some
> lame utilities on a CD that one of their less than network savvy
> technicians can use to configure your machine and the utilities are
> only written for Windoz.  The utilities are not needed and I wouldn't
> trust their techs or software within 10 feet of my systems anyway.
> It's also a cost savings measure, as they don't have to staff their
> call center with Linux/UNIX/Mac savvy people.
>
> Seems to me, if their equipment has an Ethernet interface and their
> network supports IP, it's a big stretch to say Linux (or anything else
> with an Ethernet interface and running IP) won't work.  Even if their
> equipment has a serial or USB interface, it could be made to work with
> a bit more effort. I'm not aware of any ISPs that don't support IP...

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Thu May  2 11:16:07 2002

Date: Thu, 2 May 2002 14:16:07 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Running firewall and services on one box?
In-Reply-To: <200205021739.g42HdFj09288@smtp.easystreet.com>
References: <5.1.0.14.0.20020501113000.00baca98@localhost> <5.1.0.14.0.20020501140712.00b8f440@localhost> <200205021739.g42HdFj09288@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <E173Kp9-00024L-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

hmmmm

the *NIX mantra is as follows:

"Everything is a file"

(this includes files, devices, sockets, etc)

file descriptors, 0,1,and 2 are stdin,stdout, and stderr...
The trick with web servers on *NIX systems, is that ports < 1024 are 
'protected' which means only root can open them....so the way apache 
basically works is it starts as root, opens port 80 and accepts connections 
as a non-priviledged user (apache, www, nobody, etc.) otherwise, could you 
imagine a server running CGI scripts as root? (That would be phun to play 
with.)

Programmatically, you can close standard input, output, and error and 
redirect them to wherever..files, INET sockets, or UNIX domain sockets .. 
even devices if your a sadist to some extent.


On Thursday 02 May 2002 01:45 pm, you wrote:
> On Wednesday 01 May 2002 02:09 pm, you wrote:
> > In these cases, a typical ploy is to cause the app to buffer overflow,
> > and it drops to a shell. Unfortunately, the shell provides the prompt
> > over the already established tcp/ip link on port 80. This is also why
> > it's common practice to not use a privileged user to run daemons.
>
> Ah, so!  So whatever a 'link' is technically speaking, once establised,
> almost any unix program can converse over it. Wow!

From tk-plug at perljam.net  Thu May  2 11:07:38 2002
From: tk-plug at perljam.net (T)
Date: 02 May 2002 11:07:38 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Running firewall and services on one box?
In-Reply-To: <200205021755.g42HtoQ17335@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200205021755.g42HtoQ17335@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <1020362858.28395.19.camel@Dustpuppy>

Well, as much as I hate to recommend that anyone buy anything from
Fry's, that's a good price on a nice piece of equipment.  I have some
experience with that unit (My brother in law has one & I've tinkered
with it, helped set it up) and it's a pretty versatile unit, especially
for the price.  

It works well w/ Linux, has a little internal web server so that you can
manage it through a browser, & it even has an internal print server so
you can hang a parallel-port printer off of it.  It's also gotten rave
reviews from about 3 or 4 of the sites that I looked at.

I'm sure that an older PC w/ 2 NICs can be a lot more versatile, but on
the other hand, you don't hear of any exploits being written for the
micro-OS that the SMC unit runs (I don't recall what it is now...).

I *love* Linux, but I'd suggest that you give that SMC box serious
consideration.  If nothing else, it only takes a few minutes to set up,
& then you can use the rest of your time to put out other fires...

Just my $.02...

T.

From barryb at proaxis.com  Thu May  2 11:50:35 2002
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Thu, 2 May 2002 11:50:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Print Server
In-Reply-To: <NJEJLCMFPMMBDMEBIPKOCEBECAAA.mboynay@silverliningdev.com>; from mboynay@silverliningdev.com on Thu, May 02, 2002 at 11:21:13AM -0700
References: <NJEJLCMFPMMBDMEBIPKOCEBECAAA.mboynay@silverliningdev.com>
Message-ID: <20020502115034.B8993@edge>

You can hang all 3 printers from separate parallel ports on the linux 
machine. I have configured a three printer system using the two parallel ports 
supported by the motherboard plus a parallel port on an extension card.
I currently only used the printers from the machine they are connected to so the 
the software configuration would not be useful to you. 
I have not used it yet, but I am planning to move to 
Cups http://www.cups.org/  It uses IPP, the internet printing protocol 
(modeled on http) for network printing,  and its configuration/security is
modeled on apache.

Bill

From aapuch at attbi.com  Thu May  2 12:09:51 2002
From: aapuch at attbi.com (Andrew Puch)
Date: 02 May 2002 12:09:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Print Server
In-Reply-To: <NJEJLCMFPMMBDMEBIPKOCEBECAAA.mboynay@silverliningdev.com>
References: <NJEJLCMFPMMBDMEBIPKOCEBECAAA.mboynay@silverliningdev.com>
Message-ID: <1020366592.1658.824.camel@brain>

On Thu, 2002-05-02 at 11:21, Michael Boynay wrote:
> I work for a small company that uses a cluster of windows boxes. We have 3
> printers that we want to share from one box.  We want to start integrating
> Linux into our network for an application server, floppy-fw, and web server.
> 
> I wanted to know if anyone could recommend or give insight on what could be
> done to set up a print server on a Linux box.  I also need to understand the
> hardware portion of running 3 printers off one box as well.  Is there some
> interface that would connect all three together?

1. Well look at the printers .

If the printers are nice postscript printers, life is good. 
There for any old box will do, with 3 lpr ports.

If the printers are kind of dumb, then the cpu will do the rendering of
the page via ghost script, gnu postscript. 

I have seen that that one in a while , that ghostscript fails to print
pages on my Apollo printer, cheap HP Deskjet re branded

If it were me I would look in to the new samba.  

New samba can be used as NT 4.0 PDC. 

Also one can use PAM, Pluggable Authentication  Modules, to have the NT
PDC allow you to login to a linux box. 

http://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/libs/pam/modules.html
http://www.samba.org/samba/docs/Samba-HOWTO-Collection.html#PAM

Sick but cool. 


http://www.itweek.co.uk/News/1131114
http://us1.samba.org/samba/docs/





From barkingcorndog2 at attbi.com  Thu May  2 12:14:07 2002
From: barkingcorndog2 at attbi.com (josh)

Subject: [PLUG] Qmail relay problem
In-Reply-To: <20020502043803.GHJF4412.rwcrmhc52.attbi.com@downtown>

I fixed it. Turns out that in addition to using tcpserver to field all
smtp calls, there was a qmail entry in xinetd also that was conflicting.

On Wed, 2002-05-01 at 21:38, Russell Evans wrote:
> You probably have relaying setup correctly. The qmailctl script threw me for a
> loop as I have never encountered it before. So the problem is probably in
> receiving mail, not sending.
> 
> 
> http://www.lifewithqmail.org/lwq.html#multiple-hostnames
> ==========================================
> 3.3. Multiple host names
> If your system is known by more than one name, e.g., all addresses of the form
> user at host1.example.com can also be written as user at example.com or
> user at mail.example.com, then you need to tell qmail this so it'll know which
> addresses it should deliver locally and which messages it should accept from
> remote systems.
> To do this, just add all of the names to two control files:
> rcpthosts, which tells qmail-smtpd to accept mail addressed to these hosts, and
> locals, which tells qmail-send that addresses on these hosts are to be
> delivered locally.
> ===========================================
> 
> I don't think I can say it better than this. 
> 
> 
> Thank you
> Russell
> 
> 
>

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu May  2 12:26:35 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 2 May 2002 12:26:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Print Server
In-Reply-To: <1020366592.1658.824.camel@brain>
References: <NJEJLCMFPMMBDMEBIPKOCEBECAAA.mboynay@silverliningdev.com> <1020366592.1658.824.camel@brain>
Message-ID: <20020502192635.IQMY9799.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@there>

In using Samba for sharing printers on a Linux server, I use "raw" 
printers with no input or output filters on them. I have my Samba 
configuration setup to specify what Windows printer driver a given 
"raw" printer needs to so when a Windows client sets up a remote 
printer, the driver is usually automatically installed by Windows. 

For Linux clients I have ghostscript install since one of my laser 
printers is PCL only. The postscript output from Linux programs needs 
to be filtered into something a non-postscript LaserJet 4 understands.

My setup is pretty simple and I just use the BSD print spooler system 
on my Linux servers.

Tony

> There for any old box will do, with 3 lpr ports.
>
> If the printers are kind of dumb, then the cpu will do the rendering
> of the page via ghost script, gnu postscript.
>
> I have seen that that one in a while , that ghostscript fails to
> print pages on my Apollo printer, cheap HP Deskjet re branded
>
> If it were me I would look in to the new samba.
>
> New samba can be used as NT 4.0 PDC.
>
> Also one can use PAM, Pluggable Authentication  Modules, to have the
> NT PDC allow you to login to a linux box.
>
> http://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/libs/pam/modules.html
> http://www.samba.org/samba/docs/Samba-HOWTO-Collection.html#PAM

> Sick but cool.

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu May  2 12:31:29 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu, 2 May 2002 12:31:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Print Server
In-Reply-To: <NJEJLCMFPMMBDMEBIPKOCEBECAAA.mboynay@silverliningdev.com>; from mboynay@silverliningdev.com on Thu, May 02, 2002 at 11:21:13AM -0700
References: <NJEJLCMFPMMBDMEBIPKOCEBECAAA.mboynay@silverliningdev.com>
Message-ID: <20020502123129.B602@linux-enterprise.net>

On Thu, May 02, 2002 at 11:21:13AM -0700, Michael Boynay wrote:
> I work for a small company that uses a cluster of windows boxes. We have 3
> printers that we want to share from one box.  We want to start integrating
> Linux into our network for an application server, floppy-fw, and web server.
> 

Awesome.

> I wanted to know if anyone could recommend or give insight on what could be
> done to set up a print server on a Linux box.  I also need to understand the
> hardware portion of running 3 printers off one box as well.  Is there some
> interface that would connect all three together?
> 

Absolutely. The Common Unix Printing System (CUPS) is very good. It supports printing over the router using IPP/IP (printing to a remote sight, for example), Web-based administration interface, and the ability for Windows clients to connect to the printer with the "Add Printer" function through the "Network Neighborhood."

You can get it here:

    www.cups.org

I have installed it on several machines, and it is very good. 

BTW: IPP/IP is supported by HP, Microsoft, e.t.c.

From derek at infotects.com  Thu May  2 12:46:48 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 02 May 2002 12:46:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Running firewall and services on one box?
In-Reply-To: <200205021755.g42HtoQ17335@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200205021755.g42HtoQ17335@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <1020368808.8350.29.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Alex,
On Thu, 2002-05-02 at 10:55, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Hello,
> I was in Fry's yesterday and the only available 4 port 
> cable-dsl-router on sale is SMC7004ABR at $69.99.
> Their salesman confirmed that they didn't have any of these devices on
> sale at $39 price tag.
> Where did you get that $39 deal? In your dreams?
> The next logical question: What's better to use as a firewall, that
> neat appliance or an old pentium PC with two NICs?
> 

The real question depends on what you mean by better.

Is it better to dump the old pentium in the landfill, or find a useful
purpose for it?  There is no need to spend any money, people are giving
away those old boxes that don't run the latest bloat from up north.

Is it better to have a micro-os that is limited and almost impossible to
upgrade or add software to, or to have a lot of choices about what
distribution and what software will do the job at hand?  When an exploit
for the micro-os's is found, how will you be able to patch it?

Is it better to have all the hardware proprietary, or to have a box that
can be replaced in part or in whole for almost no cost at all?

Is it better to have an easy configuration, with limited options, or a
more difficult configuration that can be fine tuned to your needs?

Anyway, I prefer the flexibility (and cost) of the old pentium.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

I'd like to know what the M$ definition of a "machine" is.

Seems like if you took donations for motherboards, cases, video cards,
NIC's, etc. none of the pieces could be called a "machine".  The only
thing that would be questionable would be storage, if the OS comes on
the harddrive, it may have to stay there (legally).

On the other hand, by not running that other OS, you are not agreeing to
the license agreement, as per the agreement, and, as per the agreement,
you must uninstall all software that you don't agree with and destroy
any backup copies (which is just the way we want it).  Nowhere does it
mention that you have to take the machine back to the retailer.

In fact, doesn't the license agreement give you the _right_ (as in
privilege) to run the software, as long as you agree to the terms.  It
has been a while since I have read through the entire agreement, but I
don't recall it stating that I _must_ run the software, it has always
been, you _may_ run this software if you agree to these terms.

Ok, I know I'm rambling, but where does M$ get this sh*t?

Thanks for letting me vent.

Derek Loree

> What models of printers do you have working with CUPS?  

There are three drivers, or "modules" included free with CUPS: a generic printer, an HP Laserjet, and an Epson. 

Does it still use ghostscript on the back end? 

Check this out (with CUPS):

lp -Pmyprinter document.ps

It automatically detects it as a Postscript document, "plugs in" the correct filter, and prints it correctly! It works!

 I have three printers in my house, and at 
> least 4 or 5 machines to printer from, and I've gotten pretty irritated 
> with the existing RedHat gimp-print stuff.  I'd like to have all the 
> "processing" of the printing offloaded to the actual print SERVER, rather 
> than done on each of the clients.  Figuring out what has gone wrong when 
> something won't print is making me pull my hair out.

Yep.

From craighead.scot at vectorscm.com  Thu May  2 15:26:43 2002

>  I just finished speaking with my insurance agent. He hates Bill Gates,
>Microsoft and Windows with a passion. Unfortunately, all the insurance
>software runs only on Windows. At the office he's running w2k and it's been
>stable for him. At home, they run XP and I would not quote him here, for
>children might be reading this list. XP apparently crashes regularly, wipes

I recently had an interesting experience with XP.  A club that is part of a
national organization asked me to help them get their accounting system
working.  The accounting package would not work with XP.  The company that
make it said it would be about a year before they would have a version that
would.  They had to use this software package because the national
organization requires it.  They had baught a new PC and it had XP.  They had
a new copy of ME.  Me would not install because it did not know what to make
of XP.  I tried to format the drive and there was just a small partition
that was the C drive.  It would not format the other partitions.  I tried to
use fdisk to remove the other partitions and it refused to do it.  Finally,
I want home and made a Linux boot disk.  I used the Linux version of fdisk
to remove the partitions and made a new partition that I could then format
and install ME on.  It seemed like they had made it as hard as possible to
get XP off of that PC.

From codeyeti at yahoo.com  Thu May  2 16:04:41 2002
From: codeyeti at yahoo.com (Michael Smith)
Date: Thu, 02 May 2002 16:04:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] YAKCP - Yet Another Kernel Compile Problem
References: <B14FD9A4BE25D31188A400508B2CBB6FC24EE2@mailsrvnt04.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <3CD1C60A.A482C814@yahoo.com>

Hehe... OK.

Did you grab the sources directly from kernel.org.  Or, more directly, where
did the source come from?  You might try getting fresh sources from a reliable
location.

The distro shouldn't matter, as long as all the libraries are installed.  If
you can get all the other parts going, then it shouldn't be a problem.

Did you try "make mrproper"?  Try that and then the other line (make clean dep
bzImage modules modules_install).

Also, try configuring it with "make menuconfig" at a console/xterm and see if
the options you're using are still selected.  Basically, what you're trying to
do is see if "make xconfig" did something wrong.

I've had this happen myself. Sometime's I'll simply 'rm -rf' the /usr/src/linux directory and start from scratch:

   cd /usr/src
   tar xvfz linux-kernel-tarball.tar.gz
   cd linux
   make xconfig
   make dep
   make bzImage
   make modules
   make modules_install

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Thu May  2 16:36:00 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Thu,  2 May 2002 16:36:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] samba mount problem
Message-ID: <20020502233600.8597210E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>

I've just set up samba (by the seat of my pants) on my Linux machine
(stock Mandrake 8.2) and I'm noticing some strange behaviour.

As with nearly everything having to do with Linux networking, I'm a
novice, so go easy please.
Explanations are welcome, however.  I love to learn.

The Story

After mucking around in the /etc/samba/smb.conf file I seem to have gotten
samba to mount remote "shares" from Windows machines w/in our lab
(which is all I care about; I don't want to share anything off the Linux
box just now).

Then I tried mounting a "share" on a colleague's w2k machine which I
don't apparently have permission to get into.

I did:

   smbmount //<machine name>/user ~/mnt

(where I have a dir called `mnt' in my home directory).

It mounted just fine (after I entered my M$ Domain password) and
I can see it mounted in the output of `mount'.

But when I try to

   smbumount ~/mnt

I get

   Could not open /home/deanm/mnt:  Permission denied.

I also get

   ls:  mnt: Permission denied

which I do `ls -l'  (but not when I do `ls').

So what's the matter and how can I unmount the thing---short of re-booting?

I've also tried stopping the smb and nmb daemons, restarting them,
killing the `smbmount' command that was showing up in `ps ax'.
Nothing seems to work.


Dean



From rob at euglug.net  Thu May  2 16:41:56 2002
From: rob at euglug.net (Rob Hudson)
Date: Thu, 2 May 2002 16:41:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] samba mount problem
In-Reply-To: <20020502233600.8597210E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>; from deanm@sharplabs.com on Thu, May 02, 2002 at 04:36:00PM -0700
References: <20020502233600.8597210E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <20020502164155.A68291@cogit8.org>

I just had to figure out how to mount a samba share here at work.  The
things I ran into were:

I couldn't run smbmount as my user, so I had to do it as root.
I didn't want to login into the other server as root so I had to add
this flag: -o username=rob
Then, it shows up in 'df' and in 'mount'.  But I couldn't write to the
share b/c it was owned by root, so I added 'uid=rob'.  

My final command was this:
smbmount //homer/projects /mnt/samba/homer -o username=rob,uid=rob

Maybe that's the reason for your permission errors?

BTW, I don't think you need smbd and nmbd running to connect to
another machine via smb, just when other machines are connecting to
you.  (Correct me if I'm wrong)

-Rob

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Thu May  2 16:49:12 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Thu, 02 May 2002 16:49:12 -0700

References: <B14FD9A4BE25D31188A400508B2CBB6FC24EE4@mailsrvnt04.enet.sharplabs.com>

Longman, Bill wrote:

> I read about the mrproper target. I didn't read it until after I had done
> the compile initially. So should I just rewind, and do that first, before I
> do the clean dep bzImage....?

mrproper will nuke your .config file.  It basically tries to recreate the 
initial virgin state of the source tree.  You may want to move your .config 
to a safe place before you do this, then move it back.

Kyle Accardi

StarBand Residential is NOT currently right for...

 Commercial/business usage 
 Macintosh, Linux, Unix 
 Gateway/router-based networking 
 Web hosting, VPN, voice and video over IP 
 Real-time shooter and RPG games 
 Mobile installation applications (e.g. RVs) 
 AOL 5.0/6.0 or Prodigy 5.0 browsers 
 Large file and e-mail uploads 
 Peer-to-peer (P2P) filesharing applications

From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)

Steve Coffman wrote:

> Running up2date -u today to get updated on a few new packages like
> sudo I get this message and only headers are downloaded:


<snip>

> So first, why is this failing?


Firstly, make sure you are using the newest up2date.  It came out a few 
weeks ago and fixed many problems.

> Second: 
> After trying to get the RH7.1 update working  , I used the system normally, then did a clean log out of the system.
> I booted it up today and got the following:
> 
> Filesystem contains large files, but lacks LARGE_FILE flag in superblock.
> /: UNEXPECTED INCONSISTENCY; RUN fsck MANUALLY.
> 
> I ran e2fsck -b 8193 /dev/hda   to change the location of the superblock since it looks like the one at block 1 has been corrupted. Even tried hda1 but still have the same problem.

Never seen that particular message, someone else can help there.  But there 
are 4? superblocks--did you try all of them.  And yes, you need to specify 
a partition to e2fsck, not just `hda`.

While I have ruined a few installations in the early days and resorted to 
re-installing, it is seldom really necessary.  You learn a lot more by 
repairing the damage.  Now whether learning an os from the bloddy hands 
perspective is fun to *you* is another matter.

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu May  2 18:35:52 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu, 2 May 2002 18:35:52 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] samba mount problem
In-Reply-To: <20020502233600.8597210E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>; from deanm@sharplabs.com on Thu, May 02, 2002 at 04:36:00PM -0700
References: <20020502233600.8597210E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <20020502183552.A1594@linux-enterprise.net>

On Thu, May 02, 2002 at 04:36:00PM -0700, Dean S. Messing wrote:
> 
> I've just set up samba (by the seat of my pants) on my Linux machine

                               ^ Love it.

> 
> As with nearly everything having to do with Linux networking, I'm a
> novice, so go easy please.

No worries. Once you get the hang of Samba it makes sense but setting it up in some environments is not obvious.

> Explanations are welcome, however.  I love to learn.
> 
> The Story
> 
> After mucking around in the /etc/samba/smb.conf file I seem to have gotten
> samba to mount remote "shares" from Windows machines w/in our lab
> (which is all I care about; I don't want to share anything off the Linux
> box just now).
> 

Would you send the output of the following command:

    smbclient -L [remote machine]

If it asks you for a password (it uses your username by default) and it does not accept it then let us know that too.

Also a quick (and insecure method) for getting it to work. If the following works then we're definitely zeroing in on the problem:

  mount -t smbfs -o mode 0777 //remote_machine/share ~/mnt

If not then try the above without the '-t smbfs' option.

Finally, check out www.samba.org, especially the "Troubleshooting Techniques" PDF under the "Documentation" section.

Message-ID: <20020503034436.74541.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>

I tend to feel that questions about WINE are
under-represented on this list, but in any case, I
have one. If an application runs under WINE, of
course, the interface looks exactly as it would under
Windows, and that includes the printing menu. So I
suppose if you can print under WINE, there must be a
new printer driver in the pull-down menu that
activates Linux printing. I haven't seen it yet,
however.

The documentation I have seen on this subject seems
inadequate and confusing to me, but perhaps mainly
because I am not familiar enough with it.
Nevertheless, I would appreciate advice on this
subject, especially from those who have succeeded at
printing under WINE. I have a number of Windows
applications that are useful on Linux, but they would
be even more so with printing capabilities.

From codeyeti at yahoo.com  Fri May  3 07:11:41 2002
From: codeyeti at yahoo.com (Michael Smith)
Date: Fri, 03 May 2002 07:11:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] annoying apache logs
References: <1020424781.1521.3.camel@enlightenment.barkingcorndog.homelinux.org>
Message-ID: <3CD29A9C.D079CB0B@yahoo.com>

It's coming from everybody on your cable network.  What I would do is allow your default gateway and whatever boxen
you want to access apache from your subnet, and then deny everything else from your subnet.

In-Reply-To: <86r8ktprq8.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.31.0205030716280.6734-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> Okay, here's a problem for you: how does one "undelete" files on a
> mounted vfat filesystem under GNU/Linux?  I deleted the files from

If its not ext2fs, you can always grep for the file, a la:

grep -a -B[size before] -A[size after] 'identifying string' /dev/sda1

I'm not sure if you can get the timestamps this way though. More info:
http://recover.sourceforge.net/unix/

Note: if you are using ext2, 'recover' is reliable, I think it even has a
gtk frontend now.


Tyler

Don't forget to do a make oldconfig when you move the file back into

will pick up any new options that might be in the new version.

built was 2.4.8... Why don't you pull down the latest since you're
building a custom kernel anyway. 2.4.18 is so much nicer than the 2.4
kernel when it was that young.

I just set up a server yesterday, with samba configured to share home
directories.  As user derek, I was able to

smbmount //server/derek /home/derek/mnt -o username=derek

I am also able to mount shares from a Win2k server as derek.  Of course
this user has administrator privileges on the M$ server.

The problems I ran into where mostly related to who owns which
directories, you can't mount to something you don't own (I have a nasty
habit of creating directories as root, even in a users directory).

machines), all mounted by the user derek.

>

> smbmount //homer/projects /mnt/samba/homer -o username=rob,uid=rob

> Maybe that's the reason for your permission errors?

> yeah, this won't work.  The way rename works is it takes  <what you
> want to change> <what to change it to> <list of files...> so linking

And beware of the openssl package.  It uses the rename command without
a complete path.  If you have your own version of a rename command in
your path, it probably won't work as expected.  Guess who this happened to.

From john at meissen.org  Fri May  3 11:29:46 2002
From: john at meissen.org (john at meissen.org)
Date: Fri, 03 May 2002 11:29:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Help with 'talk'
Message-ID: <20020503182947.17115745B6@john.meissen.org>

This is driving me nuts, and I don't know what to look at or who to
complain to.....

My friends and I like to take advantage of the standard Unix 'talk'
application. They log into my system, type 'talk john', it gets my
attention and we chat away. It works great when we're (literally)
oceans apart and we need to communicate.

However, I was so far behind in security upgrades on my old Slackware
system I decided the best approach was to do a clean install of a recent
distribution. So I "upgraded" my systems to Mandrake 8.0, and then 8.1,
running kernel 2.4.8. (various patch levels).

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Fri May  3 12:05:32 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Fri, 3 May 2002 12:05:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Help with 'talk'
In-Reply-To: <20020503182947.17115745B6@john.meissen.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.31.0205031135200.7033-100000@mi.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> Now 'talk' doesn't work anymore. Sort of.

By doesn't work, you mean it just hangs while waiting for an invitation on
the recipient's machine? or does it deny you permission to initiate the
request.

Are you using the old unix 'talk' or 'ytalk', which uses the same
framework as talk but permits multiple connections? If you're not using
ytalk you might want to install it and see if that solves the problem. (it
probably won't since they use they same daemons, but I know there issues
with talk vs. ytalk, ie from the ytalk info file:

	For any particular host, YTalk will
       attempt  to  communicate  with  a talk daemon the caller's
       host also supports.  If the two hosts have  no  daemon  in
       common,  then  UNIX  talk  will not function at all, but a
       connection is possible through (and only through) YTalk.

> works fine between pts' UNLESS one of them is associated with an
> xterm-like application. I can initiate FROM an xterm and talk to a
> pts associated with a console or telnet login. But I CAN'T initiate
> from a console/telnet login to a pts associated with an xterm.

If you are using ytalk I think there are configuration
options in /etc/ytalkrc and .ytalkrc, you might want to play with those,
though I've no idea what to look for and how this relates to xterm. You
can always contact the project maintainer;
roger.espel.llima at pobox.com.

If multiple connections aren't important, you can always revert to
'write'. Its much less nice than talk but permits chatting, the only
caveat is that the other user must type 'write <you> <terminal>'
immediately after the first time you write them to make the session
interactive.

Another solution is to install 'irc' or something.

Hope this helps...


Tyler

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri May  3 12:07:08 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 3 May 2002 12:07:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Report: Updating from SuSE 7.2 to 8.0
Message-ID: <20020503190708.ISTS4412.rwcrmhc52.attbi.com@there>

I received my SuSE 8.0 update yesterday and thought I'd report my 
results from a dry run I did which entailed updating my backup 
workstation which was running SuSE 7.2. I saw some bad reports on 
Slashdot.org about configuration problems when trying to update from 
SuSE 7.x to 8.0 because the configuration setup has changed very 
drastically from prior versions of SuSE Linux.

A few things to note before I let YaST2 commence with the 
install/update:

1) I restored a very recent backup of my home directory from my primary 
workstation on this backup station so I could gauge how many problems I 
would have with the transition from KDE2 to KDE3.

2) YaST2 looks at all of the installed packages on the system and one 
thing I did was select to have all of the unmaintained packages removed 
from the system.

3) I only had one package that required manual intervention which was 
the "sudo" fix that came out not too long ago. I just had YaST2 
overwrite it and I can get new stuff later through the online update
feature in YaST2.

The install itself took quite some time as there were 501 packages to 
update on this system. The "sacrificial" system had the standard SuSE 
"Office" install on it so it's not surprising there were so many 
packages to update. My backup workstation is a PPro 200 which isn't 
really very fast unpacking all those RPMs so I just let it run and came 
back every so often to see if it was asking for a different CD or not.

It appears that the basic configuration stuff from 7.2 was carried over 
to the new scheme pretty well: X,  sound, and networking were all 
working. The only problem I had was that the two remote printers I had 
originally setup didn't work and YaST2 wouldn't let me touch them since 
it "thought" it hadn't created those printers. I created them through 
the text-based interface in YaST2 only a few days ago under 7.2. I just 
deleted the printers and created them again and my remote printers are 
now working. 

My real test was to fire up KDE3 and see what happens since I had a 
working KDE2 for more than a year now. KDE3 detected I had settings 
from KDE2 and I had it use those settings. KDE3 chugged along for a 
while and finally came up with the desktop. Things were mostly OK 
although there were a few problems:

1) I had lots of duplicate icons on the desktop for some reason which 
wasn't a serious problem. I just deleted the duplicates items from 
the desktop. 

2) I also happened to have one virtual desktop that had a "KDE2" 
background on it that didn't exist anymore so the background was white. 
I fixed this problem by running the KDE control center and changing the 
background for that desktop.

3) I did have a few problems with my session being restored when I 
logged in at first. To solve this problem I closed all of my apps and 
then logged out from KDE3. That appeared to wipe out any session 
information KDE was saving. Upon logging back in I started up my apps 
and then logged out again. The next time logged in my session was 
properly restored.

All of my bookmarks and mail client settings were intact in KDE3 which 
was probably my biggest concern with this upgrade. It's not a big deal 
changing/fixing basic Look+Feel stuff with the conversion but 
bookmarks, email and address book settings are much more work to setup 
again if they aren't carried over.

My only real gripe is that I'm not sure I really like the look of the 
anti-aliased fonts or not. They are turned on by default but I guess 
I'll run with them on for a while and see if I get used to them. I can 
always turn them off if I find I can't stand them.

Hopefully this information is helpful for anyone considering updating a 
SuSE 7.x system to 8.0. Fairly smooth update for the most part but 
there could be some problems with some configuration settings not being 
migrated over properly from SuSE's old configuration scheme. I only had 
a few problems but more compilicated systems may be more 
problimatic...YMMV. 

Now the real work beings when I actually update my primary workstation. 
Should be a quicker update since my primary workstation has a much 
faster CPU, CDROM, and hard drives.

Tony

--
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at attbi.com

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Fri May  3 12:31:16 2002
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: 03 May 2002 12:31:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Report: Gentoo Linux
In-Reply-To: <20020503190708.ISTS4412.rwcrmhc52.attbi.com@there>
References: <20020503190708.ISTS4412.rwcrmhc52.attbi.com@there>
Message-ID: <1020454277.3582.35.camel@traveller.home.com>

I installed Gentoo over the last few days and I thought I'd give a small
review.

First of all, check out the gentoo site: http://gentoo.org it's a very
nicely done.  Well organized.  Docs are clearly written.

I was interested in trying Gentoo because of an installation review I
read at Slashdot a few weeks back.  Gentoo seemed to offer another
alternative (the other being Debian) to RPM dependency hell.  It does
this by using the BSD portage system.  All packages are downloaded as
source and then compiled automatically. For example, if you want KDE you
simply type:
emerge kde

The emerge script then goes off and figures out which packages to
download, downloads them and compiles them in order of dependency. 
After it's done, you've got KDE.

Another advantage is that since you're compiling binaries from source
you get optimized binaries for your architecture ( = greater speed).
So, while it does take quite a lot longer to install gentoo than most
other distros, you'll generally get better performance especially on
newer processors.

I started by downloading the 16MB minimal install iso from the gentoo
site and burned it on a CDR.  I followed the x86 install instructions
from the Gentoo site.  I still have a dial-up connection, so this all
took a couple of DAYS. I also followed their desktop configuration
instructions but installed GNOME instead of KDE.  In both cases their
instructions were clear, accurate and seemed to be up to date. 
Alternatives were offered for many things - for example you could choose
your own logging package and three were offered (I went with metalog).

When all was finished I ended up with a couple of problems:
1) I couldn't su to root from a user account.  I found that I needed to
add the user to the 'wheel' group and all was well after that.
2) I installed on a laptop so I wanted APM (advanced power management)
to work, but it didn't work initially.  I found that I forgot to add
'apm' to the modules.autoload file.  All was well after doing that.

I've been installing a lot of apps using emerge in the last couple of
days (I'm typing this on Evolution on the gentoo'ed laptop) and it's all
worked flawlessly.

Bottom line:
1) You should have a fast connection to install Gentoo since it needs to
download pretty much everything (including the kernel sources- which you
have to configure and compile a kernel during the install)
2) It's not for newbies.  This is not a Mandrake or Lycoris install
(Lycoris would probably be at the opposite polarity from Gentoo - I've
installed it as well, and I think that pretty much ANYONE could install
it.  Lycoris actually brings up a Solitaire game as it installs.), but
if you're yearning for the old days when you had complete control over a
Linux install then you'll appreciate Gentoo.
3) It's kind of subjective, but I do think there is a noticeable
performance boost on my laptop (previously I had Mandrake 7.1 on it).
I'm sure it's partially due to the fact that gentoo didn't install a lot
of daemons I don't need and partially due to the optimized binaries.
4) The portage system is very nice and it's probably even a bit simpler
to use than Debian's apt.

I'd give it 4 out of 5 stars (****_ ;-)

Phil

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Fri May  3 12:59:32 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Aterm Ignores /etc/profile
Message-ID: <20020503125932.A853@linux-enterprise.net>

All;

I use aterm in Window maker for my terminals. I like to use the Vi sequences when I am editing on the command line.

This works when I am in a virtual terminal thanks to a line in /etc/profile as follows:

  set -o vi

When I use 'aterm,' though, it's like the terminal completely spaces off /etc/profile.

The 'set -o vi' line in /etc/profile is totaly independent of any if statements, eg:

  if [[ $TERM = aterm ]]
   blow_off_profile_settings();
  fi

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Fri May  3 13:50:11 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Fri, 3 May 2002 16:50:11 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Need help finding package with 'rename'
In-Reply-To: <1020456993.7160.2.camel@shahms>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205031232470.21082-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <E173jPm-00010V-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> <1020456993.7160.2.camel@shahms>
Message-ID: <E173jhj-0001G1-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

actually you may want to increment $#ARGV by 1, hence the ++$#ARGV
because of some perl-weirdness.  To make it clean, i would recommend adding 
the following line to the script  before the if() block:

$ARGC = ++$#ARGV;

you could also use:

$ARGC = ($#ARGV +1);

or:
$ARGC = length scalar @ARGV;

Arrays in perl are nifty things.... 

On Friday 03 May 2002 04:16 pm, you wrote:
> Yeah, you're right, I fudged the script, doh, but you can change $ARGC

 find_request: ANNOUNCE: id 4294967295, l_user john, r_user john, r_tty pts/0

on it and see if it's me or the system ;-)

One thing I have noticed.... with the older version(s) (from
Sun, Pyramid/Siemens, older Slackware, etc) it seemed to me that
the talk request was broadcast on each tty owned by you. This
version picks the first one it finds in utmp. If that one happens
to have 'mesg n' then the request fails regardless of the state of
any other tty's. Even if it's set right, you may never see the
request if the window is obscured.

Wonder if anyone is maintaining it these days?

I tried Gentoo a few months back and I couldn't get an install.  Went to
Sorcerer Gnu Linux and it worked well outa the box so to speak.  Then
that project fell apart.  I went to both of its branches and then just
got tired of the disorganisation there.  Still have SGL on one box. 
Went back to Gentoo and havn't looked back.  It is on my main server
doing ltsp and internal services.  Just recently put it on my laptop. 
It just works.  This 266 laptop is a bit slow to compile, but once
compiled it is a rocket. ;-)

These distros really teach one about the OS though.  From the ground up.
 I now have a really good handle on pcmcia and wireless cards.   If you
really want to learn Linux, I think these source distros are the way to
go.

And like you said, everything works flawlessly.  I never knew full
screen multimedia could be so seamless on a 600 mgz processor..

Have fun.

From longman at sharplabs.com  Fri May  3 15:37:24 2002
From: longman at sharplabs.com (Longman, Bill)
Date: Fri, 3 May 2002 15:37:24 -0700 
Subject: [PLUG] Aterm Ignores /etc/profile
Message-ID: <B14FD9A4BE25D31188A400508B2CBB6FC24EEF@mailsrvnt04.enet.sharplabs.com>

> All;
> 
> I use aterm in Window maker for my terminals. I like to use 
> the Vi sequences when I am editing on the command line.
> 
> This works when I am in a virtual terminal thanks to a line 
> in /etc/profile as follows:
> 
>   set -o vi
> 
> When I use 'aterm,' though, it's like the terminal completely 
> spaces off /etc/profile.
> 
> The 'set -o vi' line in /etc/profile is totaly independent of 
> any if statements, eg:
> 
>   if [[ $TERM = aterm ]]
>    blow_off_profile_settings();
>   fi

Cooper,

The /etc/profile only gets read on login shells. You'll be hard pressed to
get it to run from X spawns. Actually, it's a common problem. You'll need to
place it in your $ENV file for it to fire each time the shell is forked. And
it doesn't work in .profile or .bash_profile either because like
/etc/profile, those only get parsed once per login.

Thus:

/home/longman
miswelux01> echo $ENV
/home/longman/.functions
/home/longman
miswelux01> cat .functions
alias ..="cd .."

function lx {
  ls -Cp $*
}

function by {
  clear
  exit
}

function ll {
  ls -l $*
}

function la {
  ls -la $*
}

set -o emacs
PS1='$PWD
$HOST> '
/home/longman
miswelux01> 

(I've switched from vi to emacs....-)

--
WEL

From longman at sharplabs.com  Fri May  3 15:50:21 2002

No, .bashrc only runs in interactive shells that are not login shells. See
the bash man page for full details, especially the first several paragraphs
of the INVOCATION section.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sat May  4 10:47:05 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat, 4 May 2002 10:47:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Possible memory leak?
In-Reply-To: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844014CC6@gilligan.gijoes.com>
References: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844014CC6@gilligan.gijoes.com>
Message-ID: <20020504174706.WXBS5896.rwcrmhc53.attbi.com@there>

If you look at the other things that "top" shows you, you'll see that 
besides processes using physical memory, Linux itself uses some of 
physical memory for buffers and filesystem cache. I guess I really 
wouldn't be worried unless your system is thrashing the hard drive 
swapping pages in and out of the system swap space(s).

If you do have processe(s) that may be leaking memory, press the "M" 
key when "top" is running so it sorts all processes by their memory 
usage. The process that is using the most memory will be on the top of 
the list. You can take a few notes and observe over time how much 
memory any suspect processes are using.

Tony
