From rddunlap at osdl.org  Sat May  4 11:17:57 2002
From: rddunlap at osdl.org (rddunlap at osdl.org)
Date: Sat, 4 May 2002 11:17:57 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Possible memory leak?
In-Reply-To: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844014CC6@gilligan.gijoes.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0205041027220.22716-100000@osdlab.pdx.osdl.net>

On Sat, 4 May 2002, John Hampton wrote:

| 	I just looked at the output of top today and it says
| that I only have about 400k of free physical memory (no swap
| is being used).  Now, in and of itself that doesn't seem too
| weird, however, I have 128 MB RAM in the box and it isn't under
| any type of load.  Also, a couple of days ago, top said I
| have greater than 20 MB of physical memory free.  And nothing
| has changed on the box between then and now.  So, I was wondering
| if there is a way to get a break down of all the memory being
| used in the system.  Something that would tell me exactly how
| much memory each process is using.  Also, I don't run X on the
| box, so a console based utility is essential.  Thanks for any
| bright ideas.

Linux doesn't attempt to free up memory until it's needed
by some other process, so having lots of memory in use
is good, not bad.

Tools:  top (like you are using), cat /proc/meminfo,
	cat /proc/slabinfo, Als-SysRq-M (if enabled)

Also, for each process, /proc/<process_number/statm prints:
		       size, resident, share, trs, lrs, drs, dt
where:
	size = number of total pages
	resident = number of resident pages
	share = number shared
	trs = number of text (code) pages
	lrs = number of library pages
	drs = number of stack/data pages
	dt = number dirty

And you can use 'h' in top to see how to
customize its field output, then use 'f' or 'F' to add or
delete fields (columns).

There's also 'vmstat', but it doesn't help very much on a
per-process basis.

-- 
~Randy




From smathews at pcez.com  Sat May  4 11:55:48 2002
From: smathews at pcez.com (Stuart Mathews)
Date: Sat, 04 May 2002 11:55:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Possible memory leak?
References: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844014CC6@gilligan.gijoes.com>
Message-ID: <3CD42EB4.C6ED931B@pcez.com>

John Hampton wrote:

> Hello,
>
>         I just looked at the output of top today and it says that I only have about 400k of free physical memory (no swap is being used).  Now, in and of itself that doesn't seem too weird, however, I have 128 MB RAM in the box and it isn't under any type of load.  Also, a couple of days ago, top said I have greater than 20 MB of physical memory free.  And nothing has changed on the box between then and now.  So, I was wondering if there is a way to get a break down of all the memory being used in the system.  Something that would tell me exactly how much memory each process is using.  Also, I don't run X on the box, so a console based utility is essential.  Thanks for any bright ideas.
>

My belief -- which may or may not be correct! -- is that the way Linux works, the system will try to load as much of the 600MB or so of the distro (whatever the size happens to be) as it can into memory based on some algorythm that tries to predict which tools, apps, etc. it thinks you might use next.  So if you were to bump your ram up to 256, you'd still see that most of it is "not free,"  but that as you begin running applications, Linux will begin removing certain tools, apps, etc. from memory to make room for the things you are firing up.

From rddunlap at osdl.org  Sat May  4 18:32:46 2002
From: rddunlap at osdl.org (rddunlap at osdl.org)
Date: Sat, 4 May 2002 18:32:46 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drive benchmarking for Linux?
In-Reply-To: <20020504170241.C2122@sparky>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0205041820070.22716-100000@osdlab.pdx.osdl.net>

On Sat, 4 May 2002, Steven Raymond wrote:

| So a friend told me to add the following bit to my grub.conf file to
| "enable" ATA66 or ATA100 speeds on my ATA100 drives:
|
| ide0=ata66
|
| Apparently "ata66" is sufficient to get even ata100 speeds, as I
| understand this parameter.
|
| 1)  Is passing this arg to the kernel truly necessary for the drive to
| operate at ATA100 speeds?

The ATA driver (according to its comments, if they can be
trusted, which is debatable) uses this "ata66" parameter for
what it calls "quirky" chipsets that are ATA-66 compliant but
the driver [developer] can't find a method to determine
the presence of an 80-pin cable.  (It also should be max.
15" [or 18" ???] long.  Longer is often a problem.)
For lots of chipsets, the driver can determine this information
without needing the ata66 parameter.

| 2)  Can anyone recommend a good disk throughput benchmarking utility so
| that I can test with & without?  I am probably imagining it, but it
| actually seems slower when I use the parameter than without.

For ATA drives (not SCSI), use 'hdparm'.  man hdparm

| To further complicate things, I have a Highpoint 370 ATA100 RAID
| controller onboard (had to specially compile that support into my
| kernel).  Any special considerations regarding #1 above?

There's lot of ata66 and ata100 code in
linux/drivers/ide/hpt366.c (which handles the HPT 370).
I don't know the answer to your question offhand and can't
look it up right now.  Sorry about that.

There are also lists of drives that have problems with
ATA66 or ATA100 in hpt366.c (blacklisted drives),
so the driver may not support higher speeds with all
drives.

-- 
~Randy

> still see that most of it is "not free,"  but that as you begin running
> applications, Linux will begin removing certain tools, apps, etc. from
> memory to make room for the things you are firing up.

Not exactly.

You should take a look at the output from the "free" command:

# free
             total       used       free     shared    buffers     cached
Mem:        387740     287252     100488      44888     194432      37244
-/+ buffers/cache:      55576     332164
Swap:       102308          0     102308

You see in the first row, the above shows 100488 free (appx. 100 Megabytes)
but the actual free RAM is what is shown in the second row under free,
332164 (332 Megabytes) this is the amount of memory available if Linux
discounts the amount of space it is using for caching data from disk (not
just programs, any data).

Linux uses all available free memory as disk cache, so if you have 200 Meg
free, over time this will all get filled with data from various accesses
to the disk.  Whenever this memory is needed to load a program, Linux will
simply free some of this cache memory and use it to load your program
while retaining the rest of the cache so that it doesn't need to go to the
disk for the data that it still has room to keep in memory.

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From codeyeti at yahoo.com  Sun May  5 10:51:08 2002
From: codeyeti at yahoo.com (Michael Smith)
Date: Sun, 05 May 2002 10:51:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hard drive benchmarking for Linux?
References: <20020504170241.C2122@sparky>
Message-ID: <3CD57114.ADA21979@yahoo.com>

"hdparm -tT /dev/hda" will do a test on your drive.  You'll get different
results if you have an IO load on your machine.  You can also change some
settings with hdparm.  Mandrake used to use hdparm as an initscript when
you booted if you selected the "Use hard drive optimizations" install
option.

A good hdparm optimization line looks like this: "/sbin/hdparm -c1 -d1
-m16 /dev/hda"  Your mileage may vary.

--Mike

From john at meissen.org  Sun May  5 15:04:41 2002
From: john at meissen.org (john at meissen.org)
Date: Sun, 05 May 2002 15:04:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Build error message 
In-Reply-To: (Your message of Sun, 05 May 2002 14:39:04 PDT.)
             <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205051431270.5697-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <20020505220441.7CEAC74218@john.meissen.org>

Clock skew means the clock on the nfs server is different from the
clock on the local machine. It can be detected if the results of the
make have a date/time significantly different from the local machine,
say, in the future.

To fix it set the clocks the same. Run ntpdate periodically, or run
NTP on your machines.

From kens at cad2cam.com  Sun May  5 17:10:30 2002
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Sun, 5 May 2002 17:10:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Build error message 
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205051532270.13669-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <NMEPJGMCLGBMCOCPJFHKMEGMDHAA.kens@cad2cam.com>

Rich,

Have you tried creating the directory structure?
/var/tmp/libcap-1.10-root/usr/man/man2 and
/var/tmp/libcap-1.10-root/usr/man/man3

Then rerunning your make.

About timing.  We discovered at work that if the system clock and the
hardware clock were out of synch, ssh would work intermittently.

You could set up your salmo as your ntp server for you workstations.  Have
it go to some standard places.
server  bogart.cse.ogi.edu
server  caesar.cs.wisc.edu
server  cs.wisc.edu

Then have your workstations have
peer salmo.appl-ecosys.com

Use hwclock to synchronize your system clock to your hardware clock:
/sbin/hwclock --systohc --localtime
The localtime option ensures that hardware clock is localtime and not UTC.

Ken

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sun May  5 17:10:42 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sun, 5 May 2002 17:10:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] server crash
In-Reply-To: <63432.216.99.218.67.1020642805.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.31.0205051706340.6863-100000@co.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

On Sun, 5 May 2002, Josh Orchard wrote:
> Does linux have a CPU temp. gague?

lm-sensors will do this. If lm-sensors is already set up, gkrellm
should detect it and display the information. If you don't use gkrellm
there are other frontends for it, ie:

$ apt-cache search lm-sensors
i2c-source - sources for drivers for the i2c bus
ksensors - lm-sensors frontend for KDE
libsensors-dev - Lm-sensors development kit
libsensors1 - Library to read temperature/voltage/fan sensors
lm-sensors - Utilities to read temperature/voltage/fan sensors
lm-sensors-source - Kernel drivers to read temperature/voltage/fan sensors
(source)
sensord - Hardware sensor information logging daemon
wmsensors - WindowMaker dock applet for lmsensors

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun May  5 17:57:48 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 5 May 2002 17:57:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] server crash
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.31.0205051706340.6863-100000@co.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.31.0205051706340.6863-100000@co.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <200205051757.48454.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Do any of these sensor daemons allow you do set them up so in the case 
of a high temperature a log entry is made to the syslog and then the 
system is shutdown to protect against any damage. This would be really 
useful in the event of a fan failure and a subsequent overheat 
condition.

Since all of the sensor stuff can be gotten as text data from the 
"/proc/sys/dev/sensors" directory, I've toyed with both a shell script 
and C program which monitors the temperature values by polling at a 
specified interval. I know some of the vendors refuse to release any 
specs for their monitor hardware and so the lm_sensors team can only do 
a "best effort" on getting some of these values. I don't like 
reinventing the wheel and so if there's some sort of monitoring daemon 
that can handle an automatic shutdown on an fan and/or overheat failure 
I would be interested.

Tony

From airneil at dimstar.net  Sun May  5 19:01:19 2002
From: airneil at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sun, 05 May 2002 19:01:19 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Why do some services not start?
In-Reply-To: <1020643463.11056.243.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020505185843.00a887b8@mail.localnet.dimstar.net>

What runlevel are you running?

(Type runlevel at a prompt to find out)

Is there a link to the scripts that don't run in the /etc/rc#.d directory, 
where # is the runlevel you are running at?

If not, the links need to be created.

Run ntsysv on a redhat or redhat-alike system and make sure those services 
have an asterisk by them.

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sun May  5 19:22:05 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sun, 5 May 2002 19:22:05 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] server crash
In-Reply-To: <200205051757.48454.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.31.0205051910510.7272-100000@co.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> Do any of these sensor daemons allow you do set them up so in the case
> of a high temperature a log entry is made to the syslog and then the
> system is shutdown to protect against any damage. This would be really

The "sensord" package does some of that:

 "This package contains a daemon that logs hardware health status to the
 system log with optional warnings on potential system problems."

Maybe it has an option which will also shut the system down, or this
could be configured manually. Sounds like a cool idea; but if there was a
bug, the system might keep shutting itself down, and this might prove
difficult to fix. :)


Tyler

-------
Package: sensord
Priority: extra
Section: utils
Installed-Size: 144
Maintainer: David Z Maze <dmaze at debian.org>
Architecture: i386
Source: lm-sensors
Version: 2.6.3-5
Replaces: lm-sensors (<< 2.5.4-8)
Depends: lm-sensors, libc6 (>= 2.2.4-4), libsensors1
Filename: pool/main/l/lm-sensors/sensord_2.6.3-5_i386.deb
Size: 30326
MD5sum: 2cf59d11cdd908741a81947f669b7a9d
Description: Hardware sensor information logging daemon
 Lm-sensors is a hardware health monitoring package for Linux. It allows you
 to access information from temperature, voltage, and fan speed sensors. It
 works with most newer systems.
 .
 This package contains a daemon that logs hardware health status to the
 system log with optional warnings on potential system problems.
 .
 You will need lm-sensors and i2c kernel modules to use this package.

-----

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun May  5 23:51:57 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 5 May 2002 23:51:57 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] linux on 166?
In-Reply-To: <200205052319.18857.myboysherman@attbi.com>
References: <200205052319.18857.myboysherman@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <200205052351.57794.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I don't know if you saw my earlier post but I did a test update of a 
SuSE 7.2 system to SuSE 8.0 on a Pentium Pro 200 system with 128MB of 
memory. I'm not sure I would recommend trying to use KDE3 on a 166 
system. I found KDE3 very slow starting up on the PPro 200 system. My 
primary workstation is a 900MHZ Athlon and so I guess I'm used to 
better performance now and have forgotten how slow that PPro 200 system 
is when I used it as my primary workstation.

If you stick to a light weight window manager it is certainly possible 
to run an X-based Linux system on rather meager hardware. I used to run 
Slackware on a 486/33 with 32MB of memory. I used the OpenLook Virtual 
Window Manager "olvwm" and the system had sufficient resources to run 
both Netscape and XEmacs simultaneously and performance wasn't real 
bad. It did take some time to load those large apps but once they were 
running performance was quite acceptable.

YMMV,

Tony

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Mon May  6 01:33:29 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Mon, 6 May 2002 01:33:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] linux on 166?
In-Reply-To: <200205052319.18857.myboysherman@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.31.0205060009490.17152-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

On Sun, 5 May 2002, Craig wrote:
> Is KDE 3.0 going to be possible?  Anyone like any lighter desktop?

The ROX desktop might be appropriate for this. It has very little overhead
and the file manager is easy to use. It's very attractive and unique as
far as desktops go.

http://rox.sourceforge.net/

You could also try running a light window manager: ctwm, fvwm2, afterstep,
blackbox, maybe sawfish, on its own without a desktop (my preference) or
alongside ROX. ROX also supports most of the European languages (spanish
included) as well as english.

With respect to the distribution, something like gentoo might be most
efficient, although I imagine any distro would be efficient if you
compiled selectively. Debian or redhat would work.

I run debian potato on a pentium-90 with 40 Mbs and I don't notice any
performance difference between it and woody on my faster system
(Celeron800 w/128 mbs) for most tasks.

> Mainly I'm interested in browsers, email and basic document handling, but the

The browser is the area where you'll notice differences with respect to
performance. Its hard to find an efficient browser that supports the
latest stylesheets and such. Galeon is nice but its really only
lightweight if you're already running Gnome. You might want to try
SkipStone, a pure gtk+ browser:

http://www.muhri.net/skipstone/

I don't know what graphical email clients/word processors are appropriate
for this system, but I'm sure they're around. Its amazing how much mileage
you can get out of old hardware via linux. :) I could almost give up my
faster desktop system for the pentium-90 and be okay, except for watching
movies.


Tyler

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Mon May  6 06:46:17 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Mon, 6 May 2002 06:46:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] linux on 166?
In-Reply-To: <200205052319.18857.myboysherman@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0205060636370.818-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Sun, 5 May 2002, Craig wrote:
>
> My 166MMX is happily running Mandrake Security.  It has been a long time since
> it has run anything else.  I would like to hear from anyone with personal
> experience running a new distro on an old Pentium.  Is KDE 3.0 going to be
> possible?  Anyone like any lighter desktop?  I would particularly like to
> hear from people who use both a modern machine and an older one.  I remember
> being fairly well satisfied with SuSE 6.4 on the box, but after using a 600
> for a while that 166 has become painful.
>
> Mainly I'm interested in browsers, email and basic document handling, but the
> key is mom and dad level ease of use and reliability, so pine and lynx won't
> cut it.  Before I blow my firewall's uptime by testing a bunch of configs and
> distros with it, I thought someone here might have some experience and point
> me in the right direction.  By the way, Spanish language support would be
> nice.
>
One project you may want to check out is RULE -- Run Up-to-date Linux
Everywhere. You can read about it at:

http://www.rule-project.org/rule/

The folks have been hacking out a couple of utilities -- miniconda & slinky --
that allow you to install the latest RH distro on machines with limited
memory or hard drive space.

I've been using it to install RH 7.2 on my old 486 with 16MB of memory, &
the install went smoothly (although very slowly -- it took about 4 hours to
load a basic configuration). Slinky 0.2.1 also allows you to install the
basic X rpms, & to select between ext2 & ext3 filesystems. (ext3 is overkill
for the small, <=1GB hard drives on older machines.)

I haven't played around with finding out how well slinky works with Mandrake;
maybe after I have finished mucking around with the current image, & am
ready to test the latest slinky release.

Geoff





From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon May  6 07:52:48 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 6 May 2002 07:52:48 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Viva Peru!
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205060744220.9616-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

This leaked letter to Microsoft from a Peruvian congressman who's
sponsoring a bill mandating the use of free software in Peru's public 
sector made my morning.

  http://www.theregus.com/content/4/24858.html

The context is that a Microsoft rep. sent the congressman a letter 
supposedly detailing the dangers of mandating free software. Some of 
the best bits in the reply deal with point 4 in the Microsoft letter:

  Your letter continues: "4. The bill imposes the use of open source 
  software without considering the dangers that this can bring from 
  the point of view of security, guarantee, and possible violation of
  the intellectual property rights of third parties." ....

  In respect of the guarantee:

  As you know perfectly well, or could find out by reading the "End 
  User License Agreement" of the products you license, in the great
  majority of cases the guarantees are limited to replacement of the
  storage medium in case of defects, but in no case is compensation
  given for direct or indirect damages, loss of profits, etc....

  On Intellectual Property:

  ...The inclusion of the intellectual property of others in works
  claimed as one's own is not a practice that has been noted in the
  free software community; whereas, unfortunately, it has been in the
  area of proprietry software. As an example, the condemnation by the
  Commercial Court of Nanterre, France, on 27th September 2001 of
  Microsoft Corp. to a penalty of 3 million francs in damages and
  interest, for violation of intellectual property (piracy, to use the
  unfortunate term that your firm commonly uses in its publicity).

In general, however, the whole thing is great. Long, but great.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Mon May  6 08:28:42 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Mon, 6 May 2002 08:28:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Viva Peru!
In-Reply-To: <20020506105900.61b1a61a.mike@linuxlink.com>

> Poor Bill.

I assume you're referring to Gates. :) Yeah MS really got hung out to dry
on this one.

Here is copy of a letter I sent to Dr. Nunez a few days ago. It might be
good for others to offer encouragement. (I wish I knew Spanish)

------------------------
From: Tyler F. Creelan <creelan at eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
To: evillanueva at congreso.gob.pe
Subject: Bill Number 1609, Free Software in Public Administration

Dr. Edgar David Villanueva Nunez
Congressman of the Republica of Peru.

Re: Bill Number 1609, Free Software in Public Administration

Dear Dr. Nunez -

I just wanted to express my admiration for your legislative activities
with regard to Free Software. Your presentation of the technical and economic
issues surrounding software and licensure are firm and insightful [1]. In
this response, I also enjoyed the acuity with which you separated
unrelated but commonly confused issues.

I have to agree with comments that: "The letter... is by far one of
the most informed, logical arguments for "free" software I've ever seen."
and "I wish our government believed in democracy as much as Peru." [2]

If you find time to visit the United States I would enjoy hearing you
speak on this subject. Your statements will guide legislators elsewhere in
passing similar laws.


Tyler F. Creelan

College of Engineering
Oregon State University
Corvallis, Oregon, 97330

1. Nunez, Dr. Edgar David Villanueva. April 8th, 2002.
<http://www.gnu.org.pe/resmseng.html> [Online].

2. Free Software Law in Peruvian Congress. May 4th, 2002.
<http://slashdot.org/articles/02/05/04/220237.shtml?tid=117> [Online].

From don at truedisk.com  Mon May  6 09:32:42 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Mon, 06 May 2002 09:32:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] MySQL / my.cnf question
References: <1020679425.14159.6612.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
Message-ID: <3CD6B02A.8479CE31@truedisk.com>

Brent Rieck wrote:
> 
> Hello,
>   I was wondering if anybody here knew a way to specify different
> usernames/passwords/hosts for different databases in a ~/.my.cnf file?
> It works well for a single database (or multiple databases with the same
> username/password/host), but I can't seem to find documentation on how
> to specify differnt usernames/etc for multiple databases in the same
> .my.cnf file.
> 

Don't know of any ways to do this within the .my.cnf file, but
you could create multiple .my.cnf-dbaseN files, and then use
a wrapper script which does something like:

  #!/bin/sh
  if [ "$1" ]
  then
    MYCNF="$HOME/.my.cnf-$1"
  else
    MYCNF="$HOME/.my.cnf"
  fi
  mysql --defaults-file=$MYCNF $*


-- 
- Don Buchholz                               <don at truedisk.com>

I've got an older fujitsu laptop with Pentium MMX 200 chip and 96 MB RAM (all it
will take).  I have no problem running the helix stuff and mozilla.

I think the trick is to cram as much RAM as you can into the box.  Linux will
work on slower processors, but there's no substitute for RAM.

Another trick is to apply the preemtive kernel patch.  I'm running it now on the
laptop, and I'm very pleased with it.

I think the best resource you can have is the linux laptop howto.  It's got a ton
of tips on running linux on small, resource-limited machines.
http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Laptop-HOWTO.html

--Mike

At 09:34 AM 5/6/2002 -0700, Bill Spears wrote:
> What would happen if I took out the windows cable
> and put in one from a linux machine?  

Depends. Many DSL services use DHCP to assign your IP and/or require that
you run a PPPoE client to make the connection.  At a minimum, you might
need to release/renew an IP from the DSL provider's DHCP.  I would expect
you might also need to re-connect with the PPPoE client.  Requirements can
vary, even within Qwest's DSL services.

Though I can't say I've actually tried.  :-)

> What if I have a dual boot and I start the DSL connection
> under Windows, and reboot to floppyfw.  Would that work?

It probably won't maintain the same session, if that's what you're asking.
 But you could launch the PPPoE connection during the startup phase of each
boot, which might produce the outcome you're looking for.

Dylan

From codeyeti at yahoo.com  Mon May  6 10:13:22 2002
From: codeyeti at yahoo.com (Michael Smith)
Date: Mon, 06 May 2002 10:13:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] DSL Elementary Questions.
References: <200205061627.g46GRct26766@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <3CD6B9B2.86876820@yahoo.com>

Ok, there are 2 types of DSL: ppp over ethernet (PPPOE) and bridging.

In bridging, you have a "real" IP address and you just connect via your cisco
router.  Basically, the telephone line handles the physical layer of your
connection.  No problem since this is looking exactly like a normal LAN.  You
can disconnect your box, put a firewall in between your internal LAN and the
world, tell the firewall that it's got your IP address and gateway, and then
turn on NAT for the internal LAN.

With PPPOE, there is a ppp connection made via the ethernet link.  That way,
the ISP can make you verify your username and password.  That's why they like
it... from their point of view, it's easier to manage.  Unfortunately, most
ISP's use this.  There is software for PPPOE on linux, but I've never played
with it.  The physical setup is the same as for bridging mode, but you still
have to negotiate the ppp link, and that's where the problem is.

The easiest/best way is to just pick an ISP that lets you do bridging.  Failing
that, it's off to a web search for "PPPOE DSL linux".

--Mike

There are probably a few different factors at work here...  Now, as I don't 
recall the specifics of your posts, I'm making generalizations.

Some people might have your free email host (yahoo.com) blocked in their 
spam-protection scripts.  Not anything against you personally, but a LOT of 
spam DOES come from yahoo.

Your post could have been vague.  The more specific, the better.  You'll often 
see people asking for log files rather than a description of the problem.  The 
less questions *WE* have to ask to get to the root of *YOUR* problem, the 
easier it is in the long run for all of us.

Your post might have simply come at the wrong time.  I know sometimes people 
are in different "help" moods, and depending on the state of that mood, they 
can reply or not.  Try again, make sure you're more specific in your query, 
and see what happens.

Most of all, around here - patience is a virtue.

Hope that helps,

-Richard

From codeyeti at yahoo.com  Mon May  6 10:51:27 2002
From: codeyeti at yahoo.com (Michael Smith)
Date: Mon, 06 May 2002 10:51:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Thanks! -- linux on 166?
References: <200205052319.18857.myboysherman@attbi.com> <200205061036.57614.myboysherman@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3CD6C29E.4546222@yahoo.com>

The preemptive patch works as follows:

Normally multitasking is done by time slicing.  Processes wait in a que and are
dealth with in order (generally).  What the preemptive kernel patch does is if a
process needs attention right now, it sends a little preempt (like a hangup
signal) and the kernel attends to its needs.

It's like Joe at home with his Significant Other (SO).  Joe has all the things
that he needs to do for himself, such as reading the perl documentation and
building his relational database on his personal mysql server.  So he's working
away.  His SO needs the trash taken out.  She sends a preempt, making Joe quit
working immediately so that he can take out the trash.  Joe takes out the trash.
Joe then returns to processing his own job que as he sees fit.

The cool part about it is that the processes that usually send the preempts are
either processes that are part of user interaction (mouse and keyboard drivers)
or IO activities (buffering MP3's to play so they don't skip).  You get a small
speed increase usually with the preemptive kernel, but your MP3's don't skip, and
your mouse is more responsive.

The patch has been folded into the 2.5 series of kernels so in the future you
won't need to patch.

--Mike

From codeyeti at yahoo.com  Mon May  6 11:09:27 2002
From: codeyeti at yahoo.com (Michael Smith)
Date: Mon, 06 May 2002 11:09:27 -0700

You can connect to the cisco router via a rj45<->serial cable that should have
come with it.  Use minicom to connect to the serial port.  I think it's 9600
8N1, but the bitrate might be different.  Then you're talking directly to the
CBOS.  Check online for a reference for CBOS commands.  The cisco will do some
crazy stuff--builtin NAT, tftp server.

Subject: [PLUG] script like parameter
In-Reply-To: <B8EFF747323ED411AC7E005004744A08035CB973@MERLOT.saq.qc.ca>; from D.D'Apice@SAQ.qc.ca on Mon, May 06, 2002 at 12:26:51PM -0400

Message-ID: <20020506114846.A2100@linux-enterprise.net>

> config=$1
> $config    (where the scripts should be execute, is this the syntax should i
> use...?)
> 
> how is the syntax to give a scripts into another script to be execute ?
> 
When you are ready to run the script supplied as an argument, It should look like this:

  . $config <-- Note the period

A dot script is a script that runs in the parent's environment. In other words, unlike a regular script, a dot script is *not* a child of the caller. The dot script inherits all of the caller's environment, including variables that haven't been exported.

On Monday 06 May 2002 10:51 am, Michael Smith wrote:
> The preemptive patch works as follows:
>
> Normally multitasking is done by time slicing.  Processes wait in a que and
> are dealth with in order (generally).  What the preemptive kernel patch
> does is if a process needs attention right now, it sends a little preempt
> (like a hangup signal) and the kernel attends to its needs.
>
> It's like Joe at home with his Significant Other (SO).  Joe has all the
> things that he needs to do for himself, such as reading the perl
> documentation and building his relational database on his personal mysql
> server.  So he's working away.  His SO needs the trash taken out.  She
> sends a preempt, making Joe quit working immediately so that he can take
> out the trash.  Joe takes out the trash. Joe then returns to processing his
> own job que as he sees fit.
>
> The cool part about it is that the processes that usually send the preempts
> are either processes that are part of user interaction (mouse and keyboard
> drivers) or IO activities (buffering MP3's to play so they don't skip). 
> You get a small speed increase usually with the preemptive kernel, but your
> MP3's don't skip, and your mouse is more responsive.
>
> The patch has been folded into the 2.5 series of kernels so in the future
> you won't need to patch.
>
> --Mike

From aarghj at yahoo.com  Mon May  6 12:22:00 2002
From: aarghj at yahoo.com (john morgali)
Date: Mon, 6 May 2002 12:22:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] DSL Elementary Questions.
In-Reply-To: <200205061802.g46I2bW09693@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <20020506192200.48347.qmail@web10508.mail.yahoo.com>

In most situations dsl is just as described.  a lan on
one end, telco on the other.  there are many types of
dsl provisioning, tho, and some provisioning is done
at the noc and contains info like the mac address of
the adapter on the other side of the cpe.  if the noc
keeps this record, you will either need to have them
switch it, or use the same nic.  other cpe's keep a
flash ram record of the mac addy, and need a power
cycle sometimes up to 3 minutes to forget that info. 
yet others dont care at all.  just hook up and go.  I
dont know about the cisco on qwest, but I think it
keeps the flash ram, and once you clear that, it is
standard dhcp lan on the inside.  set your fw to pull
its ip dhcp, and assign the inside however you like.  

let me know if this helps. 
john

> Is 2.4.x cooperative multitasking?

> I've been bragging about this feature for over a year now, and your telling me 
> I've been full of sh*t?  Crap!  I'm going to get a ribbing over this.  My Mac 
> addicted friend (ironically named Joe) will find out that I really don't know 
> what I'm talking about.  My faked "savvy user" status will evaporate!   :-o
> 
> At any rate, this sounds like a feature I want.  Thanks again for the tip.

Well, Linux is pre-emptive in running user programs (as UNIX has
been for a very long time), but not in the kernel portion of things.
What the pre-empt patch does is allow the kernel to prempt itself
at times, particularly while in device drivers that may be "slow"
to respond or complete their operations.  Some of the kernel guys
could give you a more precise explanation; there's also an article
in the latest LJ, I believe.

Wil

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Mon May  6 12:41:32 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)

In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.31.0205051910510.7272-100000@co.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Yea the auto shutdown thing needs to be tested very well before turning 
it loose on a critical system. Even with my own little programs I wrote 
I saw a case where once in while the /proc/sys/dev/sensors would report 
a high temperature at one time and then the next time the temperature 
was checked it was OK. 

I had to change my monitor to detect 3 high temperatures before it would 
go off. I'm always a bit suspicious since I have a Asus A7V133 mobo 
with the AS99127F chip. Asus won't release any specs on the thing and 
so it's a "best effort" on these values. I've compared what I get from 
the "sensors" program with what the CMOS setup shows me and the values 
are very similar. The CPU temperature in the CMOS shows about a 2 
degree Celsius difference from what "sensors" reports. That pretty 
close IMHO.

Tony

> > > lm-sensors will do this. If lm-sensors is already set up, gkrellm
> > > should detect it and display the information. If you don't use
> > > gkrellm there are other frontends for it, ie:
> > >
> > > $ apt-cache search lm-sensors
> > > i2c-source - sources for drivers for the i2c bus
> > > ksensors - lm-sensors frontend for KDE
> > > libsensors-dev - Lm-sensors development kit
> > > libsensors1 - Library to read temperature/voltage/fan sensors
> > > lm-sensors - Utilities to read temperature/voltage/fan sensors
> > > lm-sensors-source - Kernel drivers to read
> > > temperature/voltage/fan sensors (source)
> > > sensord - Hardware sensor information logging daemon
> > > wmsensors - WindowMaker dock applet for lmsensors

On Mon, 2002-05-06 at 09:32, Don Buchholz wrote:
> Brent Rieck wrote:
> > 
> > Hello,
> >   I was wondering if anybody here knew a way to specify different
> > usernames/passwords/hosts for different databases in a ~/.my.cnf file?
> > It works well for a single database (or multiple databases with the same
> > username/password/host), but I can't seem to find documentation on how
> > to specify differnt usernames/etc for multiple databases in the same
> > .my.cnf file.
> > 
> 
> Don't know of any ways to do this within the .my.cnf file, but
> you could create multiple .my.cnf-dbaseN files, and then use
> a wrapper script which does something like:
> 
>   #!/bin/sh
>   if [ "$1" ]
>   then
>     MYCNF="$HOME/.my.cnf-$1"
>   else
>     MYCNF="$HOME/.my.cnf"
>   fi
>   mysql --defaults-file=$MYCNF $*
>

From craighead.scot at vectorscm.com  Mon May  6 14:20:11 2002
From: craighead.scot at vectorscm.com (Craighead, Scot D)
Date: Mon, 6 May 2002 14:20:11 -0700 
Subject: [PLUG] Thanks! -- linux on 166?
Message-ID: <51C603B9AB4696408D7273AA133734AC1EA8B0@ljcms002.prod.vectorscm.com>

Also Sprach Craig <myboysherman at attbi.com> on Mon, May 06, 2002 at
12:20:16PM PDT
> I thought linux did that already.  Perhaps I am confusing something else.
I 
> thought I read something about preemptive multitasking vs cooperative 
> multitasking with respect to Macs.  Don't Macintosh and Windows operating 
> systems currently support pre-emptive multitasking?
> 
> Is 2.4.x cooperative multitasking?

Cooperative multitasking means that the OS gives control to an app and waits
for the app to give it back, then gives control to the next app.  Preemtive
multitasking means the OS gives the app control (lets it execute code) for a
set amount of time then takes control away.  The advantage is that if an app
is "bad" and keeps control, the machine locks up and has to be rebooted.  Or
if one app keeps control for a long time, other apps just have to wait.

> >   if [ "$1" ]
> >   then
> >     MYCNF="$HOME/.my.cnf-$1"
> >   else
> >     MYCNF="$HOME/.my.cnf"
> >   fi

On Monday 06 May 2002 12:22 pm, you wrote:
> In most situations dsl is just as described.  a lan on
> one end, telco on the other.  there are many types of
> dsl provisioning, tho, and some provisioning is done
> at the noc and contains info like the mac address of
> the adapter on the other side of the cpe.  if the noc
> keeps this record, you will either need to have them
> switch it, or use the same nic.  other cpe's keep a
> flash ram record of the mac addy, and need a power
> cycle sometimes up to 3 minutes to forget that info.
> yet others dont care at all.  just hook up and go.  I
> dont know about the cisco on qwest, but I think it
> keeps the flash ram, and once you clear that, it is
> standard dhcp lan on the inside.  set your fw to pull
> its ip dhcp, and assign the inside however you like.

  $ strace -h
  usage: strace [-dffhiqrtttTvVxx] [-a column] [-e expr] ... [-o file]
                [-p pid] ... [-s strsize] [-u username] [command [arg ...]]
     or: strace -c [-e expr] ... [-O overhead] [-S sortby] [command [arg ...]]
  -c -- count time, calls, and errors for each syscall and report summary
  -f -- follow forks, -ff -- with output into separate files
  -F -- attempt to follow vforks, -h -- print help message
  -i -- print instruction pointer at time of syscall
  -q -- suppress messages about attaching, detaching, etc.
  -r -- print relative timestamp, -t -- absolute timestamp, -tt -- with usecs
  -T -- print time spent in each syscall, -V -- print version
  -v -- verbose mode: print unabbreviated argv, stat, termio[s], etc. args
  -x -- print non-ascii strings in hex, -xx -- print all strings in hex
  -a column -- alignment COLUMN for printing syscall results (default 40)
  -e expr -- a qualifying expression: option=[!]all or option=[!]val1[,val2]...
     options: trace, abbrev, verbose, raw, signal, read, or write
  -o file -- send trace output to FILE instead of stderr
  -O overhead -- set overhead for tracing syscalls to OVERHEAD usecs
  -p pid -- trace process with process id PID, may be repeated
  -s strsize -- limit length of print strings to STRSIZE chars (default 32)
  -S sortby -- sort syscall counts by: time, calls, name, nothing (default time)
  -u username -- run command as username handling setuid and/or setgid

Ah, I see:

  $ strace -f -o /tmp/strace-foo foo-command

Salt to taste.

On Mon, 06 May 2002 10:13:22 -0700
Michael Smith <codeyeti at yahoo.com> spewed into the bitstream:

~Ok, there are 2 types of DSL: ppp over ethernet (PPPOE) and bridging.
~
~In bridging, you have a "real" IP address and you just connect via your
~cisco router.  Basically, the telephone line handles the physical layer
~of your connection.  No problem since this is looking exactly like a
~normal LAN.  You can disconnect your box, put a firewall in between
~your internal LAN and the world, tell the firewall that it's got your
~IP address and gateway, and then turn on NAT for the internal LAN.
~
~With PPPOE, there is a ppp connection made via the ethernet link.  That
~way, the ISP can make you verify your username and password.  That's
~why they like it... from their point of view, it's easier to manage. 
~Unfortunately, most ISP's use this.  There is software for PPPOE on
~linux, but I've never played with it.  The physical setup is the same
~as for bridging mode, but you still have to negotiate the ppp link, and
~that's where the problem is.
~The easiest/best way is to just pick an ISP that lets you do bridging. 
~Failing that, it's off to a web search for "PPPOE DSL linux".
~
~--Mike
~
~Bill Spears wrote:
~
~> So I've got DSL from Qwest running on a Windows machine and I'd like
~to> switch, slowly and carefully, to floppyfw.
~>
~> The way I understand it, DSL is like a lan and the modem provides a
~telco> connection on one side an a lan connection on the other.
~>
~> What would happen if I took out the windows cable and put in one from
~a> linux machine?  On a lan it would eventually adapt to the new MAC.
~What> happens in the DSL context?
~>
~> What if I have a dual boot and I start the DSL connection under
~Windows, and> reboot to floppyfw.  Would that work?

On Mon, May 06, 2002 at 05:09:53PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On 6 May 2002, Russell Senior wrote:
> 
> > Ah, I see:

> >   $ strace -f -o /tmp/strace-foo foo-command
> 
>   Thank you, Russell. The command line I used was:
> 
> /usr/bin/strace /usr1/wp8/wpbin/xwp &>logfile
> 
>   Worked, too.

Sort of. You really want the -f argument to strace, as that tells strace
to follow any children processes that xwp forks off. 

You might also try doing "ldd /usr1/wp8/wpbin/xwp" to see if any shared
libraries xwp wants can't be identified.

02:08.0 Ethernet controller: 3Com Corporation 3c900B-TPO [Etherlink XL TPO] 
(rev 04)

I'm currently trying to do my testing from user space.  Here's a snippet
of code.  The code leading up to this just reads from /proc/bus/pci/devices
to get the BAR info.  I run this code while holding a scope probe on /REQ64.

thanks,
galen



  memfd = open("/dev/mem", O_RDWR);
  function = 0;
  i = 0;
  pmem = mmap(0, size[function][i], PROT_READ | PROT_WRITE, MAP_SHARED, memfd,
       bar[function][i] & PCI_BASE_ADDRESS_MEM_MASK);
  if (pmem == MAP_FAILED)
    printf("mmap failed.\n");
  else
    printf("pmem = %08x\n", pmem);

  memset(pmem, 0, size[function][i]);
  msync(pmem,  size[function][i], MS_SYNC);

  for (offset = 0; offset < size[function][i]; offset += 8)
    {
      *(unsigned long long *)(pmem + offset) = offset;
    }

  for (offset = 0; offset < size[function][i]; offset += 8)
    {
      if (*(unsigned long long *)(pmem + offset) != offset)
	{
	  printf("Error at %04x\n", offset);
	  exit(1);
	}
    }

  close(memfd);

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon May  6 19:14:29 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 6 May 2002 19:14:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: It might not be eloquent...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0203280902280.3683-100000@quidditch.measurecast.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205061733101.28094-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

In late March, I posted to PLUG a copy of the message I sent to Sens. 
Wyden and Smith and Rep. Hooley concerning Sen. Hollings' Consumer 
Broadband and Digital Television Promotion Act, the successor to the 
SSSCA.

In the mail today (U.S. Mail, not e-mail) there was a letter from Sen.
Wyden's office. Here are the relevant bits:

  The issue of digital content protection has raised significant 
  questions about our copyright regime as we struggle to determine 
  whether and how existing intellectual property laws can adapt to the 
  changing environment in this digital age. It seems clear to me that 
  the distribution of media over the Internet is an exciting 
  development that we cannot and should not try to block. At the same 
  time, we do need to make sure that the legitimate rights of those
  who create such media are protected.

  Technological solutions may be needed to provide such protections. 
  However, like you, I am wary of having government dictate specific 
  technology standards, becasue there is a risk of locking in an 
  inflexible, one-size-fits-all approach. I am also concerned about 
  the possibility that new protections could erode or undermine
  existing consumer rights to fair use. I believe that to create a
  more secure environment for the dissemination of digital content, a
  solution can best be achieved through cooperative discussions among
  all affected parties to develop creative and balanced technological
  approaches, rather than having a government mandated approach.

It sounds like he gets part of it: inflexibility in terms of standards 
and lack of fair-use protections. At the same time, he doesn't mention 
free software's place in this cooperative vision, nor does provide a 
hint as to who belongs in the "all affected parties" category (e.g., 
students and teachers, open-source collaborations that are quite 
likely to be international in nature, etc.).

Still, it sounds as if he's leaning away from the bill for at least 
some of the right reasons. That can't be all bad :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

> still won't load. Sigh.
> 
Have you tried searching www.dejanews.com for something like, "Wordperfect for Linux won't load?"

This might generate some ideas on where to go from here as well as save you the cost of an upgrade!

Here's what I found:


    DO NOT INSTALL Corel WordPerfect 8 for Linux as ?root?.
    
    Explanation of the problem:
    
    When Corel WordPerfect 8 for Linux loads, it creates a directory called
    /tmp/wpc-<hostname> (where <hostname> is the host name of your computer)
    that has the UMASK 777.
    
    Some necessary temporary files are stored in this folder, all containing the
    UMASK 666. When Corel WordPerfect 8 for Linux loads, it checks to see that
    these files exist, and if so, it will overwrite them.
    
    However, Corel WordPerfect 8 for Linux doesn't check to see if these files
    have been replaced with sym-links of the same name. If this has been done
    (perhaps to compromise system security), Corel WordPerfect 8 for Linux will
    follow those sym-links and, if it has the rights to do so (which it will if
    you install the application as ?root?), it will overwrite the file pointed
    to by the sym-link. This problem could be used to exploit a system.
    
    Procedure to eliminate the problem:
    
    If you have not installed Corel WordPerfect 8 for Linux yet, simply follow
    the instructions under ?Installation Procedures?.
    
    If you have already installed Corel WordPerfect, we strongly recommend that
    you delete that installation and re-install the application. To delete a
    current installation of Corel WordPerfect 8 for Linux, execute the following
    instructions:
    
    rm -r <path to Corel WordPerfect 8 for Linux Installation> (answer yes to
    the prompts)
    rm -rf ~/.wprc
    rm /etc/magic
    
    Installation Procedures:
    
    If you already have another user account setup on your system, then simply
    login under that user account, and run the installation program as you
    normally would.
    
    NOTE: On most systems, you can only mount the CD-ROM drive as root, so you
    should do this before you login as a non-root user.
    
    If you do not have a ?non-root? user account setup on your system, the
    following will set that up (for RedHat Linux only):
    
    Login as root
    
    
    Type: adduser <username>
    where <username> can be any name you wish, but should be something short
    and easy to remember
    
    
    Next type: passwd <username>
    where <username> is the same as what you chose for the previous step
    
    
    You will be prompted for a password for that user, and then asked to confirm
    that password
    
    
    If all went well, you will receive a message similar to the following:
       "passwd: all authentication tokens updated successfully"
    To enact a fix to Corel WordPerfect 8 for Linux without re-installing the
    software (this should only be attempted by advanced Linux users ? Corel
    recommends deleting the software and reinstalling using the previous
    method).
    
    This procedure will change the installation of Corel WordPerfect 8 for Linux
    so that it can't be used to exploit the host system. This procedure must be
    executed as root, and is recommended for advanced users only.
    
    Command list:
    
    cd <path to Corel WordPerfect 8 for Linux Installation>/..
    chown <non-root user>: chown <non-root user>: rm -rf /tmp/wpc*
    
    
    EXAMPLE:
    
    cd /usr/local/wp8/..
    chown johnd:johnd wp8 -R
    chown johnd:johnd /etc/magic
    rm -rf /tmp/wpc*
    
--

Usually when I see something not obviously failing and doing something
time related, I assume that its waiting for something else, which is why
I really want to see "strace -f" output, to eliminate a failing child
process as a possibility.

Beyond that, I would then grep through your strace logs for your
hostname to see if it is being used inconsistently.

On Monday 06 May 2002 07:14 pm, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> In late March, I posted to PLUG a copy of the message I sent to Sens.
> Wyden and Smith and Rep. Hooley concerning Sen. Hollings' Consumer
> Broadband and Digital Television Promotion Act, the successor to the
> SSSCA.
>
> In the mail today (U.S. Mail, not e-mail) there was a letter from Sen.
> Wyden's office. Here are the relevant bits:
>
>   The issue of digital content protection has raised significant
>   questions about our copyright regime as we struggle to determine
>   whether and how existing intellectual property laws can adapt to the
>   changing environment in this digital age. It seems clear to me that
>   the distribution of media over the Internet is an exciting
>   development that we cannot and should not try to block. At the same
>   time, we do need to make sure that the legitimate rights of those
>   who create such media are protected.
>
>   Technological solutions may be needed to provide such protections.
>   However, like you, I am wary of having government dictate specific
>   technology standards, becasue there is a risk of locking in an
>   inflexible, one-size-fits-all approach. I am also concerned about
>   the possibility that new protections could erode or undermine
>   existing consumer rights to fair use. I believe that to create a
>   more secure environment for the dissemination of digital content, a
>   solution can best be achieved through cooperative discussions among
>   all affected parties to develop creative and balanced technological
>   approaches, rather than having a government mandated approach.
>
> It sounds like he gets part of it: inflexibility in terms of standards
> and lack of fair-use protections. At the same time, he doesn't mention
> free software's place in this cooperative vision, nor does provide a
> hint as to who belongs in the "all affected parties" category (e.g.,
> students and teachers, open-source collaborations that are quite
> likely to be international in nature, etc.).
>
> Still, it sounds as if he's leaning away from the bill for at least
> some of the right reasons. That can't be all bad :-)
>
> --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
>
>

Subject: [PLUG] Signing Certs with OpenSSL?
Message-ID: <20020507113256.I31086@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

I don't know if anyone here is going to know how to do this, other
than perhaps Alan, but it's worth a shot.  When I get a cert from
Thawte, one of the formats offered is supposedly able to be used for
signing other certs.  The idea being, I've got a cert signed by a
recognized CA and am able to extend my trust to a customer's cert, so
instead of my customers having to go to Verisign or Thawte (now the
same company), they can go directly to us.  From my understanding,
this should be possible, but I've never quite figured out how to
do it.  Anyone know?

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue May  7 12:17:32 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 7 May 2002 12:17:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Signing Certs with OpenSSL?
In-Reply-To: <20020507113256.I31086@rheingold.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205071212260.11753-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 7 May 2002, Wil Cooley wrote:

> I don't know if anyone here is going to know how to do this, other
> than perhaps Alan, but it's worth a shot.  When I get a cert from
> Thawte, one of the formats offered is supposedly able to be used for
> signing other certs.  The idea being, I've got a cert signed by a
> recognized CA and am able to extend my trust to a customer's cert,
> so instead of my customers having to go to Verisign or Thawte (now
> the same company), they can go directly to us.  From my
> understanding, this should be possible, but I've never quite figured
> out how to do it.  Anyone know?

Wil,

The OpenSSL stuff often ships with a CA.sh or CA.pl script.  
Eye-grepping it will be instructive. Red Hat 7.1 even includes a man
page for the Perl version of the CA script.

In general, you'd want to create your own Certificate Authority (CA). 
Then have your client generate a key (specific to the host on which 
it'll operate) and a cert request based on that key. Your CA would 
then create a new cert based on the client's request. Ship the new 
cert back to your client, install it wherever, point the client's SSL 
apps at it, et voila.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

library with it (as the service he's trying to use
demands).  I have these rules in the netopia:

dest_ip:source_ip:protocol:src_port:dest_port:active:allow
(testexternal):0.0.0.0:TCP:ALL:80:Yes:Yes
(serviceip):0.0.0.0:TCP:ALL:>=1024:Yes:Yes
(serviceip):0.0.0.0:UDP:ALL:>=1024:Yes:Yes
(internaladdresses):(anywhere):(any protocol):::Yes:Yes

The Service uses port 10021 for "secure ftp command" and
10020 for "secure ftp data". However, it's unclear to me
from their documentation if it will be connecting to that
port or from that port to "a random port above 1023". 
The rules above allow all that stuff (I want it to work,
then I'll narrow it down).  I'm forwarding all contact
for ports 10021 and 10020 from the netopia to the boss's
computer (which requires, of course that the Service is
trying to reach that port, but I don't see "forward all
ports over 1023 to the boss's computer" as ... a good
solution.  I've tried it both with and without the port
forwarding and it does not work either way.

Here's what happens... 
He can log in fine (more or less); there's no error for
password or anything. However, he cannot get a directory
listing, and recieves a "Data Error (425)" from the
NetFinder application, which leads me to believe that
there's something wrong with the (wait for it) data
channel firewall rules.  Obviously I misunderstand
something of how that all works, in regard to a double
channel connection (ie ftp versus http, which I actually
made to work).

um help?

Thanks :)

what kind of ethernet cards ??

ISA or PCI ??

I have seen some ISA card that one must 1st flash the bios on the card
to set the IRQ, so that they can be happy.

Netgear dec tulip cards seem to be happy at the same IRQ. 

more info on the cards. 

but a rule of thumb is to have 2 different brands of ether net cards. 

dec tulip, 3com etc.

from a DHCP server.

Get_local_host: hostname 'traveller.home.com' bad

My hosts file on the laptop looks like:

127.0.0.1       localhost.home.com   localhost 
192.168.0.1     jed.home.com jed
192.168.0.2     zeph.home.com zeph


If I change it to:

127.0.0.1       localhost.home.com   localhost 
127.0.0.1      traveller.home.com    traveller
192.168.0.1     jed.home.com jed
192.168.0.2     zeph.home.com zeph

I don't get the error message from lpr, but somehow I don't think it's a
good idea.

So, since I'm getting my ip address via DHCP on the laptop, what should
I put in /etc/hosts to identify 'traveller' with an ip address?

On Tue, May 07, 2002 at 01:52:08PM -0700, Galen Seitz wrote:
> > On Mon, May 06, 2002 at 06:00:03PM -0700, Galen Seitz wrote:
> > > 
> > > I'm currently trying to do my testing from user space.  Here's a snippet
> > > of code.  The code leading up to this just reads from /proc/bus/pci/devices
> > > to get the BAR info.  I run this code while holding a scope probe on /REQ64.
> > 
> > I am pretty sure you can't do this from userspace like you are trying
> > to, but you just asked this on lkml, which is the proper place for it.
> > Someone there will be able to give you a better answer.
> > 
> 
> I doubt I'm going to get an answer from lkml.  It looks like they are
> pretty busy discussing more important matters.  I'm glad you said that
> lklm was the right place for the question, though. 
> 
> If this were being done from kernel space, how would the code be written
> to get 64 bit transfers to happen?

You can't directly do a 64bit read/write (from what I can tell.)  Take a
look at the file Documentaion/DMA-mapping.txt for how to get PCI DMA to
happen properly from within a kernel driver.  It explains all sorts of
64bit access stuff.

Hope this helps,

greg k-h

> I'm trying to get printing working on my laptop which gets its address
> from a DHCP server.  
> 
> Whenever I do an 'lpr' I get:
> 
> Get_local_host: hostname 'traveller.home.com' bad
> 
> My hosts file on the laptop looks like:
> 
> 127.0.0.1       localhost.home.com   localhost 
> 192.168.0.1     jed.home.com jed
> 192.168.0.2     zeph.home.com zeph
> 
> 
> If I change it to:
> 
> 127.0.0.1       localhost.home.com   localhost 
> 127.0.0.1      traveller.home.com    traveller
> 192.168.0.1     jed.home.com jed
> 192.168.0.2     zeph.home.com zeph
> 
> I don't get the error message from lpr, but somehow I don't think it's a
> good idea.
> 
> So, since I'm getting my ip address via DHCP on the laptop, what should
> I put in /etc/hosts to identify 'traveller' with an ip address?
> 
> BTW: I'm using lprng and sending print jobs to a remote printserver.

Put both the traveller and localhost lines on one:

127.0.0.1   localhost.home.com localhost traveller.home.com traveller

Wil

From derek at infotects.com  Tue May  7 18:06:20 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 07 May 2002 18:06:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 2 Ethernets
In-Reply-To: <0507102173522.0.0005089801@mail.bctonline.com>
References: <0507102173522.0.0005089801@mail.bctonline.com>
Message-ID: <1020819981.17058.26.camel@dereklinux>

On Tue, 2002-05-07 at 18:35, chaz wrote:
> BTW, the errors at the end of the dmesg output were caused by attempting
>  to ping other systems.
> -chaz
What type of system is this (motherboard chipset, processor, etc)? Those
errors look like they may be irq sharing problems.  Is it possible to
change the slots that the cards are in?  Is the BIOS assigning an irq to
each card during POST?  Is your BIOS set to "Plug-n-Play OS"?

Good luck

Derek





From galens at seitzassoc.com  Tue May  7 18:28:11 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Tue, 07 May 2002 18:28:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 64 bit wide pci question 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Tue, 07 May 2002 15:32:54 PDT."
             <20020507223254.GW2180@kroah.com> 
Message-ID: <200205080128.g481SBP30110@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> > 
> > I doubt I'm going to get an answer from lkml.  It looks like they are
> > pretty busy discussing more important matters.  I'm glad you said that
> > lklm was the right place for the question, though. 
> > 
> > If this were being done from kernel space, how would the code be written
> > to get 64 bit transfers to happen?
> 
> You can't directly do a 64bit read/write (from what I can tell.)  Take a
> look at the file Documentaion/DMA-mapping.txt for how to get PCI DMA to
> happen properly from within a kernel driver.  It explains all sorts of
> 64bit access stuff.
> 

Thanks for the feedback.  I finally got it working, albeit in one direction.
I enabled an MTRR to do write combining over the memory space of my PCI
card.  Now when I do 'memset(pmem, 0, size[function][i])', I see activity
on req64 and ack64.  I still don't know how to get the bridge to do 64
bit reads, but at least I know my board will respond as a 64 bit target.

thanks for your help,
galen






From barryb at proaxis.com  Tue May  7 18:30:19 2002
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Tue, 7 May 2002 18:30:19 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 2 Ethernets
In-Reply-To: <0507102172825.0.0005089801@mail.bctonline.com>; from chaz@bctonline.com on Tue, May 07, 2002 at 05:28:25PM -0800
References: <0507102172825.0.0005089801@mail.bctonline.com>
Message-ID: <20020507183019.A21831@edge>

This seems to be a heavily discussed issue with the driver
for this card. You can find one thread here
http://www.tux.org/hypermail/linux-vortex/2001-Jun/0022.html
The suggestion was to pass the kernel the noapic option 
when booting. Another thing that might work is to use the
bios to force each ethernet card to have a separate IRQ.

Bill

If you built from source, then you'll need to create your own startup
script and drop it in /etc/init.d/ then make a symlink to it in your
favorite runlevel.  Here's a simple one to get you going:

#!/bin/sh

case "$1" in
start)
	/usr/local/apache/bin/apachectl start
	;;
stop)
	/usr/local/apache/bin/apachectl stop
	;;
*)
	echo $"*** Usage: $prog {start|stop}"
	exit 1
esac

exit $?


-----------

"The only thing necessary for evil to triumph is for good men to do
nothing"
  --Edmund Burke.

Message-ID: <20020508172604.RTNV25765.rwcrmhc54.attbi.com@rwcrwbc58>

How does Secure FTP differ from HTTP and SSH; ie how does
the double channel thing work?  I ask because I can make
our firewall forward SSH and HTTP from the outside world
to my internal computer (internal on the LAN, that is)
but I can't make my boss's computer SFTP to a remote site
(that apparently works for everyone else).

My rule set looks like:

The netopia router is configured like this:
1) it forwards port 22 to my workstation, and I can log
in via ssh from my home computer.  It used to forward
port 80 to my workstation and I could browse the little
web pages I have running on that computer from outside
our LAN. 
2) it forwards ports 10020 and ports 10021 to the Boss's
computer.
3) it has an out bound rule set (out from the LAN to the
WAN) that allows everything.
4) it has an inbound rule set (in from the WAN to the
LAN) that ...
  a) allows connection to port 22 for any address (ssh
for my computer)
  b) allows connections from ftp.server.com to any port
greater than 1023 to any address.

When the Boss goes to connect, he gets "logged in" (no
error message there) but an error pops up that he cannot
get a data transfer. Which implies to me something wrong
with port 10020 communications, but if the server
(ftp.server.com) tries to connect to that port, it'll get
accepted (port 10020 is greater than port 1023) and it'll
get forwarded to the Boss's computer.  

I don't really want to forward *all* connections to a
high end port to the Boss's computer, do I? That seems...
excessively dangerous.  

Any education I can acquire would be .. helpful. :)

-Russ

I had a similar problem during debian install process.  The NIC would come up, 
drivers will load, I could assign IPs manually, but -any- traffic passing over 
the NIC was summarily ignored (tcpdump confirmed this).  

I solved it by using an install image (and kernel image) that had the driver 
compiled directly in.  And it was a 3com NIC, too.  The netgear worked fine, I 
might add.

From m at netpro.to  Wed May  8 14:33:17 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Wed, 8 May 2002 14:33:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Startup scripts, was: Apache
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205081327300.24915-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0205081422080.27621-100000@lukem.com>

On Wed, 8 May 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

>
> On Wed, 8 May 2002, Michael H.Collins wrote:
> > On Wed, 8 May 2002 05:15:17 -0700 (PDT)
> > Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> spewed into the bitstream:
> > ~Why wouldn't you just symlink apachectl into /etc/init.d?
> >
> > would that do stop and start?
>
> If you look at the script Matt posted, all it does is pass a start to
> apachectl when you pass a start to the script and pass a stop to
> apachectl when you pass a stop to the script.
>
> I don't see the purpose of the intervening script there.
>
> Also, the apachectrl script takes other arguments common to init scripts
> like restart.

Using a script to call apachectl is an extra and unnecessary step, so feel
free to use the script I posted as a template for starting and stopping
other services.  For example, to start and stop sshd, you might have:

#!/bin/sh

case "$1" in
start)
	/usr/local/sbin/sshd
	;;

stop)
	killall sshd
	;;

restart)
	killall sshd
	/usr/local/sbin/sshd
	;;

*)
	echo $"*** Usage: $prog {start|stop|restart}"
	exit 1
esac

exit $?

It's better to use to the PID file of the parent process if
available.  If you just use 'killall sshd', you'll also kill your
login shell if you're logged in via ssh, which can be a PITA.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed May  8 15:04:04 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Wed May  8 15:11:55 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Wed, 8 May 2002 15:11:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] AbiWord on a network
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205081448300.17875-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>; from rshepard@appl-ecosys.com on Wed, May 08, 2002 at 02:51:02PM -0700
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205081448300.17875-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20020508151155.C4562@dalsemi.com>

On Wed, May 08, 2002 at 02:51:02PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Abiword installed itself ('make install') in /usr/local/share/AbiSuite/.
> Does this mean that I must install it on each workstation in order to have
> access to it from more than one workstation?
> 
>   I'd like to have it on a nfs-exported/mounted filesystem so it's available
> to every workstation.

During the build stage, will abiword let you specify where to install
it?  If it uses configure, the answer is almost surely yes and reading
through the equivalent of the INSTALL file will tell you what switches
to throw to make it do that.

The GNU configure default is:
  ./configure --prefix=/your/very/own/path

Colin

window mangers focus.

version to build. 


Redhat gets around this by rebuilding db3 3.1.17 in evolution build dir.

so process does not look like fun. 

Has anyone been able to pull down their mail in a redhat 7.3 box with

From dealy at deatech.com  Wed May  8 19:58:24 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Wed, 8 May 2002 19:58:24 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Printing
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205081144240.18852-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205081930470.14347-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Wed, 8 May 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Is anyone else here using WordPerfect and CUPS? I have everything working
> again except the printing. (And it was broken printing that started my
> problems the past couple of days.)
>
>   When things worked, I was able to create a printer destination of 'ljraw'.
> Now I cannot. The default lpr printer is $PRINTER with the destination
> option of 'ljraw', but it's not working. If I select a WPApp destination
> (other than disk), the printer control dialog box pops up and says there's a
> problem with /var/spool/cups/. I cannot find the problem so I cannot clear
> it up.

I am currently using WordPerfect 8 and CUPS.  Your problem is most likely
WordPerfect, I have had nothing but problems with it and printing for all
the years I have been using it under Linux.  From what you wrote I kind of
get the impression you have a different version of WP than I do, so I am
not sure if any of this will help or even applies to you.

   1 - My experience with my version of WP is that if it isn't in the
       /etc/printcap file WP can't deal with it (yes I know that CUPS
       doesn't use the printcap).
   2 - If it is in the /etc/printcap file, the definition must all be
       on one line, no continuations/multi-line definitions.
   3 - WP only understands the first name of each printer in the
       printcap file, all the others in the printer definition are
       ignored.
   4 - WP gets upset if the printer name is longer than two characters
       (possibly if it is shorter as well, I never tried it).

With these four issues as a given, I configured CUPS with a two character
printer name for the printer and added a single line description of the
printer to my printcap:

   st|StylusC80|Remote printer Epson Stylus C80:lp=:rm=nashapur.deatech.com:rp=StylusC80:sd=/var/spool/lpd/remote:mx#0:sh:

most of this is probably unnecessary since WP will just pass the data to
lpr, but if I ever use a non-cups printing program, it will probably be
useful (I only converted to CUPS one or two months ago).  Then in WP I
added a printer definition using the passthru postscript driver and
referencing this printer.

I don't know which distribution you are using, but under Debian, I needed
a separate package "cupsys-bsd" to get the old style lpr command for WP
to use when printing.  My experience with error messages from WP when the
printing failed was that they were completely useless and gave no actual
clue as to the problem which was actually occuring.  Instead I used the
printer logs and CUPS status commands to see if any attempt was actually
made to queue a job, and if so, why it failed to print.

FWIW.

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

pretty basic- page numbering, headers/footers, a bit of autotext, and word 
count. If I really want to go nuts, it has vi and Emacs key bindings. 
Combined with Klipper, the nicest clipboard tool I know of, I can crank out a 
1500-word article in record time. Klipper actually lets you see what is on 
it, unlike Brand MS, which holds up to 12 items identified only by the app 
they were made in. How useless can you get.

This is the Klez worm.  I have been getting at least 5-10 of these a
day. (From all over the world.) Turns out there are a whole bunch of
variants of this virus.  Some are pretty nasty. Some actually disable
other viruses. Some take out anti-virus software and install new
viruses.  One variant is believed to have been the result of the virus
payload being infected by another virus.

One of the main reasons I am glad I use Linux.

From alan at clueserver.org  Wed May  8 20:11:29 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: 08 May 2002 20:11:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] es1371 sound card
In-Reply-To: <20020508204735.B2389@plato.usc.edu>
References: <20020508204735.B2389@plato.usc.edu>
Message-ID: <1020913889.23292.7.camel@summanulla.clueserver.org>

It looks like your system believes you have two scsi cards installed on
the same IRQ.

It this an on-board es1371 or is it on a card? 

Check /proc/dma and see if the soundcard is fighting for dma with
something else. (I have had that problem and it caused similar weird
problems with my scsi card.)

On Wed, 2002-05-08 at 21:16, Robert Kopp wrote:
> The most widely-used compiler for Linux is free.
> Metrowerks, however, claims that their commercial IDE
> product is very popular. Would someone who is familiar
> with it care to offer an opinion as to whether it is
> worth the money ($149)?

I have an older version and I never use it.  There are a number of free
IDEs out there.  Most of them seem to work better.

The biggest problem is that it was very difficult to create
distributable code.  It did not generate make files that were useful. 
(No autoconf support and a proprietary project file format.)  Unless
that has changed, it is not really worth it.  

What language do you need to work in?  Kdevelop looked promising I tend
to use a standard text editor any more.

> computer freezes for a couple of minutes. I am running RH7.2 with kernel

You might try this in your aliases file (if you do not have devices using irq 15 (usually secondary IDE devices):

 alias sound-slot-0 es1371 io=0x300 irq=15

Or another free irq in your system.

the router, and other on the LAN?  Essentially what I am trying to do is

LAN.  We have a Linksys BEFSR41 Cable/DSL router, though there sometimes
arises the need to do a DHCP release and refresh from "inside".  It's
imperative that the dialup server allows me to do this by connecting to
the router internally on 192.168.1.1.

I guess my main question is:  Since there is only one modem/phone line,
should I configure it to just hand out a static IP?  The other systems
on the network have dynamic IP's in the range of 192.168.1.100 through
.149 (potentially, though only 100 through 105 are used).  I was
imagining that say, 192.168.1.150 would work for the one dialup user.

If anyone else has experience doing this sort of thing, I could use a
tip or two on pitfalls to watch out for.

The system is a i386 (1ghz Duron/256mb RAM, gobs of IDE HD space)
running a fairly stock RedHat 7.2 install.  I have no plans to upgrade
any of the packages to Redhat 7.3 at this time - why fix something
that's not broken.

Thanks,

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu May  9 00:00:54 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 9 May 2002 00:00:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Dialup Server on network with Linksys DSL/Cablemodem router
In-Reply-To: <00dd01c1f721$b02523d0$6401a8c0@endeavor>
References: <00dd01c1f721$b02523d0$6401a8c0@endeavor>
Message-ID: <200205090000.54848.aschlemm@attbi.com>

If you only need a command-line interface, the other way to do this 
would be to have a modem setup so you can dial-in and get a "login" 
prompt using "mgetty" on the server. You can use a simple terminal 
program that supports a VT100 or other simple text-based terminal 
program to dial into the server. I've never configured a Linksys router 
and so if it requires a web-brower then "mgetty" may not work unless 
the router configuration setup works with a text-based browser.

Tony

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Thu May  9 07:30:09 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Thu, 09 May 2002 07:30:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Kill My Modem Connection 'Politely' 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Thu, 09 May 2002 06:06:31 PDT."
             <20020509125443.7FBD834367@ados.com> 
Message-ID: <200205091430.g49EU9P19651@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

guy1656 at ados.com said:
> Rather than leave now and have the modem idly connected for hours, is
> there a  chron thingie I can type in that says "(Nicely) disconnect me
> from my ISP 55  mintues from now?" 

bash$ at now + 55 minutes
at> ifdown my_net_interface
at> <Ctrl-D>

Look at the man page for 'at'.  There's quite a bit of flexibility there.
Also, I believe the current pppd has the ability to automatically bring
the line up and down based on traffic.

galen





From revans at e-z.net  Thu May  9 07:46:19 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: 09 May 2002 07:46:19 PDT
Subject: [PLUG] Kill My Modem Connection 'Politely'
In-Reply-To: <20020509125443.7FBD834367@ados.com>
References: <20020509125443.7FBD834367@ados.com>
Message-ID: <20020509144505.OSHO25765.rwcrmhc54.attbi.com@downtown>

You didn't mention how you are setting up your connection or what email client
you are using. If you are using a graphical connection client you need to look
at how it is calling up the connection. If it is calling up a script, then
there is probably a script it calls to disconnect. Calling the disconnect
script after some time period via cron would be a not so good way to do it. If
you are using a non-graphical setup then it should be easy to find the
corresponding down script.

Having your email client controlling the connection would be the better way to
do this. You are after all interested in getting all your email, not what can
get there in 10 minutes. Your email client may have on demand checking where it
can start the connection and stop the connection based on it's own needs. This
implies the email client and you dialer have some interconnection.

Using on demand dialing would be the most eloquent way to solve the problem. On
demand, either via pppd, wdiald, or diald would setup or connection when there
are packets to be sent and would time out after a set time limit of inactivity.
this too would insure you get all you mail.


Thank you
Russell

From sledgehammer2010 at yahoo.com  Thu May  9 08:01:30 2002
From: sledgehammer2010 at yahoo.com (Dhruva B. Reddy)
Date: Thu, 9 May 2002 08:01:30 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] GNU question
In-Reply-To: <20020509144808.OVQY25765.rwcrmhc54.attbi.com@downtown>
Message-ID: <20020509150130.8216.qmail@web12904.mail.yahoo.com>

I disagree.  The license (whether GPL or otherwise)
applies only to the code that you write.  Even though
you used the work of others to write and test it.  The
original poster's scenario is really no different from
running emacs (GPL'd software) on Windoze (a
proprietary platform).

Look at JBoss, or any of the Apache Java
projects--they all run on a proprietary runtime
environment (the Java Development Kit (JDK) or Java
Runtime Environment (JRE)).

The only time a problem would arise is if M$ decides
to modify their EULA to specifically prohibit the use
of their tools for creating software that is licensed
in a certain way (they have already started doing
similar things).  If they do decide to do this, simply
use a tool that was released before M$ took the GPL
seriously.  Also, this raises some interesting legal
questions (such as, "Can a vendor tell you how you
what you can and can't do with your work, just because
you used their tools?")

Dhruva

If you only need a command-line interface, the other way to do this 
would be to have a modem setup so you can dial-in and get a "login" 
prompt using "mgetty" on the server. You can use a simple terminal 
program that supports a VT100 or other simple text-based terminal 
program to dial into the server. I've never configured a Linksys router 
and so if it requires a web-brower then "mgetty" may not work unless 
the router configuration setup works with a text-based browser.

Tony
