From mikedela at ipns.com  Fri May 10 21:52:10 2002
From: mikedela at ipns.com (mike delamater)
Date: Fri, 10 May 2002 21:52:10 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Hardware problem
In-Reply-To: <3CDC7462.C192D0E5@attbi.com>
References: <3CDC7462.C192D0E5@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <61484.63.230.184.132.1021092730.squirrel@mailman.ipns.com>

The issue at hand is bonding. Grounding and bonding are closely related, 
but different. Grounding is more about power, bonding keeps everything at 
the same potential, eliminating static discharges. Static discharges can be 
fatal for hardware at levels you can't even feel.

I'd run a wire from the computer case to any metal surfaces handy, then to 
a touch strip, like a metal edge on anything that's in your entry path to 
the area. Sprays work, but they wear off. It only takes one good zap to do 
hardware in. You might look for an ESD chair mat. I'll have to look for a 
picture I have of the plastic blown "clean off" the substrate of a 14 pin 
chip from static.

Mike

> One of my machines is set up under a leather topped, metal table. The
> monitor is on a laminate over particle board table with metal legs set
> at 90 deg to the metal table. The mouse pad is on the metal table. (See

> I walk into the room and touch the table, or even sit down on the
> Steelcase chair that is on a plastic mat over the carpet. Some of those
> times, my computer does a hard reset. Would grounding the tables and
> the computer case help, be a good idea, or a bad idea?

From pnelson at riverdale.k12.or.us  Fri May 10 22:23:35 2002
From: pnelson at riverdale.k12.or.us (Paul Nelson)
Date: 10 May 2002 22:23:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Plug For Education Meeting - Saturday 5/18
Message-ID: <1021094615.28453.30.camel@homepc>

Hello Folks,

It seems like a long time ago now that the first Plug for Education
meetings happened. I think we've done a lot since then. Plug members
have been an active part of the monthly GNU/Linux Install Clinics and
have played an active role on the K12Linux listservs answering questions
and helping to promote free software in schools.

If you've been following recent Slashdot posts for the last month or so
you'll know that PNW schools are being audited by Microsoft and that
many are now very interested in using open source software. Now more
than ever we have a chance to help schools provide reliable technologies
for classrooms at a reasonable cost.

I'd like to float an idea out to the list and suggest that we discuss it
on-line and meet for a session or two as well.

Here's the idea: July 4th - Software Freedom Day - All over the USA

I'd like to see us help LUGs in cities all over the country establish
supportive relationships with schools like the one our schools enjoy.
I'd like to celebrate the collaboration with an open house type of event
on the morning of July 4th. The basic idea is to get LUGs to plan an
event with the help of interested school/s to demonstrate the successes
of using GPL software in schools.

Outcomes would be improved relationships between LUGs and schools where
they don't exist right now, good PR for both groups and an increased
support base both locally and on-line for schools migrating towards open
source software.

The event would be for a couple of hours on the morning of July 4th and
be over in time for people to still enjoy other traditional activities.

Frankly, I think PLUG has its act together more than most LUGs and we'd
be good ones to pull this off. We'd need to do up the PR and provide
"event kits" that other LUGs and schools could download and use. I think
we can do it. What do you think?

Let's toss out some limited discussion on the list and then I'd suggest
meeting for a brown bag lunch at the next Linux Clinic which is next
weekend on the 18th. I am sensitive to the list traffic this might
generate so feel free to email me directly or bring your ideas to the
12:00 meeting on Sat. May 18.
Clinic Info: www.riverdale.k12.or.us/~danh
Directions: www.riverdale.k12.or.us/direct.html

;-) Paul

Subject: [PLUG] Dialup Server on network with Linksys DSL/Cablemodem router
In-Reply-To: <001701c1f880$16cf47f0$6801a8c0@endeavor>
References: <001701c1f880$16cf47f0$6801a8c0@endeavor>
Message-ID: <200205110041.48068.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I don't have experience with the Linksys router (I wish I did) and so 
whether or not you can access the internet through the router would 
depend on how it does NAT? If you can set it up so that it does NAT for 
your entire private subset e.g. 192.168.1.x then that would allow the 
PPP connected client to access the internet through the router as well.

Tony

>
> I think the original poster was planning on setting up a dialup PPP
> server which sits inside the private network. When a client dials in,
> it is assigned a valid, private, IP address through PPP and is then
> part of the internal 192.168.x.x network. Once the client has an IP
> address that is part of the private network it can access the router
> at 192.168.1.1.
>
> There are no routing issues with private IP addresses and a second
> public IP address isn't needed since the client system will be
> routing packets directly to the PPP dialup server.
>
> Tony
>
> On Thursday 09 May 2002 18:22 pm, Robert McIntosh wrote:
> > I've considered attempting this with my Linksys BEFSR41 Cable/DSL
> > Router as well.  I haven't spent the time to do it, for a few
> > reasons - I have one dynamic IP address that AT&T's cable internet
> > service seems to think needs to be changed every week, because
> > "assigning static IP addresses has become increasingly cumbersome."
> >
> > Here are a few problems to consider while attempting this.
> >
> > 1)	En route, other routers will NOT pass private-use IP addresses
> > (i.e, 192.168.x.y).  They will immediately be dropped, unless you
> > drag
> >
> > a LONG cable along with you connected directly to your router.
> > You really need a minimum of two static public IP addresses to do
> > this with standard ppp - one for the client and one for the host.
> > PPTP might be something to look into, but I'm unsure if the Linksys
> > router supports this, nor have I had the time to muddle through
> > PPTP. I'm sure Cisco's support it ($$).
> >
> > > My questions, before I begin are: will this allow me to interface
> > > with the router, and other on the LAN?
> >
> > You need to be explicit with packet forwarding in the Linksys
> > router to meet your particular network., otherwise you'll just be
> > interfacing
> >
> > with the router.
> >
> > > It's imperative that the dialup server allows me to do this by
> > > connecting to the router internally on 192.168.1.1.
> >
> > You won't be able to do this.  You will only be able to refresh the
> > DHCP client (your router) locally, not remotely.  It sounds like
> > you've got cable-modem access that delivers your router a dynamic
> > IP address periodically.  This is not desirable for a ppp host.
> >
> > > I guess my main question is:  Since there is only one modem/phone
> > > line, should I configure it to just hand out a static IP?
> >
> > Absolutely!  It'd be a waste of memory to run DHCP for a single
> > client.

From linux at maneuveringspeed.com  Sat May 11 08:29:13 2002
From: linux at maneuveringspeed.com (Greg Long)
Date: Sat, 11 May 2002 08:29:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Dialup Server on network with Linksys DSL/Cablemodem router / options.ttySx file
In-Reply-To: <200205110041.48068.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <001f01c1f900$9b01fec0$6801a8c0@endeavor>

I think you're describing the basic function of these routers.  I think
about ALL they do is NAT.  We have one IP adddress, and all the boxes
connected to the router have their own 192.168.1.xxx address.  I can
route up to 10 specific incoming ports to different boxes. There is also
a DMZ host option which will send all incoming ports (unless otherwise
routed) to a single box.

So....I think this will work.  I *THINK* I set everythig up OK last
night, grabbed the cel phone, gave myself a jingle, and the USR hardware
PCI modem on ttys4 picked up and started squealing. Most of my local
friends are OIT college students, and are pretty busy on Friday nights,
so I could not recruit anyone who had a modem (most are on a LAN
connection) to test it for me.  8am on  saturday is still too early to
wake anyone up.    I'll head out in awhile to a friend's with my laptop
and try it then.

---------
One thing I am unclear on is the options.ttyS4 file (S4 in my case).
Section 1.8 of the walkthrough I mentioned in my original message
suggests:

	To set a specific IP for a client and server for each tty,
update the /etc/ppp/options.ttyname file for each tty: 


   		 serverIP:clientIP

I set mine up to be:

192.168.1.102:192.168.1.140

Note that I assigned the .140 for the dialup client.

Does this sound OK?

Greg

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat May 11 09:25:00 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 11 May 2002 09:25:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] How did they do this?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205110917110.22150-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I've developed the habit of scanning the tail of /var/log/messages every
day. Occasionally I see a message from sshd that someone attempted to crack
the network that way, but was rejected.

  This morning, however, I see this:

May 11 08:25:20 salmo PAM_pwdb[15537]: check pass; user unknown
May 11 08:25:21 salmo login[15537]: FAILED LOGIN 1 FROM (null) FOR 202.166.28.209, 
User not known to the underlying authentication module

  A quick check with whois.apnic.net reveals that this IP address is
assigned to:

inetnum:     202.166.0.0 - 202.166.31.255
netname:     MAGIX
descr:       Magix Broadband Network
descr:       Singapore Telecommunications LTD
country:     SG

which I find interesting because I received two UCE spams relayed through
them yesterday. I reported both spams to abuse at magix.com.sg. Now this.

  I have two questions. First, how did the cracker attempt to login? Telnet?
It's not the usual sshd rejection method. Second, is there a method,
analagous to the MTA's access.db, that permits me to block certain IP
addresses or IP address blocks from trying to gain access. In four years of
operation, this is the first instance of such an entry in the log.

  If anyone has suggestions to strengthen security here, please share them
with me.

Thanks,

Rich




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat May 11 09:37:08 2002

[rshepard at salmo ~]$  ls -l /var/log/maillog*
-rw-------   1 root     root     36131045 May 11 09:30 /var/log/maillog

-rw-------   1 root     root       786760 Feb 10 03:51 /var/log/maillog.2
-rw-------   1 root     root       844844 Feb  3 04:03 /var/log/maillog.3
-rw-------   1 root     root       783096 Jan 27 03:30 /var/log/maillog.4

  Logging is turned on in /etc/syslog.conf:

# Log all the mail messages in one place.
mail.*                                                  /var/log/maillog

but I cannot remember where I check to see if log rotation is turned on for

I would like to get the turnover schedule back on track.

Rich




From m at netpro.to  Sat May 11 10:04:30 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 11 May 2002 10:04:30 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mail log not rolling over
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205110933130.22150-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0205110959580.3620-100000@lukem.com>

Log rotation for maillog is probably being handled by logrotate (man
logrotate).  Your /etc/logrotate.conf and /etc/logrotate.d/ should have
more info for you.  /etc/logrotate.d/syslog should contain an entry for
rotating your maillog.  Is crond still running on your system?
/etc/cron.daily should contain a script that calls logrotate.
~M

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sat May 11 10:02:56 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat, 11 May 2002 10:02:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How did they do this?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205110917110.22150-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205110917110.22150-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200205111002.56262.aschlemm@attbi.com>

So it looks like you have the login service running. It listens on port 
515 and is accessed through the "rlogin" command from a remote client. 
I use is internally on my private network but I have it blocked on the 
external interface of my network with firewall rules. 

If you're not sure what services you have running externally, have a 
friend or someone that you trust that also runs Linux or BSD, etc ran 
an "nmap" scan against your external system. Sounds like you use SSH 
and that you don't have any need to have the "login" service running. 

If you have tcpd wrapper then the /etc/hosts.allow and /etc/hosts.deny 
files can be used. When I used these files I would deny all hosts and 
then put the hosts I wanted to allow in the /etc/hosts.allow file. 

You can also use the "netstat" command to see what ports have a state of 
"LISTEN" on them. As root, run the command "netstat -avpen". You'll see 
the port numbers as well as what program is doing the listening.

Tony

From sendai at thedustyshelf.com  Sat May 11 11:28:53 2002
From: sendai at thedustyshelf.com (sendai)
Date: Sat, 11 May 2002 11:28:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] BOTS & Hidden Directories
In-Reply-To: <3CDD5768.9070607@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <PKENLAFCOOIOHAPHJGFIKEAJCBAA.sendai@thedustyshelf.com>

Well from your subject line I assume you are asking if a bot would know that
the page existed.  The answer is that no spider would, but if someone was
running a bot that picked a page and then tried every possible sequence then
yeah it would.  What are the chances of someone doing this?  How paranoid
are you?

As for general security, this is going to decrease your overall security and
should technically be served by a DMZ box, but as long as permissions are
set correctly and proper security measures taken there should be no problem.

What I used to do if I wanted a web location to access my files from is use
a 64-bit key for the url.  That would keep a bot busy enough that you would
see plenty of log before they ever got in.

Yes, the accesses will be unique to the visitor.  To make them come from
pacifier you would have to get them to set up forwarding.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sat May 11 12:28:56 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat, 11 May 2002 12:28:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How did they do this?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205111158430.11370-100000@critter.deatech.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205111158430.11370-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <200205111228.56313.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Yes they are defined in the /etc/inetd.conf file. You can disable 
services by commenting out those lines for services you don't want. 
Likewise you can uncomment lines for those services you want to enable. 
You can then force "inetd" to reread its configuration file by sending 
it a SIGHUP signal.

Tony

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sat May 11 12:54:48 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat, 11 May 2002 12:54:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mail log not rolling over
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205111102570.22275-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205111102570.22275-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200205111254.48418.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Well here's the entry I have for my maillog. 

/var/log/maillog {
    compress
    dateext
    maxage 365
    rotate 99
    size=+1024k
    notifempty
    missingok
    copytruncate
}

Create a new file called "maillog" in your /etc/logrotate.d directory or 
add it to an existing file in that directory. I'm assuming that your 
/etc/logrotate.conf has an include directive like so:

include /etc/logrotate.d

This causes logrotate to read all of the files in the /etc/logrotate.d 
directory. The man page for "logrotate" defines all the configuration 
values if you're unsure about any of the options.

Tony

From m at netpro.to  Sat May 11 14:52:19 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 11 May 2002 14:52:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mail log not rolling over
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205111102570.22275-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0205111444170.10670-100000@lukem.com>

Is there an entry for maillog in /etc/logrotate.d/syslog ?
If not, here's what's in mine:

/var/log/maillog {
	postrotate
		/bin/kill -HUP `cat /var/run/syslogd.pid 2> /dev/null` 2> /dev/null || true
	endscript
}

This would then use the default rotate options defined in
/etc/logrotate.conf, such as:

weekly
rotate 5
errors root
create
compress

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat May 11 15:46:51 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat, 11 May 2002 15:46:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] BOTS & Hidden Directories
In-Reply-To: <3CDD5768.9070607@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205111542450.21366-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 11 May 2002, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> I'd like to supplement the file storage provided by my isp.  The idea
> is to allow incoming port 80 requests to one of my own firewalled
> servers by clicking a link on a hidden page on my isp web space.

Uh... you mean you're going to put a link on a page for which you've built
no references that goes to your home webserver?

> Is this at all secure?  I don't see how anyone could possibly learn of
> a webpage that is not referenced anywhere on the `public` site, but
> what do I know.

Well, security through obscurity is no security at all.

There's nothing from stopping anyone at all from creating a link to your
"hidden" page or even directly to your webserver.

And you'd be amazed at what spiders can find.

The RIGHT way to do this really depends on your true goal and intent.

> Will incoming requests look like they are coming from pacifier.com (so
> I can allow only that host), or will they be unique to the visitor?

No, the request is still coming from the browser.  But you can configure
apache to deny serving pages based on HTTP_REFERER, which would be the
pacifier webserver if the browser followed that link to reach your page.

Of course, that can be spoofed easily.  It's just plaintext http.

Again, hiding something doesn't improve its security really.

What are you trying to do?

J.

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat May 11 16:00:43 2002

On Thu, 9 May 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:
> It costs money. Linux nerds are cheap, and would rather endlessly
> tweak a hunk of funky free software than pay for something that works.

I need to say that I'm deeply offended by this characterization -- not
because it depicts us (I'm self-identifying with the dubious term "Linux
nerds" here) as frugal (or falsely frugal, as the example of driving all
over to save a dollar shows), but because it implies, to me, that the
appeal of Free Software is its (entirely incidental) free-as-in-beer
quality and ignores the fact that Kylix may have failed for its lack of a
free-as-in-freedom quality.

The fact that Free Software is available at no cost is due entirely to
relatively low-cost storage media and high-bandwidth peer-to-peer network
connectivity.  Remember, the FSF supported itself for years selling tapes
of GNU Emacs for over a hundred dollars each.

Free Software exists because of the human drive to share with his fellow
man and improve the general condition of all people.  Proprietary software
exists to exploit relative advantage and create inequity (as much as
possible, as I understand the theory).

Perhaps, Carla, just perhaps, some people have concerns other than their
pocketbooks.

J.

From dealy at deatech.com  Sat May 11 20:04:36 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Sat, 11 May 2002 20:04:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Kylix?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205111547220.21366-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 11 May 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

>
> On Thu, 9 May 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:
> > It costs money. Linux nerds are cheap, and would rather endlessly
> > tweak a hunk of funky free software than pay for something that works.
>
> I need to say that I'm deeply offended by this characterization -- not
> because it depicts us (I'm self-identifying with the dubious term "Linux
> nerds" here) as frugal (or falsely frugal, as the example of driving all
> over to save a dollar shows), but because it implies, to me, that the
> appeal of Free Software is its (entirely incidental) free-as-in-beer
> quality and ignores the fact that Kylix may have failed for its lack of a
> free-as-in-freedom quality.

As a long time Linux user, and one who has paid literally tens of
thousands of dollars for software over the years, I have to say that the
reason that I and many other Linux user's I know generally avoid buying
commerical software products these days is not that it isn't "free", but
rather that so much of it is junk as to not be worth the time to even try
it out.  Sure, there are times when using free software that I have had to
tweak it endlessly, but that is also often the case for commercial
software that I have bought as well, so what's the point of buying
commercial, particularly when it takes a lot less time to "tweak" the
software when you have the source code.  To address the Borland/Inprise
example (they changed their name for a while to Inprise and recently
changed it back), I was a long time user of their products from about 1986
through 1998, and while it was initially great software, towards the end
of this time I was using their C++ compiler and it eventually reached the
point where each minor bugfix update introduced more bugs than it fixed,
and I would have to spend endless time in newsgroups trying to figure out
what the problem was (support was virtually non-existant even when you
paid for it), determine if I could work around it or have to downgrade
the compiler and live with the bugs in the older version, etc.  At least
with free software you have a real support option (do it yourself), and it
would have taken me less time to find and fix the compiler bugs than I
wasted dealing with their proprietary junk.  I have never looked at Kylix,
it might be great, but my last couple years experience with Borland were
so bad that I can't see wasting my time dealing with them again.  The
same kind of experiences and reasoning applies to Microsoft and many
other companies, and none of this even covers the problem that many
commercial software vendors will abandon a product line with little or no
notice, leaving you without any prospects for future upgrades/bug fixes,
and ultimately forcing you to switch to a new vendor, learn their
product's peculiarities and the proper way to "tweak" their software.
Ultimately, no matter how much time I spend "tweaking" Linux, it has been
my experience that in most cases I will have to spend more time "tweaking"
the commercial stuff over the long haul.

</end_rant_mode> :-)

FWIW.

> forcing you to switch to a new vendor, learn their product's peculiarities
> and the proper way to "tweak" their software.

  The most bothersome example of this is WordPerfect for linux/UNIX. It's a
darned shame, but the product is functionally dead.

  These messages tweak little memories from a long time ago. I think that

From bsr at spek.org  Sun May 12 00:35:30 2002
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: 12 May 2002 00:35:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] QNX
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.2.20020511170729.00acd950@mail.attbi.com>
References: <5.1.0.14.2.20020511170729.00acd950@mail.attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1021188930.1516.946.camel@obelisk.spek.org>

On Sat, 2002-05-11 at 17:08, Brent Washburne wrote:
> Has anyone used QNX before?  Any comments, good or bad?
> 	~Brent

I used QNX for a summer in 1996, writing a report generation program for
NOAA.  It ran on a QNX box and querried their homebuilt weather data
aquisition program.  As I recall we used the Watcom C compiler (are they
still around?), all of the standard "unix-y" libraries were available,
as well as a bunch of QNX specific C libraries to access all the
realtime and threading stuff QNX is capable of.

Although we never used it, one of the coolest things about the box was
that it could transparently bond IO devices into a single virtual device
- stick 5 network cards each in two QNX boxes that "trust" each other
and QNX will use all 5 to move data between the two.  Also from what I
remember it had easy to use clustering capability with transparent
memory sharing accross machines.

I was rather impressed with its very low memory usage, a highly
functional system could fit within a couple hundred Kb of ram - and if
you needed it to fit into less, because of it's very modular kernal you
were able to throw out parts of the system at will - say if you didn't
need the "fat" and feature-rich process scheduler that QNX ships with
and just need a wee one that you've writen.

Another nice thing was the access you got to people in the QNX company -
at a time when that was rare (well, it still I suppose).  The engineers
within QNX were active on public mailing lists and newsgroups about the
OS, freely giving advice and honest opinions about their products - so
very refeshing.

It seemed stable too, although nothing we did really stressed out the
box any - though I do remember grinning at their magazine ads that had
headlines like "This is Bill.  He hasn't rebooted since 1993."

Since it's some 6 years later now, I'm not sure how much of that
information is still correct.  It's niche is definitely real-time
control and data aquisition, although I could imagine one could make a
nice professional audio application or two for it.

--Brent

Well, I meant it as a loving but true jest. It is indisputable that a large part 
of Linux's appeal is that it, and other open source /free apps, can be 
legally obtained for no or very little cost. It is rather naive to believe 
otherwise. 

It is also naive to believe that Open Source/Free automatically = Good, and 
that commercial/proprietary = Evil. That's just plain silly. There's stars 
and stinkers in both worlds.

I've read the GPL, which is a work of genius, and nowhere does it say 
software should not cost money, or that programmers should not be paid for 
their efforts. 

Carla

Actually, when one says "Free" with the capital 'F', they usually are
talking about the same kind of *freedom* that the Free Software
Foundation stands for - which says that the code must be Open *AND* must
be freely redistributable to users.  This is much better than just Open
is because Microsoft can release "Open source" code which has so many
restrictions that it is useless (see: "Shared Source").

From greg at kroah.com  Sun May 12 14:08:37 2002
From: greg at kroah.com (Greg KH)
Date: Sun, 12 May 2002 14:08:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Kylix?
In-Reply-To: <1021233556.1202.12.camel@laptop>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205121142470.4323-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> <1021231649.1207.7.camel@laptop> <1021232425.25608.498.camel@sharky> <1021233556.1202.12.camel@laptop>
Message-ID: <20020512210837.GC6922@kroah.com>

To get back to the original poster's question about Kylix:

I've downloaded it and tried it out, both the 1.0 and 2.0 releases.
Here's my impressions:

	- the product is aimed at developers who currently use Delphi
	  (which is an excellent product in itself) on Windows, not
	  existing Linux programmers.
	- it looks and feels just like Delphi (this can be a good or bad
	  thing, depending on how much you liked Delphi's user interface
	  :)
	- it allows you to write code that compiles natively for both
	  Windows and Linux.  This is a very good thing for companies
	  that have a lot of internally created Delphi code (quite
	  common, as Delphi is very good at creating Database front
	  ends).
	- The database bindings look very nice, but I never wrote those
	  kinds of programs, so I can't tell you how well the Linux
	  interface to them work.
	- I dug up some old Delphi programs that I had written, and they
	  built just fine, once I removed the Windows specific portions
	  of the code.
	- The latest release is a lot better than the 1.0 release.  If
	  you originally looked at that one, spend the time to download
	  the 2.0 version.

In short, I'm not giving up gtk+ for writing Linux applications, but
Kylix isn't aimed at people like me.  And I do like the "GPL only"
free version, it shows that Borland understands Linux's roots.

Now when C++ Builder is released for Linux, that might be a different
story, I _love_ that compiler for Windows work...

thanks,

greg k-h

From klugger at maneuveringspeed.com  Sun May 12 21:47:21 2002
From: klugger at maneuveringspeed.com (Greg Long)
Date: Sun, 12 May 2002 21:47:21 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mirroring and backup - recommendations?
Message-ID: <001801c1fa39$44c42670$6801a8c0@endeavor>

After a recent scare with having to run e2fsck manually on our server
after a unclean unmount, I started thinking more seriously about
mirroring and automatic scheduled backups, and other such redundancy.

Our server runs a fairly stock Redhat 7.2 on a 1ghz AMD Duron 256mb
system with a 60gb IDE HD available. At my disposal is a Intel Pentium
233 system with 128mb RAM and a 10gb UDE HD.  the 10gb drive should be
plenty to essentially mirror the main system, with the exception of a
sizable chunk of  files that have been made available for FTP transfer
that would not have to be mirrored as they are easily replaceable.

I realize that not ALL files should be mirrored as the hardware is
different (although both can run i386 Redhat)

SO....my basic question is, what utilites are available and recommended
for this sort of mirroring?

Although I do not have a tape backup, it would be nice to periodically
take a snapshot of the system (except for the sizable file transfer
library) and split that into 700mb chunks for manually burning to CD

Thanks,

Greg Long

From tedm at toybox.placo.com  Mon May 13 01:53:01 2002
From: tedm at toybox.placo.com (Ted Mittelstaedt)
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 01:53:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RE: Mirroring and backup - recommendations?
In-Reply-To: <001801c1fa39$44c42670$6801a8c0@endeavor>
Message-ID: <000301c1fa5b$964d49a0$1401a8c0@tedm.placo.com>

:-)

I think your question is "how do I do cheap backups" ;-)

Frankly I think you should at least think about tape.  You can get
used 4mm DAT drives that are 12MB uncompressed for about $250 used.
Unlike hard drives tapes don't crash.  Also the most valuable part
of backup (I've found) is when someone needs a file that was backed
up months ago.

I realize 4mm tape drives aren't 100% reliable but if your regularly
backing up then the occasional messed up tape won't matter.

But if you can't afford tape then what I'd recommend is instead of
trying to create a backup server and guessing what you need, I'd take
that P233 and a sheet of paper and attempt to build a server on the
233 that duplicates exactly the 1Ghz AMD system.  As you are building
this server, everytime you find yourself referring back to the
original server for some piece of information, write it down on the
paper.  Once the new server is exactly identical to the old one then
you will have a list on the paper of what you need to backup.  Then
if you want to do it real time you can set up a script with scp
statements in it.  (ie: rcp except encrypted)


Ted Mittelstaedt                                       tedm at toybox.placo.com

prevents that kind of clearly anti-social behavior.

From longman at sharplabs.com  Mon May 13 10:25:54 2002
From: longman at sharplabs.com (Longman, Bill)
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 10:25:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hardware problem
Message-ID: <B14FD9A4BE25D31188A400508B2CBB6FC24F31@mailsrvnt04.enet.sharplabs.com>

More ASCII art:


  +---+
  |   |
  |   |
  |   |
  |   |
  |   | +--------+
  |   +-|--------+
  |     |        |
  +-----|--------+
        |
        |
  +-----+-----+
  0     0     0         <-- Chair frame or wheels: Ground to mat
----------------------  <-- Plastic mat: You need to ground this

Dick,

You have a huge capacitor under your feet, that's the problem. Those mats
are great to stop the wear on the carpet but it loves to keep the charge
from grounding. I had the same trouble so I solved it easily by grounding
the mat with one of those stick-on disposable wrist straps. I stuck the
strap to the mat and the other end to my desk (also a Steelcase). My desk is
already grounded but you may be able to just screw a wire from the frame to
the outlet coverplate screw (assuming it's mettalic).

The other thing I did was spray the mat with anti static spray. My chair has
a little piece of chain hanging from the central post that slides on the
floor to discharge the static. Once I step on the pad, I usually feel the
juice disappear. I used to charge myself up just by getting out of the chair
but no longer.

HTH.

--
WEL



From guy1656 at ados.com  Mon May 13 10:29:40 2002
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 10:29:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] A Good Linux Book for Novices
Message-ID: <20020513171711.EBE15352D3@ados.com>

I'd like to recommend the following book for newbies & novices (like me.)
(I have no business interest in the sale of this book, btw.)

Title "Linux! I didn't know you could do that..."
Author: Nicholas D. Wells
Publ: Sybex
ISBN 0-7821-2935-8
Price: $21.95 (Fry's)

The organization of this book overcomes a great gulf many if us novices have 
in learning to use Linux 'around the house:'

1) We can formulate an intent in English, like: "How do I play mp3's in 
Linux?" 
2) The answer is out there in the form of 3 to 5 commands or a simple slick 
install.

The problem is that it might take you 5 days or internet searching and FAQ 
reading, tweaking, etc, to find what WOULD have and SHOULD have been a couple 
of minutes' job.

Pounding through O'Reilly books is like using a dictionary to learn how to 
spell a word - you'll discover some neat words along the way that weren't 
part of your search, and a lot of useful and accurate information, but you 
still have to know how to spell the word in order to find out how to spell it.

OTOH, this book organizes its chapters around 38 basic intents, and provides 
steps proceeding from "OK is your system ready for this?" to basic tools, 
saving the most complex applications for last. (For the above, the steps 
proceed from setting up a soundcard using sndconfig, then using kscd, gtcd, 
and xmms, and a few suggestions like OpenSoundSystem. Then it's on to 
accessing CDDB, and more advanced programs like xrdb and Xwave) So, you get 
in at whereever your level of understanding is, and you can get out at the 
level where -you- decide you've learned enough for now.

Lastly, the book attempts to make each chapter as stand-alone as possible, 
for example by -NOT- assuming you already know how 'tar' works, and NOT 
sticking it in only ONE chapter (this would force a nested search: How do I 
install this? You have to unpack it. How do I unpack it? Go figure where THAT 
chapter is, then come back here and continue solving THIS problem.) 

Instead the book presents (for example)

# tar xvzf [program].tgz
# cd [directory made by program]
# make install
# [program name]

in MANY places, so you can stay focused on your current intent.
The book comes with a CD including rpm's of just about everything it talks 
about, so if you're stuck and the book says you need a diagnostic tool, you 
won't lose an hour or more looking all over for it.

For those of us who come from Windows expect to run something by clicking on 
it and watching it 'go,' this is a BIG help.

GLL

From alex at daniloff.com  Mon May 13 11:28:22 2002

OK,
Lets define, what is a job posting, job search and just a simple free
advertisement on Linux/UNIX consulting.

Job posting is a message about Linux/UNIX open positions in your
company or business.I haven't seen a lot of these messages for the
last five years.

Job search is when you're desperately searching for a Linux/UNIX job
because you have to pay the bills and feed your family. 
It's understandable, and tolerable but PLUG list is not an employment
agency in any way.

Free advertisement on Linux/UNIX consulting is when you already have
you business and in eager to increase your profit, you're publishing
your adds with all these stupid marketing words for free. 
Why PLUG should be turned into free adds agency? You can publish such
things in Computer Bits and other magazines for a monthly fee.
If you want to get more money and attention, you'll have to pay for
your adds. 
 
Alex

From rsteff at attbi.com  Mon May 13 12:04:27 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 12:04:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hardware problem - Summary
References: <B14FD9A4BE25D31188A400508B2CBB6FC24F31@mailsrvnt04.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <3CE00E3B.BD6E74C8@attbi.com>

One of the great things about this list is getting several replies with
different information. The combination of all those ideas often leads to
a better solution than using just one of them. I usually try to reply to
replies fairly quickly, but for some reason, couldn't bring myself to do
it this weekend. Then, this morning, I find one more idea that, combined
with the rest of the information, gives me what I hope will be a good
solution.

I'll be finding a way to bond the legs of the two tables and the chair
mat to each other (at one point) and then connect that bond point to the
house ground by way of the screw on one of the outlets. I'll also try
the anti-static spray ideas, but I think that providing a path for the
charge to follow from the floor mat to the house ground will be the most
productive.

Thanks to all for your ideas.

Russell Senior wrote:

> I think you want to ground yourself.

Brent Rieck wrote:

>   I'm no expert on static, but I've always found that grounding myself
> rather than the equipment is more effective
<snip>
> Spraying a little "anti-static spray" that I found
> in the storeroom on the soles of my shoes one day practicly turned them
> into grounded ESD mats.

Kyle Accardi (Who's rewiring his house) wrote:

> When the computer resets, is it only because you touched the mouse or the
> desk?  Does your keyboard have a metal chassis?  (Old IBM's do).

Actually, it's hard to say. It usually happens before I touch any part
of the computer. Sometimes it's touching the table. Sometimes it's
touching the chair. Sometimes it's just stepping onto the mat. 

> Make sure your outlet is properly grounded.  A plug-in tester is available
> in any hardware store.  (3-prong plug with 3 neon lamps inside).

I just ran the wire for this circuit, and I used one of those 3-led
testers before plugging anything else in. In my house there is one
15-amp circuit serving the entire top floor, which includes the master
bedroom and bath, and my office. When we had the walls open for the
plumbing project a couple of months ago, I ran a piece of #12 ROMEX from
the basement to the attic. I finally got around to hooking it up at each
end. Now I have an additional six outlets in my office on a 20-amp
circuit, and have plugged all the computer equipment in my office into
them.

Rich Shepard wrote:
 
>   Back in the early- to mid-1980s a lot of keyboards and systems were fried
> by static electricity. During that period I bought a grounding mat that sits
> under the keyboard, and I always touched that before touching any part of a
> computer. Now that mat is in front of the monitor, but the keyboard is on a
> pull-out support in front of the desk. I still touch either that mat or the
> metal file cabinet next to the desk whenever I return to the desk and before
> I touch the keyboard, trackball or anything else. After 20 years it's just
> reflex.
> 
>   To directly answer your question: yes. Ground everything. And make it a
> practice to touch a grounded metal table leg when you sit down. Also, buy
> some Downy fabric softener, dilute it 1:4 or 1:5 with water, then spray it
> on the carpet. Prevents static buildup. We used to do this in the office
> until the early 1990s.

>   Steelcase chairs are worth every dollar! I have one from 1985 and another
> that I bought in 1995. I can sit in them for 12 or more hours a day without
> pain or tiredness. They're great!

When I was Facility Manager at Prime Computer and later at Apollo
Computer, I was in charge of buying furniture for engineers. Steelcase
was the manufacturer of choice for most of the office furniture. That's
when I discovered these chairs. There's a used office equipment store
down on Macadam near Memory Time. I found my current chair there. I
agree, they are the most comfortable chair I have had the pleasure of
sitting in for long periods at a desk.

briand at aracnet.com wrote:

> The other thing which helps is higher humidity.
> 
> Good for the air passages too.

We have on occasion run a humidifier. The last couple of years, it
hasn't been dry enough in the house to call for it. We keep the
temperature down around 65; if we were running up near 70, that would
dry things out and we would have to use the humidifier.

mike delamater wrote:

> The issue at hand is bonding. Grounding and bonding are closely related,
> but different. Grounding is more about power, bonding keeps everything at
> the same potential, eliminating static discharges. Static discharges can be
> fatal for hardware at levels you can't even feel.
>
> I'd run a wire from the computer case to any metal surfaces handy, then to
> a touch strip, like a metal edge on anything that's in your entry path to
> the area.

This makes a lot of sense. I've understood grounding for a few years,
but hadn't thought about the difference between it and bonding.

"Longman, Bill" wrote:

> You have a huge capacitor under your feet, that's the problem. Those mats
> are great to stop the wear on the carpet but it loves to keep the charge
> from grounding. I had the same trouble so I solved it easily by grounding
> the mat with one of those stick-on disposable wrist straps. I stuck the
> strap to the mat and the other end to my desk (also a Steelcase). My desk is
> already grounded but you may be able to just screw a wire from the frame to
> the outlet coverplate screw (assuming it's mettalic).

If I were to crimp an eye-shaped lug to some wire and bolt that to the
mat, do you think that would work? I recall seeing mats with a ground
wire bolted to them. Otherwise, who carries the disposable wrist straps?

> The other thing I did was spray the mat with anti static spray. 

Spraying the mat instead of my shoes sounds good. That way I don't have
to spray several different pairs of shoes!

> My chair has
> a little piece of chain hanging from the central post that slides on the
> floor to discharge the static.

Good idea. That shouldn't be hard to do at all.

From ejahn at worksystems.org  Mon May 13 13:05:50 2002
From: ejahn at worksystems.org (Eric Jahn)
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 13:05:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] A Good Linux Book for Novices
Message-ID: <319FB8934F09BF48A3F3228370882667385F1E@wsimail.worksystems.org>

Thanks, I wish I had this book 6 months ago.  Even so, I'll check it
out.

-----Original Message-----
From: guy1656 [mailto:guy1656 at ados.com] 
Sent: Monday, May 13, 2002 10:30 AM
To: PLUG
Subject: [PLUG] A Good Linux Book for Novices

I'd like to recommend the following book for newbies & novices (like
me.)
(I have no business interest in the sale of this book, btw.)

Title "Linux! I didn't know you could do that..."
Author: Nicholas D. Wells
Publ: Sybex
ISBN 0-7821-2935-8
Price: $21.95 (Fry's)

The organization of this book overcomes a great gulf many if us novices
have 
in learning to use Linux 'around the house:'

1) We can formulate an intent in English, like: "How do I play mp3's in 
Linux?" 
2) The answer is out there in the form of 3 to 5 commands or a simple
slick 
install.

The problem is that it might take you 5 days or internet searching and
FAQ 
reading, tweaking, etc, to find what WOULD have and SHOULD have been a
couple 
of minutes' job.

Pounding through O'Reilly books is like using a dictionary to learn how
to 
spell a word - you'll discover some neat words along the way that
weren't 
part of your search, and a lot of useful and accurate information, but
you 
still have to know how to spell the word in order to find out how to
spell it.

OTOH, this book organizes its chapters around 38 basic intents, and
provides 
steps proceeding from "OK is your system ready for this?" to basic
tools, 
saving the most complex applications for last. (For the above, the steps

proceed from setting up a soundcard using sndconfig, then using kscd,
gtcd, 
and xmms, and a few suggestions like OpenSoundSystem. Then it's on to 
accessing CDDB, and more advanced programs like xrdb and Xwave) So, you
get 
in at whereever your level of understanding is, and you can get out at
the 
level where -you- decide you've learned enough for now.

Lastly, the book attempts to make each chapter as stand-alone as
possible, 
for example by -NOT- assuming you already know how 'tar' works, and NOT 
sticking it in only ONE chapter (this would force a nested search: How
do I 
install this? You have to unpack it. How do I unpack it? Go figure where
THAT 
chapter is, then come back here and continue solving THIS problem.) 

Instead the book presents (for example)

# tar xvzf [program].tgz
# cd [directory made by program]
# make install
# [program name]

in MANY places, so you can stay focused on your current intent.
The book comes with a CD including rpm's of just about everything it
talks 
about, so if you're stuck and the book says you need a diagnostic tool,
you 
won't lose an hour or more looking all over for it.

For those of us who come from Windows expect to run something by
clicking on 
it and watching it 'go,' this is a BIG help.

GLL

http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Mon May 13 13:32:10 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 13:32:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hardware problem - Summary 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Mon, 13 May 2002 12:04:27 PDT."
             <3CE00E3B.BD6E74C8@attbi.com> 
Message-ID: <200205132032.g4DKWAP30296@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

rsteff at attbi.com said:
> I'll be finding a way to bond the legs of the two tables and the chair
> mat to each other (at one point) and then connect that bond point to
> the house ground by way of the screw on one of the outlets. I'll also
> try the anti-static spray ideas, but I think that providing a path for
> the charge to follow from the floor mat to the house ground will be
> the most productive. 

If at all possible, you should put a high value resistor between the 
house ground and your mat/table/chair.  A 100 kiloohm to 1 megaohm 1/4 Watt
resistor would be appropriate.  This is to prevent your body from becoming
a low resistance path to ground should you happen to accidentally contact
the AC mains.  You should be able to find a suitable resistor at Radio
Shack or Norvac.

galen

I believe that there are multiple virii (?) that do this. I think that nimda is one of the ones that does this.  I'm not sure of all of the different ones that use this method however.  Try going to www.mcaffee.com and take a look at their virus database.

1. Systems affected:

        an off-by-one error in the channel code.

        OpenSSH 3.1 and later are not affected.

2. Impact:

        This bug can be exploited locally by an authenticated user
        logging into a vulnerable OpenSSH server or by a malicious
        SSH server attacking a vulnerable OpenSSH client.

From longman at sharplabs.com  Mon May 13 14:18:38 2002
From: longman at sharplabs.com (Longman, Bill)

>   Some of you have family members using Windows, others work in an
> OS-diverse workplace. I'd be grateful for some information 
> that I can pass
> on to these users when they write to me for help.

Most who use Outlook (aka Lookout!) can change the format of the current
message with Format -> Plain Text. They can set this as their default under
Tools -> Options -> Mail Format and changing the first field (Send in this
message format:) to "Plain Text".

It's been fun!

By the end of this month, I'll be firmly established on a farm 30
miles north of Bremerton; with my internet connection at the end of a
very long dialup - meaning that a 26k connection is likely to be the
best I can do for the short term.

As a result, I don't wanna have to deal with the bottle neck that this
wonderful forum provides with it's 50 messages a day. So until I can
evolve into a permanent full time connection thru said dialup, I'm
gonna have to disconnect from this list for awhile. I'm on a number of
other lists, which don't have the traffic this one does, so I'll stay
on them until they get too noisy. If you've got an event, post it on
the announce list, and maybe I can come down for a visit.

I plan to attend the ALT this week, but the next morning I'm taking
the first load north, and after that, I'll miss our interactions.

It would be really cool if there was a way I could post questions to
this list, but only get answers to my questions - rather than all the
rest of the traffic. That would be a really great interim solution.
Anybody got any ideas on how that might be accomplished?

In the meantime, have a great summer! I'll keep in touch....

-bk

From linux at maneuveringspeed.com  Mon May 13 16:14:16 2002
From: linux at maneuveringspeed.com (Greg Long)
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 16:14:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Running a linux mail list with Windows subscribers
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0205131512240.16140-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <002701c1fad3$e6d22620$6801a8c0@endeavor>

Most nix mail clients support HTML mail OK, but I guess you have diverse
group.

Outlook can be configured to send plain text by default, though I
beleive Matt is correct - Exchange Server can override this.

My biggest annoyance is that HTML mail sent through our KLUG mailman
list sends HTML just fine, but it ARCHIVES in plain text - so even
though there is a web interface to view the archives - the tags are
still displayed.

I think this starts to fall under the "can't we all just get along"
category. :)

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org

Unfortunately, many sites enable HTML-mail on their Exchange server, so
even if the user composes in plain text, it's still sent out as HTML. ~M


On Mon, 13 May 2002, Longman, Bill wrote:

>
> >   Some of you have family members using Windows, others work in an 
> > OS-diverse workplace. I'd be grateful for some information that I 
> > can pass on to these users when they write to me for help.
>
> Most who use Outlook (aka Lookout!) can change the format of the 
> current message with Format -> Plain Text. They can set this as their 
> default under Tools -> Options -> Mail Format and changing the first 
> field (Send in this message format:) to "Plain Text".
>

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon May 13 17:14:26 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 13 May 2002 17:14:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Pine and SSH
In-Reply-To: <1021334495.10692.167.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

	<86pu08svxb.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<1021334495.10692.167.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <868z6nshzx.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Zot" == Zot O'Connor <zot at whiteknighthackers.com> writes:

Russell> I am not exactly sure how this works, I've never (or so long
Russell> ago that I forgot) investigated, but if I have a Mozilla
Russell> running locally and I click on a URL in a ssh-piped emacs
Russell> running on a remote host, the URL gets forwarded to my local
Russell> host's Mozilla and it loads locally.  Works a lot faster than
Russell> loading and fowarding the display of a remote Mozilla.  I
Russell> know it isn't specific to Mozilla because it worked on
Russell> Netscape and maybe even Mosaic before that.

Zot> I have seen this too.

Zot> The trick seems to be "mozilla running before" This may be a
Zot> gnome, or kde thing (I run gnome).  It sure is nice!

Not Gnome or KDE, as I run neither.  I think it has something to do
with the "Common Client Interface".  See:

  <http://archive.ncsa.uiuc.edu/SDG/Software/XMosaic/CCI/cci-spec.html>

And yes, it is necessary that the local browser be running first or
the browser gets launched at the remote end instead.

Here is your culprit.
  openssh-askpass-gnome-3.1p1-1
If you can prevent the rpm from trying to build that, your X and gnome

how often you are rebuilding things.

From smathews at pcez.com  Mon May 13 19:20:51 2002
From: smathews at pcez.com (Stuart Mathews)
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 19:20:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux hurt Windows 2000?
Message-ID: <3CE07483.1319D415@pcez.com>

I heard recently that Linux is "widely believed to have hurt
significantly the roll-out and adoption of Windows 2000 Server by
companies."   Has anyone else heard anything like that?  Just
curious.




From m at netpro.to  Mon May 13 19:40:04 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 19:40:04 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux hurt Windows 2000?
In-Reply-To: <3CE07483.1319D415@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0205131932510.23158-100000@lukem.com>

On Mon, 13 May 2002, Stuart Mathews wrote:

> I heard recently that Linux is "widely believed to have hurt
> significantly the roll-out and adoption of Windows 2000 Server by
> companies."   Has anyone else heard anything like that?  Just
> curious.

Maybe to a small extent...  Problems with Win2K rollouts that I heard of
were mostly because of administrator's unfamiliarity with Active Directory
and no compelling business reason to upgrade.  Also, most companies don't
like to upgrade their Windows servers because it's usually fairly
disruptive to any installed software.  With Linux we can upgrade whichever
specific part we feel the need to upgrade, so system upgrades aren't quite
as daunting to us.
~M

Subject: [PLUG] Inconsistent MD5SUM results on ISO files
Message-ID: <20020513214256.A4892@mentorg.com>

Hi,

After repeated errors installing RedHat 7.3 on another box using some
freshly-burned ISOs, I decided to check if my originals had the right MD5SUMs.
With three ISOs to check, I tried

% md5sum valhalla-i386-disc*

The value returned for disc1 was correct, but not for disks 2 and 3.  For some
reason I tried it again, and this time I got three incorrect sums.  Repeated
attempts on a single ISO show ever-changing values:

% md5sum valhalla-i386-disc1.iso
59ea7973386287fe95152b0dff1f37e7  valhalla-i386-disc1.iso
% md5sum valhalla-i386-disc1.iso
60e1d3f990eed0d3fe2622c917ec1a82  valhalla-i386-disc1.iso
% md5sum valhalla-i386-disc1.iso
cd1cad8642579dc58ff63288fe5c404f  valhalla-i386-disc1.iso
% md5sum valhalla-i386-disc1.iso
2f59a52896c10b9f39a5588b8bebc387  valhalla-i386-disc1.iso

I am running RedHat 7.1 with my own 2.4.18 kernel.  The FS is ext2 and the disk
is an IBM 45 GB Deskstar 75GXP.  I see no (other) indications the disk is
having any problems.

Any thoughts what might be going wrong?

Thanks,

Marc

Really frustrating.  There are a couple of possibilities, what other
hardware are you using? It *COULD* be the harddrive, but it might also
be motherboard, processor or RAM.  I ended up replacing all of those
trying to track down the problem, and the only conclusion I managed to
come to was that it wasn't the RAM.  The harddrive was failing (same
model as yours), but I think that was unrelated coincident failing,
seeing as I replaced it and things kept not working.  I had been using
an AMD Athlon proc. with a Via chipset motherboard, both of which got
replaced at the same time, and almost immediately afterwards I heard
about the issues with the Athlons (can't remember exactly what they were
right now) and I had previously heard reports of problems with the Via
chipsets, so I'm convinced my problems were in one of those areas.

Hopefully I'm just jumping to conclusions and it turns out to be
something simple though...


--Shahms

From tedm at toybox.placo.com  Mon May 13 23:28:54 2002
From: tedm at toybox.placo.com (Ted Mittelstaedt)
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 23:28:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RE: FW: Response to Microsoft Putting the Squeeze on NW Schools - Are they squeezing?
In-Reply-To: <002901c1fad5$aa969d60$6801a8c0@endeavor>

>-----Original Message-----

>A long, long time ago, in the Alpha Quadrant Ted Mittelstaedt projected:
>
>> Microsoft will then cut a deal for probably about 20-50 thousand
>dollars for the whole shit-a-ree, with the stipulations that 1) the
>district will agree to a gag order on the pricing and 2) the district
>will not promote Linux in any way, shape or form.
>
>---
>
>'fore long it's likely KLUG will be going more "public" and trying to at
>least welcome the high school kids here in the area.  Is anyone aware of
>any evidence anywhere that MS is putting such a stupulation squelching
>Linux on the table to any schools?  I can only imagine that any sort of
>contract MS enters in with PUBLIC schools must be made public.
>

You don't know much about Microsoft's power of suppression of news
articles, do you? :-)

For example, read the following:

http://www.pcworldmalta.com/specials/MSPiracy/

The facts in this are true.  Now, tell me why it is that the US PC news never
ran this story.

Microsoft has also routinely put in illegal/unsupportable things into it's
contracts.  see:

http://www.advogato.org/article/453.html

and

http://www.gnu.org/press/2002-04-11-ms-patent.html

and

http://news.com.com/2100-1001-868413.html

Note in that last one that the dollar prices were gagged - and this is
court evidence!!

Anyway, to get more serious about the disclosure thing, read the following
and I hope it's not too arcane.  I've seen some really gnarly contracts.

In theory, any contract that a government agency like the school
district signs sould be available for any requestor.  But contracts
are documents that are interpreted.  It's perfectly possible for
Microsoft to write a contract that contains language that a Linux advocate
could interpret to mean that Linux is permitted, but a Microsoft
advocate could interpret to mean Linux wasn't permitted.  Then if
Microsoft's reps "explain" their interpretation to the school administrator
in a meeting, it's unlikely that such a meeting is going to be
recorded for your inspection.  Your left depending on the school
admin having some balls to reinterpret the contract favorable to
Linux and then just sign it anyway and go against was he was verbally
told.

And, of course, Microsoft could always insert a "donation" clause, in
short something to the effect that if the school runs more than 90%
Windows OS that they are elegible for "extra" money or software licenses -
for example they could say:

"in consideration for the difficulty encountered certifying an exact
number of computer systems running Microsoft OS at any given time,
Microsoft will permit a variance of 20% off the total OS count, if
the organization counts more than 80% of it's computers as running
Microsoft Windows"

In short, what they are saying there is that if the school has 2,000
PC's and claims that over 1600 of them are running Windows then
Microsoft will allow them to run an actual number of up to 1920 computers
with Windows even though they are only declaring and paying for 1600.
But if the school says that only 1599 computers are running Windows,
then they can only run an actual number of 1599.

Another trick is stepping settings - in short they
arrainge the discount curve so that the school declares, say 1-1000
Windows systems, that the per-unit cost is $100 and if they declare 1001-1800
Windows systems then the unit cost starts dropping on a curve until
at 1800 installs it hits $55.  In short:

1-1000   unit cost $100
1001-1100  unit cost $90
1101-1200  unit cost $83
.
.
1701-1800  unit cost $55

(obviously in actual practice the above is expressed in a formula,
this is the same trick the US Government does with deductions in
the tax laws, BTW)

Now get out your calculator and guess what - for any system counts
between 1000 and 1800, surprise, you pay THE SAME THING: ie: roughly around
$100,000! :-) The price doesen't start rising until after 1800 and if you
combine it with the slop trick, why then your really not forced to pay more
than that $100,000 until you get to 2160

As a result, if your a district with 2000 PC systems all running Windows, then
if you start switching over to Linux, you save NOTHING until you get
at least 1000 systems converted

Clauses like the above are not illegal and not obviously anti-Linux.
But they effectively serve to pressure network administrators to
deemphasize use of Linux - unless they are willing to go whole-hog
and switch the whole bloody site to Linux.  And this is my premise all
along - that no government school district has the balls to actually
switch over because to do it means sweeping out EVERYTHING that's
attached to Microsoft - trying to pussyfoot won't work.

You can say what you want about "controlled introduction" but that's
a cop-out.  Microsoft is going to set things up so that the schools
won't see a dime of savings until they are really honestly willing to
kiss 80% of their existing Windows installs goodbye.

Ted

From derek at infotects.com  Tue May 14 10:18:16 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 14 May 2002 10:18:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hardware problem
In-Reply-To: <3CDC7462.C192D0E5@attbi.com>
References: <3CDC7462.C192D0E5@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1021396697.17058.119.camel@dereklinux>

On Fri, 2002-05-10 at 18:31, Richard Steffens wrote:
> One of my machines is set up under a leather topped, metal table. The
> monitor is on a laminate over particle board table with metal legs set
> at 90 deg to the metal table. The mouse pad is on the metal table. (See
> ASCII art(?), below.) From time to time, I'll feel a static shock when I
> walk into the room and touch the table, or even sit down on the
> Steelcase chair that is on a plastic mat over the carpet. Some of those
> times, my computer does a hard reset. Would grounding the tables and the
> computer case help, be a good idea, or a bad idea? 

This sounds like your outlet might not be grounded very well.  Your
computer case is a very good Faraday shield (especially with the covers
on), and any static that hits the case should be dissipated to the earth
long before the electric potential of the ground plane on your
motherboard raises high enough to cause a reset.

However, your ground wire could be capacitively coupled to the earth. 
This coupling will still allow the small AC current required to light up
a tester, but static is not AC, and the coupling may be able to allow
the potential of the case to get high enough to cause the reset. 

HTH

Derek Loree

Please note that I use the word potential (short for electric potential)
where most people would use the word voltage (volts is the unit for
electric potential).  The terms voltage and amperage are not very good
terms for describing the concepts of electric potential and electric
current
> 
> 
>      -----------|-----|
>      |     Mon ||     |
>      -----------|     |
>             C   |Mse  |
>                 |     |
>                 |-----|
> 
> Mon = Monitor
> C   = Chair
> Mse = Mouse
>

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Tue May 14 12:15:28 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Tue, 14 May 2002 15:15:28 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Perl question
In-Reply-To: <1021402138.23817.11.camel@red>
References: <1021402138.23817.11.camel@red>
Message-ID: <E177hSN-00011y-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

#!/usr/bin/perl -w
undef $/;
open(IN,"< /etc/passwd") || die $!;
$var = <IN>;
close(IN);
print $var;

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Tue May 14 11:54:43 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Tue, 14 May 2002 11:54:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Perl question
In-Reply-To: <1021402138.23817.11.camel@red>; from ed@alcpress.com on Tue, May 14, 2002 at 11:48:58AM -0700
References: <1021402138.23817.11.camel@red>
Message-ID: <20020514115443.A13482@dalsemi.com>

On Tue, May 14, 2002 at 11:48:58AM -0700, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> What's the simplest way of reading the entire contents of a
> text file, including the new line characters, into a string
> variable?


#!/usr/bin/perl -w

##Enforce good programming rules
use strict;

#Create filehandle to file you want to read
open FILE, "somefile.txt" or
  die "Couldn't open file and this is why: $!\n";

# Setting the record separator, $/, to undef makes it read the entire file
undef $/;
# File IO
my $var = <FILE>;
# For closure
close FILE;

Colin

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue May 14 12:01:23 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 14 May 2002 12:01:23 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Perl question
In-Reply-To: <1021402138.23817.11.camel@red>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205141158480.22999-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 14 May 2002, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> What's the simplest way of reading the entire contents of a
> text file, including the new line characters, into a string
> variable?

# put this op in a block so we don't have to save the old
# value of $/ and then reset it later...
{
  local $/ = undef
  open( FH, "< /path/to/file" ) or die $!;
  $str = <FH>;
  close( FH ) or die $!;
}


--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From griffint at aracnet.com  Tue May 14 13:27:06 2002
From: griffint at aracnet.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Tue, 14 May 2002 13:27:06 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Recommended way to clear kmalloc'd memory?
In-Reply-To: <no.id> from "Galen Seitz" at May 14, 2002 11:11:01 AM
Message-ID: <200205142027.g4EKR6T19765@shell1.aracnet.com>

> 
> 
> Is there a kernel equivalent to calloc?  Alternatively, what is the preferred
> way to clear after kmalloc?  memset?
> 

get_zeroed_page() will allocate a page of memory and clear it out. It must
be deallocated with free_page(). Otherwise yes, you can use memset().

Terry

Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>

having.

a week after it came out. Everything seemed to go fine
except i was having this strange printer issue. The
only user that was able to print was me. Which was
very odd considering the printer is shared
peer-to-peer from a windows machine. So I did some
snooping using ethereal and figured out that the
machine accounts were not working correctly, the pdc
was returning 'user unknown errors' when machines were
logging in. Yet I was still able to log on to the
domain, I'm assuming thats because of a windows bug I
found referenced in the samba mailing list archives.
Apparently the windows box will still log on users who
have previously logged on to the domain, but no new
ones. So anyway, I'm not sure what to do about this
now. I tried re-adding my machine accounts to no
avail. Anyone got any ideas where to go next?

Thanks much for your time,

Ken

From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: 14 May 2002 15:09:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux (sorta) Advanced Topic Talk Wed May 15th Smalltalk is Alive
 and Well
Message-ID: <1021414180.10419.279.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

There will be an advanced topic talk tomorrow (Wed) on Squeak Smalltalk.

For those of you who think you know Object Oriented Programming, but
have never used SmallTalk, this a a good intro.

For those who wonder what the biggest deal is about OOP, this is also a
good intro.

For those who know more than Ken, and want to challenge him, you have to
wait 15 minutes....

The talk will be all demo -- no slides!

Squeak is a Smalltalk development system which is free and runs on most 
computers.  Ken Dickey will give a live demo of the Squeak system,
starting at the 20,000 foot view (cool eToys) then getting into how
Smalltalk development works and down into the 1 foot level (like what
happens when you drop into the debugger).

Ken spend 5 years at Tektronix, 7 years at Apple, and more recently was

From dealy at deatech.com  Tue May 14 15:38:28 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Tue, 14 May 2002 15:38:28 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] killing "D" state processes?
In-Reply-To: <86n0v2s8dm.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205141527340.19452-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On 14 May 2002, Russell Senior wrote:

>
> I've been having a little trouble with a backup process.  This morning
> an 'mt' hung on me in a "D N" state, which according to "man ps"
> decodes as Wing Attack Plan R, R for Robert ... Oops!  No, sorry.
> Those weren't today's codes.  It decodes as D = "uninterruptible sleep
> (usually IO)" and N = "low-priority task".  A "kill -9 <pid>" doesn't
> work.  The tape wasn't moving, I ejected the tape and reinserted it,
> but mt is still stuck.  Do I have to reboot the sucker?  Or is there
> some incantation like: "Peace on Earth" or "Purity of Essense" to fix
> it?

I used to get these years ago during tape backups (including the failure
of the kill -9), it turned out to be a kernel bug/race condition that
would happen on rare occasions, but as far as I can recall, it only
happened to me on pre 2.2 kernels.  The only possible cure for my problem
when I tracked down the cause was in fact a reboot, because (if I remember
correctly), the kernel code that was doing the I/O where it locked up was
coded incorrectly and did not allow for any kills in the loop where it
was waiting for an I/O event that would never come because of the race
condition.  What kernel version are you running?

A big thanks to Russel for this.  Ken is booked, announcement is out,
and two more speakers are tentatively lined up:

For June 19:
 I penciled Chris Wright <chris at wirex.com> doing Linux Security Modules
(LSM)

For July 17:

Phil Tomson has offered to talk about an open source, object oriented,
task distribution framework he calls TaskMaster.  TaskMaster allows
users to easily create their own runnable Task objects that can be
distributed to multiple machines on a network (which are running a slave
program).

Here's the funny thing, Phil's email end;s with "Would this make a good
topic?"

People if you have projects like this, AT is the place to bring them. 
You do not need polished refined projects.

AT Talks can

1)  Require knowledge before asking questions, thus allowing you to dive
in deeper on issues.

2)  Have unanswer(ed|able) questions because are still working on it.

3)  Be a "position" piece, like Jeme's belief that all systems should
compile their software and we should do away with distributions, or mine
that you need verifiable software in the field, or Wil's that you should
make your own, or anything Karl believes.....

4)  Be half a talk that you are prepping.  Sometimes the room can help
you along.

5)  Be a talk you want to see done, but can only do half.

Also a big thanks to Bruce for finding the Space, and Galen maintaining
it!

From derek at infotects.com  Tue May 14 16:14:10 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 14 May 2002 16:14:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hardware problem
In-Reply-To: <3CE15308.1FF527B3@attbi.com>
References: <3CDC7462.C192D0E5@attbi.com>
	<1021396697.17058.119.camel@dereklinux>  <3CE15308.1FF527B3@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1021418055.18186.189.camel@dereklinux>

On Tue, 2002-05-14 at 11:10, Richard Steffens wrote:
> Derek Loree wrote:
> 
> > This sounds like your outlet might not be grounded very well.  Your
> > computer case is a very good Faraday shield (especially with the covers
> > on), and any static that hits the case should be dissipated to the earth
> > long before the electric potential of the ground plane on your
> > motherboard raises high enough to cause a reset.
> 
> I've been assuming that the static is somehow travelling through the
> mouse, which is sitting on a mouse pad that is sitting on the leather
> topped metal table. Wouldn't that bypass the case?

I'm pretty sure that the plastic mouse body would keep static from
"traveling" anywhere, it is a terrible conductor.  Computers are
designed to be fairly immune to static, once they are assembled and
hooked up correctly.  Most of the wires going into the machine have a
conducting foil layer just under the insulation, effectively extending
the Faraday shield to include the device.  I also tend to think that the
chipset controlling the mouse would not like the static hit at all. 
Does your mouse still work?
>  
> > However, your ground wire could be capacitively coupled to the earth.
> > This coupling will still allow the small AC current required to light up
> > a tester, but static is not AC, and the coupling may be able to allow
> > the potential of the case to get high enough to cause the reset.
> 
> Interesting. Do you know of a way to test the ground that doesn't
> involve AC?

The best way to check it is with a load from the hot side to the ground
that is large enough to trip the breaker, but DON'T do this by just
sticking a hunk of wire between the hot leg and ground, that is very
dangerous and hard on other equipment in your house. A proper load box
can be made with a variable resistor (so you can bring on the load a
little slower than an instantaneous short), but finding one capable of
drawing 20 amps at 120 volts is really tough.  If physical inspection
doesn't convince you (a proper ground is made by driving a 12 foot
copper rod into the ground, water pipes should never be used as the
ground for a house -- water is a terrible conductor, the supply line
from the street is not deep enough and is probably made of plastic), you
could try making a test fixture with a 60 watt light bulb.
 
Derek

From dealy at deatech.com  Tue May 14 17:08:52 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Tue, 14 May 2002 17:08:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] killing "D" state processes?
In-Reply-To: <868z6ms4g7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205141658280.19536-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On 14 May 2002, Russell Senior wrote:

[snip]
> Shannon> What kernel version are you running?
>
> "uname" says 2.4.16.  Oddly, about 5 minutes after I sent the message,
> the process went away and I could at least "mt status" the drive.
> But, when I tried to rewind, it hung again.  I am getting messages in
> the logs that indicate some kind of failure (either communication or
> hardware, not sure yet).  They look like:
>
>    May 14 14:57:41 coulee kernel: scsi : aborting command due to timeout : pid 13945266, scsi0, channel 0, id 5, lun 0 Rezero Unit 00 00 00 00 00
>    May 14 14:57:41 coulee kernel: scsi0: Aborting CCB #7064897 to Target 5
>    May 14 14:57:41 coulee kernel: scsi0: CCB #7064897 to Target 5 Aborted
>    May 14 14:57:41 coulee kernel: st0: Error 26030000 (sugg. bt 0x20, driver bt 0x6, host bt 0x3).
>
> I am thinking a nice gentle reboot at this point might clear it up.

This sounds like a problem with your SCSI bus.  Some controllers and/or
tape drives are very picky about the signal quality, cabling, what else is
on the bus and even what they will talk to.  I have a DDS-3 tape drive
which will not run reliably if any other SCSI device is on the bus with
it, so I finally just bought a separate SCSI controller for it which got
rid of the problems.  My experience with SCSI has been always buy name
brand controllers (preferably adaptec), use high quality cables, and avoid
anything from Seagate or any of the companies they bought out.

If you built your SCSI drivers as modules and you don't have any critical
hard drives connected to the controller, you can simply unload and reload
the SCSI driver to clear up any driver/kernel related issues, though if
you have hardware bus problems this won't really help for the long haul.

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From pnelson at riverdale.k12.or.us  Tue May 14 17:31:57 2002
From: pnelson at riverdale.k12.or.us (Paul Nelson)
Date: 14 May 2002 17:31:57 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Clinic this Saturday
Message-ID: <1021422743.2417.46.camel@dasher.riverdale.k12.or.us>

Hello Folks,

I'm sending out our usual announcement for our monthly Linux Clinic. I'm
also posting to a wider audience in hopes of sharing a bit of how our
local user group has helped us.

Our school plays host to the clinic every month on the 3rd. Saturday. We
invite Linux experts from the PLUG (Portland Linux/Unix User Group) to
come and help with software installs and configurations for local
schools, teachers, kids and the public at large.
http://www.riverdale.k12.or.us/~danh

We meet from 1:00 to 4:00 and there are always plenty of folks who come.
Everyone helps everyone. We often have goodies to pass out and after a
new Linux release it's not uncommon to have several CD-Rom burners going
full speed all afternoon.

We have our own workstations that boot into Linux from our terminal
server for people to play with and folks bring in their own hardware to
configure.

Let me think about this for just a minute, do I want Linux experts to
come to my school every month to help me use free, stable software to
provide cool technologies for my students? They won't charge me anything
and they enjoy providing support for our schools through our local
listserv on a 24x7 basis...  Duh... It doesn't take much to realize how
well this works! It's fun for the experts too though!

For those of you in the Portland area, come and join us. If you've never
used Linux before or just want to see what the fuss is all about, you
are welcome here.

If you're a school and you want to take your first steps this would be a
good time to come by. This Saturday we have a special going... We'll
configure your hardware to be an Appleshare server and toss in a web
server for free! ;-^)

My hope is that other LUGs out there would start hosting clinics. If you
are from a school, contact your local user group and offer to host a
clinic!

Linux Journal has a great LUG locater at:
http://www.ssc.com:8080/glue/groups along with all kinds of other good
LUG stuff.

Red Hat hosts another site with lots of links too!
http://www.redhat.com/apps/community/LUG/

If you are hosting clinics with your LUGs please let us know or post
