From dealy at deatech.com  Tue May 14 17:46:39 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Tue, 14 May 2002 17:46:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Hardware problem
In-Reply-To: <1021418055.18186.189.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205141728500.19536-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On 14 May 2002, Derek Loree wrote:

[snip]
> > I've been assuming that the static is somehow travelling through the
> > mouse, which is sitting on a mouse pad that is sitting on the leather
> > topped metal table. Wouldn't that bypass the case?
>
> I'm pretty sure that the plastic mouse body would keep static from
> "traveling" anywhere, it is a terrible conductor.  Computers are
> designed to be fairly immune to static, once they are assembled and
> hooked up correctly.  Most of the wires going into the machine have a
> conducting foil layer just under the insulation, effectively extending
> the Faraday shield to include the device.  I also tend to think that the
[snip]

Don't count on this, mice, keyboards, etc. are being designed and built
very cheaply these days, cutting corners wherever possible (I have seen
keyboard and mouse combinations for under $4).  Over the years I have
encountered a number of cheap mice and keyboards that I would regularly
arc to whenever I went to use them (customer equipment, I don't buy this
kind of junk), and on many occasions computer reset ensued.  Usually the
arcing would go between the mouse buttons or keys on the keyboard.  Also,
if there is more than one connection of the shielded components to the
protective shield (which is pretty much always the case with computers),
an alternate pathway for the current has been established - through - the
computer, and while the bulk of the discharge will follow the shield, for
a high voltage discharge, you can easily get enough of a potential across
internal components to cause problems through the alternate path.  The
only real protection in most office environments is to bleed off the
charge before it has the chance to do anything.  Anti-static sprays on
floors/carpeting, humidifiers, grounded desks and chairs all help a great
deal, though what made the biggest difference for me was a different pair
of shoes.

   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From mark at planetwills.com  Tue May 14 21:46:34 2002
From: mark at planetwills.com (Mark Wills)
Date: Tue, 14 May 2002 21:46:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Page margins
In-Reply-To: <20020515021538.92225.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMEEDBCHAA.mark@planetwills.com>

pr can do lots of nice things to plain text files including margins
paginating, headers, page numbers and making columns etc.

pr
Print formatting filter. This will paginate files (or stdout) into sections
suitable for hard copy printing or viewing on screen. Various options permit
row and column manipulation, joining lines, setting margins, numbering
lines, adding page headers, and merging files, among other things. The pr
command combines much of the functionality of nl, paste, fold, column, and
expand.

pr -o 5 --width=65 fileZZZ | more gives a nice paginated listing to screen
of fileZZZ with margins set at 5 and 65.

A particularly useful option is -d, forcing double-spacing (same effect as
sed -G).

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue May 14 21:57:34 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 14 May 2002 21:57:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Page margins
In-Reply-To: <20020515023104.GA12972@austin.rr.com>
References: <20020515021538.92225.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>
	<20020515023104.GA12972@austin.rr.com>
Message-ID: <86lmamvwht.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "David" == David Bridges <dbridges at austin.rr.com> writes:

>>  $lpr textfile

David> YMMV, but I have found that something like this works great for
David> text files.

David> cat textfile | enscript | lpr

This sort of thing can drive an old unix CLI freak crazy.  The "cat"
in this instance is unnecessary.  Why not just:

   enscript < textfile | lpr

or better still, learn the "usage" of enscript ("enscript --help" or
"man enscript") and use that to your advantage:

   enscript textfile 

Because I don't like to waste paper, I always generate in intermediate
file and inspect it first with "gv".  But since I don't mind wasting
paper if it looks cool, I use fancy headers:

   enscript --fancy-header=emacs -o /tmp/test.ps textfile
   gv /tmp/test.ps
   lpr /tmp/test.ps

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue May 14 22:08:58 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue, 14 May 2002 22:08:58 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Page margins
In-Reply-To: <20020515021538.92225.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205142201480.18779-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 14 May 2002, Robert Kopp wrote:
> This may be an easy question. When I want unformatted output of a text
> file
> 
> $lpr textfile
> 
> the left margin is so narrow that about 2mm of the text is cut off to
> the left. By the way, the printing from my Linux box goes to a remote
> Samba printer. Is there an easy way to adjust this?

Depending on what kind printer you have and what print spooling package
you use, it's possible that lpr is calling an input filter and doing some
formatting for the printer before the printer sees the thing.  I'd
recommend tracking down this info in your printer package and determining
where the page definition information is stored.

Folks here often recommend enscript and it's really nice, but out of habit
I still often use a2ps for printing plain text.  The page layout info for
that package is contained in /etc/a2ps.cfg or /etc/a2ps-site.cfg.

By the way, can someone tell me how to make enscript print 4-up like this:

_______________________________________
|                  |                  |
|  text-y text     |  text text       |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
|-------------------------------------|
|                  |                  |
|  text-y text     |  text text       |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
|                  |                  |
---------------------------------------

with the old a2ps border style?

When I try 4-up with enscript I get four pages equally divided across a
landscaped page.  Ugh.

Thanks.
J.

When you are in X and suspend the machine all goes well.  When you
resume the mouse takes on a Mr. Hyde personality and does not do
anything sane.  It jumps all over the place and creates random button
presses.  Works flawlessly until you resume.

If you ctrl-alt-backspace X and then start again, everything is fine.

gpm is not even installed (can't believe how long gpm/X interaction
has remained broken in Debian) so I know that's not the problem.

I don't have a clue as to what's going on and a lot of searching on
google-groups didn't turn up anything useful - other than have apm
kill X and then restart it - which is not a solution.

Just to add insult to injury it's in that "it used to work category".

Help ?

Brian

From dealy at deatech.com  Tue May 14 23:03:42 2002

On Tue, 14 May 2002 briand at aracnet.com wrote:

>
> When you are in X and suspend the machine all goes well.  When you

> has remained broken in Debian) so I know that's not the problem.

> I don't have a clue as to what's going on and a lot of searching on
> google-groups didn't turn up anything useful - other than have apm
> kill X and then restart it - which is not a solution.

I don't have a "why" for you, but one possible work around.  I do alot of
things that screw up the mouse drivers in X, and I have found that
switching to a different virtual console using <ctl-alt-F1> and then back
again often clears up the problem without having to kill the X session.
As far as gpm and X under Debian, I haven't noticed any problems for a
couple years, though I don't really use the mouse on the console, gpm
just sits there idling.

Paul,

   This addresses something SEUL/edu has talked about for over a year
(although we haven't had the resources to do anything about it).  I hope
that through Schoolforge we can bring enough people and energy to bear to
develop this further.

   What I'm talking about is support materials for LUGs that want to do for
their local schools what PLUG is doing for the Portland schools.  Obviously,
they will have some preliminary work to do to get into their schools in the
first place; you had already done that bit.  But if we can develop useful
procedures for them to follow in contacting and communicating with the
school administrations and suggested ways in which they can help the schools
with their Linux installations, I think we can make Linux seem more like a
community-supported solution to a problem rather than a risky, eccentric
change to the standard operating procedure that it probably like to many
non-technical educators.

   Could you possibly collect, or ask someone else to collect, the materials
you use for your LUG/school interactions?  We may be able to use them as
templates for developing material useful to a wide range of circumstances.
Thanks!

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed May 15 07:39:48 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 07:39:48 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Permissions for /var/log/
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205141820020.23970-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205150727380.21996-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Tue, 14 May 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> I changed permissions on /var/log/ to 757. Now user 'majordom' can
> write to the logfile and the notice of error messages has gone. But,
> ... is this the correct way to handle writing a log file by an
> application that does not run suid or sgid 'root'?

There are a couple things you could do:

1. If you end up giving everyone permissions to write to /var/log 
   (realizing, of course, that "everyone" in your situation means only 
   you and your fiancee), then you might consider

   chmod 1777 /var/log

   The extra 1 on the beginning of the chmod string prevents "users 
   from removing or renaming a file in a directory unless they own the
   file or the directory; this is called the 'restriction deletion
   flag' for the directory." [From fileutils.info.]

   BTW. Having a world-writeable /var/log wouldn't be my first choice.

2. There may be a variable or run-time flag you can set that'll direct 
   majordomo to log into a different directory. If so, then you could 
   point it at, say, /var/log/majordomo and do something like

   mkdir /var/log/majordomo
   chown majordom /var/log/majordomo

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

after the other.

From richard.langis at sun.com  Wed May 15 10:14:01 2002

Rich Shepard wrote:

>
>   Perhaps I've not had enough caffine this morning, but I don't quite follow
> this. However, I think it might work to have the log written to /tmp rather
> than /var/log. Is there a flaw to doing this of which I am naive?


/tmp usually gets emptied upon reboot.  If you want consistent logs of your 
activities, the best place to put them would be /var/log - where all of the 
other log files go.

On Tue, 2002-05-14 at 18:16, Richard Steffens wrote:
> Derek Loree wrote:
> 
> > > Interesting. Do you know of a way to test the ground that doesn't
> > > involve AC?
> <snip of the rather hazardous sounding part>
> > If physical inspection
> > doesn't convince you (a proper ground is made by driving a 12 foot
> > copper rod into the ground, water pipes should never be used as the
> > ground for a house -- water is a terrible conductor, the supply line
> > from the street is not deep enough and is probably made of plastic), you
> > could try making a test fixture with a 60 watt light bulb.
> 
> I just wrote, and then deleted an overly long explanation of my house's
> ground system. Since this subject is already fairly OT, I decided it
> would be better if I just said that I'm confident that my ground is
> good.

I'm not so sure that the pursuit of stability is all that far OT.  

Maybe Shannon has a point about the lack of quality of parts these
days.  I have been working with computers for a few years, and have yet
to have a system reset because of a static hit, but the costumers
usually would bring in the systems without mice, keyboard and monitor. 
I personally think (given that your grounding is good) that you should
pursue this as a hardware problem (try changing the mouse or get an
anti-static pad for the mouse), not an environmental condition that
needs to be dealt with on a daily basis.

I hope that you will keep us updated on this issue.

Derek

Rich> However, I think it might work to have the log written to /tmp
Rich> rather than /var/log. Is there a flaw to doing this of which I

Yes.

Principally, that /tmp traditionally gets wiped on a reboot.  

As others have suggested, just create a subdirectory of /var/log that
is owned by whatever user owns the process that is creating it.

Matt,

-rw--w--w-   1 majordom daemon        276 May 14 21:28 majordomo.log

  My problem has been that /var/log/ itself is writable only by root. I
*think* that I need o+w on the directory so that majordomo can write to the
log file. Read and execute permissions weren't sufficient. That's why there
were no log entries and majordomo was returning an error message at the
bottom of each response it sent.

From m at netpro.to  Wed May 15 11:04:49 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 11:04:49 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Permissions for /var/log/
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205151029210.28708-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0205151100130.18611-100000@lukem.com>

chmod 755 /var/log
chown majordomo /var/log/majordomo.log
chmod 600 /var/log/majordomo.log

Majordomo will be able to write to the log, but since it doesn't have
write access to /var/log, it won't be able to delete it (which should be
fine).  You can use logrotate just like you did for your maillog to rotate
the majordomo.log.
~M

Sorry. Didn't mean that system stability wasn't a suitable topic for
this list, just that the details of my house wiring were going too far.

> Maybe Shannon has a point about the lack of quality of parts these
> days.  I have been working with computers for a few years, and have yet
> to have a system reset because of a static hit, but the costumers
> usually would bring in the systems without mice, keyboard and monitor.
> I personally think (given that your grounding is good) that you should
> pursue this as a hardware problem (try changing the mouse or get an
> anti-static pad for the mouse), not an environmental condition that
> needs to be dealt with on a daily basis.

Can't say for sure about the mouse. I got it with my laptop as part of
the equipment we got at school. It's a Mitsumi PS2 scroll mouse. It
doesn't have a wheel, but has a knob that acts like a wheel. The click
noise isn't too loud, either. The only thing I don't like about it is
that fuzz collects on the shafts of the slotted disks that turn inside
in response to the movement of the ball. Every so often I have to take
it apart and use tweezers or an Xacto knife to carefully extract the
fuzz. I also have a Logitech wheel mouse. I like everything about it
except the noise of the click, which is loud.

The machine itself is cheap. I got it a couple of years ago at Bi-Mart.
Carries the name, V-Box, and was distributed by Avatar Technology.
Unfortunately, as often happens with going the cheap route, support is
no longer available for this machine. Next time, I'll visit one of the
local shops that builds machines. I'll spend a little more, but there
will be someone to take the machine to if something needs work.

All that to say that the machine may have a lot of cut corner in the
construction department. However, it still works reasonably, other than
the occasional static reset.

Will do.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed May 15 12:20:22 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 12:20:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SuSE 8.0
In-Reply-To: <3CE212B2.A0D0BE9A@linuxlink.com>
References: <BADD847784EB7546A1B1CC69190990C60A686D51@daspost.timberline.com> <3CE212B2.A0D0BE9A@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <200205151220.22489.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I've upgraded several SuSE 7.2 systems to 8.0 a little over a week ago 
and the upgrades were pretty smooth. I had a couple of minor issues 
with printers not working and some weirdness in the KDE migration from 
KDE 2.x to 3.x. A bit of time spent configuring KDE3 fixed the KDE  
problems. 

To fix my printing problems I deleted and recreated the printers through 
YaST2. I guess SuSE 8.0 handles printing a bit differently than what 
7.2 did.

I do know that some SuSE users are quite upset about /etc/rc.config file 
not being used store the system configuration stuff anymore. Some users 
got used to editing the file directly. The new configuration scheme 
seems better with configuration settings stored off in an 
/etc/sysconfig directory structure. Should be easier to maintain rather 
than having a single, large configuration file like SuSE of old has.

Tony

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Wed May 15 14:03:03 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 15 May 2002 14:03:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] lost+found
In-Reply-To: <3CE2C670.EB57ABE0@attbi.com>
References: <3CE2C670.EB57ABE0@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1021496584.5830.15.camel@pookie>

Richard;

This directory is created anytime you create a new filesystem on a drive
with 'mkfs.' This was one of the commands your script executed to create
the new filesystem.

The ext2fs filesystem creates this directory automatically. Linux
(specifically fsck) uses this directory to place fragments of files that
it cannot correctly place back into the filesystem. A hard system crash
can cause this to happen. Sometimes (though not usually), the filesystem
"looses" the file's logical placement on the disk.

With e2fsck, it's generally up to the administrator to find out where
these go and repair the damage. The "Filesystems HOWTO" at
http://www.linuxdocs.org/HOWTOs/Filesystems-HOWTO.html for details.

At the practical level you can safely ignore this directory it's there
"just in case."

It's also a good thing to look for if you want to know if the directory
is a mount point. 


-Cooper

postscript output, and your redhat box is running ghostscript to convert

do this.  Perhaps someone else can jump in with some assistance.

the magic of rpm.

cd /usr/src/redhat/SPEC

vim/pico/emacs aspell.spec

find the line with \|/ From %configure

rpm -ba /usr/src/redhat/SPEC/aspell.spec

From dealy at deatech.com  Wed May 15 14:51:02 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 14:51:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] lost+found
In-Reply-To: <1021496584.5830.15.camel@pookie>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205151440180.21497-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On 15 May 2002, D. Cooper Stevenson wrote:

[snip]
> At the practical level you can safely ignore this directory it's there
> "just in case."
[snip]

Just clarifying, while you can ignore it, DO NOT DELETE IT.  If it should
be accidentally removed, don't create it by using mkdir, use mklost+found.
Basically this is a directory pre-initialized to be large enough to hold a
significant number of "lost" files.  If your system crashes and the file
system is full (not uncommon, since full file systems often caused system
crashes though I haven't seen this problem under Linux for many years),
then there would be no way for the fsck to save the lost files, since it
would need to create a directory to put them in on a file system which
doesn't have any room to create them.

NOTE: Not all file system types need or use a lost+found directory.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed May 15 14:01:59 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 14:01:59 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] lost+found
In-Reply-To: <3CE2C670.EB57ABE0@attbi.com>

On Wed, 15 May 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> Some many months ago I added a drive to my Linux machine. During the
> process a directory was created called lost+found. I assume it happened
> as part of some script that I was told to run. It is currently empty.
> Does it serve some purpose such that if I deleted it I would mess
> something up?

  Yes.

  Every filesystem has a lost+found/ directory. And, I suppose, we all asked
this question at some point. It needs to stay there and it doesn't take up
much room.

  If your system crashed, unidentified pieces of files would be put in this
directory. You then have the opportunity to rummage through the bits and see
if you can put them back into usable form.

  I hope you never see any contents in any of them!

Rich

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed May 15 14:58:10 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 14:58:10 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] RPMs and compiling with specific options
In-Reply-To: <1021496106.9481.62.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205151436350.1640-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On 15 May 2002, Jon Jacob wrote:

> Is there a standard way to use an rpm but send it the options I
> would want it to compile the binary with.
> 
> I like being able to query the rpm database to see what is installed
> and the ease of uninstalling which is why I like RPM, but I need to
> install something now that I want to compile using non-standard
> options.  (To be specific, it is aspell).  Is there a way to do
> that?

In general, the procedure would be

1. Grab the source rpm (e.g., aspell-0.33.7.1-9.src.rpm).

2. "Install" the source rpm: rpm -i blah.src.rpm. I put "install" in 
   quotes because installing a source rpm doesn't put any binaries in 
   your system. Instead, on a Red Hat system, it puts some files in 
   the /usr/src/redhat directory tree:

   /usr/src/redhat/SOURCES -- source files and any patches
   /usr/src/redhat/SPECS   -- the .spec file

   Unless you've run chown or chgrp against /usr/src/redhat, you'll 
   need to be root to do this. On my systems, I add myself to the 
   'wheel' group (gid 10) and then, as root, do

   chgrp -R wheel /usr/src/redhat/*
   chmod -R g+w   /usr/src/redhat/*

   That way, I can build RPMs as me. (You can also reach this goal by
   redefining %_topdir in a custom $HOME/.rpmmacros file.)

3. Edit the appropriate .spec file in /usr/src/redhat/SPECS. In your 
   case, it looks as if you'd want to focus on the stuff in the %build 
   section of the .spec file, which is where the ./configure step is
   typically executed.

   Also, you might want to increment or modify the "Release:" line 
   near the top of the .spec file. If it said "Release: 9", you might 
   consider editing it to read "Release: 9jj". That way, rpm will 
   think you're installing a later version of the package (and it'll 
   be easier to find your local mods since you can do something like 
   "rpm -qa | grep jj").

   I suggest that you edit the .spec file as little as possible to 
   accomplish your goals. The folks at Red Hat (and, presumably, SuSE 
   and the other rpm-based distros) do some pretty subtle things that 
   might break as an unintended consequence of your edits.

4. Rebuild the rpm:

   rpm -ba blah.spec                 # for i386 binary packages
   rpm -ba --target i686 blah.spec   # for i686 packagess
   rpm -ba --target athlon blah.spec # for athlon packages

   The binary packages will end up in the appropriate directory in the 
   /usr/src/redhat/RPMS tree. The new source package, including your 
   modified spec file, will end up in /usr/src/redhat/SRPMS.

5. Install the new rpm:

   rpm -Fvh /usr/src/redhat/RPMS/<arch>/blah-<version>.<arch>.rpm

Let us know if you have troubles...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed May 15 14:04:53 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 14:04:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] RPMs and compiling with specific options
In-Reply-To: <1021496106.9481.62.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205151402250.30801-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On 15 May 2002, Jon Jacob wrote:

> Is there a standard way to use an rpm but send it the options I would
> want it to compile the binary with.

  Yes.
 
> I like being able to query the rpm database to see what is installed and
> the ease of uninstalling which is why I like RPM, but I need to install
> something now that I want to compile using non-standard options.  (To be
> specific, it is aspell).  Is there a way to do that?

  Get the .src.rpm and install it ('rpm -ivh <package>.src.rpm'). cd to
/usr/src/redhat/SPECS/ and run 'rpm -ba --<options_here> <package>.spec'.
Rather than just rebuilding the package, the "build all" option works from
the spec file and will accept the same options as could be fed to
./configure.

HTH,

Rich

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed May 15 15:33:51 2002

Hi.

I'm about to take a kind of plunge.

In an effort to avoid actually practicing becoming a better programmer,
I'm going to attempt to build, configure, and leanr to use emacs under the
guise that it will make programming easier when and if I ever work harder
to actually improve my skills.  (I'm also kind of looking forward to using
a truly GPL mail reader that does everything I want it to do, but that's a
maybe right now.)

So, I'm just putting out feelers to find out if there is anything I need
to know before building emacs from source.  Is there some option that
needs to be compiled in to allow me to use particular modules, extensions,
or scripts?  Roughly how big is an emacs installation?  Should I create a
special /usr/local/emacs to hold all the emacs-specific stuff?  How many
of the add-ons need to be rebuilt when emacs is rebuilt?

My intent is to build GNU Emacs.  I am, of course, generally more
concerned with the social, legal, and political aspects of the software
than the technical merits, but I will consider particular comparisons and
contrasts to other Emacs streams to help inform my decision.

Anyway, this is an open call.  What can y'all tell me that'll help my
transition?

I've got a book (O'Reilly's Learning GNU Emacs -- the gnu book).  I don't
really have money for another.  I can look at the FSF's manual online, of
course.

But building the thing is another story.  So, if you've got something to
say, I'd like to hear it.

From bdhruva at gmx.net  Wed May 15 15:58:18 2002
From: bdhruva at gmx.net (Dhruva B. Reddy)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 16:58:18 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205151502130.1300-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205151502130.1300-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20020515225818.GC2386@dr.mobizinc.com>

I've never built emacs on Linux--only on HP-UX and Solaris.  It's just
too easy (on Debian) to type in "apt-get install emacs21".  It's pretty
straightforward, IIRC, but using your system's package manager is likely to
make it less painful.

Legal:  Gotta love the GPL!  For most purposes, you can just start using
emacs, so you don't have to worry about running afoul of the license.

Social:  I'm afraid I am unfamiliar with this term :-).  But seriously,
most people cannot tell that I use emacs (although this will change as I
subject more people to HTML files (written manually with emacs'
excellent HTML mode) and PDF (generated from my latex files)).

Political:  I have found that many developers prefer working with IDEs.
Unfortunately, these tools impose their own proprietary organizational
stuff which make it potentially messy (and sometimes impossible) to work
outside that tool.  I have not found a compelling argument against "Well,
(xxx IDE) has a built-in debugger".  Also, I have yet to meet a manager
who was impressed that I know emacs.

As for actually learning how to use emacs, I started out with a hard
copy of the FSF's manual, and now I go googling or ask my emacs-using
friends whenever I have a question.

Generally, I have been using emacs for 3.5 years (since 19.x), and have
grown to love it.  I use it for writing documents (when I can get away
with it) and writing code.  I don't wish to start a religious war, but I
would say that very few applications are as powerful and extensible as
this one.

Now if you will excuse me, I have some Tetris to play on emacs v21...

Dhruva

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed May 15 15:59:37 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 15 May 2002 15:59:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205151502130.1300-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> I'm about to take a kind of plunge.

[...]

Jeme> My intent is to build GNU Emacs.  I am, of course, generally
Jeme> more concerned with the social, legal, and political aspects of
Jeme> the software than the technical merits, but I will consider
Jeme> particular comparisons and contrasts to other Emacs streams to
Jeme> help inform my decision.

I use GNU Emacs.

Jeme> Anyway, this is an open call.  What can y'all tell me that'll
Jeme> help my transition?

It is trivial.  Build-wise, you needn't worry about a thing.
configure ; make ; make install.  I usually add
--prefix=/packages/emacs/emacs21 to configure, but that is local
seasoning.  You used to need to say --with-pop in order to use pop3 to
get mail into Gnus, but I think as of GNU Emacs 21, that configure
requirement went away.

Jeme> I've got a book (O'Reilly's Learning GNU Emacs -- the gnu book).
Jeme> I don't really have money for another.  

I've got that book too.  I haven't cracked it in about 8 years.

Jeme> I can look at the FSF's manual online, of course.

There is a tutorial built in to Emacs as well. "C-h t"

The other thing you'll want (at least until you've trained your
fingers) is the "GNU Emacs Reference Card".  It'll be located in
etc/refcard.ps

Jeme> But building the thing is another story.  So, if you've got
Jeme> something to say, I'd like to hear it.

On your box, building will go very quickly, so don't worry, just jump
in, the water is fine.  If you screw something up (very unlikely) just
rm -rf the "prefix" directory and try again.

What _can_ get hairy is your .emacs file, but it doesn't have to.
Just add things as you need them.  I've got sort of a useful
"gnus-select-persona" that I hacked myself that lets me easily switch
who I want to appear to be in Gnus.  

You'll eventually have to learn a little emacs lisp, but that's a
*GOOD* thing.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed May 15 16:08:13 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 16:08:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205151502130.1300-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205151604060.1640-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Wed, 15 May 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> So, I'm just putting out feelers to find out if there is anything I
> need to know before building emacs from source.

Jeme,

GNU emacs is one of the most well-behaved software packages on the 
face of the planet. It'll install itself and run from just about any 
directory structure you desire. Running "./configure --help" will list 
all the options. Here's what I used when I built 21.1 for the 
developers at my last job:

./configure \
  --prefix=/usr/local/emacs-21.1 \
  --with-x-toolkit=lucid \
  --with-xpm \
  --with-jpeg \
  --with-tiff \
  --with-gif \
  --with-png \
  --with-x

But there are lots of other options, too. In general, its build 
process is incredibly sane and well thought-out.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

On Wed, 15 May 2002, Dhruva B. Reddy wrote:
> I've never built emacs on Linux--only on HP-UX and Solaris.  It's just
> too easy (on Debian) to type in "apt-get install emacs21".  It's
> pretty straightforward, IIRC, but using your system's package manager
> is likely to make it less painful.

My system doesn't have a package manager.  I've never built one.

> Legal:  Gotta love the GPL!  For most purposes, you can just start
> using emacs, so you don't have to worry about running afoul of the
> license.

Well, there's no EULA at all.  The GPL is a distribution license.

However, Stallman is absolutely right in that the distribution license of
XEmacs is VERY difficult to enforce, since there are numerous copyright
holders and many undocumented authors.  Hence, a person can use XEmacs
code in violation of the GPL (i.e. through redistribution of modified code
or simple code theft in a distribution not bound by the GPL) and it would
be almost impossible to redress that particular violation.

If we are weak, we will be toppled.

> Social:  I'm afraid I am unfamiliar with this term :-).  But
> seriously, most people cannot tell that I use emacs (although this
> will change as I subject more people to HTML files (written manually
> with emacs' excellent HTML mode) and PDF (generated from my latex
> files)).

I can't tell if you're trying to be glib or flip or what.  By social, I,
of course, mean the social implications of the Free Software movement and
the spirit of cooperation and mutual aid that it fosters.

> Political:  I have found that many developers prefer working with
> IDEs. Unfortunately, these tools impose their own proprietary
> organizational stuff which make it potentially messy (and sometimes
> impossible) to work outside that tool.  I have not found a compelling
> argument against "Well, (xxx IDE) has a built-in debugger".  Also, I
> have yet to meet a manager who was impressed that I know emacs.

Well, again, I was refering to the politics of Free Software, but your
point is well-taken on its own merits.

> As for actually learning how to use emacs, I started out with a hard
> copy of the FSF's manual, and now I go googling or ask my emacs-using
> friends whenever I have a question.

Yeah, I'd like to buy that book, but I don't have any money right now.

> Generally, I have been using emacs for 3.5 years (since 19.x), and
> have grown to love it.  I use it for writing documents (when I can get
> away with it) and writing code.  I don't wish to start a religious
> war, but I would say that very few applications are as powerful and

Right.  I definitely understand the advantages and am sold on the idea of
at least giving it a shot.

I'm really looking for any information folks might have about building
Emacs from source and hearing any particular arguments against GNU Emacs
that might be compelling for their technical merit.

Thanks again.  Your note is helpful.

>
> So if a local writer asked you for some facts and success stories of how
> Linux is growing and who's using it... What would you say?
>
I think that it's a safe assumption that any company of sufficient size
(e.g., with a dedicated IS staff) will have at least one Linux box
somewhere in the system. (Unless it's a *BSD box.)

My reasoning is simple: there are enough network services (DHCP, file
sharing, DNS, firewalls, etc.) that while fragile if implimented using
Microsoft technology are simple & reliable if a techie with a clue
takes an old box, installs her/his favorite *nix variant on it, performs
the necessary configuration, & thus can count on some small corner of
the network to stay stable, while lying to the PTB that yes, they have a
100% MS environment. (And if the PTB don't need to be lied to, they
don't care about the details of how the techies do their work -- & the
techie is free to adopt Linux/BSD as she/he sees fit.)

> Are there any local stories of businesses that have migrated to Linux.
> Are you able to offer up some facts and figures?
>
My wife reports that Linux is used at her current employer, Rentrak.
(She recognized it on a IT workstation.) I had a temp job earlier this
year where the head of IT admitted their firewall are a pair of Linux
boxes. When I worked at Quality Logic, the firewall for the local office
ran on Slackware Linux.

Yes, this is all anecdotal evidence. But I'm willing to bet that if
you asked any head IT guy if they ran Linux in their office, he'd admit
that there's a Linux box or two somewhere in the organization.

> If you were to make a "Who's Who?" list of business and important
> projects running Linux, who would be on it?

As far as I can tell, all supercomputing research is done on clusters
of Linux boxes, using Beowulf technology; projects using specialized
Cray, SGI or high-end Suns have dwindled in numbers to nothing, due
to the cost benefits of Linux on commodity hardware.

All computer-generated animation for movies & television are now done
on Linux boxes. Titanic & Lord of the Rings have acknowledged using
Linux technology; I expect there are more examples out there. (If any
major movie used CGI done on Win2K or NT boxes, would you expect MS
to have NOT blared their horn long & hard about it?)

Geoff

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed May 15 16:49:59 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 15 May 2002 16:49:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205151611340.2002-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205151611340.2002-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <86wuu5otso.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> I'm concerned about these add-ons and things like Gnus.  I
Jeme> assume that that one, in particular, comes standard in the GNU
Jeme> Emacs source tree, but what about all these modes that Karl
Jeme> references constantly?  Are they standard?  

Some are and some aren't.  I am using the Gnus that came standard with
21.2, and it works fine for me.

Jeme> And if not, how are they installed?  I assume they're just lisp
Jeme> files that get dropped in some standard place, but should they
Jeme> be kept separate from the version-specific emacs tree for easy
Jeme> upgrade of the main program or must they be updated with the new
Jeme> version anyway, making a version-independent tree moot?

There is usually a "site-lisp" directory, where you put non-built-in
packages.  Of course, you can put them anywhere and just point at them
by modifying the load-path variable, e.g.:

  (setq load-path (append load-path '("/common/share/emacs/site-lisp/ESS-5.1.21"))

Non-standard packages typically come with installation instructions,
which ought to help.

Russell> The other thing you'll want (at least until you've trained
Russell> your fingers) is the "GNU Emacs Reference Card".  It'll be
Russell> located in etc/refcard.ps

Jeme> I'll print that.  But I also have the Quick Reference Card from
Jeme> the back of the O'Reilly book. 

That's probably about as good.

Jeme> I read somewhere that bracket matching wasn't inherently
Jeme> supported in the usual programming modes of GNU Emacs.  Is that
Jeme> still true?

It works in mine, but my .emacs is Rather Extensive and hasn't been
substantially hacked in a while, so I am not sure what is builtin and
what is coded into my .emacs anymore.  Try it and report back.

Russell> I've got sort of a useful "gnus-select-persona" that I hacked
Russell> myself that lets me easily switch who I want to appear to be
Russell> in Gnus.

Jeme> That's probably the primary feature that isn't supported
Jeme> (easily) in the usual GPL MUAs.

Here's the guts of it:

   (defun gnus-select-persona (&optional key)
     (interactive)
     (when (null key)
       (setq key (completing-read "Gnus Persona: "
                                  gnus-persona-alist
                                  nil t)))
     (setq gnus-active-persona key)
     (let ((persona-info (cdr (assoc key gnus-persona-alist))))
       (while persona-info
         (set (car persona-info) (cadr persona-info))
         (setq persona-info (cddr persona-info)))
       key))

The variable, gnus-persona-alist, looks like this:

   (setq gnus-persona-alist
         '(("aracnet" 
            user-full-name "Russell Senior"
            user-mail-address "seniorr at aracnet.com"
            message-user-organization "As much as seems appropriate"
            message-signature-file "~/.sig-aracnet")
           (...)
           (...)
           (...)))

The only real shortcoming in this is that the message-signature-file
gets inserted when you start a message, so that if you change your
mind about which persona is sending it after you start, you need to
change the signature manually.

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed May 15 17:00:48 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 17:00:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Wed, 15 May 2002 15:33:51 PDT."
             <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205151502130.1300-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> 
Message-ID: <200205160000.g4G00mt05457@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> Anyway, this is an open call.  What can y'all tell me that'll help my
> transition?
> 
> I've got a book (O'Reilly's Learning GNU Emacs -- the gnu book).  I don't
> really have money for another.  I can look at the FSF's manual online, of
> course.
> 
> But building the thing is another story.  So, if you've got something to
> say, I'd like to hear it.
> 

I suspect this is ancient history at this point, but I can tell you that
it used to be quite interesting porting emacs to a new architecture.  During
the build process, a minimal version of emacs would be run after it had
been linked.  At that point, the core lisp code would get loaded into
memory.  This lisp code would be located in the data or bss section
(my memory is a bit fuzzy here).  Then emacs would play some very tricky
games by calling a function named 'unexec'.  This would alter the section
boundaries such that the just loaded lisp code would be merged into the 
text section.  Then the image was written to disk to create your new
emacs executable.

I did this for one of the original Tektronix NS32000 boxes.  I certainly
learned much from the exercise.

So much for the good old days.  With the current autoconf build process,
I doubt you will have much trouble at all.  After installing, you will
probably end up with directories like /usr/share/emacs, or 
/usr/local/share/emacs.  This is where all of the elisp code ends up.
site-lisp is a directory that holds site specific elisp.  It typically
holds elisp code that is acquired outside of the regular emacs build.

If you are just starting out with emacs, I'm certain there are plenty of
people here who can answer questions.

galen

> Warning: Int 0x13 function 8 and function 0x48 return different
> head/sector geometries for BIOS drive 0x81
> Warning: Int 0x13 function 8 and function 0x48 return different
> head/sector geometries for BIOS drive 0x82
> Warning: Int 0x13 function 8 and function 0x48 return different
> head/sector geometries for BIOS drive 0x83
> Warning: Int 0x13 function 8 and function 0x48 return different
> head/sector geometries for BIOS drive 0x84
> Fatal: Empty map section
> 
> Could somebody tell me please what is wrong with my lilo.conf.

This looks more like a kernel-hardware problem.  What kind of harddrive
controller are you running?  What version is your kernel and who
compiled it?

I've seen similar errors while installing on an ABIT BE6 with the
onboard HotPoint controller.  Basic disk access is provided by the
controllers BIOS, so that OS's can see the drives without any drivers
loaded, but full functionality is not realized until the drivers for the
controller are loaded.

Derek




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed May 15 17:16:48 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 17:16:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Printing Problem
In-Reply-To: <006501c1fc18$4ab9f4c0$3c010b0a@assi.bigrocksports.com>
References: <006501c1fc18$4ab9f4c0$3c010b0a@assi.bigrocksports.com>
Message-ID: <200205151716.48858.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Are you using Samba since you say you replaced a NT server? One thing I 
do with Samba is to set it up so that any shared printers that are 
accessible from Samba go to "raw" printer queues. The "raw" printer 
queue does no input or output filtering as it is assumed that the print 
data is already in a format the printer can handle. The Windows-based 
clients use the appropriate Windows-based printer driver to produce the 
output the printer can handle. 

To make things even easier it is possible to specify the name of the 
print driver a remote printer in Samba uses so Windows will 
automatically install and use the appropriate printer driver when the 
printer is setup on a Windows client.

I know FrameMaker runs on Macs and Unix as well so I may be solving the 
wrong problem here. I apologize if my response doesn't answer your 
question.

Tony

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed May 15 17:24:08 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)

Subject: [PLUG] Emacs
In-Reply-To: <200205160000.g4G00mt05457@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

>>>>> "Galen" == Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> writes:

Galen> I suspect this is ancient history at this point, but I can tell
Galen> you that it used to be quite interesting porting emacs to a new
Galen> architecture.  During the build process, a minimal version of
Galen> emacs would be run after it had been linked.  At that point,
Galen> the core lisp code would get loaded into memory.  This lisp
Galen> code would be located in the data or bss section (my memory is
Galen> a bit fuzzy here).  Then emacs would play some very tricky
Galen> games by calling a function named 'unexec'.  This would alter
Galen> the section boundaries such that the just loaded lisp code
Galen> would be merged into the text section.  Then the image was
Galen> written to disk to create your new emacs executable.

Unexec is still used as far as I can tell.  See for example the Emacs
function dump-emacs.  C-h f tells me this:

   dump-emacs is a built-in function.
   (dump-emacs FILENAME SYMFILE)

   Dump current state of Emacs into executable file FILENAME.
   Take symbols from SYMFILE (presumably the file you executed to run Emacs).
   This is used in the file `loadup.el' when building Emacs.

   You must run Emacs in batch mode in order to dump it.

I think several other common programs use this technique.  I am pretty
sure Perl at least used to be one of them.

Subject: [PLUG] Emacs
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205151502130.1300-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205151502130.1300-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 2002-05-15 at 15:33, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> I'm about to take a kind of plunge.

Come on in, the water's fine!

> In an effort to avoid actually practicing becoming a better programmer,
> I'm going to attempt to build, configure, and leanr to use emacs under the
> guise that it will make programming easier when and if I ever work harder
> to actually improve my skills.  (I'm also kind of looking forward to using
> a truly GPL mail reader that does everything I want it to do, but that's a
> maybe right now.)

Learning emacs is part of improving your programming skills.  It will
make you a better and more productive programmer.  Learn to use "etags"
("make TAGS") to find your way around in code, to use "pcl-cvs" ("M-x
cvs-examine") and "ediff", and you'll be a lot farther along than most
of those obstinate fools who still insist on using "vi" in xterms for
everything.

> So, I'm just putting out feelers to find out if there is anything I need
> to know before building emacs from source.  Is there some option that
> needs to be compiled in to allow me to use particular modules, extensions,
> or scripts?  Roughly how big is an emacs installation?  Should I create a
> special /usr/local/emacs to hold all the emacs-specific stuff?  How many
> of the add-ons need to be rebuilt when emacs is rebuilt?

Ah, feelers are beginning to appear.  The metamorphosis has begun!

As always, my advice is to "apt-get source emacs21", and see what they
did.

> My intent is to build GNU Emacs.  I am, of course, generally more
> concerned with the social, legal, and political aspects of the software
> than the technical merits, but I will consider particular comparisons and
> contrasts to other Emacs streams to help inform my decision.

:-)  The "social, legal and political" aspects are not what define the
real differences between GNU Emacs and XEmacs.  It's the differences in
how they are implemented that matter, to those who care to read the
code.

I like them both.  Lately, I've been using GNU Emacs 21.  It's a little
faster, the font-locking works better than XEmacs, etags works better,
and it starts up a little quicker.  What I miss the most about XEmacs is
the minibuffer behaviour.

> Anyway, this is an open call.  What can y'all tell me that'll help my
> transition?
> 
> I've got a book (O'Reilly's Learning GNU Emacs -- the gnu book).  I don't
> really have money for another.  I can look at the FSF's manual online, of
> course.

There's an nice Emacs Lisp tutorial that's worth getting and reading. 
It's really a very good language.

> But building the thing is another story.  So, if you've got something to
> say, I'd like to hear it.

apt-get source emacs21
apt-get source emacsen-common

From alan at clueserver.org  Wed May 15 19:48:34 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: 15 May 2002 19:48:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat Linux 7.3 Personal Edition
Message-ID: <1021517314.15696.21.camel@summanulla.clueserver.org>

Office Despot had 7.3 in stock today, so I picked up a copy.

I won't get into install issues.  (It does not like my daughter's
machine at all, but that may be DMA problems.)

The box comes with a registration card with serial number, a quick guide
to redhat network, and a thin 140 page manual.  There are eight cdroms
included in the package.

3 install discs (The ones you can download)
2 source discs (Also downloadable)
A documentation disc (which is downloadable and only ~50 megs)
A disc of applications (not downloadable, except on warez sites.)
Star Office 5.2

I was kind of disappointed that they did not ship OpenOffice 1.0 or Star
Office 6.0. I am not certain why they chose to go that route.

As for the applications disc... It contains:

AC3D 3.x
Adobe Acroread 4.05
Alladin Stuffit 5.1.6
Beacon Fax2SendComplete 2.1
Datan dataplore 2.0
A bunch of fonts from Larabie
Photodex Compupic 5.1
Sun Forte
Sun Java JRE and SDK 1.3.1 (In bin format, not rpm packages)
VariCAD 8.1.0

The Star Office disc also has bin install files and not rpms.

As far as I can tell, there are no printed instructions on installing
the Star Office disc or the applications disc.  They have autorun files,
but I have not tested them.

I will have more information when I get it installed on a system.  My
current system has too much Ximian Gnome components on it.  It does not
like my daughter's machine.  I have a system running Redhat 7.3 beta 2.
It will probably get installed on that.

[Another interesting note.  "Ximian" is not in the spell checker used by
Evolution, which is made by Ximian.]

More when I have a chance to play with it...

From john at meissen.org  Wed May 15 21:26:42 2002
From: john at meissen.org (John Meissen)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 21:26:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Network monitoring tool?
Message-ID: <20020516042642.45C257468A@john.meissen.org>

I have a Linux gateway configured at a friend's house. It runs
DHCP and provides NAT services for the internal network. The
internal network consists of three or four Macs, several Windows
desktops and notebooks and an occasional Linux machine.

I'm running MRTG on it so we can monitor the state of the external
connection (an 802.11b link with a pair of Cisco bridges). Sometimes,
late at night when there should be no one up, I see significant
increases in both inbound and outbound traffic. The last episode
started at 10PM and ran at a pretty steady rate until almost
exactly noon the next day (a school day, no one should have been
home).

I'm monitoring both NICs, so I can see that the traffic is flowing
through the Linux machine to/from someplace on the LAN. What I
need to do is isolate which machine is doing it.

Is there any tool that can give me NAT statistics, so I can monitor
traffic flow based on the internal IP addresses? I've found a
lot of tools that will do state monitoring of systems, but so
far nothing that will give me what I need.

john-

From JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us  Wed May 15 16:03:17 2002
From: JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us (Miller, Jeremy)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 16:03:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Lilo Warning: Int 0x13 function
Message-ID: <51AE6EA505FCD111AB5600805F653ACB010AA11D@EXCHANGE>

Is it possible to send your kernel/lilo versions and partition information
(or best guess) to the list?  If so, do so.

Hard drive 1 Partition 1 (/dev/hda1) = x MB
Hard drive 1 Partition 2 (/dev/hda2) = x MB
Hard drive 1 Partition 3 (/dev/hda3) = x MB
Hard drive 2 Partition 1 (/dev/hdb1) = x MB

Or something like that is good for a hint.  Output from fdisk or other
partition tool would be best, but maybe not simple to get at unless you have
a boot disk (with those tools) handy.

I know you can get something like that error if the boot image resides past
a certain cylinder (1024 sounds familiar) on your drive with some older
kernel/bootloader combos.  The fact that yours is on hda3 makes me want to
eliminate that possibility first.

Perhaps that isn't the problem, but the info is still good for a starting
point.


Also... is this a new install, or was it working before?  And if it was
working before, what did you do to it? :)


Jeremy

From revans at e-z.net  Wed May 15 21:52:17 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: 15 May 2002 21:52:17 PDT
Subject: [PLUG] Network monitoring tool?
In-Reply-To: <20020516042642.45C257468A@john.meissen.org>
References: <20020516042642.45C257468A@john.meissen.org>
Message-ID: <20020516045416.JWDR8004.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@downtown>

How much do you want to pry?

http://www.ntop.org
Very intrusive, as in nothing private,	logger. You can know where everyone has
been and when.

http://cebu.mozcom.com/riker/iptraf/
IPtraf in IP Traffic Monitor mode might also work. Shows connections.

http://www.tcpdump.org/
The, I think, most likely to be install packet capture utility.

http://www.ethereal.com/
Another packet capture, one of my favorite programs to show how good Linux is.
mostly I talking with network types. 


http://www.snort.org/ 
snort in logger mode. Less likely to fill you disk.  

http://netfilter.samba.org/
I can log all traffic via iptables on my gateway. In SuSEFirewall2 this is very
easy to set up. Maybe whatever you are using has the same capabilities via its
configuration file. 

There are other packet loggers. These are only the ones I have personally used.


Thank you
Russell

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Wed May 15 23:06:43 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 15 May 2002 23:06:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Lilo Warning: Int 0x13 function
In-Reply-To: <1021507727.18186.327.camel@dereklinux>
References: <200205152242.g4FMgaV15505@gate.daniloff.com> 
	<1021507727.18186.327.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <1021529208.5830.69.camel@pookie>

See where the kernel is on /dev/hda3?

Older versions of LILO had problems loading the kernel past cylinder
1024. 
This tells me that this is probably a dual-boot machine. 

Try installing LILO to a boot floppy and see what happens like this:

http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/mini/LILO-8.html


-Coop

On Wed, 2002-05-15 at 17:08, Derek Loree wrote:
> On Wed, 2002-05-15 at 15:42, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> > Hello Linux folkz,
> > 
> > I'm scratching my head and still can't find a decent answer.
> > My lilo.conf includes these entries:
> > --------------------------------------
> > boot    = /dev/hda
> > change-rules
> > reset
> > read-only
> > menu-scheme = Wg:kw:Wg:Wg
> > lba32
> > prompt
> > timeout = 100
> > message = /boot/message
> >  
> >   image  = /boot/vmlinuz
> >   label  = linux
> >   root   = /dev/hda3
> >  
> >   image  = /boot/memtest.bin
> >   label  = memtest86
> >   optional
> > -------------------------------------
> > 
> > When I execute lilo in a command prompt it gives me:
> > 
> > Warning: Int 0x13 function 8 and function 0x48 return different
> > head/sector geometries for BIOS drive 0x81
> > Warning: Int 0x13 function 8 and function 0x48 return different
> > head/sector geometries for BIOS drive 0x82
> > Warning: Int 0x13 function 8 and function 0x48 return different
> > head/sector geometries for BIOS drive 0x83
> > Warning: Int 0x13 function 8 and function 0x48 return different
> > head/sector geometries for BIOS drive 0x84
> > Fatal: Empty map section
> > 
> > Could somebody tell me please what is wrong with my lilo.conf.
> 
> This looks more like a kernel-hardware problem.  What kind of harddrive
> controller are you running?  What version is your kernel and who
> compiled it?
> 
> I've seen similar errors while installing on an ABIT BE6 with the
> onboard HotPoint controller.  Basic disk access is provided by the
> controllers BIOS, so that OS's can see the drives without any drivers
> loaded, but full functionality is not realized until the drivers for the
> controller are loaded.
>

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Wed May 15 23:47:16 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 23:47:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Problem Upgrading Ximian
References: <1021529576.10386.1.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <3CE355F4.7020900@pacifier.com>

Jon Jacob wrote:


> I was trying to upgrade Evolution (and Ximian in general) today, but it
> failed saying:
> 
> Unmet dependency: libgtkhtml.so.9
> 
> Which may be all fine and good, but libgtkhtml.so.9 exists on my system
> and is in /usr/lib where you would expect it.  Is there a path someplace
> I should check or what?


Normally, I would say look at /etc/ld.so.conf and make sure /usr/lib is 
listed, but I'm guessing it doesn't need to be since it's such a common 
location.

So, perhaps you've recently added this library, but the system doesn't know 
it yet.  Run `ldconfig` as root.  This will rescan common lib locations and 
those listed in ld.so.conf and will update /etc/ld.so.cache

--
Kyle Accardi






From sandbox at pacifier.com  Wed May 15 23:53:33 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 23:53:33 -0700

Josh Orchard wrote:

> Hello all,
> 
> I'm looking for the key directories to backup on a system.  I have the
> following that I backed up.
> 
> Are there any that I MUST HAVE as an all important back?
> Or others that maybe I should.


Depends where you've put stuff.  I use /usr/local a lot as do many 
packages.  According to the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard 
http://www.pathname.com/fhs/
that dir should be off-limits for new installation routines, but you never 
can tell, until it's to late, that is.

From aapuch at attbi.com  Thu May 16 03:51:48 2002
From: aapuch at attbi.com (Andrew Puch)
Date: Thu, 16 May 2002 03:51:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Flatbed Scanner Recommendations
In-Reply-To: <3CE3597A.8090601@pacifier.com>; from sandbox@pacifier.com on Thu, May 16, 2002 at 00:02:18 -0700
References: <3CE2AD60.5090303@pacifier.com> <20020515222435.B1436@mentorg.com> <3CE3597A.8090601@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <20020516035148.P2001@brain.vncvr1.wa.home.com>

I just got my Micritek SlimScan C6 working.

$25 dollars at a junk table.

The USB was a little weird to setup.

http://www.mostang.com/sane/sane-backends.html


You need to make sure to load the usb, drivers , then mount the file 
system.

1st.  Make the device. 	MAKEDEV sg0 sga

2nd load the modules. 	Here are the modules that I needed to load. 
	scsi_mod              108608   2  [sg microtek]
	usbcore                73216   1  [ipaq usbserial scanner usb-uhci 
microtek]
	usb-uhci               24452   0  (unused)
	microtek                7032   0

3rd  load the usb file system

  	I added this to the /etc/fstab
	none                    /proc/bus/usb           usbdevfs 
defaults       0 0

4th         then one should run the cmd sane-find-scanner.


5th xsane should work as root.

6th add your self to the scanner group & chown the scanner to the same 
group.

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu May 16 08:41:01 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 16 May 2002 08:41:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Lilo Warning: Int 0x13 function
In-Reply-To: <200205152242.g4FMgaV15505@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200205152242.g4FMgaV15505@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <1021563661.5830.103.camel@pookie>

Alex;

Yesterday I wrote that putting LILO to a floppy would be a good idea. I
thought about it more since then.

That isn't going to work.

Today I worked on it a little more. I found this:


    This is a warning about possible trouble.  Your BIOS is returning
    inconsistent
    information about the disk geometry:  Cylinders:Heads:Sectors for
    drive 0x80.
    
    If you are using "lba32" addressing (default in LILO version 22),
    you have
    nothing to worry about.  The fact that int 0x13, function 0x48 is
    supported
    means that your BIOS supports the extended disk calls required to
    support
    direct 32-bit addressing of sectors.  Hence, the boot loader never
    has to
    worry about translating disk addresses to C:H:S, with the
    consequential 1024
    cylinder limit.
    
    This disk likely will not boot if you use "geometric" or "linear"
    addressing.
    If you system boots okay, leave things alone, and live with the
    Warning.
    
-Cooper




From griffint at aracnet.com  Thu May 16 08:53:16 2002
From: griffint at aracnet.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Thu, 16 May 2002 08:53:16 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] important directories to backup
In-Reply-To: <no.id> from "Josh Orchard" at May 15, 2002 11:14:05 PM
Message-ID: <200205161553.g4GFrGs25903@shell1.aracnet.com>

> 
> Hello all,
> 
> I'm looking for the key directories to backup on a system.  I have the
> following that I backed up.
> 
> Are there any that I MUST HAVE as an all important back?
> Or others that maybe I should.
> 
> Mostly just for system backup.  Not many users actually keep things on the
> machine.
> 
> /etc           Can't go anywhere w/o this.
> /var/log       Just b/c I wanted the logs
> /home/*        Some here. not all.
> /root          I store some things here (rpms and such)
> /boot          figured good to have
> 
> 
> If I missed anything please let me know.  I think I'll be upgrading my
> server this weekend and would like to know I had my ducks lined up before
> I knock them all down.
> 

/usr/local/etc		or maybe just all of /usr/local
/usr/share/ssl/certs	if you're running any secure services
/var/named		if you're running dns
/var/spool/cron		user crontabs
/var/spool/mail		user mail boxes
/var/ftp/pub		anonymous ftp files, if any
/var/www		your web pages, if any

Depending on your distro or version, your directory layout may be 
different. The above list is based on RH 7.0.

Terry

Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/

From JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us  Thu May 16 10:13:46 2002
From: JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us (Miller, Jeremy)
Date: Thu, 16 May 2002 10:13:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Drum machines
Message-ID: <51AE6EA505FCD111AB5600805F653ACB010AA11F@EXCHANGE>

First, here's where to find lots of linux sound apps:
http://www.bright.net/~dlphilp/linuxsound/


I've tried every one (drum machine) I could get my hands on and ended up
liking only one.  It has some issues, but is definitely usable.  (But my
needs may differ from yours, so don't take that as gospel or anything.)


The one I ended up using is called Trommler.  Get it here:
http://muth.org/Robert/Trommler/ 

It's a sample-based machine, so if you don't have any already there are some
good freebies here: http://hem.passagen.se/lej97/kalava/index.html .  It
does come with a basic set, so you don't have to grab more unless you need
to though.

Another sample set I use sometimes is here:
http://www.airwindows.com/studio/index.html



Someone else just mentioned it, but didn't know if it was good. So...

Here's my best shot at a review:

Trommler isn't majorly advanced (no tempo changes, limited ability to do
time/sig change) but it is fairly easy to knock something out with.  Basic
interface... sounds are in rows and beats are in columns.  Patterns are
(sortof) numbered sheets.  (Up to 64 patterns per song, I think.)  You set
up a song by punching in all of your patterns, and organizing the patterns
(by number) across the bottom of the screen.  Pretty standard layout for the
most part.

There's a couple very interesting (and useful) things about Trommler:

1.  The data format a song is stored in is plain text, and simple enough to
understand that after setting up the patterns you could just use a text
editor to lay everything out.  Very quickly.  (And even change a beat or two
in the patterns.  It's very clean.) 

2.  Another guy has written some tools that work with Trommler song files.
One converts midi songs to Trommler files.
http://www.geocities.com/eric_brunel/midi2trommler.en.html

3.  The other is a converter that reads a Trommler song file, lets you set
stereo position/room size/reverb level for each sound, and translates the
whole thing into a VSpace script.  (VSpace is a language/processor that
takes sounds and plays them back in a virtual accoustic space.)  Then you
run the script and get a really nice sounding wav file of the whole song.
  http://www.geocities.com/eric_brunel/TromVSpacer.en.html
Note:  On this website the author states that it doesn't work with the newer
versions of Trommler... that isn't exactly true.  It works on version 1 song
files, but not newer ones.  But it's extremely easy to remove the part that
makes it choke by hand in the text file.  I told him, but he's on a new
project now, and some of the features in the newer Trommler have removed his
itch.  Not mine... it still sounds better after running through VSpace.  If
you know Python and agree, he'd probably let you adopt it as the new
maintainer. :)


Back to Trommler... and a few things that suck about it:

1.  It can be a little sluggish.
2.  Playback can skip a beat here and there.  (Probably related to 1)
3.  Uses raw samples, so you have to convert wavs.  (Which is how most
samples seem to be distributed.  Instructions and script for converting is
provided.)
4.  Last time I checked exporting to a soundfile sucked.  But that's OK
because I always used VSpace to render files anyway.
5.  If using VSpace, it is fairly intensive.  Can take an hour (maybe more)
to render a wav file.  Of course that is on my old K6-2 350, so base your
estimate on that. :)
6.  16 bit 44.1KHz only.  But the majority of linux (and windows) sound apps
have that same limitation.  Good enough for most, but not considered current
professional level processing if that's what you're after.  (Though probably
still fine... don't process or bounce it around too and you should be OK.)



Now, there's onother option: Midi.  Compose on the computer and pipe it out
to a real drum machine or sound module.  Jazz is supposed to be a pretty
decent Midi sequencer.  http://www.jazzware.com/cgi-bin/Zope.cgi/jazzware/
I don't remember if it has a good rhythm editor section, though.

Not to mention you could still render a decent sounding wav file by using
midi2trommler AND trom2vspace.



Right now, I'm using a freeware Windows midi editor with a nice rhythm part
editor (http://www.anvilstudio.com/) for knocking out drum parts.  It works
pretty good.

OK, OK.  Why on earth am I using it and windows when I was working perfectly
fine under linux?  Mainly because I never found a good multitrack recorder
that I could figure out how to use well on linux.  Many were easy to use,
but sucked.  The ones that looked promising usually left me stumped.
(Ecasound, etc.)  SLab came close, I'm going to give it another go soon.
And see what has popped up since I quit.  What I'm really waiting for is
Ardour... that is going to totally rock and blow away even my windows stuff.
But till then...

Oh, FWIW, that machine is dual-boot w/Debian.  And all of the other machines
in the house are Debian too, so no knocking my single windows use!  :)



Dirk, if you want to hear samples of drum parts put together that way
(Trommer + samples from Kalava + rendered through VSpace) I can dig some up
and get them your way.  I think I also have some that didn't go through
VSpace, and at least one that was done in Midi.  (Didn't use Jazz, but Jazz
could still do it I think.)  Probably off list would be best.



And after all of that verbage on drum machines, I still think NOTHING can
ever replace a real drummer!  But even if you do have one, drum machines and
Midi (drums only for me) are pretty handy for composing/layout of tunes and
having something practice along with that won't bug the neighbors. 

Jeremy

Date: Thu, 16 May 2002 11:56:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Tru64 only boots to single user mode?
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020516115608.01f55008@localhost>

Something weird on my box. When I do a hard or soft boot, the system comes 
up in single user mode. I checked /etc/inittab, and have the following line 
in it:

is:3:initdefault:

So, it should be booting to runlevel 3.

If I type "init 3" at the single user mode prompt, it switches to runlevel 
3, and things proceed normally.

I've looked in the logfiles, and don't see anything out of the ordinary.

What else can cause the system to only boot to single user mode?

Thanks in advance!


Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net


Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.

i.e. 'd' instead of 's' for the runlevel id.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu May 16 12:09:13 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 16 May 2002 12:09:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Tru64 only boots to single user mode?
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20020516115608.01f55008@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205161203520.25151-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 16 May 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:

> What else can cause the system to only boot to single user mode?

I'd grep recursively through /etc looking for references to init or 
telinit. If you've got GNU grep, it'd be

  egrep -sr '/(tel)?init ' /etc/*

My hunch is that some startup script is doing 'init s' or something 
similar.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu May 16 12:32:53 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 16 May 2002 12:32:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix SPAM filtering?
In-Reply-To: <00ad01c1fd0e$75b2b4e0$7cf397d0@imarkpdx.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205161226100.3198-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 16 May 2002, r0bbY russell wrote:

> My home email server has been getting hammered with so many spam emails
> lately... Is there something that helps check the emails before they make
> it through to the email account?

Robby,

  You can use the same 'access.db' as is used by sendmail. In there you can
put IP addresses and domain names. The access file is built with your
favorite text editor then translated to a binary format with:
	/usr/sbin/postmap hash:/etc/postfix/access
when you're done, reload postfix:
	/usr/sbin/postfix reload
and you'll be on your way.

  Another trick I learned yesterday from Ed is to use the
smtpd_recipient_restrictions in /etc/postfix/main.cf. Mine now looks like
this:

smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
        check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/badip,
        check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/badaddr,
        permit_mynetworks,
        check_relay_domains

  The 'badip' and 'badaddr' files contain IP addresses and domain names,
respectively. They, too, are converted to binary with the postmap command.

HTH,

Rich

From sendai at thedustyshelf.com  Thu May 16 12:58:29 2002
From: sendai at thedustyshelf.com (sendai)
Date: Thu, 16 May 2002 12:58:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Tru64 only boots to single user mode?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205161203520.25151-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <PKENLAFCOOIOHAPHJGFIIEDPCBAA.sendai@thedustyshelf.com>

Did the system crash recently?  If it did and was unable to save the dump
file it will only boot to single-user mode.  Type:

# rcmgr set SAVECORE_FLAGS M

and that should allow it to boot normally.  I don't remember if rcmgr is in
$PATH, so if it's not do a find.




From russj at dimstar.net  Thu May 16 13:03:49 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 16 May 2002 13:03:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix SPAM filtering?
In-Reply-To: <00ad01c1fd0e$75b2b4e0$7cf397d0@imarkpdx.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020516125639.01fa49c8@localhost>

Please turn off html.

Thanks.

Take a look at my messages from last week. I put a script in here that 
downloads a list of known spammers, and updates the access file to reject 
them.

I had postfix set to reject mail servers that didn't reverse resolve, but I 
found I was losing too much legitimate email by doing that.

You can also add black hole relay checks.

In your /etc/postfix/main.cf, you add the following:

smtpd_client_restrictions = hash:/etc/postfix/access,reject_maps_rbl
smtpd_sender_restrictions = reject_maps_rbl
maps_rbl_reject_code = 554
maps_rbl_domains = 
west1.mail-abuse.org,ns1-relays.osirusoft.com,relays.ordb.org

I now use, balsa + procmail.

here is the scripts that I use.

The procmailrc is setup for plug,

Add this to the end of the procmailrc file
:0
  * ^Subject:.*Flame
        /dev/null

Or this
:0
  * ^From:.*spamer
        /dev/null


Or you could use evolution, which is more WYSIWYG. As far as flitering, 
calendering etc.

YellowDog 2.2

http://www.ximian.com/download/

Keep in mind that redhat upto date & redcarpet do not play nice.

On Wed, 2002-05-15 at 21:26, John Meissen wrote:
> 
> I have a Linux gateway configured at a friend's house. It runs
> DHCP and provides NAT services for the internal network. The
> internal network consists of three or four Macs, several Windows
> desktops and notebooks and an occasional Linux machine.
> 
> I'm running MRTG on it so we can monitor the state of the external
> connection (an 802.11b link with a pair of Cisco bridges). Sometimes,
> late at night when there should be no one up, I see significant
> increases in both inbound and outbound traffic. The last episode
> started at 10PM and ran at a pretty steady rate until almost
> exactly noon the next day (a school day, no one should have been
> home).
> 
> I'm monitoring both NICs, so I can see that the traffic is flowing
> through the Linux machine to/from someplace on the LAN. What I
> need to do is isolate which machine is doing it.
> 
> Is there any tool that can give me NAT statistics, so I can monitor
> traffic flow based on the internal IP addresses? I've found a
> lot of tools that will do state monitoring of systems, but so
> far nothing that will give me what I need.
I use iptraf on my lrp boxes, it pairs up the NAT portion of the
connection with the internet portion of the connection, and it is text
based, so it fits on the one floppy with the rest of the router.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

Subject: RE: [PLUG] Tru64 only boots to single user mode?


Did the system crash recently?  If it did and was unable to save the dump
file it will only boot to single-user mode.  Type:

# rcmgr set SAVECORE_FLAGS M

and that should allow it to boot normally.  I don't remember if rcmgr is in
$PATH, so if it's not do a find.

From john at meissen.org  Thu May 16 15:43:20 2002
From: john at meissen.org (John Meissen)
Date: Thu, 16 May 2002 15:43:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Tru64 only boots to single user mode? 
In-Reply-To: (Your message of Thu, 16 May 2002 15:35:29 PDT.)
             <20020516153529.A11153@kippered.herring.org> 
Message-ID: <20020516224320.0CE687468A@john.meissen.org>

I did a quick Google search, and found this:
 From: Adam Price (adam+usenet at pappnase.demon.co.uk)
 Subject: Re: Boot only goes to Single User Mode 
 Newsgroups: comp.unix.osf.osf1, comp.unix.tru64
 Date: 2000/04/13 
  >I have a Alpha Server 800 5/500 which boots to single-user mode every
  >time.  I was told to hit Ctrl-D to get it to go on to multi-user mode.
  >This works but I'd much rather not have to be there to do this if I need
  >to reboot the machine while on the road or something.
  >
  >Any ideas about what I need to do to fix this?

  Could be one of two things either your boot flags are set to S for single
  user mode, or your default run level in /etc/inittab is set to s.
  If hitting Ctrl-D works then I would guess that it is the console boot flags.

I'm not familiar with Tru64, so I can't tell you where the boot
flags are set. But it's something to check.

john-






From mph at puddingbowl.org  Thu May 16 15:44:14 2002
From: mph at puddingbowl.org (Michael Hall)
Date: 16 May 2002 15:44:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Ximian is out for Redhat 7.3
In-Reply-To: <20020516152508.A8654@brain.vncvr1.wa.home.com>
References: 
	<319FB8934F09BF48A3F322837088266763FFDF@wsimail.worksystems.org>

Message-ID: <1021589055.3723.18.camel@salusa.puddingbowl.org>

I guess my mileage is varying, then.  

Just finished a Ximian install over the top of a fresh (but completely
updated) RH 7.3.  Evolution's always the first app I check out once I've
got gpilotd talking to my Visor, and I can't complain about any of it so
far.  Is there something I should be looking for?

My one kvetch is the inevitable Ximian vs. Red Hat's errata: Ximian
wants its slightly older build of Mozilla (0.99-3) while RH has just
released a patched Mozilla (0.99-12).  No big deal either way with the
exception of scuffling over assorted secondary package dependencies
(like Galeon). That's a problem the two have traditionally had, though,
and doesn't recommend much against an upgrade of both if you're so
inclined anyhow.

Ximian has also not released a StarOffice or experimental channel for RH
7.3, so if you really like SO5.2 as packaged by Ximian or enjoyed the
new GNOME control center and assorted themes they introduced and can't
imagine installing them yourself, it's still one to avoid.

-mph

From rob at euglug.net  Thu May 16 16:51:04 2002
From: rob at euglug.net (Rob Hudson)

Subject: [PLUG] Postfix SPAM filtering?
In-Reply-To: <20020516153157.A22131@cogit8.org>; from rob@euglug.net on Thu, May 16, 2002 at 03:31:57PM -0700
References: <074601c1fd1f$d5891970$9c0a10ac@tpcllp.com> <00ad01c1fd0e$75b2b4e0$7cf397d0@imarkpdx.com> <5.1.0.14.0.20020516125639.01fa49c8@localhost> <20020516141912.A21267@cogit8.org> <074601c1fd1f$d5891970$9c0a10ac@tpcllp.com> <20020516143248.A21514@cogit8.org> <5.1.0.14.0.20020516150150.01f4f570@localhost> <20020516153157.A22131@cogit8.org>
Message-ID: <20020516165103.A23041@cogit8.org>

To reply to my own problem, I figured out that the spamassassin binary
was trying to create a directory "/.spamassassin".  Maybe this
happened b/c I added the user with no home directory.

I found the above out by su-ing to the user, and executing the shell
script.  I ended changing line 151 of spamassassin (v 2.20) and adding
the line (configuration option):     
  'dont_copy_prefs' => 1,

Now things are looking good.

-Rob
