From russj at dimstar.net  Thu May 16 17:12:51 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 16 May 2002 17:12:51 -0700
Subject: Resolved: [PLUG] Tru64 only boots to single user mode? 
In-Reply-To: <20020516224320.0CE687468A@john.meissen.org>
References: <(Your message of Thu, 16 May 2002 15:35:29 PDT.) <20020516153529.A11153@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020516171039.01f198e0@localhost>

This got me going in the right direction.

What I found was the boot_osflags in SRM was blank. I set it to "A" and 
Tru64 now boots to multi-user, GUI mode.

Major pain in the butt, and just *SO* intuitive. :)

From don at truedisk.com  Thu May 16 18:19:40 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Thu, 16 May 2002 18:19:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] lost+found
References: <3CE2C670.EB57ABE0@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3CE45AAC.16D1C7C8@truedisk.com>

Richard Steffens wrote:
> 
> Some many months ago I added a drive to my Linux machine. During the
> process a directory was created called lost+found. I assume it happened
> as part of some script that I was told to run. It is currently empty.
> Does it serve some purpose such that if I deleted it I would mess
> something up?
> 

Yes, it serves a purpose.  Should the disk ever become corrupted,
and the fsck(8) utility find allocated, but unconnected, data blocks,
it will re-connect them to the directory tree by created directory
entries in "/lost+found".  (It's analogous to the Microsoft DOS
tools which litter C:\ with FILEnnnn.CHK files -- just a bit tidier,
is all.)

--

From rsteff at attbi.com  Thu May 16 19:46:39 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Thu, 16 May 2002 19:46:39 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] system call in php
Message-ID: <3CE46F0F.44A45716@attbi.com>

I have the following line in a php file:

system("/usr/bin/mpg123 $fileList &");

$fileList is the name of the selected option in a select box that lists
all the .mp3 files in a particular directory.

This does what I expect it to do, mostly. The php file is on the Linux
machine in my office. The output of that machine's sound card is
connected to the stereo in the living room. Using a laptop in the living
room, I connect to the php file on the machine in the office and
successfully start music file playing with mpg123. That's the part works
the way I expect it to.

With the "&" after the "mpg123 $fileList" I expect the php file to
complete loading. It doesn't. I thought that the "&" was the thing to
use to have a process start up "in the background" and let you continue
doing other things. This does work if I run mpg123 from the command
line. Is there something I should be doing differently with php to get
the same effect?

Also, is there a way for php to receive information about what the pid
is for the process it just caused to be launched? I'd like to build in a
way to stop the music other than logging in, su'ing, running ps -ax, and
then killing the process.

Thanks in advance.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From rob at euglug.net  Thu May 16 20:10:33 2002
From: rob at euglug.net (Rob Hudson)
Date: 16 May 2002 20:10:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] system call in php
In-Reply-To: <3CE46F0F.44A45716@attbi.com>
References: <3CE46F0F.44A45716@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1021605031.23249.2.camel@fuggles>

Look at the difference between:
http://www.php.net/system
http://www.php.net/exec

I think exec doesn't wait for a response unless you pass it an array,
but you still need to redirect output to a file (/dev/null?) so PHP
knows it's not supposed to wait.  The '&' is good in that it kicks up a
child process.

-Rob

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu May 16 20:30:26 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: 16 May 2002 20:30:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] system call in php
In-Reply-To: <3CE46F0F.44A45716@attbi.com>
References: <3CE46F0F.44A45716@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1021606226.29260.20.camel@rheingold>

On Thu, 2002-05-16 at 19:46, Richard Steffens wrote:
> I have the following line in a php file:
> 
> system("/usr/bin/mpg123 $fileList &");

Try instead:

system("sh -c \"/usr/bin/mpg123 $fileList &\"") ;

The background '&' is a shell operation and the PHP system call might or
might not exec a shell.
 
Wil

There are some problems with the JRE and glibc you'll have to contend 
with. I've included the SuSE Oracle install URLs below. These 
instructions helped me get Oracle installed last year on my SuSE 7.1 
system. Since I installed Oracle I've upgraded my system to SuSE 7.2 
and now to 8.0 and my Oracle installation still appears functional. 

The JRE issue is noted in the common issues link for Oracle 8:

http://www.suse.com/en/support/oracle/db/81x_common.html

Here's the main Oracle 8.1.7 link from SuSE's website:

http://www.suse.com/en/support/oracle/db/817_71.html

Good Luck,

Tony

Well, I have never done three OS's, but I have done dual boots, and the MBR 
always works fine for me, and Grub lists both OS's automagically, while with 
LILO I used to have to add Windows by editing (that may have changed with the 
newer LILO).  I always thought adding the boot sector was only necessary when 
the OS was beyond the 1025 cyl limit, which I don't think is an issue with 
newer hardware and OS's.
Rick

SETI at home?

NRST/SST (part of Merlo Station High School in Beaverton) has a mosix
cluster up too and was working on putting SETI at home on it.  

You could have a riverdale seti team, or if you don't want to bother
with the hassle of setting up a team, you could always join the NRST
team. ;)  http://sharky.dyndns.org/nrst/

Oh if your school uses Blender (www.blender.nl is the site, but they are
down now - you can still "apt-get install blender" on Debian though) you
can make a "render server" just like they use in hollywood.  However,
the Blender renderer is meant for networks of workstations, not mosix
(its called "renderd" I think?).

On Thu, 2002-05-16 at 22:22, Robert Kopp wrote:
> I have a computer with both Linux and Windows
> installed, using GRUB as the boot loader. Now I'd like
> to install Red Hat along with the others. I would
> prefer to use the GRUB boot loader now installed to
> boot any of the three, adding the Red Hat installation
> to the present boot menu. 
> 
> Red Hat allows one to install a boot loader or not. If
> it is installed, it can go into the MBR or the first
> sector of the root partition. I know that it shouldn't
> be installed into the MBR, but should it be installed
> on the first sector of the root partition instead of
> not at all?

I don't think you should need a boot loader.  However, you will probably
have to boot into the your current version of Linux installed and edit
your /etc/grub.conf (unless the RedHat install lets you tweak the
existing /etc/grub.conf) to add the new RedHat option. 

Actually, in the past i've installed the RedHat grub boot loader in the
MBR and had the options "Redhat", "Win2k" and "Debian", and the debian
listing would point to a certain partition (where Debian was installed)
which would then have lilo on it, so that I could choose between kernel
versions in Debian. 

Sorry I'm not more familiar w/ Grub... hope this helps... ;)

~Peter

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 13:20:54 -0400
From: Helen Trimes <hetr at manning.com>
To: Pat Eyler <pate at gnu.org>
Subject: Manning Releases Web Development with Apache and Perl



Attention MetroWest.pm Members --- Manning Publications announces the
release of:

Web Development with Apache and Perl
By Theo Petersen

To learn more about this book and find out how to get a free copy for your
group, please read ...

Greenwich, Connecticut, May 2002 -- Web Development with Apache and Perl
teaches web developers how to easily build a site with features like message
forums, chat, session management, custom preferences and other features.
More than a programming book, it covers a wide spectrum of practical issues
and how to handle them such as when to use a database, what information
needs to be secure (and how to secure it), and how to keep traffic from
crippling a website. It teaches the empowering use of ready-made modules so
developers do not have to reinvent the wheel. It even teaches how to
successfully advocate the use of Open Source tools in the corporate
environment.

What's Inside Web Development with Apache and Perl
* CGI and mod_perl programming
* mod_ssl, mod_rewrite and other Apache modules
* Using DBI with databases
* HTML::Mason and Template Toolkit for embedded scripting
* User login and session management
* Performance and system monitoring tools
* Growth planning and disaster recovery
* Sample layouts for community, corporate and e-commerce sites.

years collecting experiences from other developers and evaluating web
development languages, add-ons and techniques to create a best-of-breed
toolkit for web applications. This book is the result. Theo lives in Denver,
Colorado.

From rsteff at attbi.com  Fri May 17 08:41:04 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Fri, 17 May 2002 08:41:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] system call in php
References: <3CE46F0F.44A45716@attbi.com> <1021605031.23249.2.camel@fuggles>
Message-ID: <3CE52490.F371E8E@attbi.com>

Wil Cooley wrote:

> Try instead:
> 
> system("sh -c \"/usr/bin/mpg123 $fileList &\"") ;
> 
> The background '&' is a shell operation and the PHP system call might or
> might not exec a shell.

Didn't make any difference.

Rob Hudson wrote:

> Look at the difference between:
> http://www.php.net/system
> http://www.php.net/exec
> 
> I think exec doesn't wait for a response unless you pass it an array,
> but you still need to redirect output to a file (/dev/null?) so PHP
> knows it's not supposed to wait.  The '&' is good in that it kicks up a
> child process.

exec worked the same way as system. However, while reading the info at
php.net I came across this note.

  Note: If you start a program using this function and want to leave it
  running in the background, you have to make sure that the output of
  that program is redirected to a file or some other output stream or
  else PHP will hang until the execution of the program ends. 

I included redirection in my system call and got what I was looking for. 

system("/usr/bin/mpg123 1>outputfile 2>errorfile $fileList &");

Thanks for the suggestion of where to look.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

understandable given the cost of supporting proprietary software.

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri May 17 09:43:36 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri, 17 May 2002 09:43:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] JBuilder 6
In-Reply-To: <20020517163009.GG2386@dr.mobizinc.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205170828580.22305-100000@zulu.launi.com>
 <20020516231449.42761.qmail@web9604.mail.yahoo.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205170828580.22305-100000@zulu.launi.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020517093631.01fc2960@localhost>

Not only support, but it's probably only been tested on that distribution 
as well.

While we like to think that all Linux distributions will run anything 
compiled for "Linux", that's not always the case, what with many variations 
of libraries, CPUs, etc.

Each distribution requires a testing effort to ensure proper functionality 
and graceful exiting on errors. In other words, each distribution *SHOULD* 
have the same suite of tests run on it as OSes as different as Redhat 7.2 
and Solaris 7.0. Otherwise, the vendor may be opening themselves up to 
major cost overruns in support and services.

This can be argued away with open source arguments, but I'm not interested 
in that. Many businesses (evil and not) choose to NOT release their 
software source code, as is their right. You have the right to use the 
software or not.

At 10:30 AM 5/17/2002 -0600, you wrote:
>When a vendor says that their product works on
>certain distributions, it usually means that they are only willing to
>support their product on those distributions--if you use another, you
>may or may not have any problems, but you're your own.

Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net

  Never before did I notice that I have a file, ~/mail/default. Sure enough,
that's where all these messages ended up. Sigh.

  Fixing the problem was easy: in ~/.procmailrc I changed $DEFAULT to

  Why this never exhibited the lost message before, I've no idea.

  Whew! Thanks to all, but especially to Ed who had the intelligence and
good sense to suggest that I run 'rgrep' on the entire filesystem to see
where a message subject was put.

Sandy,

  In ~/.procmailrc. I must have done something to that file in the middle of
February because it read:

#diagnostic:
DEFAULT=default

  I never saw that. So, it happily created a file called mail/default and
has put 2500+ messages there since then. No wonder I didn't get mail I
expected from individuals and mail lists!

  Sheesh! That's what I get for not looking carefully at sample files I use.
Now, of course, DEFAULT=/var/spool/mail/rshepard and all's well.

INCOMING!!!!! FLAME WAR ALERT!!!!!

Well, <standard reply>it depends.</standard reply>

If your data base is write intensive, it's best spread across as many
spindles as you can get. If it's read intensive, get lots of RAM and speedy
spindles.

<bill's personal preference>
I like mirrors. You can just pause the db, break the mirror, do your stuff
and bring it back up and let it sync. Lots of things you can do with
mirrors, and best of all, your butt's still pretty well covered.
</bill's personal preference>

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Fri May 17 14:38:39 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Fri, 17 May 2002 17:38:39 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Database layout vs. performance
In-Reply-To: <200205172101.g4HL1kV19416@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200205172101.g4HL1kV19416@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <E178p7Q-0005SX-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

RAID 1 might be good, but if it is at all possible, you should try a RAID 5 
(If you have at least a third disk).  RAID 0 has no real fault tolerance.  
Which database is this for? can you use some sort of LVM? or will you be 
using segments? ALSO...You are putting your logs on separate disk devices, 
right?

Alot of the decision making for this is also decided upon by what the 
database's main use is going to be.  OLTP? Generic Data Storage?

With small Sybase installs, a long chain of single disks is very fast, with 
the backup server using DIFFERENT disk devices....for pete's sake..

what kind of uptime/IO/other requirements does this proposed database need?

Hello Brian,
Thanks for your response.
This MySQL with InnoDB tables database is intended for collecting real
time test/process data from the running equipment log files and
providing raw data for data analysis software to display results over
the FCGI web interface. Web server, data analysis software and
database should be residing on the same box to reduce network traffic.

We have two el'cheapo SideBus soft Raid0 EIDE controllers and four
ATA100 EIDE 40GB hard drives. Sorry we can't afford SCSI. Budget is
tight.

There are two possible solutions: 
We can set up two Raid0 arrays and mirror one another simultaneously
or syncronizing them once a day.
Or we can just leave these hard drives where they are and spread data
directories across all four of them.

My major question is which method is better for best performance and
what FS (EXT2, EXT3, ReiserFS, JFS) is better to use for this task.

Thank you in advance for any thoughts or sources of information.
Alex

Another thing to consider is your table layout:

1) How normalized will your data structure be?
2) Can you avoid 15-table joins for a general SELECT statement?

There are alot of things in addition to disk placement that can utilize or 
inhibit a database's response...

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Fri May 17 15:28:12 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Fri, 17 May 2002 18:28:12 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Database layout vs. performance
In-Reply-To: <200205172142.g4HLg6i19468@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200205172142.g4HLg6i19468@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <E178ptR-00060v-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Interesting. It seems to me that instead of depending upon (as you said) 'el 
cheapo' RAID Controllers you may want to go with using the disks themselves...
(a box is only as strong as the weakest joint)  If you are to do this, I 
would definitely recommend using EXT3, I have never used ReiserFS knowingly 
but I have become a definite believer in EXT3's Journaling stuff...

>From the InnoDB documentation, its good to see that MySQL is using 
transactions, and has better dump capabilities and recoverability.  This with 
the goodies from EXT3 will definitely be a help.

With a small RAID0 array, I don't think you'll get the performance 
improvement/reliability you're looking for.

As far as backups, logs, etc...Depending on what kind of space you need for 
pertinent data, you might want to consider the following:

scenario #1::
first 2 disks: database devices MIRRORED (active/online/whatever you want to 
call them)
third disk: DB dump archive disk (cron-jobbie-job dump and possibly gzip)
fourth disk: add'l db disk for testing/recovering dumps....

scenario #2::
[if data is super-important -- kinda wasteful]
software raid 5 (you need 3 of the disks -- fourth for dumps, etc)

un-scenario #3::
Have you considered Sybase?
(not trying to start a flame war, but I'm personally a Sybase junkie...and it 
works VERY well on linux.

Also, if response time via a web server is an issue, rather than FCGI, (which 
I have seen get sick many times onder a heavy load) have you considered PHP?
similar to perl, no additional process creation, and it's buzzword 
compliant....syntax is also similar to perl in some regards.

Brian,

We already have our modules written in Perl which resemble subselects,
triggers, stored functions and other features MySQL doesn't have. 
At least for for now.

I assume that Sybase is free to use in development systems, but what
about using it in commercial applications? How much It'll cost and
what is its lisence schema? 
We just don't want to have additional head aches with commercial EULA
and other greedy needy stuff.

By the way, you've mentioned that Perl FCGI is dieing under a heavy
load. Did you mention FCG not FCGI? CGI is prone to consume a lot of
system resources because Perl script must be interpreted, compiled and
executed upon every user request.  
In case with FCGI the script is interpreted, compiled and executed
only once. After this it runs persistently servicing multiple users
requests. If there are too many users for one process, web server
spawns second third and so on process untill bandwidth is saturated.
Generally properly written Perl FCGI script runs faster than PHP.

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Fri May 17 16:17:15 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Fri, 17 May 2002 19:17:15 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Database layout vs. performance Addendum
In-Reply-To: <200205172234.g4HMYMg19562@gate.daniloff.com>

Alex,

The FCGI that I have seen die was standard Perl/DBI stuff...I'm pretty sure 
alot of it was sloppy coding....

Sybase Licensing is a tricky thing....If this is going to be a commercially 
distributed project, perhaps MySQL would be a bit better (at least less 
costly)  MySQL's licensing (from what I understand) is a bit less in 
price/headache/etc...

Having never used/written for FCGI personally, I guess I put my head on the 
chopping block with that statement.

The issue I was raising as far as stored procs, triggers, etc.  is that in a 
database such as Sybase (for example) the actual query is stored with a query 
plan which is good for non ad hoc queries, in that the SQL doesn't have to be 
compiled and a query plan doesn't have to be generated every time the query 
is executed.  Like by an external entity (Perl) the query plans would be 
freshened whenever an 'update statistics' is run or if a table is modified, 
by dropping and re-creating the proc.  This is, of course unless you are 
using Perl to tie directly into the DB engine....which would be phun....

From aapuch at attbi.com  Fri May 17 19:46:18 2002
From: aapuch at attbi.com (Andrew Puch)
Date: 17 May 2002 19:46:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Database layout vs. performance
In-Reply-To: <200205172142.g4HLg6i19468@gate.daniloff.com>

On Fri, 2002-05-17 at 14:42, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Hello Brian,
> Thanks for your response.
> This MySQL with InnoDB tables database is intended for collecting real
> time test/process data from the running equipment log files and
> providing raw data for data analysis software to display results over
> the FCGI web interface. Web server, data analysis software and
> database should be residing on the same box to reduce network traffic.

MySQL, is not the greatest database. 

It does not pass Mr Dodd ACID Test.

Look into postgres, in some cases it was faster then MySql. 

MySQL has the habbit of not gracefully failing. 

here read these links. 

http://www.phpbuilder.com/columns/tim20000705.php3


> 
> We have two el'cheapo SideBus soft Raid0 EIDE controllers and four
> ATA100 EIDE 40GB hard drives. Sorry we can't afford SCSI. Budget is
> tight.
> 
> There are two possible solutions: 
> We can set up two Raid0 arrays and mirror one another simultaneously
> or syncronizing them once a day.
> Or we can just leave these hard drives where they are and spread data
> directories across all four of them.
> 
> My major question is which method is better for best performance and
> what FS (EXT2, EXT3, ReiserFS, JFS) is better to use for this task.

EXT3 or XFS. 

I know the Redhat developers they swore by EXT3. but they pay for the
development of ext3. Aka the own dogfood theory. Steven Tweedy of Tweedy
disk farm, works for the hat. but I would look into.

I love ext3 for my home box, I have 2 40G /home. So Fdisk is nice and
fast. 

I used to work for IBM setting up Linux for benchmarking SAP/Oracle. 

We found that we got higher threw-put via software raid, on 4-8 ways
Zeons. And 4 way PPros.

Working at IBM we had all the nice raid cards and they were always
slower. Then software RAID. Buy a nice SMP motherboard, will out
preform, UNI motherboard with the raid controller that money could by.
If the drives remain the same, and the # of channels in the raid array. 

XFS. 

IMHO is the best journaling file system for linux. 

It has been design from the ground up to be a true journaling file
system. 

EXT3 is a hack, to ext2 to add journaling. 

JFS is not the JFS on AIX. 

It is from the source tree of Stale OS/2 JFS. So the development is not
the to the same level as the enterprise level as IBM AIX. 

http://oss.sgi.com/projects/xfs/features.html

2^63 = 9 x 1018 = 9 exabytes.  or 9000 Terabytes I think :) 
That is alot of MP3. 

POSIX Access Control Lists (ACLs)

The Linux XFS filesystem supports the ACL semantics and interfaces
described in the draft POSIX 1003.1e standard.

Maximum File Size

For Linux 2.4, the maximum accessible file offset is 16TB on 4K page
size and 64TB on 16K page size. As Linux moves to 64 bit on block
devices layer, file size limit will increase to 9 million terabytes (or
the system drive limits).



Hardware 

I would buy a new MPX Athlon with a dual 2, load up the ram. 

Buy a few Promise ATA 133 cards. 

For Best performance, no chaining the ide. aka 1 drive per each ide
cable.  

Loadup the ide, there is a new Wester Digital Driver with 2 or 4 megs of
cache. I think. 

Also I would do a nice raid 5. 

The hardware above is what I priced out for myself. 

was around 2,000 for 1/4 Terabyte. 


Also you want to see if the LVM, stuff works now. Aka not buggy.

From CurtisE at CurtisE.net  Sat May 18 01:11:06 2002
From: CurtisE at CurtisE.net (CurtisE)
Date: Sat, 18 May 2002 01:11:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] display options
In-Reply-To: <1103_1021707686@hal-9000>
Message-ID: <GJELJBAKILGBFNJHBMKGKELACDAA.CurtisE@CurtisE.net>

Oh, someone more novice than me.  What a rare find. ;)

You can use the pipe symbol (|) (shift - backslash) to send the output of
your ls command to either less or more.  less is nicer than more, because
you can use your arrow keys to scroll back up.  So, the command would look
like this;

ls |less

or, if you want a long listing (shows files details);

ls -l |less

Note: In linux and some UNIX flavors, ll is a shortcut for ls -l.
So, ll |more would give you the same output as ls -l |more.

Hope this helps.
Good luck.

CurtisE

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat May 18 07:06:07 2002

On 18 May 2002, Andrew Puch wrote:

> also mc = Midnight commander .

Since Andrew's suggestion of mc was buried in a longer list, let me 
reiterate it.

Midnight Commander is sort of a file-manager shell program. It lets 
you copy, move, rename, examine, and even ftp files from the command 
line. If you want to peek inside tar files, gzip files, or other file 
sets (.deb, .rpm, etc.), it knows how to do that, too.

Oh, one other suggestion: Try the key combo 'Ctrl + PageUp' after 
you've run ls. Some console terminals will keep a buffer and let you 
scroll back through it.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>





From mph at puddingbowl.org  Sat May 18 08:27:08 2002
From: mph at puddingbowl.org (Michael Hall)
Date: 18 May 2002 08:27:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] fonts in Redhat 7.3
In-Reply-To: <1021710417.6233.1.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <GJELJBAKILGBFNJHBMKGKELACDAA.CurtisE@CurtisE.net> 
	<1021710417.6233.1.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1021735640.2516.16.camel@salusa.puddingbowl.org>

I had the same thing, and it was the usual "AbiWord's god-awful
knock-off truetype" issue.

You can:

a.) Remove AbiWord if you don't use it

b.) Remove the entry for the AbiWord fonts in /etc/X11/fs/config by
commenting out this line:

/usr/share/AbiSuite/fonts

Which will at least keep them out of your way until you use AbiWord and
it goes ahead and adds them to your path anyhow

c.) Get the real Times New Roman, Arial, and a few others that AbiWord
fakes and put them in /usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/TTF since Red Hat has at
least jimmied the aliases on AbiWord's fonts so they'll be used after
the real ones if it can find them. If you must use AbiWord, this is your
best solution.

Between antiword for catting out the .doc's I get to a text file and
OpenOffice for reading .rtf's and others, AbiWord has found its way off
my machine.  Too bad, since it's a passable WordPad substitute, but the
entire font situation (two years in the making, and stubbornly stuck to
despite consistently being the most voted-on bug) will keep it off my
machines until they get around to introducing proper freetype support.

The bug report itself on this particular issue makes for some
interesting reading:

http://bugzilla.abisource.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1030

I sympathize with the developers, who aren't running Burger King
regardless of the gifts they bring to the table, but the entire debate
feels a little mule-headed nonetheless.

From wallywharton at attbi.com  Sat May 18 09:01:16 2002
From: wallywharton at attbi.com (Wally Wharton)
Date: Sat, 18 May 2002 09:01:16 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] More Oracle install troubles
In-Reply-To: <01C1FE24.C0AB15C0.jorgens@coho.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0205180840530.12541-100000@dhcp-73-190.attbi.com>

On Sat, 18 May 2002, Steve Jorgensen wrote:

:
: The error window says
: 	Error in invoking target relink of makefile
: 	/u01/app/oracle/product/8.1.7/precomp/lib/ins_precomp.mk
: 	Buttons: [Help] [Retry] [Ignore] [Cancel]
:

I checked on Oracle's support site, and found a few relevant hits:

- Make sure `make' is in the PATH of the installation environment.  Modify PATH and rerun the installation if it doesn't.

- LD_LIBRARY_PATH should include $ORACLE_HOME/lib .  In your case, /u01/app/oracle/product/8.1.7/lib .

- Check whether the precompilers and samples are installed properly inside $ORACLE_HOME/bin and $ORACLE_HOME/precomp/demo/ .  If they are installed properly you may have recieved these errors due to insufficient temp space and swap space.

- The log file resides in $ORACLE_HOME/install/make.log .

- You can manually relink your precompilers any time by using the makefile, $ORACLE_HOME/precomp/lib/ins_precomp.mk. The make command uses the following convention:

     $ make -f ins_precomp.mk relink EXENAME=executable
     (where executable = proc or procob , profor etc.)


Good luck.

Wally

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat May 18 09:46:22 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 18 May 2002 09:46:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] discovering how much tape consumed on a DDS drive with compression?
Message-ID: <86y9eh5rq9.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

For a long time I have wondered how I could know how much remaining
capacity I have on a tape cartridge when the drive has built in
hardware compression.  I've had this question on DDS-2 and DDS-3
drives.  Does any clever person on this here mailing list know the
answer?  

I can do an "mt tell" to get the block number, but I find that is the
block number of the uncompressed data.  E.g., on a DDS-3 (12 gig
native capacity), with blocksize set to 32768 bytes:

  $ tar -b 64 -clf /dev/nst0 . 

  $ mt -f /dev/nst0 tell
  At block 405606.

  $ tar -b 64 -clf - . | wc
  98016073 949999497 13290897408
 
The byte count is consistent with the blocksize and block count, but
it is obviously greater than the native capacity, so we are talking
about the uncompressed figure, whereas I am really interested in the
fraction of the tape left (which would give me a way of estimating the
data holding capacity remaining).  Since the tape mechanism is hidden
inside a box, I can't just look at the reels to get an idea.

Clues?

I tried with both Net::Whois and Net::XWhois with poor results.  I got
false negatives on domains I knew we still had and inconsistent
results.  I even put a sleep in after each query, because I seem to
recall the WHOIS servers limiting connections to prevent
spammer-harvesting.  We've got a lot of domains, some of which are no
longer registered to host with us, so I was trying to find an automated
way of verifying them.  So far, 'bwwhois' and some grep/awk filters seem
to work best.

Attached are the two scripts I wrote (to use the respective modules); if
anyone sees anything obviously wrong with them let me know.

On Sat, 2002-05-18 at 01:11, CurtisE wrote:
> Oh, someone more novice than me.  What a rare find. ;)
> 
> You can use the pipe symbol (|) (shift - backslash) to send the output of
> your ls command to either less or more.  less is nicer than more, because
> you can use your arrow keys to scroll back up.  So, the command would look
> like this;
> 
> ls |less
> 
> or, if you want a long listing (shows files details);
> 
> ls -l |less
> 
> Note: In linux and some UNIX flavors, ll is a shortcut for ls -l.
> So, ll |more would give you the same output as ls -l |more.

For some reason on my system, the color escape codes aren't turned off
when ls is piped to less, so I have to add '-r' to less to make it
interpret the escape codes.  'ls -l|less -r'

Message-ID: <1021748779.7902.5.camel@bittersweet>

On Sat, 2002-05-18 at 01:11, CurtisE wrote:

> Note: In linux and some UNIX flavors, ll is a shortcut for ls -l.
> So, ll |more would give you the same output as ls -l |more.

That is because one of your startup scripts contains "alias" statements
that create that.  You can read about "alias" in the Bash, Zsh, or Ash
manuals.

alias ll='ls -l '

On Sat, 2002-05-18 at 11:09, Wil Cooley wrote:

> For some reason on my system, the color escape codes aren't turned off
> when ls is piped to less, so I have to add '-r' to less to make it
> interpret the escape codes.  'ls -l|less -r'

Look for an "alias" for "ls" that sets it up to use the "--color"
option, and see that it's using "--color=auto" so that it detects
whether or not it's running on a TTY, and if the TERM supports color.

From flee at aracnet.com  Sat May 18 18:23:11 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Sat, 18 May 2002 18:23:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Ownership of ports
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205181802360.8723-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> on Sat, 18 May 2002 18:05:35 PDT.
Message-ID: <200205190123.g4J1NB832001@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

When you add yourself to a group, you may have to log out
and log in again for it take effect.  group membership, like
user-id, is a per-process attribute and gets inherited by
child processes, and is normally only set once by "login".

The command "groups" will tell you what groups your current
shell are in.

You can also use the command "newgrp" to create a subprocess
with different group membership.
--

From rob at euglug.net  Sat May 18 21:06:28 2002
From: rob at euglug.net (Rob Hudson)
Date: 18 May 2002 21:06:28 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PHP question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0205181722260.8911-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0205181722260.8911-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <1021781187.24208.6.camel@fuggles>

Here's how I usually handle file uploads...

Note, you do need the form encoding type to be multipart/form-data...

The example below is from the form element:
<form type=file name=img>

// Check if there was anything in the img form element...
if ($img != '' && $img != "none") {
  // Check for correct type
  if (($img_type != 'image/jpeg') && ($img_type != 'image/pjpeg')) {
    echo "Not the right file type.  Image must be in jpeg format.";
    exit();
  }
  // Check for limited size
  if ($img_size > 81920) {
    echo "Thumbnail image is too large.";
    exit();
  }
  // Read in the binary
  $img_bin = fread(fopen($img, "r"), filesize($img));
  // Write it to where we want it
  if (fwrite(fopen($file, "w"), $img_bin, filesize($img))) {
    echo "<p align=center><b class=red>Thumbnail image uploaded successfully. (" . filesize($img) . " bytes)</b></p>\n";
  } else {
    echo "Upload error.";
  }
}

The thing to note is that PHP automatically adds the:
 _type and _size 
for you.  There may be more efficient ways, but this is from working code.

Hope it helps,
Rob

> exist when I look in /tmp.

Did you try getting the temporary file name using:
  $tmp_file= $HTTP_POST_FILES[ 'file'][ 'tmp_name'];
?

Your form should also have a MAX_FILE_SIZE hidden variable:
<input type="hidden" name="MAX_FILE_SIZE" value="100000"/>

Value is the maximum upload file size in bytes. I have read that the
maximum maximum is 2 Megabytes.

The temporary file is automatically deleted when the script completes.

- Aj

From m at netpro.to  Sat May 18 22:38:04 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 18 May 2002 22:38:04 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] PHP question
In-Reply-To: <20020519044428.GE15519@zappa>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0205182232560.12759-100000@lukem.com>

Thanks to all that helped me on this.  It's working now.  Here's the PHP
code I'm using:

<?
if ($_FILES['file']['tmp_name'] != "") {
	copy($_FILES['file']['tmp_name'], "/tmp/" . $_FILES['file']['name'])
		or die("Couldn't copy file.");
}
else {
	die("No file specified.");
}
?>

Global vars are disabled in newer releases of PHP, so that's why I
couldn't use the $file_name and $file_size type variables.
~M

From m at netpro.to  Sat May 18 23:04:25 2002

One other thing...  You must have this line:

<input type="hidden" name="MAX_FILE_SIZE" value="200000">

Otherwise the upload won't work (with no obvious explanation as to what
went wrong).  The value can be changed to what you want (within the limits
of the php.ini file, of course), but this line must be present in the HTML
file.
~M

From jorgens at coho.net  Sun May 19 00:21:59 2002
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Sun, 19 May 2002 00:21:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Database layout vs. performance
Message-ID: <01C1FECB.333D5C00.jorgens@coho.net>

On Saturday, May 18, 2002 10:16 PM, Alex Daniloff [SMTP:alex at daniloff.com] 
wrote:
...
> Why not ReiserFS? What are disadvantages?

My understanding is that, although ReiserFS is working very well now and is 
a fine journaling file system, it is significantly slower than EXT3 and 
others.  The big advantage of ReiserFS is compact storage (with the tail 
option on - the default, I think) and rapid opening/closing of large 
numbers of small files, but this is no help with large, single-file 
databases.

I'm told that ReiserFS speeds up kernel builds significantly, and it's 
great for news servers because you can efficiently store message as files 
and use grep, etc.

----------------------------------------------------------
CAUTION

1. Don't use linux kernel 2.4.16 or earlier for reiserfs operations, as

> a fine journaling file system, it is significantly slower than EXT3 and

How come? 
Their published benchmarks shows completely opposite picture
http://www.namesys.com/benchmarks/benchmark-results.html


>The big advantage of ReiserFS is compact storage (with the tail
> option on - the default, I think) and rapid opening/closing of large
> numbers of small files, but this is no help with large, single-file
> databases.
>
> I'm told that ReiserFS speeds up kernel builds significantly, and it's
> great for news servers because you can efficiently store message as files
> and use grep, etc.

According to what you've wrote ReiserFS is suitable for web and news server 
applications with a bunch of small static files or CGI/FCGI scripts.
EXT3 or may be XFS are suitable for dealing with large files and databases.

It means that if you want to combine web and database server in one box you 
have to put all your web content on ReiserFS partition and  locate your DB 
data directories on EXT3 or XFS partition.
Did I make a right assumption?

From tedm at toybox.placo.com  Sun May 19 08:20:49 2002
From: tedm at toybox.placo.com (Ted Mittelstaedt)
Date: Sun, 19 May 2002 08:20:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RE: [KLUG] Hello / K12Linux / Job posting
In-Reply-To: <003301c1fef0$26dd7ba0$6501a8c0@endeavor>
Message-ID: <001601c1ff48$c1b55820$1401a8c0@tedm.placo.com>

Speaking of non-PDX job opps, there was a small article in the Oregonian about
Symantec corporation.

I don't supponse anyone recalls, but several years ago Symantec corporation
(makers of Peter Norton's PC Anywhere, Norton Antivirus and others) got a
series of special tax breaks and a shitpile of lottery money to locate a
tech support center down in the old BonMarche shopping mall in Eugene that
employed up to 300 people I think it was.

I remember going down there once when I was still working for Symantec and
getting a kick out of seeing the old escalator in the building - first office
building I ever saw with an escalator.  It was cheaper to just leave it in
there instead of taking it out.

Well anyway Symantec is cutting loose all the customer support and tech
support positions to an outsourcer.  What the article didn't explain was
that usually how this happens is that Symantic terminates all employees
across the board.  Then the incoming outsourcing company
reads through the personell files and any managers that are making less
than some arbitrary amount they instantly hire, then they take those guys
and run through the rest of the personnel list and line out the
non-performers,
and the folks making a lot of money who have been there for a long time.
Then they offer the remaining employees new jobs at the same pay rate, but
less benefits.  Then they go out and hire the remaining people that they
need to fill the empty positions.

If you know anyone who has zero professional computer experience but wants
to break into the industry, let them know about this, the outsourcer is
Spectrum Contact Services, of Dallas TX.  Doing desktop support for these
kinds of products is a killer, and I guarentee that the benefits and pay
will be worse for the employees that get fired from Symantec and rehired by
these people, so your going to see a lot of disgruntled employees quit over
the next year.  It's not a fun kind of job.  But, it's one of the best ways
to gain experience and having a year of support work on your resume is a
lot better than nothing.  Also the location is close to the University of
Oregon.

The article did take the space to mention that doing this disqualifies the
company for any economic development tax breaks.  No word on if they have
to pay back the lottery money.  I suppose I could make a mention here about
the uselessness of having government officials wasting taxpayer dollars on
boondoggles like getting corporations that run sweatshops to locate in their
cities but I suppose I'll just keep quiet. ;-)

Ted Mittelstaedt

             <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205181722510.8325-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <200205200114.g4K1EEt17756@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> 
>   I added myself to the group "uucp" then changed permissions to 660. Now I
> cannot get jpilot talking to that port. I also added myself to the group
> "wheel", changed the port's group to that, but find the same results. The
> only way it works is when the device is owned by me.
> 

Here is what I believe to be a typical setup for serial ports.

crw-rw----    1 root     uucp       4,  64 May 17 13:03 /dev/ttyS0
crw-rw----    1 root     uucp       4,  65 Jul 31  2001 /dev/ttyS1

-rwxr-sr-x    1 root     uucp      1503024 Jan 13  2000 /usr/bin/kermit

YMMV,
galen

On Sun, May 19, 2002 at 08:20:49AM -0700, Ted Mittelstaedt wrote:
> Speaking of non-PDX job opps, there was a small article in the Oregonian about
> Symantec corporation.
> 
> I don't supponse anyone recalls, but several years ago Symantec corporation
> (makers of Peter Norton's PC Anywhere, Norton Antivirus and others) got a
> series of special tax breaks and a shitpile of lottery money to locate a
> tech support center down in the old BonMarche shopping mall in Eugene that
> employed up to 300 people I think it was.
> 

I was down there at the time. I got tired of watching the local city government
people falling all over themselves as they described in gushing detail how
much of a positive impact Symantec was going to have on the downtown mall.

The city had this great idea about blocking the downtown off from auto
traffic. And then they were puzzled when everyone drove to gateway mall
to do their shopping.

Businesses began deserting the downtown like rats from a sinking ship.

> I remember going down there once when I was still working for Symantec and
> getting a kick out of seeing the old escalator in the building - first office
> building I ever saw with an escalator.  It was cheaper to just leave it in
> there instead of taking it out.

I applied there (Symantec in Eugene) once, just to get an idea of
what was on the questionaires.

I passed info back to my friend who was a CC instructor. He wanted to
get an idea of what skills his retrained-logger students would need to
get into tech support.

The questions centered around what happens in DOS before Windows starts.

> 
> Well anyway Symantec is cutting loose all the customer support and tech
> support positions to an outsourcer.  What the article didn't explain was
> that usually how this happens is that Symantic terminates all employees
> across the board.  Then the incoming outsourcing company
> reads through the personell files and any managers that are making less
> than some arbitrary amount they instantly hire, then they take those guys
> and run through the rest of the personnel list and line out the
> non-performers,
> and the folks making a lot of money who have been there for a long time.
> Then they offer the remaining employees new jobs at the same pay rate, but
> less benefits.  Then they go out and hire the remaining people that they
> need to fill the empty positions.
> 

Sounds like the scenes of "Office Space" when the efficiency expert is
brought in.

> If you know anyone who has zero professional computer experience but wants
> to break into the industry, let them know about this, the outsourcer is
> Spectrum Contact Services, of Dallas TX.  Doing desktop support for these
> kinds of products is a killer, and I guarentee that the benefits and pay
> will be worse for the employees that get fired from Symantec and rehired by
> these people, so your going to see a lot of disgruntled employees quit over
> the next year.  It's not a fun kind of job.  But, it's one of the best ways
> to gain experience and having a year of support work on your resume is a
> lot better than nothing.  Also the location is close to the University of
> Oregon.

It would be a good fit for my brother, but it would be hard to justify
his moving down there.

> 
> The article did take the space to mention that doing this disqualifies the
> company for any economic development tax breaks.  No word on if they have
> to pay back the lottery money.  I suppose I could make a mention here about
> the uselessness of having government officials wasting taxpayer dollars on
> boondoggles like getting corporations that run sweatshops to locate in their
> cities but I suppose I'll just keep quiet. ;-)
> 
> Ted Mittelstaedt

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org

router / options.ttySx file


I think you're describing the basic function of these routers.  I think
about ALL they do is NAT.  We have one IP adddress, and all the boxes
connected to the router have their own 192.168.1.xxx address.  I can
route up to 10 specific incoming ports to different boxes. There is also
a DMZ host option which will send all incoming ports (unless otherwise
routed) to a single box.

So....I think this will work.  I *THINK* I set everythig up OK last
night, grabbed the cel phone, gave myself a jingle, and the USR hardware
PCI modem on ttys4 picked up and started squealing. Most of my local
friends are OIT college students, and are pretty busy on Friday nights,
so I could not recruit anyone who had a modem (most are on a LAN
connection) to test it for me.  8am on  saturday is still too early to
wake anyone up.    I'll head out in awhile to a friend's with my laptop
and try it then.

---------
One thing I am unclear on is the options.ttyS4 file (S4 in my case).
Section 1.8 of the walkthrough I mentioned in my original message
suggests:

	To set a specific IP for a client and server for each tty,
update the /etc/ppp/options.ttyname file for each tty: 


   		 serverIP:clientIP

I set mine up to be:

192.168.1.102:192.168.1.140

Note that I assigned the .140 for the dialup client.

Does this sound OK?

Greg

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Anthony Schlemmer
Sent: Saturday, May 11, 2002 12:42 AM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Dialup Server on network with Linksys DSL/Cablemodem
router


I don't have experience with the Linksys router (I wish I did) and so 
whether or not you can access the internet through the router would 
depend on how it does NAT. If you can set it up so that it does NAT for 
your entire private subset e.g. 192.168.1.x then that would allow the 
PPP connected client to access the internet through the router as well.

Tony

> -----Original Message-----
> From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
> [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Anthony Schlemmer
> Sent: Thursday, May 09, 2002 8:08 PM
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: Re: [PLUG] Dialup Server on network with Linksys 
> DSL/Cablemodem router
>
>
> I think the original poster was planning on setting up a dialup PPP
> server which sits inside the private network. When a client dials in, 
> it is assigned a valid, private, IP address through PPP and is then 
> part of the internal 192.168.x.x network. Once the client has an IP 
> address that is part of the private network it can access the router 
> at 192.168.1.1.
>
> There are no routing issues with private IP addresses and a second
> public IP address isn't needed since the client system will be routing

> packets directly to the PPP dialup server.
>
> Tony
>
> On Thursday 09 May 2002 18:22 pm, Robert McIntosh wrote:
> > I've considered attempting this with my Linksys BEFSR41 Cable/DSL
> > Router as well.  I haven't spent the time to do it, for a few 
> > reasons - I have one dynamic IP address that AT&T's cable internet 
> > service seems to think needs to be changed every week, because 
> > "assigning static IP addresses has become increasingly cumbersome."
> >
> > Here are a few problems to consider while attempting this.
> >
> > 1)	En route, other routers will NOT pass private-use IP addresses
> > (i.e, 192.168.x.y).  They will immediately be dropped, unless you
> > drag
> >
> > a LONG cable along with you connected directly to your router. You
> > really need a minimum of two static public IP addresses to do this 
> > with standard ppp - one for the client and one for the host. PPTP 
> > might be something to look into, but I'm unsure if the Linksys 
> > router supports this, nor have I had the time to muddle through 
> > PPTP. I'm sure Cisco's support it ($$).
> >
> > > My questions, before I begin are: will this allow me to interface
> > > with the router, and other on the LAN?
> >
> > You need to be explicit with packet forwarding in the Linksys router

> > to meet your particular network., otherwise you'll just be
> > interfacing
> >
> > with the router.
> >
> > > It's imperative that the dialup server allows me to do this by
> > > connecting to the router internally on 192.168.1.1.
> >
> > You won't be able to do this.  You will only be able to refresh the
> > DHCP client (your router) locally, not remotely.  It sounds like 
> > you've got cable-modem access that delivers your router a dynamic IP

> > address periodically.  This is not desirable for a ppp host.
> >
> > > I guess my main question is:  Since there is only one modem/phone
> > > line, should I configure it to just hand out a static IP?
> >
> > Absolutely!  It'd be a waste of memory to run DHCP for a single
> > client.
> >

Are you starting up pppd? For a user dialing in they would login and 
only have a shell prompt until "pppd" is started. Did you look at the 
PPP-HOWTO? It shows a useful "ppp" alias that will overlay the user's 
shell process with a running PPP daemon.

http://www.thelinuxreview.com/howto/ppp/

Tony

> > I think the original poster was planning on setting up a dialup PPP

> > then part of the internal 192.168.x.x network. Once the client has
> > an IP address that is part of the private network it can access the
> > router at 192.168.1.1.
> >
> > There are no routing issues with private IP addresses and a second
> > public IP address isn't needed since the client system will be
> > routing
> >

> > >

> > >

> > > (i.e, 192.168.x.y).  They will immediately be dropped, unless you
> > > drag

> > >

> > >

From aapuch at attbi.com  Sun May 19 23:43:48 2002
From: aapuch at attbi.com (Andrew Puch)
Date: 19 May 2002 23:43:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs modes.

> 
> /usr/share/emacs/site-lisp/lilypond-mode.el

Hmm, you see this 
http://www.lilypond.org/wiki/?LilyPondInstall

 Is there an emacs mode?

Yes. It is included with the source archive as `lilypond-mode.el'. If
you have an RPM it is in `/usr/doc/lilypond-<VERSION>/'. You have to
install it yourself:

Move lilypond-mode.el into a suitable directory (in this example:
~/usr/share/emacs/ ), and put the following into your emacs startup file
(typically this is ~/.emacs)

(setq auto-mode-alist
	      (append '(("\\.ly$" . lilypond-mode)
			)
		      auto-mode-alist))

(autoload 'lilypond-mode "~/usr/share/emacs/lilypond-mode"
	 "Lilypond editing mode." t)

From flee at aracnet.com  Mon May 20 00:19:54 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Mon, 20 May 2002 00:19:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] /dev/ttyS0 strangeness
In-Reply-To: <20020520042043.5F9FB7468D@john.meissen.org> on Sun, 19 May 2002 21:20:43 PDT.
Message-ID: <200205200720.g4K7JsY16169@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

"John Meissen" <john at meissen.org>:
> Look in /etc/security. Check for a file called console.perms.
> Wish I understood where this came from, and why. It wreaks all sorts
> of havoc with my system. In my opinion this sort of thing doesn't
> belong on a multi-user system.

It's to give the person sitting at a PC access to devices
that they're supposed to be able to use, like audio devices,
mouse devices, display devices, etc.  Generally, on a
multi-user system you don't want everybody to have access to
/dev/audio or whatever, cuz then a remote user can fuck
things up for the person sitting at the console.

The old method was to make these devices owned by root or
some non-root system uid or gid, and any programs that
needed to play with sound or whatever would need to be
set-id, or else talk to a daemon with the right privileges
that enforced access control.  This method is prone to
stupid security holes.

The new method is to have login give ownership of these
devices to the person who logs in on the console, which
isolates the treacherous security code to just one place.
--
[ sometimes tigers fall down wishing wells ]

>  Is there an emacs mode?
> 
> Yes. It is included with the source archive as `lilypond-mode.el'. If
> you have an RPM it is in `/usr/doc/lilypond-<VERSION>/'. You have to
> install it yourself:
> 
> Move lilypond-mode.el into a suitable directory (in this example:
> ~/usr/share/emacs/ ), and put the following into your emacs startup file
> (typically this is ~/.emacs)
> 
> (setq auto-mode-alist
> 	      (append '(("\\.ly$" . lilypond-mode)
> 			)
> 		      auto-mode-alist))
> 
> (autoload 'lilypond-mode "~/usr/share/emacs/lilypond-mode"
> 	 "Lilypond editing mode." t)

As I read this, I understood it to mean this autoloads the lilypond mode

enter lilypond mode from an empty buffer.

From briand at aracnet.com  Mon May 20 00:53:05 2002
From: briand at aracnet.com (briand at aracnet.com)
Date: Mon, 20 May 2002 00:53:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs and Gnus.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205200038060.18658-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <20020520073054.GA3461@puddingbowl.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.21.0205200038060.18658-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <15592.43873.736450.828376@soggy.deldotd.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

  Jeme> I want to use emacs, but I want to apply regular expressions
  Jeme> to lines as I edit a file.

  Jeme> Is that available in default mode emacs?

regular expression searching is available as both a search and an
incremental search.

use "ctrl-h a regexp" to get a list of commands which use regexp.

meta-ctrl-s is isearch-forward-regexp

search-forward-regexp is not assigned to a key by default.

ctrl-h f search-forward-regexp

The only way I know of to apply a regexp search to a given set of
lines is to "narrow" the file.

All of this is also available from within the info file for emacs.

You have stumbled across the biggest problem with emacs - finding the
name of a command for something you are just sure should exist.  At
this point in human history - if you think that you should be able to
do something in emacs then someone has already written a routine to do
it.  You have no choice but to read the documentation.  The info file
is best.

Brian





From briand at aracnet.com  Mon May 20 01:16:47 2002
From: briand at aracnet.com (briand at aracnet.com)
Date: Mon, 20 May 2002 01:16:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs modes.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205200039350.18658-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <1021877030.1910.26.camel@brain>
	<Pine.LNX.4.21.0205200039350.18658-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <15592.45295.513992.815833@soggy.deldotd.com>

Generally you can enter a mode by doing:

M-x name-of-the-mode-mode

So for this lilypond thing, you should be able to say:

M-x lilypond-mode

and the buffer should be in lilypond-mode.


Brian

Are you starting up pppd? For a user dialing in they would login and 
only have a shell prompt until "pppd" is started. Did you look at the 
PPP-HOWTO? It shows a useful "ppp" alias that will overlay the user's 
shell process with a running PPP daemon.

http://www.thelinuxreview.com/howto/ppp/

Tony

In-Reply-To: <001001c1fff0$9e8ae060$6401a8c0@endeavor>
References: <001001c1fff0$9e8ae060$6401a8c0@endeavor>
Message-ID: <1021900636.30893.15.camel@sneaker.got-roots.com>

On Mon, 2002-05-20 at 04:22, Greg Long wrote:
>  People have a habit here of including only part of
> previous posts when replying, so I see it is not included below.  

Probably since that is proper email etiquette. Its pretty rude to expect
people to read through a whole thread of irrelevant stuff to get to the
point you are replying to. This is also why companies like mine spend
huge amounts of money backing up email that is pretty much the same
information over and over again. The proper way to respond is to edit
out all but what you are responding to and then put your response
underneath. Some bad email clients like Outlook ..the one you use) make
this harder by  putting the cursor and signature on top. 

>From RFC 1855 ( http://www.albury.net.au/new-users/rfc1855.txt ) :
"- If you are sending a reply to a message or a posting be sure you
      summarize the original at the top of the message, or include just
      enough text of the original to give a context.  This will make
      sure readers understand when they start to read your response.
      Since NetNews, especially, is proliferated by distributing the
      postings from one host to another, it is possible to see a
      response to a message before seeing the original.  Giving context
      helps everyone.  But do not include the entire original!"

Doug Davis

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Mon May 20 08:42:43 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Mon, 20 May 2002 08:42:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs modes. 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Mon, 20 May 2002 01:19:26 PDT."
             <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205200118530.19199-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> 
Message-ID: <200205201542.g4KFght21244@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> 
> On Mon, 20 May 2002 briand at aracnet.com wrote:
> > Generally you can enter a mode by doing:
> > M-x name-of-the-mode-mode
> > So for this lilypond thing, you should be able to say:
> > M-x lilypond-mode
> > and the buffer should be in lilypond-mode.
> 
> Right.  You must have missed my original message.
> 
> I tried that and got [No match].
> 
> So what am I doing wrong?
> 

Emacs doesn't automatically scan or load the files in
/usr/share/emacs/site-lisp, so it doesn't know where to find the function
called lilypond-mode.  Try adding this line to your .emacs.

(autoload 'lilypond-mode "lilypond-mode" "LilyPond major mode." t)

This will cause emacs to load lilypond-mode.el or .elc when the 
lilypond-mode function is executed.  Once the file is loaded, all of the
emacs lilypond functions will be available.

Alternatively, you add this to /usr/share/emacs/site-lisp/site-start.el.
This eliminates the need to modify the individual ~/.emacs files.

You will probably still want to add a line like this:

(setq auto-mode-alist (cons '("\\.ly$" . lilypond-mode) auto-mode-alist))


jeme at brelin.net said:
> As I read this, I understood it to mean this autoloads the lilypond
> mode when I edit a file ending in .ly.  That's all well and good, but
> I want to enter lilypond mode from an empty buffer. 

If you add the autoload line from above, you will be able to enter
lilypond-mode from an empty buffer by typing M-x lilypond-mode.  However,
I would suggest a slightly different approach.  I rarely if ever start
editing in an empty buffer.  I usually do a C-x C-f to start editing a
new file.  By doing it this way the buffer is automatically put into
the mode indicated by the filename extension.  For instance, if I do
C-x C-f new.c, I get a new buffer named new.c that is in C-mode.  If
you changed your mind about the file name, you can just write the buffer
out to a different name with C-x C-w.

galen







From jeme at brelin.net  Mon May 20 08:45:08 2002

On Mon, 20 May 2002, Greg Long wrote:
> It always seemed like selective quoting, often taking things out of
> context - like the press does.

Well, if you ever see that happen, it's pretty easy to just call someone
on it.  I find it's rare that a person is even motivated to do such a
thing [as choose selected quotes that are misleading out of context], but
it has happened and never stands up to public scrutiny.  Remember, this is
an interactive medium.  It's nothing like the press.

We work in an electronic (and therefore maleable) medium therefore we have
an added responsibility to maintain accurate records for posterity.  Once
there was a request from the users of a mailing list I administered to
modify the archives to remove data that "shouldn't have gone to the list".  
I refused and all hell broke loose.  I tried to explain that the archives
existed as the objective collective memory of the list and tampering with
them destroys any concept of reality we might entertain.  A person will go
back to the archives to verify a memory.  If the information is not in the
archive, the memory failes to be validated and, in some kinds of reasoning
where one expects the archive to be accurate and complete, often
INVALIDATED.  Surely we can't fuck with people's memories like that.  
[The compromise was to modify the post with big red warnings all
throughout that post saying that the information had been compromised and
modified and should not be considered an accurate record.  I then
immediately resigned as administrator and forced the list to be hosted
elsewhere.]

> Plus, with the entire message quoted, you have a chronological record
> going down the line, which people can selectively read.

And yet, it causes a person to spend three times as long reading a post of
any complexity because we read from top down.  A person reads the reply at
the top, needs context and hence reads the body of the message quoted
below, then goes back to the top to try to re-interpret the reply in light
of the refreshed memory/new information provided by the original
post.  Repeat for each post in the thread.

We have a chronological record going back down the line for each thread
that people can selectively read.  They're called the archives.  We don't
need it in every freakin' post.

> but that's just my $.02.  It does increase the size of the email over
> time of course.

Consider the multiple copies of the PLUG footer, signature files, and
other meaningless dreck.

J.

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Mon May 20 08:47:01 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Mon, 20 May 2002 08:47:01 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs and Gnus.
In-Reply-To: <15592.43873.736450.828376@soggy.deldotd.com>
	(briand@aracnet.com)
References: <20020520073054.GA3461@puddingbowl.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.21.0205200038060.18658-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> <15592.43873.736450.828376@soggy.deldotd.com>
Message-ID: <20020520154701.C439610E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>

 :: >>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:
 :: 
 ::   Jeme> I want to use emacs, but I want to apply regular expressions
 ::   Jeme> to lines as I edit a file.
 :: 
 ::   Jeme> Is that available in default mode emacs?

If I understand what you want, you are looking for M-C-%
which is emacs' regexp search and replace function.

Do:   C-h C-k M-C-%
to get you into the on-line Emacs Manual entry for this command.

If you have some really complicated application it is very easy to
write a "keyboard macro" to do it for you.  Very briefly, C-x ( puts
Emacs into "record keyboard macro" mode. (I'm using "mode" here in
its colloquial, not its Emacs, sense).  Emacs will now remember nearly
any sequence of keystrokes, including multiple M-C-% with changing
arguments, &c.  Close the macro with C-x ).  Now every time you hit
C-x e, the entire sequence is run.  I've done some wonderfully
complicated things this way.  There's much more to this.
Hit C-h C-k C-x ( u to begin learning.

Finally, I hope you have a proper Meta (or Alt) key defined and are
not having to use the ESC-ESC trick. I recently put someone onto
Emacs here in the lab and after a month checked back in on him.
He was using ESC-ESC for all the M- commands (but _still_ using
Emacs, nonetheless---which is a testimony either to his
stupidity or The Power of Emacs). 


Dean

P.S.  There are also ways to apply Unix commands like `sed'
      to individual lines (or regions) if you like, but I think
      M-C-% may be what you are looking for.

P.P.S.  Pay no attention to the riff-raff who try to steer you
        from Emacs to lesser editors :-)

From richard.langis at sun.com  Mon May 20 08:49:02 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Mon, 20 May 2002 08:49:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Considering adding 802.11 to my LAN
References: <1021900369.32542.61.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <3CE91AEE.9060509@sun.com>

Probably the easiest way to do this would be to get a standalone AP (Access 
Point) and a PCMCIA card for your laptop.  Linksys seems to make a good 
product, I believe they support 128-bit encryption (although WEP isn't exactly 
'good' encryption).  I'm using a Dell-branded Orinoco/Lucent RG-1000 and 
Silver 802.11b PCMCIA card in a Inspiron 8100.  I've also got a Linksys PCI 
card in my workstation upstairs.

Another option might be to purchase a PCI card (or PCI/PCMCIA Adapter card and 
a PCMCIA Card) that you can install into your Linux box to act as an AP.  The 
PersonalTelco website has lots of information on this. 
(http://www.personaltelco.net)

Although, you'll probably be just fine grabbing something off-the-shelf from 
whatever Big Electronics Store (tm) that complies with the 802.11b standard. 
I'd personally stay with brands you know, but others may know of better 
solutions for more reasonable prices.

Hope that helps,

-Richard

Jon Jacob wrote:

-----Original Message-----
From: Michael Hall [mailto:mph at puddingbowl.org] 
Sent: Saturday, May 18, 2002 8:27 AM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] fonts in Redhat 7.3


I had the same thing, and it was the usual "AbiWord's god-awful
knock-off truetype" issue.

You can:

a.) Remove AbiWord if you don't use it

b.) Remove the entry for the AbiWord fonts in /etc/X11/fs/config by
commenting out this line:

/usr/share/AbiSuite/fonts

Which will at least keep them out of your way until you use AbiWord and
it goes ahead and adds them to your path anyhow

c.) Get the real Times New Roman, Arial, and a few others that AbiWord
fakes and put them in /usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/TTF since Red Hat has at
least jimmied the aliases on AbiWord's fonts so they'll be used after
the real ones if it can find them. If you must use AbiWord, this is your
best solution.

Between antiword for catting out the .doc's I get to a text file and
OpenOffice for reading .rtf's and others, AbiWord has found its way off
my machine.  Too bad, since it's a passable WordPad substitute, but the
entire font situation (two years in the making, and stubbornly stuck to
despite consistently being the most voted-on bug) will keep it off my
machines until they get around to introducing proper freetype support.

The bug report itself on this particular issue makes for some
interesting reading:

http://bugzilla.abisource.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1030

I sympathize with the developers, who aren't running Burger King

If you do, then this is a normal message that sendmail has accepted a 
message, but doesn't know who the user is (which you say is correct).

Sendmail said, it may be forged.

Yes, it's probably spam. mail.com is a known spamhouse.

No, it doesn't look like they are trying to relay through you. At least, 
not from what you have above.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon May 20 13:30:11 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 20 May 2002 13:30:11 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] IP lookup
In-Reply-To: <3CE9599F.308B9B77@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205201327060.2626-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 20 May 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> Where do I go (on the Internet) to look up who uses a particular IP
> address?

  whois.

  There are three whois servers:

   whois xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx at whois.arin.net		North America
   whois xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx at whois.ripe.net		Europe
   whois xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx at whois.apnic.net	Asia & Pacific Rim

  If that doesn't give you enough informaiton, try the 'host' command (which
does essentially the same thing) but, better yet,
http://www.betterwhois.com.

  nslookup has been deprecated.

Rich

>>>>> "briand" == briand  <briand at aracnet.com> writes:

briand> You have stumbled across the biggest problem with emacs - finding the
briand> name of a command for something you are just sure should exist.  At
briand> this point in human history - if you think that you should be able to
briand> do something in emacs then someone has already written a routine to do

Yes, emacs is to "text editing" what Perl is to "scripting".

What's even more amazing is you can embed a Perl interpreter into an
Emacs process, and pass Emacs data to Perl and Perl objects to Emacs
rather cleanly.  And you can invoke it in command-line mode (to use
Emacs Lisp as a subsystem of Perl) or window mode (to use Perl code as
a subsystem of Emacs).

The mind boggles.

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Mon May 20 16:41:56 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Mon, 20 May 2002 19:41:56 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Reading and writing on different partitions/hard drives
In-Reply-To: <200205202236.g4KMagj23466@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200205202236.g4KMagj23466@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <E179wT1-00012o-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Alex,

It is possible to gain performance this way, but you first have to consider 
the disk IO model/characteristics for the machine...

if you have your web stuff on a separate partition that would be good to 
mount on the faster drive.  the general / partition things are *usually* low 
in IO intensity, /etc, /lib, /boot, etc.

What I normally do (dependent upon the machine and its use) is allocate a 
disk (or volume) specifically for web/net services usually including a 
sandbox for most services as well. (SIDE NOTE: if you run bind, please do so 
in a chroot() sandbox....very easy to do with bind9 but preferrably not on a 
web server). 

I do this because apache/Zope/other goodies can be VERY IO INTENSIVE,
and you don't want a heavily pounded web site to slow down normal system 
resources.

If you have a small apache document root directory, and cgi-bin, etc, 
etc...and you have ALOT of ram, you might want to consider testing a 
ramdisk...basically a mmap()'ed directory so that HTML files are delivered 
from memory rather than disk....much faster...

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Mon May 20 17:43:49 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Mon, 20 May 2002 20:43:49 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Reading and writing on different partitions/hard drives
In-Reply-To: <200205202358.g4KNwRp23585@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200205202358.g4KNwRp23585@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <E179xR4-0001k5-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Alex,

ok....here goes....

What I'm referring to as IO intensive is when there is a disk seek and read 
or disk seek and write, for example opening a HTML page spitting it out to a 
client and closing it....standard webserver stuff...if you have stuff that is 
accessing disk files, standard HTML pages, etc. OR doing alot of logging 
(writing to a log file) -- these are IO procedures....something that is 
pre-compiled, or already loaded into resident memory would not necessarily 
create alot of disk IO, however if such a process is opening a standard file, 
like a template or an include file of some sort, this is where the majority 
of the IO traffic comes into play...you should be able to watch this with 
'top'. --The FreeBSD version (as well as Solaris version) gives IO stats...(I 
screwed up my linux 'top' because I was rebuilding my linux emulator and 
decided to get creative--wrong move) .

The sandbox I was referring to is kindof a BSD-ish jargon term for running a 
process in a jailed environment.  For example: say i have an insecure server 
running on port 65534 called 'hack_me_d' and through the latest in script 
kiddie code, someone causes my horrible server to fall back into a 
shell..boom! they're in...
If the process is running in a sandbox or chroot() jail they would do 
something like:
user at insecure ~ $ cd /
user at insecure / $

when in actuality their REAL position in the filesystem would be something 
like:
/sandbox/insecure/hack_me_d/

((man chroot))

they cannot get outside of the /sandbox/insecure/hack_me_d/ directory tree.

this takes some playing around with source code sometimes but there are alot 
of HOWTOs on this stuff....

If you're running a database on the same box, I would stay away from the 
ramdisk, but they are pretty fast and fun to play with....

A note of caution:
Be very careful what you move around on different partitions....don't put 
/bin on its own partition, same with /lib and /etc...these all have to be 
under / so the machine can boot and recover if necessary..../tmp can be 
linked to /var/tmp if /tmp fills up fast and /var is a big phat 
slice...(Linux systems tend to have bigger / partitions than BSD systems but 
that is a matter of personal preference)

Hope this helps...
-Brian

From rob at euglug.net  Mon May 20 22:03:22 2002
From: rob at euglug.net (Rob Hudson)
Date: 20 May 2002 22:03:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] postfix + spamassassin
In-Reply-To: <20020520095847.C37217@cogit8.org>
References: <20020520095847.C37217@cogit8.org>
Message-ID: <1021957397.27239.10.camel@fuggles>

Reply to self:

Postfix does do header checks _after_ spamassassin filtering.  I added
the following header check:

 /^X-Spam-Flag: YES/     REJECT

And it rejects e-mails with that header, which spamassassin adds if it
attains the required hits (points).

-Rob

On Mon, 2002-05-20 at 09:58, Rob Hudson wrote:
> I got spamassassin working on Postfix (using the spamd/spamc combo).
> It works well.  For now, I'm only adding the words [SPAM] to the
> subject, so I can filter it at my email client.
> 
> If later I just want to drop all those emails, or even reject them,
> does anyone know if the filter comes before the header_checks?
> 
> My thought was to add a header_check for /^Subject: [SPAM]/ or one of
> the spam headers.
> 
> Or does spamassassin have another way to just reject the mails marked
> as spam?
> 
> Thanks,
> Rob

Gah!

OK.  First, to restate yesterday's question in a real-world example:

Somebody sent me a text file that is english prose.  The beginning of each
paragraph started with many spaces.  I wanted to quickly convert all the
spaces at the beginning of a line that began with more than three spaces
into a single tab.

I ended up using vi and typing the familiar:
%s/   */^I/
and that did the trick nicely.

How would this be done in emacs?

Second, I'm having trouble finding a mode that does what I expect it to do
with english prose.

For example, this same file has newlines only at the ends of paragraphs
and between sections (where you'll find two or more consecutive newlines,
one delimiting the paragraph, the next the section).  The wrapping in
text-mode is not using word breaks as the wrap point.  So I type M-q to
try and reset the paragraph using the current line break setting of 70
characters and I get the entire section indented one tab and lines broken
on less-than-70-char word breaks with a complete loss of paragraph
delineation.

Is there a mode for english prose or, more specifically, fiction?

Lastly, if someone could actually point me in the right direction to begin
using Gnus with my existing mbox files and gpg, that'd be fantastic.  I'm
really interested to use that thing.

Thanks again.
Jeme.

From briand at aracnet.com  Mon May 20 23:22:41 2002

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

  Jeme> I ended up using vi and typing the familiar:
  Jeme> %s/   */^I/
  Jeme> and that did the trick nicely.

  Jeme> How would this be done in emacs?

esc %

to access search and replace

3 spaces

then use 

ctrl-Q tab

to enter the tab character.  ctrl-q is the "literal" prefix.  Use it
to enter in control characters.

That should do it.

  Jeme> For example, this same file has newlines only at the ends of
  Jeme> paragraphs and between sections (where you'll find two or more
  Jeme> consecutive newlines, one delimiting the paragraph, the next
  Jeme> the section).  The wrapping in text-mode is not using word
  Jeme> breaks as the wrap point.  So I type M-q to try and reset the
  Jeme> paragraph using the current line break setting of 70
  Jeme> characters and I get the entire section indented one tab and
  Jeme> lines broken on less-than-70-char word breaks with a complete
  Jeme> loss of paragraph delineation.

Does the paragraph begin with indentation ? If it does then emacs is
using that indentation for the whole paragraph.  I'm not actually sure
how you would preserve indentation on the first line only.  As a
matter of fact I looked at the INFO FILE FOR EMACS, and found that, in
theory, it should be possible using the text properties indent.  You
did know that emacs allows text properties, didn't you ?

If it's not filling @ character 70, be sure that the variable
"fill-column" is really truly set to 70.  I know this works because I
use it ALL the time.

ctrl-h v fill-column

  Jeme> Lastly, if someone could actually point me in the right
  Jeme> direction to begin using Gnus with my existing mbox files and
  Jeme> gpg, that'd be fantastic.  I'm really interested to use that
  Jeme> thing.

Can't help you.  I find gnus to be a bit of a pain to use.  I suspect
I use approx .0001% of its potential functionality.

gnus has its very own info file and it is BIG.

Brian

From codeyeti at yahoo.com  Tue May 21 10:25:11 2002
From: codeyeti at yahoo.com (Michael Smith)
Date: Tue, 21 May 2002 10:25:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Where to buy SSL certs?
References: <3CE91AA3.12035.10C8C276@localhost>
Message-ID: <3CEA82F4.168FDFE5@yahoo.com>

The problem with SSL certs is that a browser has a list of Certification
Authorities (CA's) that it allows to sign the certs.  What that means is
that there only is a limited number of organizations out there that sell
them, so they can charge whatever they want.  It's like domain registration
used to be when NSI was the only registrar.

You can self-sign your ssl certificate, but dumb browsers (*cough* IE) will
basically say that your site is a fraudulent site and that your cert
shouldn't be trusted.  Other browsers such as mozilla just make you review
the details of the certificate and then say "OK" to it.  If your
organization are going to be the only ones using this cert, then it isn't a
big deal, and you can sign it yourself.  It won't work for an E-commerce
site or a site intended for the general public because the warnings will
scare them off.

When I was working with the OpenSRS DNS registry system, they were starting
to sell SSL certs.  I would take a look at opensrs.org and check out the
resellers links to see if anybody is offering them currently.

--Mike

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Tue May 21 10:57:15 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
