References: <Pine.LNX.4.33L2.0205201655400.16584-100000@dragon.pdx.osdl.net> <20020521171835.52746.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20020521105715.A166@coopie.coopnkass.com>

Randy;

Would you please provide us with your ``mount'' command and the output of ``dmesg?'' This will help us determine your hardware and get your CD mounted. It may be the case that you are doing something like this:

    mount /dev/cdrom /mnt/cdrom

That should be fine except ``/dev/cdrom'' points to a device that does not exist.

You can get a copy of dmesg by performing the following:

  dmesg > dmesg.txt

This will re-direct the output of the dmesg command to a file for later inclusion to your email.


-Cooper

Subject: [PLUG] Extracting the pid from ps -ax
Message-ID: <3CEA8BF4.A5998052@attbi.com>

The next thing I want to do with my php juke box is to allow for
shutting down a playing mp3 file. I can send a ps -ax command to find
out what the pid is, but I'm having trouble extracting just that number.
I want to use the number so I can create a button that will send kill
(pid).

Can someone suggest a single line command that will extract the pid of
the process that is actually running mpg123 and ignore the processes
related to finding mpg123 in the output of ps?

Here's what I've tried:

ps -ax | grep mpg123

This returns:

 2365 ?        S      0:01 /usr/bin/mpg123
/home/mp3/Classical/BestOfEliotFisk.m
 2369 ?        S      0:00 sh -c ps -ax | grep mpg123
 2371 ?        S      0:00 grep mpg123

Next, I tried:

ps -ax | grep mpg123 | cut -f1

which returns the same thing:

 2365 ?        S      0:01 /usr/bin/mpg123
/home/mp3/Classical/BestOfEliotFisk.m
 2369 ?        S      0:00 sh -c ps -ax | grep mpg123
 2371 ?        S      0:00 grep mpg123

So then I tried:

ps -ax | grep mpg123 | cut -f1 -d' '

which returns nothing, or maybe it returns a space.

Trying:

ps -ax | grep mpg123 | tr -s ' ' ' ' | cut -f1 -d' '

doesn't change anything.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

  pid=`ps -C $target -o pid=`
to get PID of $target in a bash script.

From rseymour at spamcop.net  Tue May 21 11:09:30 2002
From: rseymour at spamcop.net (Richard F Seymour)
Date: Tue, 21 May 2002 11:09:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Extracting the pid from ps -ax
References: <3CEA8BF4.A5998052@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3CEA8D5A.1020800@spamcop.net>

You could try:

ps ax | grep mpg123 | awk '{print $1}'


or to exclude the grep line itself:

ps ax | grep [m]pg123 | awk '{print $1}'


There's a better way to do my second try, but I can't remember it.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue May 21 11:12:47 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)

Subject: [PLUG] Extracting the pid from ps -ax

On Tue, 21 May 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> Can someone suggest a single line command that will extract the pid
> of the process that is actually running mpg123 and ignore the
> processes related to finding mpg123 in the output of ps?

See the pidof(8) man page for the gory details.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue May 21 11:22:24 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 21 May 2002 11:22:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] More Emacs.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205202206400.4482-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205202206400.4482-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <86g00l5pjz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> Gah!

Jeme> OK.  First, to restate yesterday's question in a real-world
Jeme> example:

Jeme> Somebody sent me a text file that is english prose.  The
Jeme> beginning of each paragraph started with many spaces.  I wanted
Jeme> to quickly convert all the spaces at the beginning of a line
Jeme> that began with more than three spaces into a single tab.

Jeme> I ended up using vi and typing the familiar: %s/ */^I/ and that
Jeme> did the trick nicely.

Jeme> How would this be done in emacs?

Here's what I'd do.

M-x replace-regexp

At 'Replace regexp:' prompt: ^[ ]+\([^ ]\)
At `with:' prompt type C-q C-i (inserting a tab character), then: \1

Jeme> Second, I'm having trouble finding a mode that does what I
Jeme> expect it to do with english prose.

Jeme> For example, this same file has newlines only at the ends of
Jeme> paragraphs and between sections (where you'll find two or more
Jeme> consecutive newlines, one delimiting the paragraph, the next the
Jeme> section).  The wrapping in text-mode is not using word breaks as
Jeme> the wrap point.  So I type M-q to try and reset the paragraph
Jeme> using the current line break setting of 70 characters and I get
Jeme> the entire section indented one tab and lines broken on
Jeme> less-than-70-char word breaks with a complete loss of paragraph
Jeme> delineation.

Jeme> Is there a mode for english prose or, more specifically,
Jeme> fiction?

I don't quite parse your description.  It sounds like you are saying
there are single new-lines between paragraphs and double new-lines
between sections.  If so, you'll probably want to replace single
new-lines with double new-lines.  Maybe something like:

  M-x replace-string
  at the "Replace string:' prompt, type C-q C-j
  at the "with:" prompt, type C-q C-j C-q C-j

That will provide the necessary spacing for M-q to do its work.

BTW, I wasn't aware that "english prose" had a standard format, beyond
text-mode, such that a special mode could be designed for it.  You
don't say what you intend to do with the material.  Does it need to go
back into that format before it goes back to your friend?

Jeme> Lastly, if someone could actually point me in the right
Jeme> direction to begin using Gnus with my existing mbox files and
Jeme> gpg, that'd be fantastic.  I'm really interested to use that
Jeme> thing.

There is a section in the Gnus info document (well hidden) that
describes the steps to go through.  I'll see if I can dig it up.

Is it Mandrake?  I had a similar problem with Mandrake 8.2
I found that the automounter was calling my cdrom0, cdrom3 and creating a 
link in /dev  from /dev/cdrom to dev/cdroms/cdrom3.  I had to hack around it, 
though perhaps I should have just turned off the automounting.

In-Reply-To: <3CEA8BF4.A5998052@attbi.com>

Message-ID: <1022008614.21445.7.camel@pookie>

You can also do this:

ps -e -o pid -o command | grep -v grep | grep mpg123

Experiment with the `-o' switch; you will find it to be a good switch
for filtering process lines.

The `grep -v grep' part strips out the grep process. Here's an example I
ran using Netscape as an argument for grep without the -v switch:

 628 netscape
 1356 grep netscape

When I added ``grep -v grep,' I get this, the correct answer:

 628 netscape


-Cooper

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Tue May 21 12:26:23 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 21 May 2002 12:26:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Extracting the pid from ps -ax (ADDENDUM)
In-Reply-To: <1022008614.21445.7.camel@pookie>
References: <3CEA8BF4.A5998052@attbi.com>  <1022008614.21445.7.camel@pookie>
Message-ID: <1022009183.21445.11.camel@pookie>

Here's an addendum to my previous post. The following will strip out the
name of the process leaving only the process number. This is capable of
running in a heterogeneous environment:

ps -e -o pid -o command | grep -v grep | grep mpg123 | awk `{ print $1
}'

Pay special attention to the direction of the ticks.


-Cooper

From JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us  Tue May 21 12:39:53 2002
From: JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us (Miller, Jeremy)
Date: Tue, 21 May 2002 12:39:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SB Audigy Experiences ?
Message-ID: <51AE6EA505FCD111AB5600805F653ACB010AA12C@EXCHANGE>

Don't have an audigy, but I do have an SBLive Platinum.  Works fine (of
course) but I REALLY wish I'd done more research before I bought it, because
there are a ton of cards that would have been better for what I need.

What do you intend to use the card for?  Playing music?  Games?  Do you plan
on using it for any recording or midi work?

The SB Live and Audigy are great for playing music, games, sampling, and
midi.  But not as great for recording.  (Even the Audigy is limited to
recording at 48khz 16bit. Don't be misled by the 24/96 playback specs. :)
I'm currently debating whether to get a Midiman Delta series or bite the
bullet for an RME Multiface.  (Overkill for most, but would have been a
better use of my money in the long run.)

Anyway, I just wanted to point out that if you just need a standard card for
regular things, the SB cards are great.  Get one.  In particular the OEM
version is the best deal.

But... if you intend on doing any recording and are thinking about shelling
out bigger bucks for the Platinum, DON'T.  Look around first, because you'll
get more for your money with something else, like a Midiman or even an
ST-Audio product.  (Most of them have good linux drivers, at least in ALSA.
There are others, too.)

Here's a review I just found, that says it better than I can.

http://music.multimedian.com/reviews/audigy.html)


Jeremy

1. Downloaded the 2.4.18 kernel from kernel.org (tarball style, into
/usr/src)
2. Unzipped, then unpacked the tarball
3. Backed up my modules file, just in case
4. Made sure I was in /usr/src/linux-2.4.18 directory
5. Executed #make config and make dep commands
6. Than ran make bzImage
7. Rna #make clean
8. Began looking for a file named bzImage, vmlinuz or z Image

Terry,

  I've no idea where you are located, but the Portland "Oregonian" had
another column today by Steve Duin on Microsoft's heavy-handed tactics with
schools across the country. Many systems (including one in Iowa) are saving
hundreds of thousands of dollars by moving to linux from Windows.

  IDG's linux report had a link to an article on the increasing costs of
Microsoft licenses. They say it will only get worse.

  Uptime and stability ought to be secondary issues; they are probably not
as intuitively important to digitally impaired decision makers. Talk about
the cost of purchase -- er, annual rent -- and the costs of lost time and
productivity caused by Microsoft virii and worms. One of the articles I
scanned this week had a rough total cost of ownership comparison that was
greater than 50%.

Good luck,

Rich

Stuart;

Drop the 'make clean' command at the end. Observe:

root at linux-enterprise:/usr/src/linux/arch/i386/boot# ls
    
    Makefile    bbootsect.o  bootsect.S  bsetup.o  bzImage     
    install.sh  tools/
    bbootsect*  bbootsect.s  bsetup*     bsetup.s  compressed/ 
    setup.S     video.S
    
root at linux-enterprise:/usr/src/linux# make clean

root at linux-enterprise:/usr/src/linux/arch/i386/boot# ls

    Makefile  bootsect.S  compressed/  install.sh  setup.S  tools/ 
    video.S
    
-Cooper

When I bought this system a few months ago, the plan was to include a 
high-end card tbd.  As time went by, money dwindled, and I've had no 
luck getting the on-board sound working.  Been using a cheaper SB in 
the mp3 fileserver, but a PII-333 takes forever to rip a 2Gb wav 
(24hrs, to be precise).  The new system did the same job in 2hrs.

Right now, all I am doing is occasional recording of radio broadcasts, 
which is fairly lo-fi.  I don't need mic pre-amps either (a Mackie 
mixer does that very well.)  Soon will be transferring lps to cd so 
recording fidelity is ultimately important.

I know the Live! card has been out for awhile and is fairly well 
supported, and the oem price may be enough to tempt me until more 
money shows up.

There's probably other reasons as well, but IE is partially loaded all the 
time Windows is running. Since IE uses many of the same dlls that Explorer 
(the windows window manager) uses, it doesn't have to load everything from 
disk, much of it is already in memory.

From bdhruva at gmx.net  Tue May 21 15:34:34 2002
From: bdhruva at gmx.net (Dhruva B. Reddy)
Date: Tue, 21 May 2002 16:34:34 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Another web browser
In-Reply-To: <319FB8934F09BF48A3F3228370882667385F6C@wsimail.worksystems.org>
References: <319FB8934F09BF48A3F3228370882667385F6C@wsimail.worksystems.org>
Message-ID: <20020521223434.GO16771@dr.mobizinc.com>

Assuming you are talking about Mozilla on Windoze, I can think of a
couple of reasons.  Internet Explorer is integrated with Winschmoes
(although you will never convince it is inextricably so), and it is
designed to run only on Winblows.

Mozilla, on the other hand, uses a widget framework (the name eludes
me) that is designed more for cross-platform compatibility than
performance.

In other words, IE sacrifices cross-platform compatibility for speed,
and Mozilla vice-versa, although it has improved performance by leaps
and bounds.

Dhruva

> These dillo posts make me wonder: why does MS Internet Explorer load
> faster than Mozilla?

My guess:  because MS Internet Explorer is tightly integrated with the core,
there are probably dll's or something similar resident in memory whenever
you use it, thus not requiring them to be loaded.

I once freaked out a girlfriend with this integration.  Netscape kept
crashing, but she insisted that she didn't have IE on her computer.  I
opened up Windows Explorer, typed in the URL for Yahoo!, et voila!, it
morphed into IE.

> > faster than Mozilla?
> 
> My guess:  because MS Internet Explorer is tightly integrated with the core,
> there are probably dll's or something similar resident in memory whenever
> you use it, thus not requiring them to be loaded.
> 
That is exactly it. Basically, when you start Windows, 80% of IE is
already loaded -- everything except the executable. That's why Mozilla
gives the option of "partially" loading on login: so that it can load as
fast on-demand as IE does.

Sean

> 
> As does this. This one seems the cleanest, too. As with many things in
> Linux, there is often more than one way to get something done.

Either pidof or pgrep will do what you'd like, but the CLEANEST way to
handle this sort of thing is to capture the pid when you exec mpg123 in
the first place and store it for later use.

other OS's that give low-level and background processes higher priority

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue May 21 16:28:22 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue, 21 May 2002 16:28:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] complex expressions with egrep
In-Reply-To: <1022016494.1998.10.camel@red>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205211625390.19848-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 21 May 2002, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> I have log files that I want to grep to extract only log
> entries that meet the following requirement:
> 
> string1 and (string2 or string3)

Russell's note on whether or not string1 should come before, after, or
either is important when designing a SINGLE regexp to match this.

> grep "string2|string3" logfile | grep "string1"
> 
> Is there a better way?

Yes.

There's probably also a BEST way, but the BETTER way that leaps
immediately to mind is:

grep string1 logfile|grep "string2|string3"

That way, you're not doing the OR for every line when you are going to
discard the ones that don't match string1 anyway.  Of course, I can
imagine that with a very complext string1, you'll get better performance
the other way.  So yymv, I suppose.

J.

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205211625390.19848-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205211625390.19848-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <867klxxdte.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> There's probably also a BEST way, but the BETTER way that leaps
Jeme> immediately to mind is:

Jeme> grep string1 logfile|grep "string2|string3"

Jeme> That way, you're not doing the OR for every line when you are
Jeme> going to discard the ones that don't match string1 anyway.  Of
Jeme> course, I can imagine that with a very complext string1, you'll
Jeme> get better performance the other way.  So yymv, I suppose.

In "database land", they call this sort of thing "query optimization".

Quite. :)

>  Soon will be transferring lps to cd so 
> recording fidelity is ultimately important.

An SBLive is probably just fine for that... considering that it a one-time
transfer of an existing recording (rather than a live source that is going
to see a lot of manipulation).  An Audigy wouldn't buy you any benefit over
the Live for that, really.  But the SBLive would do the trick.  If you add
better interface later, it can still do midi/sampling duty.  (And system
sounds, and games and whatever else the pro card won't do.)

> I know the Live! card has been out for awhile and is fairly well 
> supported, and the oem price may be enough to tempt me until more 
> money shows up.

They ARE fairly cheap (<$40), and if you record at 16/48 it isn't that bad,
quality wise. That's what I've been using so far, and it's fine for that.  I
wish I'd gone OEM instead of the Platinum, though. It's not worth the extra
dough.  (BTW the advertised "24/96 DAC performance" of the Audigy drives me
nuts... it's DA only! Not AD! Just a tad misleading!)

To upgrade from that level takes semi-pro gear and can cost a pretty penny.
(Though some are actually less than the Platinum versions of SB stuff.)
Here's a few I know off the top of my head, to give an idea of the market,
from entry to pro-level.  (Prices pulled from bayviewproaudio.com)  Hope
this isn't overkill or OT, but I've been looking at this stuff a LOT just
the last few weeks.

I'm listing mainly 3 brands because I've looked into them before and they
have linux drivers.  (Many pro/semi-pro cards don't.)  ST Audio is the
cheapest, but not as good sound quality as the others.  RME is pretty
serious high-end gear.  M-Audio is a nice in-between.  Both M-Audio and RME
alsa appear to be pretty supportive of linux drivers, and advertise (and
link to ALSA) from their websites.


16/48 Stereo (SB's weren't listed at bayview.  Prices from bestbuy.com...
could do much better.)
-----------------------
$70	SB Live
$100	SB Audigy
$200	SB Audigy Platinum


24/96 Stereo
-----------------------
$175	ST Audio DSP24 Value
$179	M-Audio Audiophile 2496
$189	TerraTec EWX 24/96


24/96 Multiple Channel
-------------------------
$199  Midiman Delta 410 (4in/10out - sortof... 2 analog inputs, 2 digital)
$229	ST Audio DSP24 MKII (2in/out - upgradeable, see below)
$229	Midiman Delta 44 (4in/4out - all analog on breakout box)
$289	ST Audio DS2000 (8in/out breakout box - requires DSP24 MKII)
$299	Midiman Delta 66 (6in/out - 4 analog on same breakout box as 44, 2
digital)
$379	Midiman Delta 1010LT (10in/out - 8 analog)
$439	ST Audio DSP2000 CPort (8in/out - DSP24 + DS2000)
$599	Midiman Delta 1010 (10in/out - 8 analog all on 19" rackmount
breakout).
  |-- I see these brand new from Ebay retailers for $500-520 all the time.
$260	RME Hammerfall DSP Interface (PCI card, requires Multiface or
Digiface)
$315	RME Hammerfall DSP Interface (Cardbus for laptops, requires
Multiface or Digiface)
$575	RME Digiface (3 ADAT, 1 SPDIF on breakout - requires PCI or Cardbus
interface)
$725	RME Multiface (8in/out analog, 1 ADAT, 1 SPDIF on breakout -
requires PCI or Cardbus interface)
$985	RME Multiface Package (Multiface + Hammerfall DSP - PCI version)

... and up.  (Say, a complete RME Digiface system plus $thousands for
standalone AD/DA converters or a digital mixer, and so on.  If you're at
this level you're probably spending more than that on fancy microphones and
preamps anyway! :)

From lemming at attbi.com  Tue May 21 18:10:36 2002
From: lemming at attbi.com (lemming at attbi.com)
Date: Wed, 22 May 2002 01:10:36 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] clear packet counters?
Message-ID: <20020522011037.WIJP11183.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@rwcrwbc56>

Well, you could do it this way:
-------
ifdown eth0
rmmod e100 (If you network module is e100)
ifup eth0
------
Of course doing this while using the card is not a good 
idea, though you can run this as a script and most of 
the time you'll stay connected.

From sharbours at yahoo.com  Tue May 21 19:02:58 2002
From: sharbours at yahoo.com (Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour)
Date: Tue, 21 May 2002 19:02:58 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Regular expressions
Message-ID: <20020522020258.92368.qmail@web14405.mail.yahoo.com>

Help! I'm having a hard time grasping regular expressions.

Given an example like this:

(^|)(one|two|three|four)?

"one" is not a match, but "one two" or "three four" are.

Why does it only match 2 or more combinations of the second atom?

The way I read it, the first atom translates as:

Null character representing the beginning of a string (Where the
following word in the next atom would count as 1 string) and/or null

The second atom translates simply as:

string "one" and/or string "two" and/or string "three" and/or string
"four" with a modifier meaning return true only if zero or one
matches .

And how would I get it to match only 3 or more combinations?

I'm trying for a plain english translation so my poor old brain can
understand the logic behind the madness...or should I reverse that
last statement? AHHG!

Sean Harbour

From ross at principia.edu  Tue May 21 19:49:06 2002
From: ross at principia.edu (Ross Brattain)
Date: 21 May 2002 19:49:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Extracting the pid - Resolved
In-Reply-To: <3CEAE535.CE3E7FC9@attbi.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205211612530.19848-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
	<3CEAE535.CE3E7FC9@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <87n0us28yl.fsf@maas-neotek.attbi.com>

Richard Steffens <rsteff at attbi.com> writes:

> 
> But, since this whole thing is intended to be a learning experience
> (along with providing a way to send mp3 music to my stereo), how would I
> capture the pid when I exec mpg123?
> 

In a shell $! is the PID of the last backgrounded process.
So a shell script wrapper that background mpg123 and saves $! might
work.

example:
#!/bin/bash

mpg123 $* &
echo $!


-Ross

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue May 21 21:37:37 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 21 May 2002 21:37:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Regular expressions
In-Reply-To: <20020522020258.92368.qmail@web14405.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205212126580.27283-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Tue, 21 May 2002, Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour wrote:

> Given an example like this:
> 
> (^|)(one|two|three|four)?
> 
> "one" is not a match, but "one two" or "three four" are.

What regex engine did you use for testing? Perl? sed? [e]grep? In
Perl, that regex would match any single string or line in a file; same
with egrep and sed, though the latter wouldn't be able to comprehend
it unless you escaped the metacharacters.

In every case, it should match the beginning of the line/string. Since 
the second group is entirely optional -- and since you don't rule out 
duplicate strings by anchoring the end of the string -- there are no 
disqualifying strings.

Can you post the file/stdin that you passed to the regex engine and 
the exact invocation of the utility you used to match it?

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

On Sat, 18 May 2002 07:41:26 GMT
Paul Harris <pharris at iname.com> wrote:

>  Anything like
> "more" or "less" that works for directories rather than files?

I often want to see only directories, and this is the way I do it:

$ ls -l | egrep ^d | less

Alternatively, if you don't like the long listing:

$ ls -l | egrep \/$ | less

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Wed May 22 00:44:53 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Wed, 22 May 2002 00:44:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] "who pays these people" [for open-source software]?
References: <003201c2015f$886cd570$6401a8c0@endeavor>
Message-ID: <3CEB4C75.5020203@pacifier.com>

Greg Long wrote:
> I found an interesting article, which does raise, and essentially answer
> a good question for current and future software engineers like myself.
> 
> http://www.infoworld.com/articles/op/xml/01/11/19/011119opsource.xml
> 
> Even considering the current recession, which is perhaps at its worst in
> the IT field, I still see (just as an example) a lot of kids buying PS2
> and gameboy games and countless products designed with tons of code.
> There will surely still be the need for a lot of custom and other
> development.


Thank the GPL.  Folks at big companies that adopt GNU/Linux have a 
legal obligation (and most of them know it) to contribute back.  They 
pay good money for  highly-skilled (and some not-so-skilled) 
programmers to develop products that make use of OSS.

The big companies that "get it" use this to leverage hipness, not to 
mention shareholder-happiness.  Some lawyers are not so comfortable 
with the GPL and if they work for a large enough company, create 
variations of the license which are generally acceptable.

Considering the alternatives, OSS is an automatic win for many 
companies.  Bottom line: they need people that know Linux.

--
Kyle Accardi

Hello,

Does anyone know of a way to install OpenOffice (or StarOffice - from
now on i'll just say OpenOffice, but this applies to both) on a computer
in such a way that all users automatically have icons in their menu's
which will open the program (and preferably so the 2 MB ~/OpenOffice
directory from "Workstation Install" is not needed)?

This is for school computers, which have lots of users (who are K-8) -
so having each user run the install is out of the question IMHO. 


I thought about just doing the "workstation install" for one user and
then moving the ~/OpenOffice directory which was created to say, /opt/,
and then making a symlink from each users ~/OpenOffice/ to
/opt/OpenOffice/, but it seems that the username is repeated quite often
in files within ~/OpenOffice.  And it seems that OpenOffice checks for
~/OpenOffice and starts the installer if that directory isn't found.

Any ideas on this?


Thanks,

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed May 22 05:23:29 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 22 May 2002 05:23:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] display options
In-Reply-To: <20020521225755.0cc04054.kevinh@ados.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205220515170.27283-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Tue, 21 May 2002, Kevin Hammack wrote:

> I often want to see only directories, and this is the way I do it:
> 
> $ ls -l | egrep ^d | less

This recipe won't show dotfiles (e.g., .mozilla or .kde) unless you 
also pass the '-a' option to ls.

> Alternatively, if you don't like the long listing:
> 
> $ ls -l | egrep \/$ | less

This one only works if the '-F' option is passed to ls somehow (i.e.,
in an alias).

Or you could use find, which arguably is more suited to this sort of 
task. All of the recipes below could also be piped into less:

# show the names of directories occuring in the current directory
find . -type d -maxdepth 1
# show 'ls -l' info about them
find . -type d -maxdepth 1 -exec ls -ld {} \;
# find all directories in current directory or below
find . -type d
# show 'ls -l' info about all of 'em
find . -type d -exec ls -ld {} \;

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed May 22 08:05:49 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 22 May 2002 08:05:49 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OpenOffice/StarOffice system wide install?
In-Reply-To: <1022061492.584.22.camel@sharky>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205220758540.15878-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On 22 May 2002, Peter W wrote:

> Does anyone know of a way to install OpenOffice (or StarOffice - from now
> on i'll just say OpenOffice, but this applies to both) on a computer in
> such a way that all users automatically have icons in their menu's which
> will open the program (and preferably so the 2 MB ~/OpenOffice directory
> from "Workstation Install" is not needed)?

  I'll tell you what I did here and you can decide if it will work for you.

  I installed OO-1.0.1 in an nfs-shared filesystem, /usr1/. The installation
routine (I *think* it was workstation that I selected) placed the startup
script in:

/usr1/open-office/OpenOffice.org1.0/program/soffice

  Then I created a soft link on each workstation that pointed to this file;
e.g.,

[rshepard at salmo ~]$ ls -l /usr/local/bin/soffice 
lrwxrwxrwx   1 root     root           51 May  8 18:14 /usr/local/bin/soffice ->
/usr1/open-office/OpenOffice.org1.0/program/soffice*

  Finally, I pointed the appropriate icon for each user's copy of xfce to
'soffice'. Because /usr/local/bin/ is in each user's $PATH, it's found and
another instance of OO is opened.

  I've no idea if this is the "right" way, the "best" way or anything other
than it works. And, I have OO in a single directory where upgrades will be
easy to manage.

HTH,

Rich




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed May 22 08:30:59 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 22 May 2002 08:30:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OpenOffice/StarOffice system wide install?
In-Reply-To: <1022061492.584.22.camel@sharky>
References: <1022061492.584.22.camel@sharky>
Message-ID: <200205220830.59813.aschlemm@attbi.com>

After OpenOffice has been installed, it is possible for other users to 
install the necessary files in their home directory by running the 
"soffice" shell script. Users only need to do a "Workstation 
Installation" which installs something like 2.1 MB worth of files to 
their home directory. You don't want them doing a local install since 
that takes something like 210MB of disk space. 

As far as I can tell, the OpenOffice installation program only runs from 
the "soffice" command if no "OpenOffice.org1.0 directory is found 
within a user's home directory.

Tony

> 'soffice'. Because /usr/local/bin/ is in each user's $PATH, it's found and
> another instance of OO is opened.
> 
>   I've no idea if this is the "right" way, the "best" way or anything other
> than it works. And, I have OO in a single directory where upgrades will be
> easy to manage.

> HTH,

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Wed May 22 09:12:18 2002
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Wed, 22 May 2002 09:12:18 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] "No medium found"
In-Reply-To: <E17AELf-0006T7-00@atlantic.mail.pas.earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <20020522161218.46847.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>

--- Rick Konold <cccs at teleport.com> wrote:
It may be the case that you are doing
> something like this:
> > |
> > |     mount /dev/cdrom /mnt/cdrom
> > |
> > | That should be fine except ``/dev/cdrom'' points
> to a device that does
> > | not exist.
> > |
I'd like to thank everyone who responded for their
helpful comments. My HP7950 has two optical drives, as
many newer computers do. When I checked /etc/fstab, it
became evident that the DVD drive was linked to
/dev/cdrom, and the CD-RW did not appear at all. When
I placed a disk in the tray of the CD-RW, the computer
didn't find anything there because it was looking in
the other tray.

It is possible to use the CD-RW for conventional
reads, although it is unnecessary to do so, by
referencing it by its real name:

mount -t iso9660 /dev/sr0 /mnt/cdrom

assuming, of course, that the DVD drive is not mounted
there already!

The construction of the fstab file seems to be
somewhat capricious, varying from one distribution to
the next. It is a good idea to examine it carefully.

Actually, I'm not sure. I've been using Visual REGEXP 2.2 to test
with on my Mandrake 8.2 workstation. The observed behavior seems to
be exactly what I see from the production Mandrake 8.1 servers using
this statement in the expression list on squidGuard 1.2. What I've
been doing is taking the expression list straight from Eric's
/squidGuard/blacklists/adult/expressions and trying to figure out how
and why it works. You probably want to grab a copy directly from
Eric's site, but here is a sanitized version:

(one|two|three)
(^|[-.\?+=/_0-9])(four|five|six)?(seven|eight|nine?|ten|el?ven)s?(twelve|thirteen|fourteen)?([-.\?+=/_0-9]|$)

Sample input:
http://groups.google.com/groups?q=one+two+three&ie=UTF8&oe=UTF8&hl=en&btnG=Google+Search
http://groups.google.com/groups?hl=en&lr=&ie=UTF8&oe=UTF8&q=nineteen+ten+eleven&btnG=Google+Search
http://groups.google.com/groups?hl=en&lr=&ie=UTF8&oe=UTF8&q=one+ten+twelve&btnG=Google+Search

Observed behavior:
A URL with any single pattern matching the first line will always
match.
A URL with any two matches from seven through el?ven on the second
line will always match.
Four through six don't seem to match anything.
Twelve through fourteen I have not verified as matching anything
either.

Sean Harbour

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed May 22 10:08:43 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 22 May 2002 10:08:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat 7.3 and SCSI AIC7XX
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20020522091953.00b42dc8@localhost>
References: <5.1.0.14.0.20020522091953.00b42dc8@localhost>
Message-ID: <200205221008.43686.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I don't use RedHat but I believe that scsi_hostadapter is an alias in 
the /etc/modules.conf file. 

The first thing I notice is that you have "scsi _hostadapter". Did you 
type the error message into your email or did your cut and paste it? 
The correct name is "scsi_hostadapter with no space between "scsi" and 
the underscore. If you did cut and paste then it appears that perhaps 
the alias name is wrong in the /etc/modules.conf file. Remove the extra 
space and then run "depmod -a" to update the modules.dep file.

Another possible fix:

If you find that the AIC7xxx kernel module is being loaded correctly, 
try adding the following line in your /etc/modules.conf file:

alias scsi_hostadapter off

Once you've updated the /etc/modules.conf file run the command:
"depmod -a". Note that you'll need to be logged in as "root" to perform 
both of these steps. By aliasing the scsi_hostadapter to be off kmod 
will not attempt to load the module and the error will go away. I have 
this alias line in my /etc/modules.conf file and my system still 
manages to load the AIC7xxx module for my Adaptec controller.

Tony

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed May 22 10:29:00 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 22 May 2002 10:29:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] quickie iptables log scan scripts
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205221015190.28925-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

With all the reports of that SQL Server script the kiddiez are using 
these days -- and the continued Code Red scans that hit my box -- I'd 
thought I'd whip up a couple little tools to give me some stats.

1. Produce list of all hosts that send me packets I don't want, sorted 
   by frequency of unwanted packets, useful for spotting the worst 
   individual hosts:

   #!/bin/sh

   grep 'SRC=' /var/log/messages* | \
   sed 's!.*SRC=\(.*\) DST=.*!\1!' | \
   sort | \
   uniq -c | \
   sort -nr

2. Same list, sorted by ip address, useful to see if certain nets are 
   esp. bad:

   #!/bin/sh

   grep 'SRC=' /var/log/messages* | \
   sed 's!.*SRC=\(.*\) DST=.*!\1!' | \
   sort  -n -t. -k 1,1 -k 2,2 -k 3,3 -k 4,4 | \
   uniq -c

3. Sorta sorted list of those hosts, this time with per-port 
   statistics, useful for spotting scans. Run this perl script against 
   /var/log/messages*:

   #!/usr/bin/perl -w

   while ( <> ) {
     my ( $host, $port ) = /^.+ SRC=([^\s]+) DST=.+ DPT=(\d+) \w.*$/;
     next unless $host and $port;
     $list{$host}{$port}++;
   }

   foreach my $host ( sort keys %list ) {
     print qq/$host: /;
     print join( ', ', map { "$_ ($list{$host}{$_})" }
                           sort keys %{ $list{$host} }
           );
     print "\n";
   }

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From dealy at deatech.com  Wed May 22 11:13:27 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Wed, 22 May 2002 11:13:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] display options
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205221030270.28925-100000@billings.heinlein.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205221048040.5854-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Wed, 22 May 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> On Wed, 22 May 2002, Longman, Bill wrote:
>
> > If you want to fork fewer processes just to find directories, why
> > not do this:
> >
> > ls -ld */
>
> I can't get this to show hidden directories, even if I pass ls the -a
> switch. Am I missing something?

The usual default in bash is that "*" does not match on file names with
a leading ".", you have to play with the settings of "dotglob" and "GLOBIGNORE"
in your shell environment to change this behaviour.  I prefer a different
approach to this problem:

   find . -maxdepth 1 -type d

and if you want something similar to the "ls -l" output, the "-ls" option to
find will give a somewhat more verbose version of it, or alternatively,
the "-printf" options used with it's format modifiers can be used to give
exactly the output you want without spawning a bunch of sub-processes or
playing with regular expressions.

I don't know what sort of setup you have Rich so this may not help you 
at all...

Does the system "salmo" have a public DNS entry? It may be that Qwest 
considers the message to be from an unknown host or domain and rejects 
it as spam. I remember going through something similar with rejected 
emails with sendmail long ago. 

At the time my system's sendmail process couldn't send anything directly 
to some other domain since my local system, which was on a dialup PPP 
connection, didn't have any sort of public hostname and domain 
available via DNS. In the end I had to setup my sendmail configuration 
so my local sendmail process would relay through my ISP's mail server. 
This fixed my problem since my ISP's mail server recognized my system 
and my ISP's mail server was publicly recognized.

Tony

>   Anyway, I suspected it was trapped by either headers_check or body_check.
> So I tested my theory (as all good scientists do). Commented out the calls
> to those two files and reloaded postfix. The spam reports went out (one to
> qwest, the other a new and also bounced spam to icgcom.com).
> 
>   Which modifies my first question to this: if the subject or body content
> was identified as spam as I tried to report the spam, why wasn't it caught
> on its way in? I suspect this has to do with the sequence of checks in
> /etc/postfix/main.cf:
> 
> smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
>         check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/badip,
>         check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/badaddr,
>         permit_mynetworks,
>         check_relay_domains
> #header_checks = regexp:/etc/postfix/header_checks
> #body_checks = regexp:/etc/postfix/body_checks
> 
>   As a tyro mail administrator I may be clueless how to get all the checks
> and traps to work properly.

For one thing, you should move permit_mynetworks above the
check_client_access lines.  None of your outgoing mail will ever be
caught by them then, and you can selectively allow mail in from
RBL-listed hosts (if you're using something like ORDB).  

Perhaps it was missed on the way in because you've got something in
body_checks that wasn't in header_checks; when you forwarded the message
(with full headers, I hope), you moved something from headers to body.

Wil

On Wed, 2002-05-22 at 12:33, Dylan Reinhardt wrote:

> called by hyperlinks?  

If you are running GNOME, try going to:
Settings > Document Handlers > Default Applications 
and in there go to the "Web Browser" tab and it lets you tell it which
browser to use as the default GNOME one (which i think is what Evolution
uses).  If you for some reason don't have that menu or something, the
actual program that it runs is "default-application-properties-capplet".

hth.

From JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us  Wed May 22 13:37:38 2002
From: JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us (Miller, Jeremy)
Date: Wed, 22 May 2002 13:37:38 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SB Audigy Experiences ?
Message-ID: <51AE6EA505FCD111AB5600805F653ACB010AA131@EXCHANGE>

Warning:  Since you say you DO want to get into hard disk recording
eventually, this might be a little long. :)

(And hopefully a REAL audio person or DSP programmer doesn't scream at me if
I'm getting parts of it wrong or slightly off-key.  I'm just trying to get
the basic idea across, and probably butchering some details in the process.
If anyone has corrections or clarifications, please do. :)

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Kyle Accardi [mailto:sandbox at pacifier.com]
> Sent: Tuesday, May 21, 2002 11:05 PM
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: Re: [PLUG] SB Audigy Experiences ?
> 
> 

<<snip>>

> Help me understand what you are saying.  How is a capture from an lp 
> less subject to post-processing than a live signal?  I'm likely to 
> manipulate either depending on need: de-pop, reverb, etc.  Which, as 
> far as I know, is done in software and with no regard to the 
> soundcard's capabilities, no?  (or are you talking about bouncing to 
> out-board effects processors?)

Well, I was going under the assumption (whoops) that you wouldn't be doing
much post-processing.  Pulling out clicks and pops isn't much, because it
isn't really altering the overall signal... that's basically just trimmming
out spikes and peaks in the waveform.  But reverb definitely changes the
signal, and uses lots of heavy math.  (As do most effects: chorus,
compression, distortion, phasing/filters, eq, etc.)  I guess it sort of
depends on what you want the recording for.


CASE 1:  You want to archive your albums or do a somewhat permanent transfer
to CD.

I would definitely de-pop, but consider skipping the reverb or anything
else.  At least for one master copy of each.  Why?

1.  That part is going to take a loooong time.  You won't want to have to do
it again if you change your mind. :)  If you make a clean master, you can
use it the same way any other CD.  (Rip to disk, add effects, convert to mp3
or burn a copy for listening, etc.  If you change your mind, you just work
with the master again, without waiting 1hour or so for another A/D
conversion.

2.  CDR's are dirt cheap.  Make clean masters, and just keep them stored
with the albums.

3.  Different sound systems (everything in consumer range) can sound WAY
different from each other.  Be aware of that, and careful when deciding to
"remaster" anything unless you have flat-response speakers or studio
monitors to eliminate that possibility.  (I guarantee the person who
mastered it originally did, and they aren't cheap.)  You can play around all
you want with copies, and have something to fall back on when the mix that
sounds beatiful on the computer (and maybe even the home stereo) sounds like
crap in your car.  Or your friend's house.

--This whole part (3) maybe isn't quite as important for your album
transfers... but it is extremely important when you start doing any
hard-disk recording.  Just a heads up, there.  You CAN do it without real
monitors (sortof) but it is hard.  You need a ton of practice in recognizing
the way your own "monitors" color the sound, which means taking a mix you've
made and trying it out in everthing else you can get your hands on and
noting the differences.  In fact even engineers with real monitors sometimes
do the same thing with other monitors and even consumer systems just to make
sure. :)


CASE 2:  You're not that interested in archival/permanent transfer/high
quality for your album transfer.  You just want a darned copy on CD that
sounds good on your equipment (really all most people want).

Rip away, and don't worry about any of that crap I just went on about!  An
exccelent program for doing exactly that (ripping lp albums to disk) in
linux is gramofile.  It'll record and automatically split tracks out and can
do filtering to get rid of pops and hiss.  (Works good on tapes, too.)  The
only possible drawback is that it is limited to 16 bit recording.  (But not
a big deal if all you're not doing any effects or other processing.)  I'm
not sure if it can do higher than 44.1KHz, either... which would be
preferrable on an SBLive or Audigy card.  (For 44.1 the chip actually
captures at 48, but it gets dithered down to 44.1 INSIDE the card before the
OS gets it.  It's a much better idea to just grab it at 48 if possible, then
let your software/CPU render it down to 44.1 when you need to.)



Now, for what the soundcard capabilities have to do with it:

Basically, any change you make to a waveform in software introduces rounding
errors.  You can only be so precise when trying to represent curves, and
mathmatically altering them in ways that simulate the effects of analog
equipment.  So the higher the resolution, the more precise the calculation,
the less effect the rounding errors will have on the result.  The more
changes you plan on introducing in software to a sound file, the higher
resolution you want to work with.  (In order to carry out the math as
accurately as possible with the least rounding errors and whatnot.)  Sort of
the same way a graphics person will work with extremely high resolutions for
an original piece, and only render down a copy at the intended "published
size" when finished.  (TIFF vs. JPG for example.)

In essence, if you understand the difference in the abilities of scanners
(16bit/480x600 vs. 42bit/1600x3200 or whatever) and why you want the latter
(even if the end result is supposed to be 16bit/480x600)... then you've got
it.

The reason live recording is much more intensive (and A/D sample quality is
more critical) is that you are trying to produce an actual original master
of the highest quality possible.  (In the case of an lp, that was already
done by the studio.  Which was used to mass produce copies for sale.)  But
there's a catch... at the same time you may be doing TONS of manipulation to
try to create it.  Potentially introducing those rounding errors at ever
iteration.  An extremely over-simplified example:

1.  Scanning in lots of original copies
	(miked individual drums, vocals, horns, amp speakers, room;
direct-in keys, bass, samples)
2.  Altering some or all of them individually in various ways
	(reverb, eq, comp)
3.  Mixing some of them together into submixes
	(drumkit, non-solo horns, bg vocals)
4.  Altering some or all submixes individually in various ways
	(reverb, eq, comp)
5.  Mixing submixes and single tracks into a final mix.
	(self-exp)
6.  Altering the final mix in various ways
	(eq, comp)

So by the time you reach the end, not a single part has gone through
untweaked.  And the majority have gone through a lot more than that.

I'll try to represent it in a psuedo formula of sorts... lets say the
original sound quality = 1 (perfect) and each digital tweak (DSP, not
copying) degrades the original signal by a factor of the sample quality.
And our sample quality is 2.  And the whole shebang is multiplied by how
many tracks we're starting out with.

Now take 2 guitars, 1 bass, 1 lead vocal, 2 background vocals, 1 keyboard,
and 4 mikes on a drumkit (bass, snare/hihat, and two overheads for
toms/cymbals) for a total of 11 tracks.  Go through the process exactly as
described so that each track has been tweaked 3 times. 

The end quality is 66 (2cubed x 11tracks) it in comparison to hearing it
live in the studio (1).  Add another tweak to each and you're at 176.  An
untweaked 2track (stereo) recording off an lp once has a much better score:
4. (The original sample quality of 2, by 2 tracks.  Tweak it once, and have
4x2 and a score of 8.  Still a lot better than 66.)  Also notice that by
increasing the quality of the sample (approaching a factor of "1") that the
scores get way better.


Note, that whole excercise was for pure comparitive purposes and has no
basis in real numbers or math!  :)

(I'm also completely ignoring that even with correct math it is still wrong
because the effect on a single track is going to be different than the same
track within a submix, and again within a stereo mix.)




> What about pro-level cards makes them unsuitable for gaming?  I'm not 
> a gamer and don't follow the hardware that closely.  Is it 
> because pro 
> cards forego the 5.1 stuff and only provide stereo out?

Something like that.  At least under windows.  Pro cards will have different
sorts of drivers, and may not provide the ability to do regular system
functions.  In linux (ALSA) this is probably a little different.  I don't
know many details here, but know it can be an issue.  Maybe this is the next
thing I should look into. :)  I believe some can and some can't in windows.
I'm curious now, and thinking it might not matter at all with ALSA.  Now I
wanna know.

But maybe it's sort of like comparing a pure 8-track (no mixer) tape to a
stereo tape deck.

 - Channels don't line up (heads and track alignment, channels to channels)
 - Different bandwidth (1" to 1/4" width, 24 bit to 16)
 - Different speed (5 inches per second to 1, 96KHz to 44.1KHz.)

Or something like that.

> Thanks for the list.  If you don't mind, what means Multiface & 
> Digiface?  (Software, hardware?)

They are both breakout boxes that are part of the RME Hammerfall DSP system.
A working system consists of an interface card (PCI or Cardbus) connected to
one of these breakout boxes.  (I'm unsure whether you can run more than one
box at once, and intend to find out.)  The connection is via firewire
connectors and cables, but the protocol is proprietary.  (In the sense that
it isn't IEEE 1394, it's their own thing.  They tested with firewire and say
it didn't measure up to their needs, so they built their own card.  And
released specs so ALSA could write drivers for it. :)

The Multiface is the box that focuses on providing analog inputs and outputs
and built-in A/D-D/A conversion.  (Which isn't quite as pristine as their
standalone converters, but close and way better than most.)  Here's what it
has:

8 x analog line I/O, 96 kHz/24 bit, SNR 105 dBA, 1/4" TRS jacks
1 x ADAT digital I/O
1 x SPDIF digital I/O
1 x ADAT Sync In (9-pin D-type)
1 x Word clock I/O (BNC)
1 x analog line/headphone output, separate output for independent submix
1 x MIDI I/O (16 channels)

The Digiface is for those that don't need the analog inputs because they're
already in the digital domain before they get to the machine.  (Via
standalone DA/AD converters, ADAT decks, digital mixers and other equipment
that can speak on ADAT channels, and so on.)  So instead of a bunch of
analog jacks you get more ADAT channels, and another midi:

3 x ADAT digital I/O, based on RME's reliable Bitclock PLL
1 x SPDIF digital I/O, based on RME's reliable DIGI96 technology
1 x ADAT Sync In (9-pin D-type) for sample accurate transfers
1 x Word clock I/O (BNC)
1 x analog Line/headphone output, separate output for independent submix
2 x MIDI I/O (32 channels)


On the other hand, once you start getting picky (and think about spending
this much money) on stuff it's probably best to sit back first and think
about it... are your mics/preamps/monitors/space good enough to justify it
or even use it to its' potential, or would that money be better put into
those other things first.  (Especially since those things don't improve
quite as fast as computer tech.)

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Wed May 22 14:36:53 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Wed, 22 May 2002 14:36:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] TIP: How to Report Bugs
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0205221430170.27808-100000@joan.burling.com>

I was poking thru some scripts in the AfterStep distribution, &
found this small gem. In short, it sets out a series of steps
& applications useful in collecting relevant information when
reporting a problem with software. All of the commands are
explained in their respective man pages.

(You will have to tweak it a little, though, to adapt it to
your needs.)

Geoff

=====
bughint:
#!/bin/sh

echo "Please include sysinfo.gz in your bug report"
echo
echo "Gathering information for bug tracking..."
uname -a > sysinfo
echo "=============== AfterStep ===============" >> sysinfo
echo "afterstep version :">>sysinfo
afterstep -v >> sysinfo
echo "located at :">>sysinfo
which afterstep >> sysinfo
echo "=============== xdpyinfo ================" >> sysinfo
xdpyinfo >> sysinfo
echo "=============== env ================" >> sysinfo
env >> sysinfo
echo "=============== ldconfig ================" >> sysinfo
if [ `uname` = 'Linux' ]; then
        /sbin/ldconfig -p >> sysinfo
else
        /sbin/ldconfig -r >> sysinfo
fi

gzip -9 sysinfo

echo done.

>>>>> "D" == D Cooper Stevenson <cooper at linux-enterprise.net> writes:

D> You can also do this:
D> ps -e -o pid -o command | grep -v grep | grep mpg123

D> Experiment with the `-o' switch; you will find it to be a good switch
D> for filtering process lines.

D> The `grep -v grep' part strips out the grep process. Here's an example I
D> ran using Netscape as an argument for grep without the -v switch:

D>  628 netscape
D>  1356 grep netscape

D> When I added ``grep -v grep,' I get this, the correct answer:

D>  628 netscape

I always get freaked at the "grep -v grep" being added ritually.

What's wrong with:

        ps c | awk '/netscape/ { print $1 }'

where the "c" flag ensures that the command name is included
*without* its parameters so that you don't get a hit on the grep
in the first place!

From dealy at deatech.com  Wed May 22 16:13:47 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Wed, 22 May 2002 16:13:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard Recommendations?
In-Reply-To: <3CEC0CA7.3010400@sun.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205221547350.6222-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Wed, 22 May 2002, Richard Langis wrote:

> That entirely depends on what you want.  Onboard lan/video?  Intel or AMD?
> Dual procs?  ATA-100/133?  SCSI?  Small as in dimensional size or more along
> usage load?  Too many variables there to give a good answer to such a vague
> question.
[snip]

Also, are you looking for maximum stability/reliability?  This would
imply support for ECC memory, and many motherboards either don't support
ECC, or have bogus support for it -- some have a BIOS option for
enabling ECC (assuming you install ECC memory modules) but the hardware is
not actually capable of supporting it regardless of how you set the BIOS.

For maximum stability/reliability, check the motherboard overclocking web
sites, the further you can push a motherboard with overclocking, the more
stable it will be running at it's rated speed, and it also implies a
better overall design.  It should be noted that some very good
motherboards don't really support overclocking very well, but should not
necessarily be ruled out.

I have read in a number of different places that Tyan is the preferred
manufacturer for many people/companies who build alot of servers.

> On Wed, 22 May 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> 
> > On Wed, 22 May 2002, Longman, Bill wrote:
> >
> > > If you want to fork fewer processes just to find directories, why
> > > not do this:
> > >
> > > ls -ld */
> >
> > I can't get this to show hidden directories, even if I pass ls the
> > -a switch. Am I missing something?
> 
> The usual default in bash is that "*" does not match on file names
> with a leading ".", you have to play with the settings of "dotglob"
> and "GLOBIGNORE" in your shell environment to change this behaviour. 
> I prefer a different approach to this problem:
> 
>    find . -maxdepth 1 -type d
>

From shark at sharky.dyndns.org  Thu May 23 01:12:10 2002
From: shark at sharky.dyndns.org (Peter W)
Date: 23 May 2002 01:12:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] evolution configuration q's
In-Reply-To: <1022109171.2745.75.camel@mikado>
References: <1022096015.2481.27.camel@mikado> 
	<1022099210.3474.7.camel@sharky>  <1022109171.2745.75.camel@mikado>
Message-ID: <1022141530.3474.59.camel@sharky>

On Wed, 2002-05-22 at 16:12, Dylan Reinhardt wrote:
> So you can't configure Evolution unless Gnome is installed?
> 
> Sounds like that might be my problem(s).

I'm not actually sure (I've just always had GNOME). 
I wonder now how Evolution actually works... do you by any chance find
you have the "gnome-moz-remote" program installed?  I looked at my files
in ~/.gnome while I tried changing default browser, and noticed that the
~/.gnome/gnome-moz-remote file changes according to my changes (i'm not
sure if any other files are changing though). 

If you do have gnome-moz-remote (the program) and that is what Evolution
is using to start up the browser, you might try editing your
~/.gnome/gnome-moz-remote file by hand.
Here's what it looks like:
filename=/usr/local/mozilla/mozilla 
NEEDS_TERM=false
NREMOTE=true

the first line is the path to the browser, the second is whether it'll
start the browser in a terminal, and the third is whether the browser
supports the Netscape Remote Control protocol.

anyway... ;)

~Peter

Robert,

approximately these places (this is from my RH 6.2 server):

	(and all the files under this directory)
/usr/lib/cups/
	(and all the files under this directory)
/usr/lib/cups/backend/
	(and all the files under this directory)
/usr/lib/cups/cgi-bin/
	(and all the files under this directory)
/usr/lib/cups/daemon/
	(and all the files under this directory)
/usr/lib/cups/filter/
	(and all the files under this directory)
/usr/lib/libcups.a
/usr/lib/libcups.a.O
/usr/lib/libcups.so.2.O
/usr/lib/libcupsimage.so.2.O
/usr/lib/libcups.so
/usr/lib/libcups.so.2
/usr/lib/libcupsimage.so
/usr/lib/libcupsimage.so.2
/usr/man/man5/cupsd.conf.

/usr/man/cat8/cups-polld.8
/usr/sbin/cupsd
/usr/sbin/cupsd-nopam
/usr/sbin/cupsd-pam
/usr/share/cups/
	(and all the files under this directory)
/usr/share/doc/cups/
/usr/share/doc/cups/ipp.html
/usr/share/doc/cups/ipp.pdf
/usr/share/doc/cups/overview.html
/usr/share/doc/cups/overview.pdf

CUPS was straightforward to set up for a local printer on Redhat 7.3,
but I wouldn't know how to tackle a remote printer.  I like the new
LPR/CUPS switching utility they packaged with the distro.  If I were
you, I'd first try to get it working on a local printer to eliminate
variables and make sure CUPS itself is functional, then tackle the
remote printer "guess an IPP or URL address" stuff for remote printing.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu May 23 13:50:03 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 23 May 2002 13:50:03 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] rc.local question
In-Reply-To: <3CED4B82.9D5E2D78@anodizing.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205231344210.11192-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 23 May 2002, Abraham Zwygart wrote:

> It is as though the rc.local file is not being used.  As su I can do
> type in the ipx_ commands with no errors. Then as a user I can type
> in the ncpmount command and all is working.  Any ideas as why
> rc.local file is not being used?

You should see a symlink named S99local in /etc/rc{2,3,4,5}.d/. If 
it's not there, just do

  su
  cd /etc
  [ -L rc.local ] || ln -s rc.d/rc.local .
  for n in 2 3 4 5
  do
    cd /etc/rc${n}.d
    ln -s ../rc.local S99local
  done

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From russj at dimstar.net  Thu May 23 14:03:59 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 23 May 2002 14:03:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] CUPS configuration--Red Hat 7.3
In-Reply-To: <20020523180558.80177.qmail@web9603.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020523135705.01f2cd50@localhost>

At 11:05 AM 5/23/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>What's a URI?


In answer to this question, a URI is a Uniform Resource Identifier. This 
may or may not be different from a URL (Uniform Resource Locator), as 
outlined in the RFC covering URIs.

Extracted from RFC 2396 (Uniform Resource Identifiers (URI): Generic Syntax):

1.2. URI, URL, and URN

    A URI can be further classified as a locator, a name, or both.  The
    term "Uniform Resource Locator" (URL) refers to the subset of URI
    that identify resources via a representation of their primary access
    mechanism (e.g., their network "location"), rather than identifying
    the resource by name or by some other attribute(s) of that resource.
    The term "Uniform Resource Name" (URN) refers to the subset of URI
    that are required to remain globally unique and persistent even when
    the resource ceases to exist or becomes unavailable.

The whole RFC is here: http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2396.txt

Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net

From mph at puddingbowl.org  Thu May 23 15:59:39 2002
From: mph at puddingbowl.org (Michael Hall)
Date: Thu, 23 May 2002 15:59:39 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RPM v build from source- removing?
In-Reply-To: <20020523224904.13099.qmail@callisto.affordablehost.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205231512270.26600-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <20020523224904.13099.qmail@callisto.affordablehost.com>
Message-ID: <20020523225939.GA30602@puddingbowl.org>

# cd /usr/local/src/whereeveryoumadethepackage
# make uninstall

{pray the maintainer added an uninstall rule}

or 

use the fabulously helpful checkinstall, which will build RPM's, tgz's, or
.deb's out of a configured && made source package for easy sharing with
others or removal later on:

http://asic-linux.com.mx/~izto/checkinstall/

<quote>
"A lot of people has asked me how can they remove from their boxes a program
they compiled and installed from source. Some times -very few- the program's
author adds an uninstall rule to their Makefile, but that's not usually the
case. This is my primary reason to write CheckInstall. After you
./configure; make your program, CheckInstall will run make install (or
whatever you tell it to run) and keep track of every file modified by this
installation, using the excelent installwatch utility written by Pancrazio
'Ezio' de Mauro (p at demauro.net).

When make install is done, CheckInstall will create a Slackware, RPM or
Debian compatible package and install it with Slackware's installpkg, "rpm
-i" or Debian's "dpkg -i" as appropriate, so you can view it's contents with
pkgtool ("rpm -ql" for RPM users or "dpkg -l" for Debian) or remove it with
removepkg ("rpm -e"|"dpkg -r"). Aditionally, this script will leave you a
copy of the installed package in the source directory so you can install it
wherever you want, which is my second motivation: I don't have to compile
the same software again and again every time I need to install it on another
box :-)."
</quote>

-mph

References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205231512270.26600-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <20020523224904.13099.qmail@callisto.affordablehost.com>
Message-ID: <20020523160112.C22950@dalsemi.com>

On Thu, May 23, 2002 at 06:49:04PM -0400, Carla Schroder wrote:
> Hola, o fabulously brilliant, selfless Linux geeks. A question have I: how 
> do you remove software built from source? Uninstalling an RPM is easy- is 
> there a different method for removing roll-yer-own? 

Nay, lass of the media variety.

You are solely at the mercy of the programmer.  If they be thorough,
then you may find that:

make uninstall

works.  Otherwise, a lengthy and painful process of grokking the
output of

make -n install

ensues.  I've read of methods that alter the install program to keep
a log of what it installs and where, but again, if you're doing this
after the fact you're back to the grok.

Colin



From griffint at aracnet.com  Thu May 23 16:05:41 2002
From: griffint at aracnet.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Thu, 23 May 2002 16:05:41 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] RPM v build from source- removing?
In-Reply-To: <no.id> from "Carla Schroder" at May 23, 2002 06:49:04 PM
Message-ID: <200205232305.g4NN5fL29195@shell1.aracnet.com>

> 
> Hola, o fabulously brilliant, selfless Linux geeks. A question have I: how 
> do you remove software built from source? Uninstalling an RPM is easy- is 
> there a different method for removing roll-yer-own? 
> 
> thanks much! 
> 

If you still have the original source tree where you did the build, 
sometimes you can do a "make uninstall" from there.

If that doesn't work then you have to do a little detective work.
Usually I try to find one file that I know belongs to the package,
and then find all other files on the system with a creation date
around the same time. Usually they're all within a few seconds of each 
other.

Somewhere on the net there's an install-watcher utility that is a wrapper 
around "make install." It monitors the installation process and then 
provides a means to undo it, not unlike InstallShield for Windows. For 
things that are already installed it wouldn't help.

Terry

Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/

www.Gentoo.org
Source. *BSD Ports-like system ('pretend' installs, so you know exactly what its going to put on your machine, before you put it on your machine). optimized for your system.
I swear by it now. I have a KDE gnome arts, and alsa free system...i don't want gnumb or kiddie libraries on my sytem (don't ask, i just don't we all have our quirks), so I can specify that during compiles of various apps, those dependencies are ignored (gaim for example, has a configure option to not include gnome libs).

On Thu, 2002-05-23 at 15:04, CopyRoom wrote:
> Hi there, I am sort of a newbie to Linux and new to this list.

welcome:) 

>  One of the topics I have been researching is enabling NTFS support on my RedHat 7.3 install (dual boot w/ XP).  Most of the info I have found says this should already be compiled in my kernel, but I can't seem to use it.  I also read that the driver has corrupted data before, has anyone has this happen?

Well the last that I checked, NTFS was read only. in the stock linux
kernel tree. 

You need to build your own, and enable the experimental support for read
/write NTFS. 

There was talk of killing off the driver due to lack of developer
interested.

I used to use it, but I went back to vfat for my windows stuff, due to
that driver not building in the experimental kernels.  

vfat is nasty, but it is also the least common detonator, so it is
guaranty to always work.  
 
 
> 
> I did go ahead and set up a FAT partition on my drive to exchange MP3's etc between the 2, but I am still curious about getting NTFS to work,
> 
> On the flipside, has anyone used the ext2fsnt driver with windows?  

> I was wondering if this will work with ext3 fs as well.
I do not think so, but steve tweedy is a smart man.

Do you like to play Russian Rulette with your file system ? 

> 
> Thanks for your advice
> Dave P

I prefer to just install to a local prefix.  Then uninstall really is
just an `rm -rf' and the price is just a tiny bit of $PATH
maintenance.  Don't have to worry about filename clashes that way,
either.  Don't need no steenking "make uninstall".

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu May 23 17:30:26 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 23 May 2002 17:30:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RPM v build from source- removing?
In-Reply-To: <51C603B9AB4696408D7273AA133734AC1EA986@ljcms002.prod.vectorscm.com>
References: <51C603B9AB4696408D7273AA133734AC1EA986@ljcms002.prod.vectorscm.com>
Message-ID: <86r8k2crq5.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Scot" == Craighead, Scot D <craighead.scot at vectorscm.com> writes:

Russell> I prefer to just install to a local prefix.  Then uninstall
Russell> really is just an `rm -rf' and the price is just a tiny bit
Russell> of $PATH maintenance.  Don't have to worry about filename
Russell> clashes that way, either.  Don't need no steenking "make
Russell> uninstall".

Scot> Personally, I would be afraid to install something with make
Scot> install that came from a programmer that was so sloppy that he
Scot> didn't include this option.  

It isn't a matter of sloppy, it is a matter of the build source not
being around after the install.  I unpack in /src, usually build from
a different directory, make check ; make install, then blow away both
the /src/foo and /build/foo.  The /build/foo would contain the
Makefile with the uninstall target.  Poof!  Not there anymore.  I
don't want a particular package any more, I just go to prefix I
installed, e.g.: /packages/utils/foo and say "ba-bye" with an rm -rf
and everyone goes home fat, dumb and happy.

This is about eliminating the need to retain and manage complex
"state" (in this case, what files you plunked where) by just putting
them all together.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``The two chiefs turned to each other.        
seniorr at aracnet.com      Bellison uncorked a flood of horrible       
                         profanity, which, translated meant, `This is
                         extremely unusual.' ''

installed, e.g.: /packages/utils/foo and say "ba-bye" with an rm -rf
and everyone goes home fat, dumb and happy.

This is about eliminating the need to retain and manage complex
"state" (in this case, what files you plunked where) by just putting
them all together.

                         extremely unusual.' ''

On Thu, 2002-05-23 at 20:24, Phil Tomson wrote:
> On my laptop I use DHCP to get the IP address for eth0 upon bootup.
> However when I'm booting up somewhere and not connected to my network or
> another one with a DHCP server, I have to wait a couple of minutes for
> the network setup script to timeout before it realizes that it's not
> gonna get an address.  It seems that I recall that there is some way to
> skip a something like network setup while booting - some conrol-key
> sequence or other - how is it done?

If you are in Redhat, you can press 'i' right as when it starts loading
services and stuff (when you see "Starting foo ....   OK" instead of
kernel messages).  Then it'll ask you if you want to start each thing,
and you say 'y' up until it asks about "eth0", at which point you say
'n'.  At the next question you can say 'c' to continue with everything
else i think (and it won't keep asking you to confirm). 

HTH.

~Peter

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri May 24 06:14:27 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 24 May 2002 06:14:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] RPM v build from source- removing?
In-Reply-To: <B14FD9A4BE25D31188A400508B2CBB6FC24FA7@mailsrvnt04.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205240607360.3541-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Thu, 23 May 2002, Longman, Bill wrote:

> This was a bit of a question that's been clanking around up top. Is
> that the typical way to get a source rpm to install into my
> directory of choice. In other words, what's the rpm equivalent of
> "tar xvf filename" when "filename" is a, say, kernel source rpm?

1. Create a $HOME/.rpmmacros file that defines the _topdir variable, 
   e.g.,

   %_topdir         /var/tmp/redhat

2. Create the appropriate subdirectories in %_topdir:

   #!/bin/bash

   topdir=$(grep ^%_topdir $HOME/.rpmmacros | awk '{print $2}')
   expr "$topdir" : '/' > /dev/null || {
     "$topdir looks funny";
     exit 1; }

   for d in \
     BUILD \
     RPMS/alpha \
     RPMS/alphaev6 \
     RPMS/athlon \
     RPMS/i386 \
     RPMS/i486 \
     RPMS/i586 \
     RPMS/i686 \
     RPMS/noarch \
     SOURCES \
     SPECS \
     SRPMS
   do
     if [ -n "$topdir" -a ! -d $topdir/$d ]; then
       install -dv $topdir/$d
     fi
   done

3. Install the source rpm: rpm -i blah-version.src.rpm.

The source tarball(s) and patches will end up in %{_topdir}/SOURCES. 
Good luck.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>





From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri May 24 06:33:46 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 24 May 2002 06:33:46 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] RPM v build from source- removing?
In-Reply-To: <51C603B9AB4696408D7273AA133734AC1EA988@ljcms002.prod.vectorscm.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205240615130.3541-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Thu, 23 May 2002, Craighead, Scot D wrote:

> How do you force it to install into the directory you want?

I'm not sure what question you're asking:

1. How do I compile a package so that its final resting place will be 
   somewhere other than /usr/local?

2. How do compile a package so that it'll install into /tmp/package
   even though it'll eventually end up in /usr/local?

As many people have suggested, the answer to #1 is typically to set 
the --prefix variable when running the configure script, e.g.,

  ./configure --prefix=/opt/package --sysconfdir=/opt/etc ...
  make 
  make install

The answer to #2 varies a bit, and usually the only way to know for 
sure is to look in the Makefile that configure builds. Let's say that 
you're building a package that will reside in

  /etc/
  /usr/
    - bin/
    - lib/
    - sbin/
    - share/

but you want to have it install itself into

  /tmp/package-build/
     - etc/
     - usr/
       - bin/
       - lib/
       - sbin/
       - share/

Using a fake buildroot is a trick that most package managers use, and 
a good way to get an idea of what any given <package> is going to 
install into your filesystem. Let's assume that you set the prefix and 
sysconfdir correctly at build time:

  ./configure --prefix=/usr --sysconfdir=/etc
  make

Then what? Well, it depends. Here are the two most common tricks:

  make install \
    prefix=/tmp/package-build/usr \
    sysconfdir=/tmp/package-build/etc

or

  make DESTDIR=/tmp/package-build install

I usually grep a package's Makefiles looking for DESTDIR first of all.
If I get lots of return values, that's the easiest path to take. Other
package maintainers, however, use other environment variables for
accomplishing the same thing, so it's usually a good thing to read the
README and INSTALL files :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

Paul Heinlein wrote:

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri May 24 08:48:06 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 24 May 2002 08:48:06 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla
In-Reply-To: <1022253508.1492.279.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205240845560.3541-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On 24 May 2002, Jon Jacob wrote:

> Just out of curiousity, I tried to run Mozilla on my RH7.2 system and
> got the following message:
> 
> /usr/bin/mozilla: /bin/test: No such file or directory

/usr/bin/mozilla is a shell script, not the mozilla binary itself. Why 
the developers would hard-code test to be /bin/test is beyond me. 
There are two fixes available to you:

1. Edit /usr/bin/mozilla, changing references to /bin/test to either 
   /usr/bin/test or simply test.

2. Put a symlink to /usr/bin/test in /bin.

Your call.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

Until I converted to Gentoo (It's an amazing piece of work!).

I used a tool called checkinstall that I would run in place of make
install after I had made from source.

It would create and RPM for me and then install it from my custom build.
I only found a couple of things it couldn't handle (I can't remember
what they were, and I believe it must have been due to a broken autoconf
configuration). It can also create Slack and Debian packages. I still
use it on all my RH boxes that I have not had the time to convert to
Gentoo.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri May 24 09:58:33 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 24 May 2002 09:58:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla
In-Reply-To: <1022256161.1501.282.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205240954490.3541-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On 24 May 2002, Jon Jacob wrote:

> Well, I changed the /usr/bin/mozilla file as you suggested but now I
> get no message and no mozilla either.  It does not start at all.

OK. From within an xterm, try 

  bash -o xtrace /usr/bin/mozilla

You'll get lots of flotsam from your .profile or .bashrc file, but 
eventually you should see what commands get executed by the mozilla 
wrapper script. That might provide some insight. Otherwise, you might 
try launching the binary directly, typically

  /usr/lib/mozilla/mozilla-bin

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>





From dealy at deatech.com  Fri May 24 09:56:09 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 24 May 2002 09:56:09 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla
In-Reply-To: <1022256161.1501.282.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205240950210.9333-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On 24 May 2002, Jon Jacob wrote:

> Well, I changed the /usr/bin/mozilla file as you suggested but now I get
> no message and no mozilla either.  It does not start at all.
>
> Maybe its just me, but that doesn't seem right ;)
>
> On Fri, 2002-05-24 at 08:48, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> > On 24 May 2002, Jon Jacob wrote:
> >
> > > Just out of curiousity, I tried to run Mozilla on my RH7.2 system and
> > > got the following message:
> > >
> > > /usr/bin/mozilla: /bin/test: No such file or directory
> >
> > /usr/bin/mozilla is a shell script, not the mozilla binary itself. Why
> > the developers would hard-code test to be /bin/test is beyond me.
> > There are two fixes available to you:
> >
> > 1. Edit /usr/bin/mozilla, changing references to /bin/test to either
> >    /usr/bin/test or simply test.
> >
> > 2. Put a symlink to /usr/bin/test in /bin.

Some shells like bash have a built-in "test" command which used to have
some differences from the command line version (and may still have
differences).  Maybe they were trying to force the use of the external
version by giving the path, in which case if you changed the
/usr/bin/mozilla reference to just "test", it might now be using the
internal version and having problems.  In bash you can disable the
internal version with:

   enable -n test

or you can just give the explicit path to where test actually resides.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri May 24 10:44:11 2002
