  I'm conserving electrons by combining two subjects in a single message.

  1) Fonts. I discovered that hidden deep in the bowels of OpenOffice is a
way to turn on all sorts of font attributes, including small caps. I'm a
happy camper now and will continue migrating documents from WordPerfect to
OpenOffice. As an aside, I guess WP is officially dead now. Not even Amazon
is selling copies of it in any form. Oh well.

  2) Gentoo (say it out loud and people think you're sneezing). I looked at
the description on freshmeat and have a few questions about it. What are
"ports" -- a la BSD -- and why are they a Good Thing (R)? Why is gentoo
marketed to developers and network administrators rather than to end users?
Other than the apparently neat installation and packaging capabilities, what
else of value does it offer? I'm curious.

Thanks,

Rich




From tjg at craigelachie.org  Fri May 24 11:26:50 2002
From: tjg at craigelachie.org (Timothy Grant)
Date: 24 May 2002 11:26:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] fonts and gentoo
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205241038370.7902-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205241038370.7902-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1022264811.2203.32.camel@reepicheep.craigelachie.org>

On Fri, 2002-05-24 at 10:44, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   2) Gentoo (say it out loud and people think you're sneezing). I looked at
> the description on freshmeat and have a few questions about it. What are
> "ports" -- a la BSD -- and why are they a Good Thing (R)? Why is gentoo
> marketed to developers and network administrators rather than to end users?
> Other than the apparently neat installation and packaging capabilities, what
> else of value does it offer? I'm curious.

Gentoo rocks because of their Portage system which is sort of a super
BSD Ports system.

Basically what Portage allows you to do is to create the system you
want, not what the packagers think you want.

One small example. When I first installed Gentoo on my notebook, I
immediately needed Vim (Gentoo's default is Nano and I can just barely
tolerate it). So, the first thing I installed after zsh was Vim. The
default Vim build that comes with Gentoo also builds gVim. So, Portage
downloaded and built X v4.2, downloaded and built GTK, and when I was
done with building Vim I actually had a working X configuration as well.

Gentoo also uses non-standard runlevels. Basically you can create any
runlevels you want. services are started and stopped based on
dependencies. My network card can't be started until PCMCIA services
start, and my RC scripts are smart enough to "know" that. So, while I
was quite capable of tweaking the SXXpcmcia SYYnetwork startup scripts,
it was much easier (once I figured out how it works!) to tell the
network scripts that it depended on PCMCIA.


 
-- 
Stand Fast,
    tjg.

Timothy Grant
www.craigelachie.org

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri May 24 13:53:52 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 24 May 2002 13:53:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] rc.local question
In-Reply-To: <3CEEA652.92276454@anodizing.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205241348560.3541-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

Hmm. Everything looks OK. My two remaining questions are

1. Is /etc/rc.d/rc.local executable?

2. Are the ipx_* and ncpmount utilities in root's default $PATH?

Otherwise, I'd be interested to see what happens if you put a bunch of 
echo statements at the end of your rc.local file, e.g.,

echo +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
echo completed executation of rc.local
echo +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
sleep 3 # so you can see this stuff before the console clears

If rc.local is being executed at boot time, you'll be able to see that 
spewage on the console.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Thu May 23 22:35:11 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Thu, 23 May 2002 22:35:11 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] RPM v build from source- removing?
In-Reply-To: <51C603B9AB4696408D7273AA133734AC1EA982@ljcms002.prod.vectorscm.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0205232231070.27808-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Thu, 23 May 2002, Craighead, Scot D wrote:

> >Hola, o fabulously brilliant, selfless Linux geeks. A question have I: how
> >do you remove software built from source? Uninstalling an RPM is easy- is
> >there a different method for removing roll-yer-own?
> >
> >thanks much!
>
> Usually you install it with :
> make install
> and uninstall it with
> make uninstall
>
> Varies with each package, though.
>
If you are forced to do an uninstall by hand, there is a hard way to do
it completely -- use the -n switch for make with the install switch as
so: ``make -n install". What will do is print out (not execute) all of the
commands make install generates, & allows you to a clue to track down
all of the places make has placed files.

Best if the maintainer added the uninstall target to the makefile, though.
By far the best.

Geoff

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Fri May 24 16:26:33 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Fri, 24 May 2002 16:26:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Q: System Backup
In-Reply-To: <20020523184150.1bbb8458.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0205241612340.993-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Thu, 23 May 2002, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

> G'day,
>
> I've been chipping away at yet another Linux install, this time an LFS
> system.  Having gotten things working pretty well--all the way down to
> the antialiased fonts, I want to make sure things don't go worng for me

What an appropriate typo.

> again, so I'm ready to back up my system.  Good idea, huh?
>
> It should be simple enough, but I need a recommendation on how to do it.
> The whole system is basically in one partition (except for a swap
> partition and some mounts which belong to other OSes), and I have space
> for the backup in another ext2 partition (where I installed Mandrake
> prior to building LFS).  Ideally, I'd like a procedure that would only
> copy changes to my system on subsequent runs, and which would preserve
> both permissions and symlinks, so if my kernel panics again and I can't
> recover, I can just boot to my old Mandrake install and recopy
> everything.
>
As you described your problem, I see two solutions:

1) Learn & implement a backup utility like dump or Amanda. Dump is a UNIX
tool, & might even exist in your LFS distribution, having been built while
you built another package -- ar as part of one. Amanda, meanwhile, is a
GPL backup utility available from http://www.amanda.org, & would require
downloading & building. Both of these packages support full & incremental
backups.

Now what you need to do before you get too carried away with this plan is
to plan out how you are going to alternate between full & incremental
backups -- & at which levels. And verify that these backups are correct.
(You will also want to perform periodic full backups, instead of a number
of incrementals diff'ed from the original backup.) Take a look at Curtis
Preston's _UNIX Backup & Recovery_ for ideas of how to design this.

2) Do you have a CD burner attached to this computer? It may be simpler
to burn an image of your /bin, /sbin, /usr/sbin & /etc directories to a CD
each night while you sleep, & with the cost of CD media so low it would
be less of a cost than it first appears.

Geoff

From rddunlap at osdl.org  Sat May 25 10:07:27 2002
From: rddunlap at osdl.org (Randy.Dunlap)
Date: Sat, 25 May 2002 10:07:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Xeon?
In-Reply-To: <000e01c203c1$77a92360$6401a8c0@endeavor>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33L2.0205251001100.18051-100000@dragon.pdx.osdl.net>

On Sat, 25 May 2002, Greg Long wrote:

| What are the advantages of running these Intel PIII Xeon CPU's vs.
| Pentium IV OR AMD Athalon CPU's in a K12LTSP server?
|
| It seems the biggest need of these servers is RAM and fast HD, not CPU.

Intel Xeon CPUs are server CPUs.  The biggest difference
that I recall from the (Intel) mainstream desktop CPUs
is larger on-chip cache.

P-III goes up to 1.2 GHz IIRC.  Don't know about P-III Xeons.
P4's go begin at 1.3 (?) or 1.5 GHz and now go up to 2.6 GHz.
P4 Xeons don't have as much speed variety (i.e., there are
a smaller number of P4's that are built and qualified as
Xeons) since it takes a separate design, manufacture, and
test for each one, and they don't expect to sell quite as
many Xeon (server) chips as desktop chips.

Anyway, for a (what, 30-node) server in this environment,
I'd expect the lower-cost P-III's [Xeons or not] or Athlons
(MPs) to be sufficient.

-- 
~Randy

From kens at cad2cam.com  Sat May 25 12:14:02 2002
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Sat, 25 May 2002 12:14:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] skipping DHCP during boot
In-Reply-To: <1022210645.3877.6.camel@traveller.home.com>
Message-ID: <NMEPJGMCLGBMCOCPJFHKKEJEDIAA.kens@cad2cam.com>

Phil,

There is an option for dhcpcd that sets timeout.  Do a man on dhcpcd (Nice
way to say RTFM).  Then edit your /sbin/ifup to include that option.  You
want 30 seconds, then the option would be -t 30.  Find in the ifup script
where it invokes dhcpcd and add that option in there.  BTW
www.google.com/linux is your friend when learning Linux.  Almost any
question can be answered searching with this engine.  Of course the biggest
problem then becomes "how to phrase the question".

Ken

Dump is not on my system, either.  (Jeme, yours is LFS too, no?)  The
man page for dumpe2fs says it "prints the super block and blocks group
information", so it doesn't look like a file backup tool, more like a
filesystem restoration utility.

And actually, I'm trying not to get carried away at all.  Preston's
book and even the "Linux Complete Backup and Recovery HOWTO" seem like
overkill.  I'm hoping learning to use dump or even just tar will be
sufficient for this machine.  Amanda may be more than I need.

(I don't need complete disaster recovery here.  In the unlikely event of
a tornado in downtown Portland, I have a complete set of notes I can use
to reinstall everything, and important things like my sourcecode and
personal stuff are backed up elsewhere.  But Linux has fubar'ed my root
partition on two occasions now, and it's for that contingency in
particular that I would be prepared.)

Full & incremental backups?  At which levels?  Well, my plan was just to
copy all of /, sans the mounts, /proc, etc., to another drive initially.
Then, every night, I'd just like to update that copy with any changes
made.  Oversimplified?  Shortsighted?  Well, probably, but I don't care
about restoring to a given date or anything like that.  This is just my
workstation, and I'm just planning for what seems most threatening,
trying to learn this stuff bite by bite--the only way I know how to eat
an elephant.  But if you can explain how I'm going about this the wrong
way, please do.  For now I'll just read up on those simpler tools in
hopes that they will do the job.

--Jason

From dealy at deatech.com  Sat May 25 20:02:39 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Sat, 25 May 2002 20:02:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Q: System Backup
In-Reply-To: <20020525184337.75081801.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205251934001.2732-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Sat, 25 May 2002, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

> Hmm, thanks, Shannon.  I thought of rsync, but as no one had recommended
> it, I wasn't sure was a viable option.  I guess I'll look into it more.  I
> don't want to waste harddrive space with incremental backups, so I was
> hoping dump could be configured to overwrite changes.  But maybe rsync
> is really what I'm after.
>
> Any thoughts on this?  Will rsync preserve symlinks, permissions,
> ownership, and all that?

Current versions of rsync if given the appropriate options will
copy and preserve: ownership, permissions, modification date/time, soft
links, hard links, named pipes, devices, and probably other things I
haven't thought of.  It only transfers what is necessary, though it does
have to scan both source and destination directory trees before it
starts (which can take quite a while on a large drive).  It also has
options which allow it to make backup copies of any changed files before
replacing them with the new version.  I have been using it for a number
of years for all backups in my office, all computers are mirrored to one
very large drive on the server each night, then an incremental backup of
that drive to tape is performed.  If it misses any detail in the
transfers, I haven't noticed it, and I have on more than one occasion
wiped the main drive of a computer and re-initialized it from the rsync
backup on the server.  The biggest difficulty I have had with it was
getting my script files for it configured correctly, because in giving
it the names of directories to transfer and directories to exclude,
including or excluding the trailing slash in the name has different
results, also I've messed up the wild cards more than once trying to
get all the exclusions right -- there are files and directories that may
be scattered through the file system that I try not to backup: core
files, cache directories for web browsers, swapfiles, etc..
Once I got it configured right, I haven't had any problems since.
To make sure it is backing up everything I want, I did a "find" on the
root directory that was being backed up, and again on the backup
directory, and then did a diff on the output from both finds.  This
allowed me to relatively quickly tell if anything was being missed that I
wanted backed up.

From alan at clueserver.org  Sun May 26 11:24:58 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: 26 May 2002 11:24:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Printer Suggestions
In-Reply-To: <1022441272.7784.43.camel@brain>
References: <NMEPJGMCLGBMCOCPJFHKOEJKDIAA.kens@cad2cam.com> 
	<1022441272.7784.43.camel@brain>
Message-ID: <1022437498.31358.14.camel@summanulla.clueserver.org>

Keep these things in mind when buying a color printer.

Does the printer have one cartridge or one for each color?  A printer
with just one big cartridge will be more expensive and wasteful because
you never use colors at the same rate.

Is the ink water soluble? Some are and some are not.  If you are
printing things that are going to be handled a lot, you will want inks
that will not rub off or bleed when handled.

How much are cartridges?  Sometimes the printer is cheap but the
cartridges are very expensive.  (As much as the printer sometimes!)

Can the cartridges by refilled?  Is it worth refilling them?  Some
printers have cartridges that cannot be refilled. They either won't work
after being refilled or even disable the printer if you use a refilled
cartridge.

Most printers are supported by Linux. Sometimes you have to update
gimp-print or the cups drivers.

I don't do a lot of color printing, but I have one here.  I have yet to
find one that is very cheap. The Cannon 660 costs about $16 for the
black cartridges. Not certain about the color ones. i will know soon as
I need to buy more.  They sure get burned up MUCH faster than my HP 4p
laser printer.  I can go through many reams per print cartridge.  I
doubt if I could go through more than one with a color printer.

"Kenneth G. Stephens" wrote:

> The suggestion before was to create a small quiet file you combine in

> file1+quiet-zone-file+file2+quite-zone-file+ . . . .  Just record a few

Now that you mention it, I remember that recommendation. That answers
the question of how to put a gap between songs, but how do you combine
several files into one file? I'm assuming that simple concatenation
won't work due to the presence of a header in each file. What I'd like
is something that would work like cat, but would build a new header for
the finished file. Something like:

mp3cat file1.mp3 gap.mp3 file2.mp3 gap.mp3 file3.mp3 > newfile.mp3

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun May 26 14:55:50 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun, 26 May 2002 14:55:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] mp3 file question
In-Reply-To: <3CF1555B.5E1368C2@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205261439090.21058-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sun, 26 May 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:
> Now that you mention it, I remember that recommendation. That answers
> the question of how to put a gap between songs, but how do you combine
> several files into one file? I'm assuming that simple concatenation
> won't work due to the presence of a header in each file. What I'd like
> is something that would work like cat, but would build a new header for
> the finished file. Something like:
> 
> mp3cat file1.mp3 gap.mp3 file2.mp3 gap.mp3 file3.mp3 > newfile.mp3

I'm not aware of such a utility, but I've never looked for one.

In reading the lame man page, there's a special switch for "gapless
encoding" which makes me think that the default mode is to include gaps
for contiguous files.  If that's the case, you can simply experiment with
dumping giving lame a string of raw PCM or PCM with WAV file headers and
letting it handle the gaps.

I also might just do something LIKE this:

for song in *.mp3; do
	mpg123 -s $song >>longsong.raw
	mpg123 -s blank.mp3 >> longsong.raw
done
# Of course, this adds some blank to the END of the album, but you can
# figure out your way around that.
lame -m s -r -s 44.1 longsong.raw album.mp3

But those are just some suggestions.  You'll have to play with the
options.

J.

information in the header; imagine "tuning in" to a live MP3 stream--you
don't necessarily start from the beginning.  And it works with .mpg
video.

> information in the header; imagine "tuning in" to a live MP3 stream--you

> video. 

And in the case where the bitrates are different or where a simple cat
doesn't give you the expected results, most command-line and GUI mp3
players will ouput WAV to a file, which you can then convert.

mpg321(1):

       -s, --stdout
                 Use standard output instead of an  audio  device
                 for  output.  Output  is  in 16-bit PCM, little-
                 endian.

       -w N, --wav N
                 Write to wav file N instead of using  the  audio
                 device.  This  option will be preferred if --cdr
                 or --au are specified too. Specifying '-' for  N
                 will  cause  the  file to be written to standard
                 output.

       --cdr N   Write to cdr file N instead of using  the  audio
                 device. Specifying '-' for N will cause the file
                 to be written to standard output.

       --au N    Write to au file N instead of  using  the  audio
                 device. Specifying '-' for N will cause the file
                 to be written to standard output.

Wil

From hedlunch at yahoo.com  Sun May 26 20:12:32 2002
From: hedlunch at yahoo.com (mark hedlund)
Date: Sun, 26 May 2002 20:12:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Resolved: mp3 file question
In-Reply-To: <3CF193B6.5FFEE8C8@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20020527031232.98032.qmail@web20511.mail.yahoo.com>

Actually the header for an mp3 file contains a lot of really important info.
That's were the player program gets the data rate, stereo and file size, etc.
The only reason that cat works is that it does. It really shouldn't. The player
program, mpg123 probebly is _playing_ the second header. That's only a few
bytes but it's not mp3 encodeing. I don't think you'd be able to hear it. You
might be hearing silence at the begining and end of the audio tracks. The only
real way to join two or more mp3 files is to either rewrite the header after
joining the files and remove the second files' header or you could cat wave
files and then encode them or find a program that does this. I don't know of
one but it wouldn't be hard to write. The header for wave files also has some
important info: samples per second, stereo, file size, 8/16 bit samples, etc.
If you can dump sound as raw pcm data and cat, rip that it would work just
fine. I guess all I'm really saying is that...  I'm glad it works for you. If
you join two mp3s with different data rates it won't sound very good. I'm
pretty sure that most player programs won't be looking for header info at
arbitrary points in the file. They'll just play through it and it sounds like
mpg123 doesn't care if the file size in the header is wrong. Some programs like
baudline will refuse to deal with sound files with bad header data. There is
also id3 tag info, title artist etc. That would get lost, listened to, as well.
Baudline by the way is a really amazing but not open source signal analysis
program for linux.
http://www.baudline.com/

mark

From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Sun May 26 22:31:50 2002
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Sun, 26 May 2002 22:31:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Xeon?
In-Reply-To: <64618.12.231.181.15.1022474994.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205262218480.32036-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Sun, 26 May 2002, Dan Young wrote:

>FWIW, I think one reason lots of k-12 sites are using the Xeons on their
>K12tlsp servers is that StRUT had (has?) boatloads of these still in the
>shrinkwrap for the taking for participating sites. I believe they get lots
>of surplus, and engineering samples from Intel. We even got some "big
>iron," 4 and 8-way Xeon rigs, sans plastic bits.
>-Dan Young
>-Parkrose School District

Yeah, the donations to schools helps. In addition to the extra cache, XEONs
require a good motherboard which can make a significant difference over an
el-cheapo desktop board.

Terminal services is a numbers game, most machines are idle most of the time.
For example, if every user is idle 90% of the time and the 10% of non-idle
time is spread out evenly, you can have 10 people use a single machine at
full speed without their even knowing that they only really have 10% of the
resources available. If you have users who hit the cpu, ram, or disk hard
for extended periods of time, it is best to give them a stand-alone desktop.

Even when users are idle, they are chewing up ram... so that is the most
critical item. Excessive swapping will lead to a quick death-spiral.

-Eric

From jason at vancleve.com  Mon May 27 00:30:37 2002
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Mon, 27 May 2002 00:30:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Copying files with rsync
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0205262343370.29913-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0205262343370.29913-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <20020527003037.6c8098ee.jason@vancleve.com>

On Sun, 26 May 2002 23:50:55 -0700 (PDT)
Matt Alexander <m at netpro.to> wrote:

> Question 1:  If a data file is only slightly changed, does rsync only
> copy over that small change and then insert it properly into the data
> file on the backup server?

I think only the different parts of the file are transferred.  There is
a page on the site describing the algorithm
(http://rsync.samba.org/tech_report/node2.html), which states:

"The end result is that $\beta$ gets a copy of A, but only the pieces of
A that are not found in B (plus a small amount of data for checksums and
block indexes) are sent over the link."

Whether a copy is made at the destination I can't say, but maybe you can
divine that from the algorithm I linked.  There is an
option "W", as well, by which you can bypass that algorithm and copy
"whole files".  This is actually the default when rsync is copying
locally.

> Question 2:  If the data file is being written to when I run rsync, do
> I run the risk of ending up with a corrupted data file on the backup
> server?

I'm not sure about this one, but I would sure like to be!  I hope with
crossed fingers that it waits to copy any file that is write-locked, at
least.

--Jason V. C.



From dealy at deatech.com  Mon May 27 00:37:06 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Mon, 27 May 2002 00:37:06 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Copying files with rsync
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0205262343370.29913-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205270012410.685-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Sun, 26 May 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

> I'm using rsync to copy files from a file server to a backup server.  I
> have several rather large data files (1 to 2 gigs) that are being copied.
>
> Question 1:  If a data file is only slightly changed, does rsync only copy
> over that small change and then insert it properly into the data file on
> the backup server?

It depends on the options you give it, the default is to only transfer
small blocks of data containing the areas of the file that have changed,
but there is an option to do only whole file transfers.  In my office, I
generally do whole file transfers for any computer on the 100 Megabit
network which can use rsh as the default login shell for the transfers
because it seems to be the fastest approach.  For lower speed links such
as the old 10 Megabit network or modem links I use the default option
which just transfers what is needed.  It is particularly important to use
the default "only transfer what you need" mode if you are connecting to
the remote computer with rsync using ssh, even on a high speed link,
because everything has to be encrypted/decrypted which has enormous
overhead on large file transfers.

> Question 2:  If the data file is being written to when I run rsync, do I
> run the risk of ending up with a corrupted data file on the backup server?

Absolutely, but this is the case with any backup system that doesn't get a
lock on the file before transfering it.  The only way to be completely
safe is to stop all processes that might modify the files before doing
the backup, or alternatively, if the programs accessing the critical files
allow it, to generate a backup copy of the data on the local system before
it is transfered to the remote computer.  Databases generally will allow
you to dump the data to an external file in a manner that preserves it's
integrity, other programs sometimes have similar facilities.  Ultimately,
you have to evaluate each file that is likely to be modified during the
backups for risk of data loss and how serious that loss would be to you,
then act accordingly.  In my case, the backups are run at a time of day
when I am rarely using the computers, so my working data generally won't
be modified during the backups.  Other files that are likely to be
modified while the backups are running are primarily log files, incoming
email storage, and the database, so the database is dumped each night just
before the backup, who cares about lost log files, and most of my incoming
email at that time of night is spam so no great loss :-)

dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers

laptop, as opposed to kernel 2.2? My old Gateway was running fine
(mostly) with Red Hat 7.0 (which installed kernel 2.2), but lost all
PCMCIA functionality when I upgraded to RH 7.2 (kernel 2.4).

new built-in PCMCIA driver software, which has no support for PCI-based
PCMCIA bridges (like the Cirrus bridge in my Gateway). I attempted a
custom kernel/pcmcia-cs (modular PCMCIA support) compile yesterday, but
had no luck getting the damned thing to work properly. The core PCMCIA
modules load just fine, but it won't recognize any PC cards as other than
"anonymous memory" types. This apparently is related to some timing issue
that could be rectified by the use of an appropriate config parameter,
but I certainly couldn't track it down.

I could beat my head against the wall some more attempting to get
this working with kernel 2.4, but I'm tempted to just downgrade to the
combination I knew worked. Will I encounter any problems trying to run
a RH 7.2 install with the older (2.2) kernel?

Subject: [PLUG] TeX errors.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205271649070.7878-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

Message-ID: <15602.51494.935198.931217@soggy.deldotd.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

This undefined control sequence error is not good.  It means there is
either an error in the style you are using, or, more likely, an error
in your input file.

Latex will sometimes give you lots of "overflow h-box" warnings and
the like, but these simply mean it couldn't fit something into a box
and so you may end up with a ragged right edge or some other non-fatal
condition.

  Jeme> ! Undefined control sequence.  <argument> ...121.0686
  Jeme> \outputscale {}\embeddedps { 0.0426 2.6373 0.4800 dra...


  Jeme> I used to get different errors and then I added an assload of
  Jeme> symlinks in my /usr/share/texmf tree to the
  Jeme> /usr/share/lilypond tree and now I'm here and stumped.

Hmmm.  That really shouldn't have been necessary and could still be
contributing to your problem, i.e. maybe it's not your source file.
It's been a while since I added an "external" latex package in, but
when I did putting it in the right place seemed to do the job.

Have you read the docs for lilypond and looked for installation advice ?

Brian

From dealy at deatech.com  Mon May 27 19:54:11 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Mon, 27 May 2002 19:54:11 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] mkisofs is insane.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205271653020.7878-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205271940550.2831-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Mon, 27 May 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

[snip]
> When I run `mkisofs -r -o cd_image /path/to/directory`, my system slows to
> a standstill and other processes bog down and I cannot be productive until
> it's done.
[snip]
> I assume I'm IO bound, but shouldn't this just be a single read and a
> single write process?
[snip]

I can't speak to your mkisofs problem specifically, but the behavior you
describe is pretty much what I would expect.  mkisofs by itself should be
a completely I/O bound process which is constantly seeking the disk to
alternately read then write data, any other process that wants disk access
is  going to be competing with the constant seeking for the reads and
writes of mkisofs which will only make the problem much worse.  The best
thing I can suggest is stick a "nice -20" in front of your mkisofs
command which will then at least give your other processes higher
priority and make them somewhat more responsive.  One other thing that
may help a little (if you haven't done it already) is to add the
"noatime" option to the mount command for your file system(s) which
should also cut down on the amount of disk seeking required by all of
your processes which do disk I/O.

From poiridav at parkrose.k12.or.us  Mon May 27 22:11:02 2002
From: poiridav at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dave Poirier)
Date: Mon, 27 May 2002 22:11:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Copying files with rsync
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205270012410.685-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205272208350.14855-100000@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 27 May 2002, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:

> On Sun, 26 May 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > Question 2:  If the data file is being written to when I run rsync, do I
> > run the risk of ending up with a corrupted data file on the backup server?
> 
> Absolutely, but this is the case with any backup system that doesn't get a
> lock on the file before transfering it.  The only way to be completely
> safe is to stop all processes that might modify the files before doing
> the backup, or alternatively, if the programs accessing the critical files
> allow it, to generate a backup copy of the data on the local system before
> it is transfered to the remote computer.  Databases generally will allow
> you to dump the data to an external file in a manner that preserves it's
> integrity, other programs sometimes have similar facilities.  Ultimately,
> you have to evaluate each file that is likely to be modified during the
> backups for risk of data loss and how serious that loss would be to you,
> then act accordingly.  In my case, the backups are run at a time of day
> when I am rarely using the computers, so my working data generally won't
> be modified during the backups.  Other files that are likely to be
> modified while the backups are running are primarily log files, incoming
> email storage, and the database, so the database is dumped each night just
> before the backup, who cares about lost log files, and most of my incoming
> email at that time of night is spam so no great loss :-)

Other option is to use LVM or other snapshot capable volume manager and 
then back up the snapshot.

Dave

On Sun, 2002-05-26 at 23:28, Dan Young wrote:
> I believe you are looking for the windbind stuff in Samba that allows you
> to authenicate against a Windows domain controller. Some of this might be
> out of date but its a place to start:
> http://us1.samba.org/samba/docs/man/winbindd.8.html
> http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=samba+winbind
> http://www.mandrakeuser.org/docs/connect/csamba5.html
> 

Absolutely. This is the route I would take. The latest Samba daemon is
capable of authenticating against your primary domain server and
creating translated Linux users "on the fly" based on the PDC's
authentication response.

This avoids your having to constantly update user accounts, passwords,
e.t.c.--Samba and the PDC do that work for you.


-Cooper

From dealy at deatech.com  Mon May 27 22:50:36 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Mon, 27 May 2002 22:50:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Copying files with rsync
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205272208350.14855-100000@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205272233320.3252-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Mon, 27 May 2002, Dave Poirier wrote:

> On Mon, 27 May 2002, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:
>
> > On Sun, 26 May 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > > Question 2:  If the data file is being written to when I run rsync, do I
> > > run the risk of ending up with a corrupted data file on the backup server?
> >
> > Absolutely, but this is the case with any backup system that doesn't get a
> > lock on the file before transfering it.  The only way to be completely
> > safe is to stop all processes that might modify the files before doing
> > the backup, or alternatively, if the programs accessing the critical files
[snip]
> Other option is to use LVM or other snapshot capable volume manager and
> then back up the snapshot.

Interesting, I wasn't aware of this feature of LVM.  Unfortunately this is
only a partial cure for the problem, it nicely prevents on-going
operations from causing inconsistencies/corruption during the backup, but
it does not deal with the problem of data which is in an inconsistent
state at the time the snapshot occurs.  Some databases in particular, and
probably other programs as well would need to be momentarily paused with
their files in a consistent state before taking the snapshot in order to
insure a completely clean backup.  In theory, a properly implemented
database system will always keep it's files in a consistent state at
any given instant, and should be fine to backup live using the snapshot
feature (no need to pause), but experience says never trust that any
implementation is what it "should" be.

> [snip]
> > Other option is to use LVM or other snapshot capable volume manager and

> 
> Interesting, I wasn't aware of this feature of LVM.  Unfortunately this is

> operations from causing inconsistencies/corruption during the backup, but

But the nice thing about a snapshot is that it can be taken very
quickly, so you can shutdown your databases, take the snapshot, then
bring the DBs back up--in considerably less time than if you shut them
down and then backed up, and only brought them back up after they'd been
updated.  Or, you can dump your databases to text files (assuming you
don't have too much data) and ignore the state of the db files
themselves.

Wil

The Red Hat 2.4.9 kernel is heavily patched. I haven't used it on a
laptop recently, so I can't speak to pcmcia support, but the RH kernel
has proven very stable on the dozen-plus machines on which I support
it.

2.4.18, otoh, appears pretty stable, but there's a known nfs race 
condition that plagues it.

From dwingate at wagl.com  Tue May 28 08:18:56 2002
From: dwingate at wagl.com (WAGL)
Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 08:18:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Your Resume
Message-ID: <MDB21ju2iDL6e5f6WVY00004b39@toon.fws.net>

Dear Candidate,

My research assistant submitted your resume to me a few days ago that he found 
posted on the Internet.  Your skills and experiences are impressive.  I would 
like to keep in contact with you for future opportunities that might be a better 
fit than any of our current assignments.

Just for your reference, you can view a few of the non-confidential job listings 
listed on our web site http://www.wagl.com.  Our company specializes in helping 
advanced/middle management professionals into positions with outstanding growth 
potential.  Most of the jobs we work on are 100% confidential.  We also, on occasion, 
represent our clients with other types of positions that are normally outside 
this focus.

If you have been searching for your next opportunity for a few weeks or longer, 
you should find the following information useful.  This simple newsletter has 
helped a few of the candidates we couldn't work with directly.   We have outlined 
the benefits and weaknesses of various Internet job-seeking resources.  I find 
that too many job seekers limit their search to just one or two job sites.  This 
strategy is extremely limiting.  There are a lot of opportunities on the Internet 
but they will not be found with limited research. 

Most of the best jobs are not advertised; those jobs are only found through networking 
or by reaching out to new recruiters in your field of expertise, on a large scale, 
before they recommend candidates to their clients.  Even in today's economy, 
the independent recruitment business is alive and well.  Recruiters are responsible 
for placing 50% of jobs between $50,000 and $90,000 per year and 85% of jobs 
over $100,000 per year.  Love us or hate us, we are still in business.  If this 
is your target salary, we need each other for our mutual success.

JOB SEARCHING -- You can search for jobs at no charge on virtually every job 
site.  These sites make money by charging recruiters and employers to post jobs. 
The drawback is that the best jobs are not posted here or anywhere.  Here are 
a few well-known examples.
http://www.Monster.com  (for general jobs)	http://www.dice.com  (tech jobs)
http://www.vault.com (general and various jobs)
http://www.RecruiterConnection.com  (for middle/upper management jobs)
http://www.HeadHunter.net  (lots of tech jobs, as well as many general ones)

RESUME POSTING -- Posting your resume is also free most everywhere.  The drawback 
is, in order to be effectively 'found', there are a few hundred places where 
you need to post your resume.   All 'top level' job sites (the ones with television 
ads) charge large sums of money to search that resume database.  This pricing 
model virtually guarantees that most employers and recruiters will not find your 
resume.  Posting your resume to lesser-known job sites is often more effective 
because most have a larger recruiter and employer user base (those sites charge 
little or nothing to search for resumes).  There are a few online services that 
take the pain out of posting your resume to 30 or 40 effective job sites.  Each 
site charges a nominal fee for the time they save finding and posting to that 
many job sites.  Here are a few examples.
http://www.resumevalet.com
http://www.careerexpress.com 

CAREER COUNSELORS -- Realizing a need for career marketing services a few companies 
are successfully assisting executives with a personal direct marketing campaign. 
Their services include resume writing, counseling, and resume distribution via 
regular mail.  This type of marketing effort will uncover the hidden job market 
for the few professionals smart enough to recognize the benefit.  The personal 
attention they offer is great but you will spend as much as $8,000 with no guarantee 
of a job.   Here are two established firms that help many people.
http://www.wsacorp.com  and http://www.job-hunting.com 

TARGETED RESUME DISTRIBUTION -- For proactive job seekers who earn between $40k 
and $260k and want an intelligent connection to the executive recruiters that 
serve their industry, profession, and location, this is the best answer.  This 
service focuses solely on the distribution of your resume, via email, to over 
10,000+ executive recruiters.
It is much better than being lost in a database and putting your life on hold 
while waiting to be found.

We see job seekers succeed with this approach on a daily basis.  This approach 
builds an instant network for the job seekers who have been too busy to cultivate 
one while they were working.  This instant network helps find rewarding jobs 
close to home or in another part of the country.  With a proactive approach on 
a large scale, you will uncover all the opportunities you really have, rather 
than accepting the ones that find you.  

When we receive distributed resumes from recognized firms we read them because 
we know those resumes are targeted to our needs.  And, they are sent without 
attachments. Due to virus threat, it is our policy to delete every email that 
contains an attachment unless we have a prior relationship with the sender.

Keep in mind that traditional boundaries in recruiting have been eliminated due 
to the Internet and low-cost phone services.   At this moment our California 
office is working on two confidential positions: one in Atlanta and the other 
in Chicago.  Simply put, the more targeted recruiters you contact, the more opportunities 
you will uncover... even in your own city. 

Here are two older established firms that are leaders in filtering technology. 
They will help open the doors of opportunity, targeted to your background and 
interests.  So small an investment into your future; we encourage you to take 
a look at two of the best firms we use.  
http://www.RecruiterConnection.com  
http://www.Xpostit.com 

I hope that you found this information useful and will use it in your job search. 
Pass it on to a close friend, but only if you wish.  In the mean time, I will 
contact you again, when a suitable opportunity arises.  
 
Best wishes with your search.

Donald Wingate, Managing Partner 
Wingate and Grossman, Ltd.
http://www.wagl.com 

If you do not want our firm to contact you in the future, please reply with "REMOVE" 
in the subject.  Our email server will put your email address into our database 
of "inactive" job seekers.  You will not be contacted in the future, even when 
a job matches your background.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue May 28 09:27:02 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 09:27:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] What does .nscd_socket do?
In-Reply-To: <20020528084425.A3558@12-225-216-145.client.attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205280918200.23784-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 28 May 2002, Andy Boyce wrote:

> Can someone please give me a brief explanation of what
> /var/run/.nscd_socket does, or a link to some place where I might
> find more info. I tried google but the majority of it was straces.

nscd is part of newer glibc releases; it "handles passwd and group
lookups for running programs and caches the results for the next
query. You should install this package only if you use slow Services
like LDAP, NIS or NIS+." [1]

The socket file you mention is opened so that basic system calls 
(getpwnam, getpwuid, etc.) can communicate with the daemon -- as 
opposed, say, to communicating with it via a tcp/udp port.

Basically, if you rely only on DNS and local files for host/user/group
lookups, nscd probably isn't helping you -- and may be cacheing
outdated stuff. The nscd(8) and nscd.conf(5) man pages are helpful.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

[1] http://packages.debian.org/stable/admin/nscd.html

Subject: [PLUG] Copying files with rsync
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205272233320.3252-100000@critter.deatech.com> <1022566690.5889.5.camel@rheingold>
Message-ID: <3CF3BBB0.9040208@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

Wil Cooley wrote:

>>>Other option is to use LVM or other snapshot capable volume manager and
>>>then back up the snapshot.
>>>      
>>>
>>Interesting, I wasn't aware of this feature of LVM.  
>>
 From the LVM Howto:

A wonderful facility provided by LVM is 'snapshots'. This allows the 
administrator to create a new block device which is an exact copy of a 
logical volume, frozen at some point in time. Typically this would be 
used when some batch processing, a backup for instance, needs to be 
performed on the logical volume, but you don't want to halt a live 
system that is changing the data. When the snapshot device has been 
finished with the system administrator can just remove the device. This 
facility does require that the snapshot be made at a time when the data 
on the logical volume is in a consistent state, later sections of this 
document give some examples of this.


>>    
>>
>
>But the nice thing about a snapshot is that it can be taken very
>quickly, so you can shutdown your databases, take the snapshot, then
>bring the DBs back up--in considerably less time than if you shut them
>down and then backed up, and only brought them back up after they'd been
>updated.  Or, you can dump your databases to text files (assuming you
>don't have too much data) and ignore the state of the db files
>themselves.
>
>Wil
>  
>

References: <3CF3A7EA.8080902@parkrose.k12.or.us> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205280919310.4917-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <20020528094534.A69364@cogit8.org>

Here's what I've got in root's crontab on the mail server:

# minute |  hour  |  date  | month  |  day  |         command
# (0-59) | (0-23) | (1-31) | (1-12) | (0-6) |
#--------|--------|--------|--------|-------|---------------------------
    59        23      *        *        *      perl \ 
/usr/local/pflogsumm-1.0.3.pl -d today /var/log/maillog

It runs right before midnight, giving the statistics for today, so I can 
read them first thing tomorrow morning. As long as you are getting 
root's mail on that server, the results will go to you. If not, edit 
/etc/aliases appropriately.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue May 28 10:55:41 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 10:55:41 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] new (v5.05) acrobat reader available for linux
In-Reply-To: <200205281631.g4SGVYt22427@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205281039280.23784-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 28 May 2002, Galen Seitz wrote:

> This just showed up on the Linux Today web site.  I have yet to try
> it.
> 
> Adobe Quietly Releases Acrobat Reader 5.05 for Linux
> http://linuxtoday.com/news_story.php3?ltsn=2002-05-28-009-26-NW-SW

It works fine for me. If you want to grab the tarball 
(linux-505.tar.gz) for yourself, I've updated my .spec file that'll 
turn it into an RPM for you:

  http://www.madboa.com/geek/specs/acroread.spec.txt

Easy steps:

#!/bin/sh

# season to taste
rpmroot="/usr/src/redhat"
srcfile="linux-505.tar.gz"

# grab the requisite files
cd /var/tmp
wget http://www.madboa.com/geek/specs/acroread.spec.txt \
  --output-document=acroread.spec
ncftpget ftp://ftp.adobe.com/pub/adobe/acrobatreader/unix/5.x/$srcfile

# the following may have to be done as root
ln -s $srcfile ${rpmroot}/SOURCES
rpm -bb acroread.spec
# the following most certainly will have to be done as root
rpm -Uvh ${rpmroot}/RPMS/i386/acroread-5.05-2.i386.rpm

# clean up
rm -rf acroread.spec \
       $srcfile \
       ${rpmroot}/SOURCES/$srcfile \
       ${rpmroot}/BUILD/acroread

#
# eof
#

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue May 28 11:35:49 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 11:35:49 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] running multiple sessions
In-Reply-To: <200205281721.g4SHLlU07560@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205281131370.22335-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 28 May 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:
> I've been playing with running multiple concurrent sessions on one machine. 
>
> For example, at Alt+F6 I'll fire up KDE. Works fine until I switch to one of 
> the others, for example Ctrl+Alt+F1. when I come back it is crashed. Same for 
> Gnome and XFCE. Should be plenty of hardware resources, Duron 800/256 RAM.
>
> Should it not be possible to do this? All of my personalities must find 
> simultaneous expression. Red hat docs are unhelpful.

I had a problem with crashes or lock-ups when switching between X and
consoles some time ago.

I'm pretty sure it was related to a hardware problem wherein the wrong
size resistor was installed between the two CPUs on the mainboard
(combined with a particular kernel, X revision, and video driver).

To answer your question, it not only SHOULD be possible to do what you
describe, but I believe many of us do it many times every day.

So, I would suggest taking a look at your software revisions across the
board, video drivers, and any hardware errata that might exist.  Running
memtest probably isn't a bad idea, either.  In other words, you have a
problem and need to do some deep troubleshooting.

J.

The average CPU was 8% with a few spikes to 45%. Mem usage was about 43M with a
few plunges. I have a hardware ATAraid on the drives using raid 0, one bigger
disk from two smaller. 

Doing the test over using one IDE drive and writing to the hardware ATAraid
drive, the CPU utilization is always around 25%. Memory usage is topped at 10M. 

I'm writing this as file is being created, the cd_image file up to 9.9G, The
windows manager commands (PWM) seem sluggish when using key shortcuts and terms
are slow to load. I have Pronto 2.4, Opera 6, amd gaim with all the plugins
running.  Sound is choppy and annoying, kernel AC97.

I have been making cds with xcdroast, (uses mkisofs) on p166s for years but

xcdroast always worked, no sluggishness, so I think you have an issue. 

Recompile of the latest cdrecord tools

Look at your hdpram settings. bonnie++ and dbench are, in my opinion, better
tools to measure the effects of the settings than using the -tT options on
hdpram.

Maybe the file system? I haven't played with any of other new file systems. New
means anything other than ext2 for me. 

Is the file system a local resource or mounted remote file system? NFS or Samba
mount? I've never tried that.

From mph at puddingbowl.org  Tue May 28 12:07:17 2002
From: mph at puddingbowl.org (Michael Hall)
Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 12:07:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Konsole for Gnome?
In-Reply-To: <20020528114424.A26845@dalsemi.com>
References: <20020528114424.A26845@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <20020528190717.GB30967@puddingbowl.org>

If the tabbed interface is what you're after, there's:

* multignometerm - a patched version of the basic gnome-terminal program
http://multignometerm.sourceforge.net/

* powershell - which has been doing this for a while but looks like it might
be stalled and never was particulary outstanding
http://powershell.sourceforge.net/

* dzt - which was launched to address stability issues with powershell
http://dzt.sourceforge.net/

fwiw and btw, the generic gnome-terminal uses a factory-server, so the
memory footprint of multiple open windows/sessions is less than it might be
otherwise.

-mph

From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)

Message-ID: <1022614631.12331.19.camel@dereklinux>

On Tue, 2002-05-28 at 10:30, Carla Schroder wrote:
> I've been playing with running multiple concurrent sessions on one machine. 
> It is easy and fun, at least in console mode. (RH 7.2) I can open six, 
> Alt+F1- F6, any combination of users I want. but when I try to open an x 
> session it crashes as soon as I switch away.

I had a similar problem with my new NVidia card, it turned out to be an
issue with framebuffers being enabled in the kernel.  As soon as I
recompiled the kernel without framebuffers, I could switch to any
console without lockup.  I can now start multiple X sessions (each as a
different user), and switch between them.

Good Luck

From JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us  Tue May 28 13:11:52 2002
From: JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us (Miller, Jeremy)
Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 13:11:52 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Sound Capture ?
Message-ID: <51AE6EA505FCD111AB5600805F653ACB010AA14E@EXCHANGE>

On linux I use gramofile.  I've used it to record practice tapes (45min a
side) many many times, and it's stable as a rock.

The interface is simple.  It does a decent job of de-hiss and de-pop if you
want it to.  And it it can automatically split the tracks for you if you
like, as well.

I never had any luck at all with Audacity... flakey as hell.

Agreed, most linux wav editors suck.  One that is stable and OK to use is
Studio.  (http://studio.sourceforge.net) But it can be really slow when
performing operations, or at least was the last time I used it.  The most
powerful one is mxv.  (Mixviews.)

It is very stable and has more features than you can shake a stick at.
BUT... it might very well fall under your definition of "convoluted".  It's
pretty hard to use without reading how to get started with the interface.
The manual isn't with it, which makes it worse.  But it is on the website.
(Hint: go to the "selecting edit points" chapter to get started.)
http://www.create.ucsb.edu/~doug/htmls/mxv-manual.html 


Jeremy

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue May 28 13:19:32 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 13:19:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] mkisofs is insane.
In-Reply-To: <20020528184200.EXHS11183.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@downtown>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0205281254460.22335-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 28 May 2002, Russell Evans wrote:
> All file systems are resierfs 3.6 mounted with noatime. kernel 2.4.18 with SuSE
> patches. mkisofs version 1.15a21

I probably should have mentioned that this is a reiserfs as well.  But I
don't use noatime.

> Running `mkisofs -r -o /tmp/cd_image /usr` 
> 
> The average CPU was 8% with a few spikes to 45%. Mem usage was about
> 43M with a few plunges. I have a hardware ATAraid on the drives using
> raid 0, one bigger disk from two smaller.
> 
> Doing the test over using one IDE drive and writing to the hardware
> ATAraid drive, the CPU utilization is always around 25%. Memory usage
> is topped at 10M.
> 
> I'm writing this as file is being created, the cd_image file up to 9.9G, The
> windows manager commands (PWM) seem sluggish when using key shortcuts and terms
> are slow to load. I have Pronto 2.4, Opera 6, amd gaim with all the plugins
> running.  Sound is choppy and annoying, kernel AC97.  
> 
> The system is workable.  

Right... sorry.  It's rare that the system isn't at all workable.  It's
just quite unresponsive and ONCE mkisofs segfaulted and the system locked
(pingable, but not responsive).

> I have been making cds with xcdroast, (uses mkisofs) on p166s for
> years but never was doing much else on the box when I was doing the
> burns. The GUI to xcdroast always worked, no sluggishness, so I think
> you have an issue.

Well, cdrecord always works fine.  It's just kind of a ridiculous slowdown
when I run mkisofs.  It's not terrible.

> Recompile of the latest cdrecord tools

I did.  I would say that, as a matter of maintenance, I rebuild just about
everything every couple of months (not intentionally, just through normal
rotation of packages and rebuilding when dependencies are updated and so
on).

> Look at your hdpram settings. bonnie++ and dbench are, in my opinion,
> better tools to measure the effects of the settings than using the -tT
> options on hdpram.

I definitely will look at hdparm.  I've installed it (quite recently), but
haven't configured it to be run in any runlevel.  I've confirmed that the
disk is in the appropriate dma mode.

> Is the file system a local resource or mounted remote file system? NFS
> or Samba mount? I've never tried that.

As I said, it's local for both read and write.  There are NFS mounts, but
I'm not working in those trees.

Anyway, I'm thinking that we're seeing the same behavior but I'm finding
it more startling than you are.

Fuggetaboutit.

J.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue May 28 13:16:29 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 13:16:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix has taken an evil turn
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205281311440.5818-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  One of my mail list subscribers has the domain aol.com. While there were
no problems before, now his attempts to post are being rejected as spam by
postfix. What's even worse is that my replies to him are also being rejected
and never make it out of my system here.

  I've no idea where the problem is located.

  In /etc/postfix/access I've commented out all *@aol.com users, and rebuilt
the hashed database before reloading postfix. The message I get from postfix
doesn't tell me what generated the error, only that it occurred.

  This is the same problem I see when mail from root to postmaster is
redirected to me.

  I'd greatly appreciate some guidance here on how to track this down and
fix it. There are no aol IP addresses in my badip file and no aol.com's in
my badaddr file. I'm completely stymied here.

Thanks,

Rich

-------------------
> Dear Candidate,
> 
> My research assistant submitted your resume to me a few days ago
that he found 
> posted on the Internet.  Your skills and experiences are impressive.
 I would 
> like to keep in contact with you for future opportunities that might
be a better 
> fit than any of our current assignments.
> 
> Just for your reference, you can view a few of the non-confidential
job listings 
> listed on our web site http://www.wagl.com.  Our company specializes
in helping 
> advanced/middle management professionals into positions with
outstanding growth 
> potential.  Most of the jobs we work on are 100% confidential.  We
also, on occasion, 
> represent our clients with other types of positions that are
normally outside 
> this focus.
> 
> If you have been searching for your next opportunity for a few weeks
or longer, 
> you should find the following information useful.  This simple
newsletter has 
> helped a few of the candidates we couldn't work with directly.   We
have outlined 
> the benefits and weaknesses of various Internet job-seeking
resources.  I find 
> that too many job seekers limit their search to just one or two job
sites.  This 
> strategy is extremely limiting.  There are a lot of opportunities on
the Internet 
> but they will not be found with limited research. 
> 
> Most of the best jobs are not advertised; those jobs are only found
through networking 
> or by reaching out to new recruiters in your field of expertise, on
a large scale, 
> before they recommend candidates to their clients.  Even in today's
economy, 
> the independent recruitment business is alive and well.  Recruiters
are responsible 
> for placing 50% of jobs between $50,000 and $90,000 per year and 85%
of jobs 
> over $100,000 per year.  Love us or hate us, we are still in
business.  If this 
> is your target salary, we need each other for our mutual success.
> 
> JOB SEARCHING -- You can search for jobs at no charge on virtually
every job 
> site.  These sites make money by charging recruiters and employers
to post jobs. 
> The drawback is that the best jobs are not posted here or anywhere. 
Here are 
> a few well-known examples.
> http://www.Monster.com  (for general jobs)	http://www.dice.com 
(tech jobs)
> http://www.vault.com (general and various jobs)
> http://www.RecruiterConnection.com  (for middle/upper management
jobs)
> http://www.HeadHunter.net  (lots of tech jobs, as well as many
general ones)
> 
> RESUME POSTING -- Posting your resume is also free most everywhere. 
The drawback 
> is, in order to be effectively 'found', there are a few hundred
places where 
> you need to post your resume.   All 'top level' job sites (the ones
with television 
> ads) charge large sums of money to search that resume database. 
This pricing 
> model virtually guarantees that most employers and recruiters will
not find your 
> resume.  Posting your resume to lesser-known job sites is often more
effective 
> because most have a larger recruiter and employer user base (those
sites charge 
> little or nothing to search for resumes).  There are a few online
services that 
> take the pain out of posting your resume to 30 or 40 effective job
sites.  Each 
> site charges a nominal fee for the time they save finding and
posting to that 
> many job sites.  Here are a few examples.
> http://www.resumevalet.com
> http://www.careerexpress.com 
> 
> CAREER COUNSELORS -- Realizing a need for career marketing services
a few companies 
> are successfully assisting executives with a personal direct
marketing campaign. 
> Their services include resume writing, counseling, and resume
distribution via 
> regular mail.  This type of marketing effort will uncover the hidden
job market 
> for the few professionals smart enough to recognize the benefit. 
The personal 
> attention they offer is great but you will spend as much as $8,000
with no guarantee 
> of a job.   Here are two established firms that help many people.
> http://www.wsacorp.com  and http://www.job-hunting.com 
> 
> TARGETED RESUME DISTRIBUTION -- For proactive job seekers who earn
between $40k 
> and $260k and want an intelligent connection to the executive
recruiters that 
> serve their industry, profession, and location, this is the best
answer.  This 
> service focuses solely on the distribution of your resume, via
email, to over 
> 10,000+ executive recruiters.
> It is much better than being lost in a database and putting your
life on hold 
> while waiting to be found.
> 
> We see job seekers succeed with this approach on a daily basis. 
This approach 
> builds an instant network for the job seekers who have been too busy
to cultivate 
> one while they were working.  This instant network helps find
rewarding jobs 
> close to home or in another part of the country.  With a proactive
approach on 
> a large scale, you will uncover all the opportunities you really
have, rather 
> than accepting the ones that find you.  
> 
> When we receive distributed resumes from recognized firms we read
them because 
> we know those resumes are targeted to our needs.  And, they are sent
without 
> attachments. Due to virus threat, it is our policy to delete every
email that 
> contains an attachment unless we have a prior relationship with the
sender.
> 
> Keep in mind that traditional boundaries in recruiting have been
eliminated due 
> to the Internet and low-cost phone services.   At this moment our
California 
> office is working on two confidential positions: one in Atlanta and
the other 
> in Chicago.  Simply put, the more targeted recruiters you contact,
the more opportunities 
> you will uncover... even in your own city. 
> 
> Here are two older established firms that are leaders in filtering
technology. 
> They will help open the doors of opportunity, targeted to your
background and 
> interests.  So small an investment into your future; we encourage
you to take 
> a look at two of the best firms we use.  
> http://www.RecruiterConnection.com  
> http://www.Xpostit.com 
> 
> I hope that you found this information useful and will use it in
your job search. 
> Pass it on to a close friend, but only if you wish.  In the mean
time, I will 
> contact you again, when a suitable opportunity arises.  
>  
> Best wishes with your search.
> 
> Donald Wingate, Managing Partner 
> Wingate and Grossman, Ltd.
> http://www.wagl.com 
> 
> If you do not want our firm to contact you in the future, please
reply with "REMOVE" 
> in the subject.  Our email server will put your email address into
our database 
> of "inactive" job seekers.  You will not be contacted in the future,
even when 
> a job matches your background.
>

> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

You know this is a real opportunity for alot of people.  I know several
people I used to work with at Nortel did this.  A couple of guys who were
laid off organized alot of other guys who were laid off and they started an
employee owned company stealing Nortel's customers.  Anyone who wanted to
put money into the company got a partial ownership and if you didn't have
any money you could work there and accrue stock by by taking a lower salary
than usual.  If you weren't willing to do either then you couldn't get a job
there.  The company has been in business for two years now and everyone is
back to making the same money or more than they did at Nortel.  Some people
are making a lot more.

Point is if someone could get these people together and come up with a
reasonable business idea something could really come of this.  Something
better than what everyone had in the first place.

Something to think about guys.

I spoke with the Enterprise Business Center this morning. They are an
incubator in this area for small businesses.

For the last ten years I have created IT infrastructures for businesses
large and small. From this experience I have taken with me a firm grasp
of the requirements necessary for an effective business network.

Now it's time to raise the bar.

Here is a link covering the major points of my business plan. There are
some areas that need work. Even the name, for example needs work; we
found out that our target market thought `MetaSource' sounded like a
pharmaceuticals company. I am certain, however, that I will be
successful.

     www.metasource.us

I want to pamper my customers. I want my customers to feel like they've
just stepped into the IT equivalent of a Hilton Luxury Suite. No
worries, no hassles, the systems simply work. From the customer's point
of view it's as if there are little unseen technicians humming away
making things run smoothly.

...And I'm going to do it running Linux.

In short, I want them to forget about us in a way because ``the trains
are arriving on time.''

It may be a month before I am ready to take on contractors, but who
knows what could happen in the mean-time? 

Give me your input. Give me your resumes. I am working hard for this and
I hope to provide contracts in the near future. Basically I will simply
do the best I can.

Finally, I need to be perfectly clear: it is my intention to generate
income for myself and the open source community. This is not an
advertisement; it is a Request For Comment.


Best Regards,


Cooper Stevenson

Hi:

The only thing I feel it is wrong is the user and
group  in the proftpd.conf file, you set as "apache"
for both name. In your passwd file, the name is
"tester", "site60", but not "apache". Try to change
the user name and group name as the same as the name
in your proftpd.conf file.

Melinda :)

> </Global>

On Tue, May 28, 2002 at 03:52:00PM -0700, Richard Kurth wrote:
> Hello Colin,
> Ok I tried adding  AuthPAM  AuthPAMAuthoritative  and that did not
> make any difference. I thought the default for authorization was set to us
> the shadow password file.

Okay, with a little playing around I found that 530 login failed can
be due to:

1) User not being in the password file.
2) A valid user sending an incorrect password.

Are you sure that you're using the correct password?

What do the proftpd and system logs say after you try to log in?

Colin

While businesses like these can bring work to a few or maybe more than a
few, they don't even begin to touch on the talent pool now available in
Oregon.  There is enough laid off talent to start a major corporation with a
major product or service line.  If I didn't have a U-Haul truck sitting in
my driveway I would get things started.

There are alot of people here who like to succeed and they just need the
chance.  The first step to take would be to find someone familiar with the
layoffs at some of these companies and find out who the executives were that
lost their jobs.  They have the business sense needed to get something like
this off the ground.  Talk to them and try to enlist their help.  They would
also know alot of the better technical people who got laid off and could
contact them.  There are plenty of executives, managers, customer support,
PR and technical people out there to staff something big and if enough of
them came onboard there would be enough money to make it work.

Or, since I am not going to be here and therefore don't really count, nobody
could do anything and let a rare, rare, golden opportunity slip away...

I spoke with the Enterprise Business Center this morning. They are an
incubator in this area for small businesses.

For the last ten years I have created IT infrastructures for businesses
large and small. From this experience I have taken with me a firm grasp
of the requirements necessary for an effective business network.

Now it's time to raise the bar.

Here is a link covering the major points of my business plan. There are
some areas that need work. Even the name, for example needs work; we
found out that our target market thought `MetaSource' sounded like a
pharmaceuticals company. I am certain, however, that I will be
successful.

     www.metasource.us

I want to pamper my customers. I want my customers to feel like they've
just stepped into the IT equivalent of a Hilton Luxury Suite. No
worries, no hassles, the systems simply work. From the customer's point
of view it's as if there are little unseen technicians humming away
making things run smoothly.

...And I'm going to do it running Linux.

In short, I want them to forget about us in a way because ``the trains
are arriving on time.''

It may be a month before I am ready to take on contractors, but who
knows what could happen in the mean-time?

Give me your input. Give me your resumes. I am working hard for this and
I hope to provide contracts in the near future. Basically I will simply
do the best I can.

Finally, I need to be perfectly clear: it is my intention to generate
income for myself and the open source community. This is not an
advertisement; it is a Request For Comment.

Cooper Stevenson

From lynnming at yahoo.com  Tue May 28 16:50:11 2002

Message-ID: <20020528235011.41751.qmail@web10907.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi 

In my proftpd.conf file the setting is like this:

# Set the user and group that the server normally runs
at
user            nobody
group           nobody

# A basic anonymous configuration no upload
directories
User            mmm
group           mmm

# We want clients to be able to login with
"anonymous"as well as "mmm"
user Alias            anonymous mmm

for example: I ftp to www.redhat.com
I type in " ftp ftp.redhat.com" then using "anonymous"
as my login name, then it ask for password, I just use
one of my e-mail address. Of course you need to start
the proftpd first.

Melinda

From bdhruva at gmx.net  Tue May 28 16:52:10 2002
From: bdhruva at gmx.net (Dhruva B. Reddy)
Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 17:52:10 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Your Resume
In-Reply-To: <200205282113.g4SLD2A11136@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205281343480.6883-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <200205282113.g4SLD2A11136@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <20020528235210.GD10956@dr.mobizinc.com>

I recently had a related idea of my own.

There are a lot of HR folks (and most headhunters) who insist on
receiving resumes as an M$ Word document.  This annoys me for several
reasons.  In addition to the obvious, I've recently found using a word
processor messy and tedious (especially since I discovered LaTeX :-)

Also, many organizations are switching to web based job applications.
If you have ever used one of these, you know what a PITA it is to cut
and paste your resume to fit their form.

Anyway, my idea is to come up with a format (open, of course!)
specifically for resumes, based on XML (called, say, CVML--Curriculum
Vitae Markup Language).  The point of this is to separate the content
from the formatting. 

My vision includes a desktop application that takes the content and
formats it however desired (HTML, LaTeX, RTF, even *shudder*...a Word
document).  This application would also let the user edit the content,
without worrying about the formatting.  Since the candidate would have
access to the same application, they could format the resume themselves,
if appropriate..."Here's my resume, both in CVML and Postscript"...

If successful, this would have the following benefits:
	-Resume content would be standardized to an open format.
	-You come up with the format for a resume exactly once.  Once
	you get it right, you can change the content without ever having
	to fiddle with the formatting again.
	-The standardization opens up all kinds of possibilities in
	information exchange and archival.
	-The obvious--freedom from M$'s stranglehold.

What would you folks think of this concept, and of using this
directory/database as a launching pad for it?

Dhruva

Greetings,

Starting a business without adequate funding is (in my
opinion and experience - just ask my wife!) crazy!

But, if there are the right technical people (willing
to work night and day,executives (eager to be very
frugal in spending) with leadership plus money
connections, and marketing/sales people (willing to
pay low cost economy airline seats all the time), then
this sounds like an excellent opportunity.

Finally, product also has to be realistic and again
everyone involved has to work harder than they ever
had  in their life.

Hope some of you could get a project like this off the
ground, the rewards are great - so are the sacrifices.

Writing out of experience.

Sorry, as a tech boom skeptic who prayed nightly for people to come to
their senses ever since the Dow crossed 7,000, I don't have much good to
say about most executives. If executives actually cared about getting
business done and not about stock value and making themselves wealthier,
we wouldn't be in a situation where thousands of people needed jobs in the
first place.

It sounds like a nice idea to start a new company that focuses on the
customers, but as someone else already pointed out, the reason this is
even a discussion is because of what happened to Sequent. So apparantly
the cycle is always going to be that technologists and those who LOVE to
do good work will always come up with good ideas and will poor sweat and
blood into getting something off the ground and then the suits will step
in to ruin the entire operation by focusing primarily on making middle to
upper management rich.

I don't see this cycle ever ending.

Preston

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Tue May 28 17:39:18 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 17:39:18 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: CV Markup Language (Was: [PLUG] Your Resume)
In-Reply-To: <20020528235210.GD10956@dr.mobizinc.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0205281712140.7545-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Tue, 28 May 2002, Dhruva B. Reddy wrote:

> I recently had a related idea of my own.
>
> There are a lot of HR folks (and most headhunters) who insist on
> receiving resumes as an M$ Word document.  This annoys me for several
> reasons.  In addition to the obvious, I've recently found using a word
> processor messy and tedious (especially since I discovered LaTeX :-)
>
> Also, many organizations are switching to web based job applications.
> If you have ever used one of these, you know what a PITA it is to cut
> and paste your resume to fit their form.
>
> Anyway, my idea is to come up with a format (open, of course!)
> specifically for resumes, based on XML (called, say, CVML--Curriculum
> Vitae Markup Language).  The point of this is to separate the content
> from the formatting.
>
I've had the same idea for a year or two, & looked hard at the DocBook
DTD as a prototype. Unfortunately, one can't print from XML so I've fallen
back on LaTeX to at least start producing a prototype that could be
later ported to an XML DTD.

So far my exploration with resumes & LaTeX have uncovered four different
packages written for resumes or curriculum vitas[*], & of the three I've
tired, none do exactly what I want to: one I couldn't get to work without
error messages; one defines the attributes of the occupational & skill
classes nicely, but it doesn't allow for a simple title class; & the
third defines the classes nicely yet I don't like how it formats the
information.

> My vision includes a desktop application that takes the content and
> formats it however desired (HTML, LaTeX, RTF, even *shudder*...a Word
> document).  This application would also let the user edit the content,
> without worrying about the formatting.  Since the candidate would have
> access to the same application, they could format the resume themselves,
> if appropriate..."Here's my resume, both in CVML and Postscript"...
>
<rant=abbreviated>
Sending a resume in ascii text to a job shop should be good enough.
After all, they are going to enter it into their database, massage it
to their standards -- all of which far too often occurs after the print
the thing out & then scan it back in. (Yes, I was told this happened
once -- which is still one time too often.) And Word will open ascii
text files.
</rant>

On the other hand, I seem to remember MS Word being able to import
LaTeX format documents. Am I confusing MS Word with another word
processing program?

> If successful, this would have the following benefits:
> 	-Resume content would be standardized to an open format.
> 	-You come up with the format for a resume exactly once.  Once
> 	you get it right, you can change the content without ever having
> 	to fiddle with the formatting again.
> 	-The standardization opens up all kinds of possibilities in
> 	information exchange and archival.
> 	-The obvious--freedom from M$'s stranglehold.
>
> What would you folks think of this concept, and of using this
> directory/database as a launching pad for it?
>
It makes sense: I have heard the factoid that the average resume is
read in 10 seconds or less; the hiring manager wants to know what
skills a potential interviewee has, & gain a clue just how strong
those skills are. Such a structured means of presentation would
improve efficiency all around: we could write better resumes, &
hiring managers could read these resumes faster.

Unfortunately, because it's such a good idea I doubt it would work.
Job shops & HR departments would balk at adoption because they
couldn't import the XML resume into MS Word. And if MS adopted
the proposed CVML DTD, I'd bet money they make changes to it that
either break other implimentations, or add features that annoy
the hiring managers (e.g., the ability to embed animation in a
resume).

Having said all of that, I would be interested in working on such
a project. Who knows -- maybe we can create something that proves MS
chases more taillights than the volunteer software camp?

Geoff

OK, everyone suggests a hardware issue. I don't think so. I'm starting from 
the console- no X sessions running at all. F1-F6 are available, which I think 
is normal behavior. I gleaned this nugget from another place: run

startx -- :1

from any of the consoles. This starts X on F7. I have KDE going there, happy 
as a lark. I can switch back n forth just fine. There must be more to this. 

Digging digging digging...... (to the tune of "Rawhide")

Carla
