From alan at clueserver.org  Fri May 31 10:05:14 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: 31 May 2002 10:05:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Vulgarity: Was: Steve Duin's column of 5/21/02
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20020531092508.020242b8@localhost>
References: <200205310447.g4V4lTl23554@smtp.easystreet.com> 
	<5.1.0.14.0.20020531092508.020242b8@localhost>
Message-ID: <1022864714.13433.35.camel@summanulla.clueserver.org>

On Fri, 2002-05-31 at 09:30, Russ Johnson wrote:
> That's just it. *I* don't. Everyone I knows can count the number of cuss 
> words that have come out of my mouth on one hand. As far as I'm concerned, 
> everyone I meet is a potential client, and as such, I present the best I 
> can, always.
> 
> I'm not censoring myself, or acting different, or some such nonsense. I 
> simply have different ways of expressing myself, and don't feel the need to 
> utter explicatives when frustrated. To do so, and blame it on the 
> environment is a cop out. Even my grandfather knew that cussing to express 
> yourself was a cop out. There are so many other ways to express yourself, 
> and/or vent your frustration.

"Profanity is the first language of the programmer."

Is profanity "profesional"?  Depends on your definition of "profesional"
I guess.

This argument went on for months on the Linux kernel list.  Some people
objected to the language used in the kernel comments.  (Comments were
things like "this hardware model is really fucked up".)  The swearing
was not gratuitous, but described the frustration the programmer had
with that section of code.

It is *not* unusual to find those comments in professional source code. 
Netscape had lots of them.  (One of the big delays on release of the
source code was removing all the profane comments sprinkeled throughout
the code.)  Having looked at the early code, I understand why they were
there.

It is a very common practice by profesionals.  It occurs regularly in
source and on the job.  It is only when you start dealing with
management types that it becomes "unacceptable". 

In my experience, when some one cries "that is not profesional
behaviour", they see or hear something that they don't like.  Either it
is someone using a word that they do not like, or making a joke that
they do not like, or just having a little bit too much fun. It is a term
used to control.  To keep people in line.  It has little to do with what
really goes on when work is done.  It is a term used by people who
prefer nice words over blunt honesty.

Does profesional behaviour apply here?  It does when you start paying
for my services.  Since I know what a cheap lot of bastards PLUG members
are, I know that will never happen and tailor my comments accordingly.

People choose this forum because we give good advice, not because we sit
still with out hands folded in our laps.

If they don't like it, then they can pay $150/hr for advice from people
who may or may not know what they are doing, but wear the right suit and
tell you what you want to hear.

I've been thrilled to hear of Apple's efforts to make OSX part of the
unix and open-source community as much as they have.  It's to the
point where I'm retooling my conversion kits to use OSX instead of
Net/OpenBSD for Mac hardware when people want Mac BSD servers.  I can
see that as OSX matures within the unix community, more and more people
will come up with methods for tuning the OS.  My only hope is that
Apple will realize the real opportunity they have and just how much
they will gain if they mature OSX in a way that will provide the unix
community the means to tweak OSX into a "master of one" tuned server.
I, for one, am tired of the mediocre performance Net and OpenBSD give
on Mac hardware that, specwise, should give better performance than PC
hardware.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri May 31 18:00:00 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 31 May 2002 18:00:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Serial console with grub
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205311754580.4272-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

I finally got the time to experiment with having a grub-loaded kernel 
use a serial port as its main console (very handy for remote 
administration!). What follows is part of the documentation I prepared 
on the subject for work...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at cse.ogi.edu>

...

This is a short cookbook-style document. A much better and more
complete discussion of this issue can be found in the Linux
Documentation Project's "Remote Serial Console HOWTO."

Red Hat's 2.2.x and 2.4.x kernels are all capable of using a
serial port as their default console. If you're building a custom
kernel, make sure you set CONFIG_SERIAL_CONSOLE=y during the
configuration process.

Note: In the directives provided below, I assume that the serial
console will always be connected to ttyS0 (COM1). You'll have to
season things to taste should you connect it to a different serial
port.

Once you've got a Linux host booting with grub, the recipe for letting
it use a serial console is pretty basic:

1. Edit /etc/grub.conf (=> /boot/grub/grub.conf). See the grub info
   page for the details about the directives listed below. The grub
   configuration file is line-oriented, and I think that directives
   can NOT be continued between lines. IOW, each directive needs a
   line to itself, and cannot be continued on the next line.

   a. In the opening section, add 'serial' and 'terminal' definitions,
      e.g.,

      serial --unit=0 --speed=9600 --word=8 --parity=no --stop=1
      terminal --timeout=5 serial console

   b. Remove or comment out any 'splashimage' directives. Failure to
      do so will mean you won't have access to the grub boot menu at
      boot time.

   c. Add 'console' parameters to each 'kernel' directive. Say, for
      example, that the default kernel directive as installed by Red
      Hat looks like this:

      kernel /vmlinuz ro root=/dev/hda1

      Your edited version will specify two consoles, one a normal tty,
      the other a serial port:

      kernel /vmlinuz ro root=/dev/hda1 console=tty0 console=ttyS0

      The console specified last is used when you open /dev/console,
      so in my example serial port ttyS0 would be the default
      console. See Documentation/serial-console.txt in the Linux
      kernel sources for a more complete discussion of the 'console='
      flags that get passed to the kernel.

      You can append the console flags at kickstart time by appending
      them to the bootloader directive:

      bootloader --append "console=tty0 console=ttyS0"

2. Edit /etc/inittab so that a getty is spawned on ttyS0 in all
   working runlevels, e.g.,

   # serial console
   con:2345:respawn:/sbin/agetty ttyS0 9600 vt100

   See the inittab(8) and agetty(8) man pages for more details.

3. Edit /etc/securetty to ensure root can login via a serial
   port. This merely involves adding a line for your tty at the end of
   the file, e.g.,

   ttyS0

4. Finally, delete /etc/ioctl.save and reboot.

...

I hate top-posters.  Grrr...  so this part was said EARLIER:

It's not FreeBSD.  It never has been.  It's the Mach kernel, with many
BSD tools for userspace, mostly grabbed from the freebsd heritage.
But that's like saying "Linux is GNU".  It's not.  It has a unique
kernel, and userspace tools are drawn from the GNU project.

That crazy rumor keeps going around.   It needs to die soon.

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri May 31 22:56:46 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)

Subject: [PLUG] NEW TOPIC:  Hibernate in Linux (Specifically Redhat 7.3)
In-Reply-To: <005101c20876$ac061c80$6401a8c0@endeavor>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205312244080.17685-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 31 May 2002, Greg Long wrote:

> Anyone successfully get this to work? A number of us like to dual boot
> our laptops, and it would be that much easier to spend more time in
> Linux (I use Linux mostly as a server, not as a client as much as I'd
> like to now that available software is getting better and better)
>
> But to the point:  Does this need to be a kernel mod that needs to be
> recompiled, and how does Gnome/KDE do upon resume?

I assume by "hibernate" that you mean "suspend" where the computer keeps
everything in ram but shuts down the screen, hard drive, CPU, etc., so you
can quickly power-up and pickup where you left off.  I have done this
successfully on my old laptop, but haven't used the feature with the
latest upgrades or gnome (I don't use this laptop much these days).  As
far as what you need, it requires APM (advanced power management) be
compiled into the kernel or a kernel module.  There are also some options
to look at which are specific to some poorly behaved laptops when you
select the APM option.  Aside from the kernel option(s), you need the
program "apmd" which provides the interface to the power management system
and does things like reset the Linux time when the system powers back up
and other power management related stuff.  This setup worked fine for me
using fvwm and ice window managers (never tried Gnome or KDE).

I'm working from memory of an older configuration, so there may be some
differences with the latest stuff, perhaps someone else on the list has
done this more recently.

Miller, Jeremy wrote:
> Actually, I remember being told (by an HP tech) that while rubbing alcohol
> will work fine, it can actually dry out the roller and get it crumbling
> faster over time.

I've maintained my own cassette decks and was a audio repair tech for years. 
      All I've ever used was 92% Isopropol alcohol on pinch rollers (some 
cost over $300).  I've heard the same warnings about drying, but never 
experienced it.  Note that common rubbing alcohol has many 
impurities/additives and is *not* what you should use.  (But it probably 
wouldn't matter in a printer if you did.)

There are rubber reconditioners that contain TCE, but I only used that nasty 
stuff to confirm the rubber needed replacing.
